b'After 14 years of talks, members of the World Trade Organization have effectively ended the Doha round of negotiations. That was not unexpected given how fruitless these discussions have been. Now, world leaders need to think anew about the global trading system.'b'Countries had hoped that the talks, named after the capital of Qatar, where they began in late 2001, would substantially lower trade barriers, contribute to development in poor nations and tackle difficult issues like agricultural subsidies that were not resolved in earlier pacts, like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.'b'Failure to achieve this ambitious agenda has undermined the credibility of the multilateral trading system and hurt the least-developed countries, which are desperate to export more of their goods to richer countries.'b'At a meeting of the W.T.O. in mid-December in Nairobi, trade ministers from more than 160 countries 'b'failed to agree'b' that they should keep the negotiations going. In recent years, it became clear that the talks, which were originally supposed to 'b'conclude in 2005'b', were paralyzed because neither developed economies like the United States and the European Union nor developing countries like China and India were willing or able to make fundamental concessions.'b'At the start of the Doha round, American and European officials committed to producing a trade agreement that would 'b'promote development'b' in poorer countries without asking them to reduce import barriers to the same extent as industrialized nations. But as developing countries, particularly China, began exporting far more than they were importing, wealthier countries started demanding that they also lower import barriers and cut subsidies to their farmers. Not surprisingly, China and India refused, insisting on sticking with the original principles.'b'Many countries have been so frustrated by the Doha stalemate that they have been negotiating bilateral and regional trade deals. For example, the United States recently concluded the 'b'Trans-Pacific Partnership'b' with Japan, Vietnam and nine other countries. America and the European Union are also negotiating the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. China, which is not part of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, has signed many bilateral and regional agreements and proposed a 'b'16-country trade deal'b' that would include India and Japan.'b'Regional agreements can be useful if done right, but they threaten to segregate the world into overlapping trading blocs with different rules in areas like labor rights, environmental protection and access to medicines. And most such pacts \xe2\x80\x94 in which countries agree to eliminate tariffs for products made within the trading bloc \xe2\x80\x94 do not include the world\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'least-developed countries,'b' like Bangladesh and Ethiopia.'b'Another approach is to pursue more limited pacts that include many or all members of the World Trade Organization. A good example is the 'b'Trade Facilitation Agreement'b' reached in December 2013 in which all W.T.O. members agreed to improve their customs departments, border crossings and ports. Under that agreement, less-developed countries will receive aid and technical expertise to help them upgrade their trading systems. Another worthwhile effort that began in 2014 with 14 W.T.O. members, including the United States, China and the European Union, is designed to eliminate tariffs on 'b'environmental goods'b' like solar panels and wind turbines.'b'While pacts focusing on specific issues are easier to negotiate, they can\xe2\x80\x99t cover the broader issues that countries, rich and poor, have to wrestle with. Trade increasingly determines how governments set social policies and labor conditions within domestic markets, and, of course, affects the future of the environment locally as well as globally. The Doha talks may be at a dead end but there has to be a place for global trade pacts that encourage development and sustainable economic growth.'b'The community of Elmont, on Long Island, may soon be getting a neighborhood amenity that\xe2\x80\x99s high-class and exciting, if you think a big carpeted box filled with a thousand video gambling machines is high-class and exciting.'b'On Tuesday the Nassau Regional Off-Track Betting Corporation announced that it would seek New York State\xe2\x80\x99s permission to open a 100,000-square-foot gambling emporium at Belmont Park, the racetrack on the edge of Queens that is home to the Belmont Stakes.'b'We already knew that casino-style gambling was coming to Long Island; that\xe2\x80\x99s because of a deal struck in 2013 by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Dean Skelos, then the powerful Senate Republican leader from Nassau County, when Mr. Cuomo was seeking to legalize full-fledged casino gambling upstate.'b'The agreement 'b'allowed'b' one gambling hall in Nassau County and one in neighboring Suffolk County, each with up to 1,000 video-lottery terminals, or V.L.T.\xe2\x80\x99s, which are similar to slot machines and are wired into the state lottery system. They were going to be a shot in the arm for county officials who were forever clawing for revenue and didn\xe2\x80\x99t care how they got it.'b'From the experience of other places, we know that casinos and gambling are 'b'instruments of blight'b' \xe2\x80\x94 blighted neighborhoods, the blighted lives of problem gamblers and the blighted politics of elected officials who can\xe2\x80\x99t, or won\xe2\x80\x99t, find a better path to economic development.'b'In New York, the plan has long been to attach a dubious financial engine (gambling) to a broken-down heap of an industry (horse racing) and fuel it with people\xe2\x80\x99s thinly stretched paychecks and Social Security benefits. Giving up on better ways of reviving the upstate economy, Mr. Cuomo doubled down on gambling: He engineered the 2013 referendum that rewrote the State Constitution to open the door to seven Las Vegas-style casinos, and then cut the deal for the two video gambling parlors on Long Island.'b'Yet many people in Nassau don\xe2\x80\x99t want slot machines anywhere near their homes. Because of local resistance, the Nassau parlor was never considered for the retail and entertainment heart of the county, called the Hub. Why is that, if gambling is such an economic boon? It was blocked from an OTB \xe2\x80\x9crace palace\xe2\x80\x9d in Plainview and from the site of a shuttered department store in Westbury. He has already put $20 million of gambling revenue in his 2016 budget. That\xe2\x80\x99s based on estimates that the parlor will net at least $150 million a year.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of losing gamblers.'b'This is a big day for Texans yearning to flaunt their handguns in belt and shoulder holsters. A new \xe2\x80\x9copen carry\xe2\x80\x9d law enacted by the Republican Legislature goes into effect on Friday, posing a challenge for law enforcement, businesses and other institutions that are understandably wary of how social interchange will be affected.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also a big day in Seattle, where the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s new \xe2\x80\x9c'b'gun violence tax'b'\xe2\x80\x9d takes effect, levying a $25 charge on each gun sold and an ammunition tax of 2 to 5 cents per round. The First Baptist Church of Arlington, on the other hand, decided it was safe to allow its 2,500 worshipers to show up armed.'b'Texas had banned public packing of handguns after the Civil War. More and more, the open-carry movement is being used to make confrontational and intimidating protest statements.'b'The confusion for the public can be considerable. A woman called 911 in Colorado Springs 'b'in October'b' when she saw a man toting a weapon in the street. She was told the gunman had that right under the open-carry law. The man began a shooting spree outside her door and randomly murdered three innocent people.'b'Wealth can be bad for your soul. That\xe2\x80\x99s not just a hoary piece of folk wisdom; it\xe2\x80\x99s a conclusion from 'b'serious social science'b', confirmed by statistical analysis and experiment. The affluent are, on average, less likely to exhibit empathy, less likely to respect norms and even laws, more likely to cheat, than those occupying lower rungs on the economic ladder.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious, even if we don\xe2\x80\x99t have statistical confirmation, that extreme wealth can do extreme spiritual damage. Take someone whose personality might have been merely disagreeable under normal circumstances, and give him the kind of wealth that lets him surround himself with sycophants and usually get whatever he wants. It\xe2\x80\x99s not hard to see how he could become almost pathologically self-regarding and unconcerned with others.'b'So what happens to a nation that gives ever-growing political power to the superrich?'b'Modern America is a society in which a growing share of income and wealth is concentrated in the hands of a small number of people, and these people have huge political influence \xe2\x80\x94 in the early stages of the 2016 presidential campaign, around 'b'half the contributions'b' came from fewer than 200 wealthy families. The usual concern about this march toward oligarchy is that the interests and policy preferences of the very rich are quite different from those of the population at large, and that is surely the biggest problem.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s also true that those empowered by money-driven politics include a disproportionate number of spoiled egomaniacs. STETZ'b'Newark, Del.'b''b'The writer, a professor of women\xe2\x80\x99s studies at the University of Delaware, is co-editor of \xe2\x80\x9cLegacies of the Comfort Women of World War II.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'IN police shooting cases like that of 12-year-old Tamir Rice in Cleveland, grand jurors are typically asked to focus on one question: At the moment the officer fired, did he have reason to believe the person he shot posed a grave and imminent threat?'b'This question fails to consider whether alternatives to deadly force were available and how race might have affected the officer\xe2\x80\x99s perception of the threat. Under the prevailing legal standard, those questions aren\xe2\x80\x99t relevant. Until we make them relevant, American policing will continue to have a tragic excessive force problem and, specifically, a race problem.'b'American police officers killed 74 unarmed black people in 2015. From January through July, according to The Washington Post, unarmed black men were 'b'seven times more likely 'b'than unarmed white men to die by police gunfire.'b''b'An analysis of F.B.I. data 'b'from 2010 to 2012 concluded that the police killed black men ages 15 to 19 at a rate 21 times greater than the statistic for white men the same age. Department of Justice numbers indicate that a black person is about 'b'four times as likely'b' to die in custody or while being arrested than a white person is.'b'What can be done about these appalling facts? Increased use of body and dashboard cameras should help, but will fail to address a fundamental problem.'b'Police officers in the United States are taught that they can use deadly force if they reasonably believe an individual poses a grave, imminent danger to themselves or others. Superficially, this \xe2\x80\x9creasonableness\xe2\x80\x9d rule looks unobjectionable.'b'But racial bias can affect what seems reasonable. Individuals of all races in America perceive black people as 'b'more aggressive'b' and dangerous than white people. Studies show that black people are seen as being physically stronger and 'b'less prone to feeling pain'b' than people of other races, and black children are often 'b'perceived to be older than they are'b'. When faced with 'b'an armed black target'b', shooters are both more likely to shoot and quicker to shoot than they are when faced with an armed white target.'b'These biases can affect the way we think, judge and act. As a result, force that may seem unreasonable if used against a white person may seem perfectly \xe2\x80\x9creasonable\xe2\x80\x9d when used against a black person.'b'One critical and common-sense change would be to adopt a necessity rule. The difference is simple but crucial. Even when the police have a reasonable belief that a person is dangerous, the necessity standard does not permit deadly force if non-deadly or less deadly alternatives are available and adequate to meet the threat.'b'Before objecting that this rule would be impractical or subject officers to 20/20 hindsight, consider that it\xe2\x80\x99s already the 'b'Department of Justice'b'\xe2\x80\x99s standard. As a D.O.J. policy statement puts it, \xe2\x80\x9cThe necessity to use deadly force arises when all other available means of preventing imminent and grave danger to officers or other persons have failed or would be likely to fail.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Unfortunately, the D.O.J. necessity standard, adopted in 1995, is not the law; it\xe2\x80\x99s a discretionary policy, and it applies only to federal agencies like the F.B.I. and the Drug Enforcement Administration. Worse, many state police departments and even some courts have explicitly rejected the necessity rule in favor of a mere reasonableness test. To quote the Seventh Circuit, the federal appeals court that covers Chicago, \xe2\x80\x9cwe do not believe that the Constitution requires the use of the least or even a less deadly alternative so long as the use of deadly force is reasonable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The difference is not semantic; it can be a matter of life or death. A serious necessity rule would require all officers to carry nonlethal weapons and deploy them when feasible. If this rule had been in effect in Chicago, Bettie Jones \xe2\x80\x94 the 55-year-old woman apparently killed by a stray bullet on Dec. 26 by officers responding to a domestic disturbance call \xe2\x80\x94 would almost certainly still be alive.'b'Chicago just 'b'announced'b' that it would equip more officers with 'b'Tasers'b'. But this step was discretionary, too; current law doesn\xe2\x80\x99t require it. And today\xe2\x80\x99s Tasers can also be lethal and are frequently misused. If a necessity standard were rigorously pursued by courts and legislatures, we would develop better nonlethal weaponry, with better training and stronger punishments for misuse.'b'Only eight states legally require their police officers to give a warning, where feasible, before using deadly force. The necessity rule would make this mandatory. The officer who killed Tamir Rice fired less than two seconds after arriving on the scene. If Ohio law had required the police to first try warning Tamir, which they could have done from inside their vehicle, he, too, would probably still be alive.'b'One piece of good news is that the federal appellate court that covers California, the Ninth Circuit, has been edging toward the necessity rule, holding that courts must inquire whether nonlethal alternatives were available in excessive force cases. As a result, in 2014 a district court in San Diego held that officers in a fatal shooting could be held liable because they didn\xe2\x80\x99t use a Taser or try other nonlethal alternatives before opening fire.'b'Police officers often do heroic work, and of course they need leeway for split-second decision making in dangerous situations. But deadly force has to be necessary to be justified. The felony charges stemmed from an incident more than a decade ago, in which Andrea Constand says Mr. Cosby drugged and assaulted her in his home. Mr. Cosby says he intends to fight the charges, and no court has found him liable for sexual misconduct.'b'The timing of the criminal charges was not arbitrary. The date of the alleged assault was Jan. 15, 2004, and Pennsylvania\xe2\x80\x99s statute of limitations for rape and sexual assault is 12 years: If prosecutors had delayed two and a half weeks, the limit would have tolled.'b'Mr. Cosby\xe2\x80\x99s public fall in the wake of dozens of accusations has been an education in the reality of sexual assault, especially concerning the long conspiracy of silence, and the weight of shame victims are made to carry, when the suspect is powerful and famous. \xe2\x80\x9cI was a teenager from Denver acting in McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s commercials,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Barbara Bowman, another of his accusers, in The 'b'Washington Post'b' in 2014. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was Bill Cosby.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After decades of unsettling claims and quietly settled lawsuits, Mr. Cosby\xe2\x80\x99s public reputation has gone from America\xe2\x80\x99s dad to America\xe2\x80\x99s creepy uncle. But Mr. Cosby finally faces prosecution only because of a deposition 'b'made public'b' in July: If that testimony had been revealed just a few months later, it could have been too late for prosecutors to try this case.'b'The charging of Mr. Cosby, just under the wire, raises a key question: Why is there a statute of limitations for rape and sexual assault at all? Across the country, 34 states 'b'have'b' statutes of limitations on rape, sexual assault or both, ranging from as little as three years up to 30. (A few states also have reporting deadlines tied to statutes of limitations; and a number of states provide for an exemption from statutes of limitations if a DNA match is later made on a reported rape or sexual assault.)'b'Restrictions on how long charges can be brought after the alleged commission of a crime exist primarily to prevent the deterioration of evidence, but also to promote public order, protect criminal defendants who may have a harder time guarding themselves against long-ago accusations, and encourage plaintiffs to bring cases or report crimes swiftly.'b'Those are laudable goals that make sense in theory. But in practice, they undermine justice for survivors.'b'Most sexual assault survivors don\xe2\x80\x99t report the crime right away, especially if the perpetrator is someone they know \xe2\x80\x94 which applies in about four-fifths of cases. Data from the Department of Justice indicates that rape and sexual assault are the 'b'least reported'b' violent crimes, with only around a third of victims reporting. Even when survivors do go to the police, law enforcement routinely fails to fully investigate their claims. Nationwide, as many as 'b'500,000'b' rape kits still await testing.'b'Among the reasons survivors don\xe2\x80\x99t go to the police, one is the well-founded fear they won\xe2\x80\x99t be believed; another is that they may be 'b'accused of lying'b' or even be 'b'prosecuted themselves'b'. Cases where the accused and the accuser know each other, or where there is little physical evidence, are especially difficult to prove.'b'Even evidence doesn\xe2\x80\x99t guarantee a prosecution. In the 24 states where there is no DNA exemption to the statute of limitations, if a rape kit finally is tested and there\xe2\x80\x99s a match, the victim is out of luck if it has been too long.'b'It shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take multiple accusers to bring about a full investigation, but that\xe2\x80\x99s sometimes the reality. The allegations against Mr. Cosby span decades. Once one woman speaks up, others may find the courage to do so. According to New York City crime figures, the number of women willing to report rapes that occurred in previous years is rising rapidly \xe2\x80\x94 a phenomenon that has been called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'the Cosby effect'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Those survivors shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t miss their day in court because they were too traumatized or too scared of possible repercussions to speak out sooner.'b'While good data is lacking on how many suspects are charged a decade or more after the fact, reports of such cases are rare. Some assailants, though, have 'b'gotten off'b' because they admitted to their crimes after the statute of limitations expired.'b'The differing statutes of limitations across state lines create a ZIP code lottery. Where a person is assaulted shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t determine whether she gets justice.'b'An end to statutes of limitations would also allow prosecutors more time to build thorough cases against alleged assailants, instead of rushing up against a dwindling deadline to file slapdash charges, potentially compromising the rights of the accused in the process. It would also allow the accused to defend themselves in a court of law, with its high bar to conviction, rather than in the court of public opinion.'b'Perhaps some state legislators fear ending statutes of limitations for sexual assaults would create chaos and a flood of reports of decades-old crimes. They need not worry: The 16 states with no statute of limitations for rape or sexual assault are not overwhelmed with huge numbers of stale claims.'b'Increasing reporting of rapes and sexual assaults is a complicated challenge, and requires cultural changes as well as improvements in law and policing. For state legislatures to eradicate statutes of limitations for sex crimes is a small enhancement, not a big fix. But for the women and men who find the courage to speak after years of silence and fear, it could be everything.'b'Nearly three years ago, when I first 'b'thought about 'b'living without cable TV, it seemed impractical. But given the proliferation of entertainment choices online, life without cable no longer seems impossible.'b'In early December, I canceled my \xe2\x80\x9ctriple play\xe2\x80\x9d package of TV, telephone and Internet service with Time Warner Cable and switched to a stand-alone Internet access plan. That cut my monthly bill by about $100, without having any impact on how much time I spend in front of my television. Netflix and Amazon Prime have seen to that.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve plowed through the Netflix drama \xe2\x80\x9cSense8\xe2\x80\x9d and watched the 2014 movie \xe2\x80\x9cInterstellar\xe2\x80\x9d on Amazon. Next up is the Amazon series \xe2\x80\x9cThe Man in the High Castle.\xe2\x80\x9d Later, when I run out of things I want to watch on those two services, I might drop them and subscribe to Hulu or HBO Now to watch the movies and TV shows in their libraries.'b'Most Americans still pay for a cable-TV package, but that\xe2\x80\x99s gradually changing as consumers decide there\xe2\x80\x99s no reason to pay for several hundred TV channels they don\xe2\x80\x99t watch. At the end of June, 83 percent of American households paid for TV service, down from 87 percent five years earlier, according to estimates by the 'b'Leichtman Research Group'b'. And as cable viewership has declined, so have the profits and the stock prices of some media companies, like 'b'Disney'b' and 'b'Viacom that'b' own cable channels. Cable companies, which distribute channels to consumers over their wires, 'b'have fared better'b' because they are still earning a lot of money selling Internet service.'b'Media companies will need to come up with new strategies as technology works against predetermined bundled content, just as record labels were forced to deal with online music sales and services like Spotify.'b'Some TV networks, like HBO and CBS, have started selling subscriptions directly to viewers over the Internet. But many companies, especially those that broadcast sports, like ESPN, have resisted the trend toward streaming. Insisting that people who want to watch sports must have a cable subscription might help retain die-hard sports fans, but more casual fans like me will continue to drift away.'b'For me, cutting the cord is as much about saving money as it is about controlling my entertainment diet. With cable\xe2\x80\x99s hundreds of channels, I would get sucked into a show or movie I happened to land on. Canceling cable has meant becoming more intentional and picking out things I really enjoy. I may end up a bit behind the pop culture curve, but so far, I feel liberated \xe2\x80\x94 and still have access to more shows and movies than I can possibly watch.'b'For Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, 2016 could and should be a year of great achievement. He is not facing re-election and is not seeking a spot on the national Democratic ticket. That means his considerable drive and political talents can be trained on making the state more livable for its 20 million inhabitants, and its government more ethical.'b'Mr. Cuomo will combine two important speeches \xe2\x80\x94 his annual State of the State and his budget address \xe2\x80\x94 in one address on Jan. 13. Here are some ideas.'b'The No. 1 issue should be the most obvious: the abysmal transgressions of the Albany crowd. Mr. Cuomo has acknowledged the need for ethics reform after the corruption convictions of two Albany powerhouses, Sheldon Silver and Dean Skelos. But he keeps trying to lower expectations, arguing that there is little he can do about runaway political spending as long as the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s Citizens United decision is in force, and blaming the Republicans in the Legislature for doing nothing to reform its own scandalous behavior.'b'These are excuses meant to shield Mr. Cuomo from future criticism. Of course he will need the Legislature\xe2\x80\x99s help. He clearly wants to position New York as a co-leader with California in the fight against climate change. Which is just where New York should be.'b'As they clasped hands while walking down the red carpet at the Lahore airport recently, Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and Narendra Modi of India looked more like close friends than the leaders of two countries whose tense relations have long been a threat to regional stability.'b'Mr. Modi\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'visit to Pakistan'b' was arranged on short notice and marked the first visit by an Indian prime minister in almost 12 years. But while the two leaders got the political optics right, the challenge, as always, will be overcoming formidable obstacles at home.'b'Mr. Sharif has pressed for engagement with India; Mr. Modi has been conflicted. He invited Mr. Sharif to his inauguration last year but soon after canceled high-level talks, annoyed that Pakistani diplomats had met with separatist leaders from disputed Kashmir. Mr. Modi has also taken a harder line than his predecessor on security issues involving Pakistan.'b'Domestic constraints limit both leaders, especially Mr. Sharif. His power is eclipsed by an army that controls the fastest-growing nuclear weapons program in the world and has long played a double game of taking American assistance while supporting the Taliban in Afghanistan as well as militants opposed to India.'b'The army exploits tensions with India to bolster its importance in Pakistan. Whether the generals support Mr. Sharif\xe2\x80\x99s new outreach to Mr. Modi is unclear, though it seems clear that contact between the two nuclear-armed countries is imperative given the many points of friction, including Afghanistan and Kashmir.'b'Mr. Modi seems to have finally decided that better relations are not only necessary, but require his personal involvement. So far he has not delivered on that promise, spurring protests by middle-class Indians demanding more good jobs.'b'Meanwhile, members of his government and political party have been inflaming sectarian tensions, alarming many Indians and damaging Mr. Modi\xe2\x80\x99s international reputation. A 'b'recent report'b' by the Council on Foreign Relations concluded that without market reforms India risks being left behind in international trade, and that the risk of conflict with Pakistan \xe2\x80\x9cthreatens to drag India down.\xe2\x80\x9d The group said India should seek better relations \xe2\x80\x9cfor the sake of its own future.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One major test of the Modi-Sharif relationship will be whether the two can work together to promote peace talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban, which has been making gains on the battlefield. Other experts are doubtful. Whether a stronger personal connection between Mr. Modi and Mr. Sharif can lead to real trust and cooperation on such issues remains to be seen.'b'MORE than 57,000 New Yorkers will sleep in a shelter tonight. In this city of glistening wealth, they lack a permanent place to call home. Thousands more suffer outside the shelter system; they are on the streets, bracing for the bitter cold ahead.'b'Many in the system are women and children \xe2\x80\x94 families comprise two-thirds of those in shelters. Nine of 10 homeless families are led by women, many of whom have fled domestic violence. Nearly a third of these women are employed. But their low-wage jobs leave them unable to afford the city\xe2\x80\x99s skyrocketing rents.'b'At Win, the nonprofit I lead, we serve the women and children who are the forgotten face of homelessness in New York. They are mothers and grandmothers and aunts and sisters. They work long hours and make sacrifices few of us can fathom, all to give their children and grandchildren a chance to tap the well of dignity inside each of us and break the cycle of homelessness. They are our neighbors, our fellow New Yorkers. Yet, all too often, we fall short of treating and housing New York\xe2\x80\x99s homeless thoughtfully and with care.'b'Three weeks ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a 90-day comprehensive review of city services for the homeless, and a laudable new initiative, Home-Stat, to combat street homelessness. This is an important step to address some of the most visible manifestations of our homelessness crisis. But more is needed.'b'New York has a different agency or office that focuses on just about every challenge homeless families face. Yet little is done to coordinate these services toward the goal of providing permanent housing.'b'Nearly all of those in our shelters are eligible for city-funded housing vouchers. But the agency that oversees cash assistance, which includes vouchers, and job-readiness efforts, the Human Resources Administration, is not the one in charge of shelters. Shelters are instead run by the Department of Homeless Services.'b'We need to combine those two agencies. Until the mid-1990s, services for the homeless were under the purview of the human resources commissioner, and they should be again. This change would be a recognition that homelessness is not an isolated problem; it interacts with, and is a consequence of, a maelstrom of factors \xe2\x80\x94 unaffordable rents, insufficient job training, lack of accessible child care, untreated mental illness and substance abuse, and too few stable work opportunities.'b'Our current shelter system is a hodgepodge of repurposed manufacturing sites and rickety apartment buildings. In the past 20 years, only one new shelter in the system \xe2\x80\x94 Win\xe2\x80\x99s facility on Glenwood Road in Brooklyn \xe2\x80\x94 has been built with families in mind. We need to reimagine our shelters \xe2\x80\x94 and, yes, open new ones \xe2\x80\x94 so that they can offer the holistic services that are critical to equipping homeless families with the skills and treatment they need.'b'Shelters should have free on-site G.E.D. preparation classes and exams. They should offer vocational training programs and job placement support, targeting growth industries where well-paying jobs are most likely to be available. The city could further help by partnering with companies and labor unions to create paths to economic security.'b'Some of these shelters should be built under the same roof as permanent housing and community spaces, to provide a continuum of care and a connection with the neighborhood as well as to leverage existing community resources.'b'Opening new shelters will put thousands of affordable apartments back on the market. For years, the city 'b'has rented apartments'b' and even paid for hotel rooms as temporary shelter units. These apartments and hotel rooms are scattered throughout the city, leaving the homeless without on-site access to support services. The city pays landlords more than someone with a rental voucher can pay, which only exacerbates New York\xe2\x80\x99s already severe housing shortage. More than 3,000 homeless families are housed in apartments that could be permanent homes.'b'Adding quality, integrated shelter capacity and forcing landlords to put up \xe2\x80\x9cfor rent\xe2\x80\x9d signs on these scattered apartments will make more units affordable to working families. This should be a core piece of the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s aggressive housing plan.'b'Another critical focus area is the aftercare services that help families move from shelters to permanent housing. The city has an effective model in Brooklyn, 'b'Home to Stay'b', which provides customized care that gradually decreases in intensity as families become more independent. It should be scaled citywide.'b'We need to learn from what works \xe2\x80\x94 and eliminate what does not, including a web of rules, regulations and laws that run counter to the interests of the homeless. For example, domestic violence survivors 'b'who seek refuge in an emergency shelter'b' should not be uprooted and moved elsewhere after 180 days. This counterproductive policy makes no sense. We should change it.'b'Homelessness is among our city\xe2\x80\x99s most daunting challenges, but it is not intractable. To work with homeless women and children is to be inspired by the grit of mothers who strive daily to improve their kids\xe2\x80\x99 circumstances.'b'They will never accept that better is impossible. Neither can we.'b'LAST month, President Obama inaugurated yet another way to encourage Americans to save for retirement. In the new myRA accounts, workers can save up to $15,000 in a low-fee investment plan that, like a government savings bond, guarantees the principal. The accounts are a small step toward helping households save, but they are not an effective solution to the coming retirement crisis.'b'Starting in 2020, the numbers of very low-income elderly will rise sharply as the retired population soars to almost 56 million. More middle-class working Americans will be poor or near poor after they reach the age of 65. Most currently have inadequate 401(k)-type accounts or no retirement account at all. For good reason, voters tell pollsters that their top economic concern is retirement security.'b'We need a bolder plan, which we are calling the guaranteed retirement account (G.R.A.). Under our proposal, all workers and employers will have to make regular payments into a G.R.A., which builds until retirement age, then pays out a supplemental stream of income until that person and his or her beneficiary die.'b'The current system \xe2\x80\x94 a mix of 401(k)s and individual retirement accounts (I.R.A.s) \xe2\x80\x94 is broken. These plans are individually directed, voluntary and leaky. Just over half of workers don\xe2\x80\x99t have access to a workplace retirement plan. According to the National Institute on Retirement Security, Americans between the ages of 40 and 55 have retirement savings of $14,500, when they will need between 20 and 30 times that amount. Many people take money out before they retire. And the wealthy tend to pay lower fees and get higher subsidies for their savings.'b'A bigger flaw is the way these plans hinder wise investing. Individualized retirement accounts are effectively restricted to short-term liquid stocks and bonds because they are designed to allow people to withdraw their money before retirement. So employees are paying for liquidity they don\xe2\x80\x99t need and achieving subpar results. Traditional pension plans consistently perform better because they are diversified in long- and short-term investments.'b'In our plan, the more than 95 million workers without a pension plan would each have his or her own G.R.A. managed by an independent federal agency. Workers and employers would each contribute a mandatory minimum of 1.5 percent of the salary or contract. The current tax deduction for retirement savings would be converted to a $600 refundable tax credit to pay for the contributions of households below median income.'b'Workers could not withdraw money early, even for emergencies \xe2\x80\x94 and they won\xe2\x80\x99t like that. But allowing exceptions creates a slippery slope. Just as Social Security is protected from early withdrawal, retirement accounts should be used for old-age income. Employers won\xe2\x80\x99t like paying more. But in return, they are free from administrating and worrying about providing retirement plans if they don\xe2\x80\x99t offer a 401(k) or pension. In the long run, employers would benefit because a nation of financially secure retirees would pre-empt higher corporate taxes.'b'Individuals would not make investment decisions directly. Instead, low-fee diversified retirement portfolios would be created by a board of professionals who would be fiduciaries appointed by the president and Congress and held accountable to investors. The fees and investments would be much less prone to corruption because the managers\xe2\x80\x99 income would not depend on the investments, the fees would be disclosed, and the accounts separated from government funds and owned by the individuals.'b'Since contributions would be pooled and fees kept low, a guarantee of a return of around 3 percent \xe2\x80\x94 about half the expected return on stocks over the long term \xe2\x80\x94 would be essentially costless even as the underlying rate fluctuated with the market and inflation. For someone making an average salary of about $48,000, a 3 percent contribution would yield about $170,000 over a lifetime. Three percent is not an adequate saving rate, it is a starting base. Our plan would provide a lifelong annuity, like a defined benefit plan, so no one would face the risk of outliving his or her money.'b'This proposal would require federal legislation. Many states, like California, are now implementing a version of what we are proposing, but the plans aren\xe2\x80\x99t mature enough for us to know if they work. People in their 50s and 60s won\xe2\x80\x99t be helped as much as younger people, but some savings can help delay collecting Social Security. Most nations support retirees through universal two-tier systems consisting of a Social Security-type plan and funded workplace pensions. Our plan would guarantee millions of Americans safe and secure retirements that would benefit them, their families and the nation\xe2\x80\x99s economy.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Aging Society Changes Story on Poverty in Old Age'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Economic Scene, Dec. 23), Eduardo Porter concludes that it is becoming more challenging for American retirees to avoid poverty.'b'Social Security is indeed critical to preventing poverty among older Americans, and AARP, in its Take a Stand campaign, is pressing every presidential candidate to unveil his or her plan to ensure that the program remains financially sound.'b'But as Mr. Porter also noted, private pensions and personal savings make up the rest of the traditional \xe2\x80\x9cthree-legged retirement stool.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Unfortunately, workplace retirement savings options are unavailable to over half of New York State\xe2\x80\x99s private-sector workers 18 to 64 and a quarter of the state\xe2\x80\x99s Generation X and baby boomer voters, according to AARP surveys and research.'b'With Americans 15 times as likely to save if they can do so at work, AARP is urging Gov. McDONALD'b'Founder and President, The Doe Fund'b'New York'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Your Dec. 27 editorial \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Congress and the War Against ISIS'b'\xe2\x80\x9d presents the burdens backward. The burden is not on Congress to give him authority; rather, the restriction is on the president not to make war without getting such authority.'b'The law was enacted with full recognition that such authority is hard to get \xe2\x80\x94 that Congress is exquisitely skilled in doing nothing. It is quite another to expect Congress to formalize such tying of military hands for both him and his successor. (The draft proposed a three-year duration.)'b'While Congress could have toyed with the language, by sending a flawed draft, the president from the outset gravely complicated any reasonable action on this sensitive subject.'b'JAMES FRANKLIN JEFFREY'b'Alexandria, Va.'b''b'The writer, a former ambassador to Iraq, is a fellow at the Washington Institute.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'ISIS Incitement on Internet Raises Second Thoughts About First Amendment'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Dec. 28):'b'There are understandable concerns that any weakening of the \xe2\x80\x9cclear and present danger\xe2\x80\x9d criterion for restrictions on free speech could initiate a slippery slope. Ceci alors m\xc3\xaame que le parti est men\xc3\xa9 par deux femmes. Une contradiction similaire est visible chez les islamistes : leur discours r\xc3\xa9trograde et sexiste est souvent d\xc3\xa9fendu par des femmes, couvertes, qui vantent le voile comme outil de lib\xc3\xa9ration.'b'Les parall\xc3\xa8les sont tels que certains accusent l\xe2\x80\x99extr\xc3\xaame droite de faire le jeu des islamistes en encourageant elle aussi une rupture au sein de la soci\xc3\xa9t\xc3\xa9 occidentale. Apr\xc3\xa8s le premier tour des derni\xc3\xa8res \xc3\xa9lections r\xc3\xa9gionales en France, pays-\xc3\xa9prouvette de la fausse confrontation entre ces deux camps, un caricaturiste avait dessin\xc3\xa9 un salafiste hurlant \xc2\xab On a gagn\xc3\xa9 ! \xc2\xbb \xc3\xa0 propos des avanc\xc3\xa9es record du Front national aux urnes.'b'No\xc3\xabl a co\xc3\xafncid\xc3\xa9 avec le Mawlid en 2015, pour la premi\xc3\xa8re fois depuis plusieurs si\xc3\xa8cles. Mais ce hasard ne mettra pas fin \xc3\xa0 la guerre des calendriers. Bien au contraire. Il aura plut\xc3\xb4t mis en exergue les points communs entre extr\xc3\xa9mistes musulmans et extr\xc3\xa9mistes de droite, qui souvent restent occult\xc3\xa9s.
