C\xe2\x80\x99est g\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9ralement vrai, tant qu\xe2\x80\x99il s\xe2\x80\x99agit d\xe2\x80\x99hommes. Mais l\xe2\x80\x99extr\xc3\xaame droite tue l\xe2\x80\x99humanisme, pourtant la seule chose qui pourrait tous nous sauver.'b'Oran, Algeria \xe2\x80\x94 IT might have been an occasion for collectors of omens to rejoice: For the first time in nearly five centuries, in 2015 the Prophet Muhammad\xe2\x80\x99s birthday coincided with Jesus\xe2\x80\x99 birthday. A cause for hope? Too little, it turns out.'b'Throughout the Muslim world, a harsh campaign was conducted against people who celebrate Christmas. In Algeria, Islamists worked the streets under the regime\xe2\x80\x99s tolerant eye, distributing leaflets denouncing the day as unholy, discouraging customers in pastry shops from buying Yule logs and cakes, and sermonizing in mosques. In Brunei and Somalia, celebrating Christmas could 'b'lead to imprisonment'b'.'b'The Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 argument came down to one essential point: To celebrate Christmas or New Year\xe2\x80\x99s was to imitate the \xe2\x80\x9cKuffar'b',\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'or atheists, which is to say, basically, Westerners. At all cost the man in the white beard had to be kept away from the men with black beards.'b'Pointing out that Christmas is Jesus\xe2\x80\x99 birthday and that Jesus is a recognized prophet in the genealogy of the Quran would have served no purpose. The Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 mental cartography is binary: \xe2\x80\x9cDar el-Islam, Dar el-Koffr\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 Land of Islam versus Land of Impiety. They want to de-Westernize the Arab world.'b'Is it permissible to celebrate the birth of Buddha? Islamists don\xe2\x80\x99t much wonder about that, if only because it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t help them tap anticolonial sentiment or play it up to legitimize themselves. Their enemy is the West, both because of its very nature and because of its military aggressions and economic predations. Islamist literature invokes religion to reject the West, as the land of Crusaders and Jews.'b'But the war of the calendar also goes further: It touches even the birthday of the Prophet Muhammad, though that was consecrated a long time ago. For purists of Islam, the way Muslims celebrate Mawlid, the birthday of Muhammad, today \xe2\x80\x94 with street processions, fireworks, special dishes or new clothes for children \xe2\x80\x94 is a folkloric deviation from doctrine. It is a \xe2\x80\x9cBid\xe2\x80\x99ah,\xe2\x80\x9d an innovation. And innovation implies dissidence, overthrow and revolution: For Islamists, especially Wahhabists, behind every novelty lurks the devil.'b'To celebrate a birthday, even that of a prophet, is to accept the existence of Time, whereas Islamists fantasize about eternity. In their eyes, Time itself is a crime, because it is a departure from original Islam. Thus restoration is the Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 second foundational myth. Their goal is to return to the beginning of Time, to T=0. To the moment of Revelation, when the prophet was still alive and God was so close to his ear. To the moment when Islam had not yet been soiled, to before it was contaminated by History and \xe2\x80\x9cFitna,\xe2\x80\x9d the first Muslim civil wars, which followed the death of Muhammad.'b'This quest for purity also explains Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 relation to physical space. In addition to wanting to conquer territory, the Islamic State seeks to negate and destroy any evidence of the passing of time, such as monuments and ruins, in Palmyra and elsewhere. It tries to extend the desert\xe2\x80\x99s domain: to replace walls with sand, to flatten out landscape, to return to a vacuum so as to start history all over again.'b'The purification myth is not the exclusive purview of Salafists. It also runs through other utopian and totalitarian movements, as well as some of the Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 enemies, like the far-right political parties of today. All of them share the same fantasy of returning to some (imagined) original state of purity.'b'The far right in France, for example, wants to go back to \xe2\x80\x9cla souche,\xe2\x80\x9d its roots, and restore the land of its Gallic ancestors to what it was before immigrants, the Stranger, flooded in. Like the Islamists, it glorifies geography and negates Time.'b'Islamists and far-right groups also share an awkward relationship to women. For Islamists, women are a source of evil: They represent the body, the carnal, and separate men from God. For average militants of the National Front, the modern woman is a 'b'source of disorder'b' in society. And so they promote policies both nativist and 'b'natalist'b', with feudal undertones, that extol the benefits of 'b'breeder housewives'b'. This is the case even though the party is now led by two women. A similar contradiction exists among Islamists: Their retrograde, sexist talk is often defended by women who cover themselves and praise the head scarf as a tool of emancipation.'b'The parallels are such that some people accuse the far right of doing the Islamists\xe2\x80\x99 bidding by also seeking to cause a rift within Western society. After the first round of recent regional elections in France \xe2\x80\x94 a test tube of a country when it comes to the cooked-up confrontation between the two camps \xe2\x80\x94 a cartoonist drew a Salafist yelling \xe2\x80\x9cWe won!\xe2\x80\x9d in response to the National Front\xe2\x80\x99s record showing at the polls.'b'Christmas coincided with Mawlid this year, for the first time in centuries. But the happenstance has highlighted the shared features of Islamists and far-rightists, which usually remain hidden. The two camps feed on each other, providing mutual reinforcement.'b'One might counter that of the two groups, only Muslim extremists kill. Which is true, at least when it comes to people. But the extremists of the right kill humanism, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing that could save us all.'b'MONTREAL \xe2\x80\x94 AS scandals go, it was a juicy one. Volkswagen, one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'highest grossing'b' automakers, persuaded consumers it had created a new generation of so-called clean diesel cars \xe2\x80\x94 until investigators discovered that defeat devices, which activated emissions controls only when the cars were tested, were concealing the fact that its vehicles emitted up to 40 times the permitted levels of pollutants during regular use.'b'Volkswagen has been punished with consumer opprobrium, a costly recall and plummeting sales. Yet the public outrage over the fraud obscures a much larger issue.'b'Volkswagen played a leading role in convincing people to accept a technology that in many countries is causing a precipitous decline in air quality for millions of city-dwellers: the diesel engine. Monitoring sites in European cities like London, Stuttgart, Munich, Paris, Milan and Rome have 'b'reported'b' high levels of the nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, or soot, that help to create menacing smogs.'b'Recently, officials in Milan temporarily 'b'barred'b' cars from the city; in Rome, too, persistent smog has forced the authorities to limit the use of private vehicles. Back in March, Paris was 'b'enveloped'b' in a gray cloud of choking fumes that obscured the Eiffel Tower for hours and briefly earned the French capital the title of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most polluted city, beating out even Beijing. An air quality expert in Britain 'b'reported'b' that much of it was \xe2\x80\x9cstale diesel\xe2\x80\x9d from traffic emissions generated in European cities.'b'This diesel pollution is not just unpleasant; it is also dangerous. The nitrogen oxides produced by diesel engines, which are far more popular in Europe than in the United States, are a potent irritant for asthma sufferers. Health officials in Italy also noted increased reports of cardiovascular disease this week.'b'Diesel exhaust is laden with insidious soot particles, the so-called PM 2.5 (particulate matter smaller than 2.5 microns, or one-thirtieth the width of a human hair), which 'b'allow'b' carcinogens to penetrate deep into tissues and organs. In other words, a driver who steps on the accelerator of a diesel car may be filling the lungs of nearby pedestrians, cyclists, infants in strollers and other drivers with potentially deadly particulate matter.'b'According to one'b' study'b', 9,416 premature deaths in London in 2010 were attributed to nitrogen dioxide and PM 2.5 particles. Annual deaths linked to air pollution in Britain as a whole now rival the death toll in the early 1950s, when \xe2\x80\x9cpea souper\xe2\x80\x9d fogs caused by coal fires 'b' shrouded'b' the capital for weeks.'b'How did we get here?'b'The German engineer 'b'Rudolf Diesel'b' must have thought he was on to a good thing when he built his prototype engine in 1893. Unlike gasoline engines, diesel engines required no spark plugs to ignite the fuel injected into each cylinder: Pressure and high temperatures caused it to combust spontaneously.'b'Diesel\xe2\x80\x99s engine also ran on a grade of fuel far less flammable than gasoline. More economical than other internal combustion engines, diesels became the workhorses of the 20th century: They powered ships, trains, trucks and tanks; they cut trees, dug ore and drove factories. Generations of children in rural areas got to school thanks to buses running on diesel.'b'The diesel engine is inherently efficient: Even a heavy sedan can get as much as 50 miles per gallon, while 'b'producing'b' fewer carbon dioxide emissions per mile. The relatively light carbon footprint of Diesel\xe2\x80\x99s invention meant that in the late 1990s, policy makers in Europe, eager to meet Kyoto Protocol goals, initiated a \xe2\x80\x9cdash for diesel.\xe2\x80\x9d Consumers got a push from sharply reduced taxes on diesel fuel.'b'In Europe, where tens of millions of cars run on diesel, 55 percent of all new vehicle registrations are now for diesel cars. Thanks also to 'b'a glut'b' of cheap diesel from Russian refineries, which last year ramped up production to half a million barrels a day, diesel is now a cheap option at many gas stations.'b'Industry soon took the hint: Diesel could be marketed as green. The Diesel Technology Forum\xe2\x80\x99s website 'b'proclaims 'b'that \xe2\x80\x9cToday\xe2\x80\x99s ultralow sulfur diesel, advanced engines and effective emissions control combine to achieve near zero emissions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the United States, which has some of the world\xe2\x80\x99s toughest air pollution laws, automakers worked hard to convince consumers that a new generation of \xe2\x80\x9cclean diesel\xe2\x80\x9d cars were far less polluting. Volkswagen heavily promoted its \xe2\x80\x9cTDI\xe2\x80\x9d (turbocharged direct injection) technology.'b'We know better now. As anybody who has seen the black smoke spewing out of the pipes of a big rig as it changes gears can testify, diesel has a fatal flaw. It tends to burn dirty, particularly at low speeds and temperatures. In cities, where so much driving is stop and start, incomplete diesel combustion produces pollution that is devastating for human health.'b'Fortunately, Volkswagen sold under half a million of its \xe2\x80\x9cclean diesel\xe2\x80\x9d cars to the American public before the emissions scandal broke. Today, fewer than 1 percent of the passenger vehicles sold in the United States run on diesel fuel.'b'So Americans have a head start on Europe, where policy makers are belatedly coming to view diesel as a devil\xe2\x80\x99s bargain. In a bid to make quick gains in the fight to slow global warming, they abetted a dramatic and quickly apparent decline in urban air quality. It turns out opting for diesel may even have failed to limit climate change: Researchers at Stanford 'b'found'b' in 2002 that the warming because of soot from diesel emissions may more than offset the cooling because of reduced carbon dioxide emissions over the long term.'b'Europe is now scrambling to undo the damage. In London, Mayor Boris Johnson last year called for a national program to pay some drivers to scrap their diesel vehicles. In Paris, Mayor Anne Hidalgo has 'b'gained'b' broad support for a proposed ban on diesel cars.'b'City leaders have a ways to go. On half a dozen visits to Europe in the last five years, I\xe2\x80\x99ve marveled at the way traffic-limiting policies, along with better transit and bicycle infrastructure, have made life there more pleasant. While I envy such smart advances in urbanism and transportation, I\xe2\x80\x99ve also noticed a paradoxical decline in air quality.'b'Elsewhere around the world, such forward-thinking leaders as Enrique Pe\xc3\xb1alosa, the recently 'b're-elected'b' mayor of Bogot\xc3\xa1, Colombia, are betting on public transit, rather than private cars, to keep their cities moving. Battling its own smog problem, Bogot\xc3\xa1 'b'now has'b' a pilot project to replace its rapid transit system\xe2\x80\x99s diesel-powered buses with Chinese-made electric vehicles. Officials in Madrid 'b'have gone'b' further, with plans to make its city center car-free by 2020.'b'Last month, the signatories of the climate deal in Paris agreed that the world has to begin a long-term shift from fossil fuels to more sustainable forms of energy. Recognizing \xe2\x80\x9cclean diesel\xe2\x80\x9d for the oxymoron it is would be a good place to start.'b'In recent years, Congress and the Pentagon have stood in the way of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s goal of shutting down the prison at Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, Cuba. The legislative hurdles have been predictable in a Republican-led Congress that so often opposes Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s initiatives reflexively. The stalling at the Defense Department, where officials have used every bureaucratic trick in the book to slow down the release of inmates, is startling, though, and basically amounts to insubordination.'b''b'A Reuters article'b' on Tuesday shed new light on the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s obstinance on Guant\xc3\xa1namo and the extent to which the department has sought to keep detainees locked away for years without due process in a prison established to sidestep the Constitution and international law.'b'Officials at the Pentagon, Reuters reported, scuttled a potential plan to resettle 'b'Tariq Ba Odah'b', a Yemeni detainee who has been imprisoned since 2002 and was cleared for release in 2009. He is now severely malnourished from having been on a hunger strike for almost nine years. After officials at the State Department persuaded officials from a foreign government to consider taking Mr. Ba Odah in September, those officials made the reasonable request to examine his medical records. Mr. Ba Odah\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer approved the request. The Pentagon, however, stalled for six weeks, preposterously arguing that it was protecting Mr. Ba Odah\xe2\x80\x99s privacy. Mr. Ba Odah remains locked up, raising the likelihood that he will die in detention.'b'In interviews with Reuters, former senior American officials have criticized the Pentagon with unusual candor. James Dobbins, the former State Department envoy for Afghanistan and Pakistan, said that dealing with the Pentagon on Guant\xc3\xa1namo issues was like \xe2\x80\x9cpunching a pillow.\xe2\x80\x9d The reasons are political and ideological. Congress has for several years required that the defense secretary personally sign off on every release and assert that the risk of recidivism has been mitigated. That requirement raised fears of political backlash should a detainee take up arms abroad and became an excuse to delay decisions. Beyond that, some officials see value in having a permanent offshore prison available for terrorism suspects.'b'Time after time, officials at the Pentagon have found ways to delay releases. For instance, Gen. John Kelly, the commander of the United States Southern Command, which oversees the naval base in Cuba, has made it unnecessarily hard for foreign delegations to visit the prison. This has stymied negotiations with countries that have been willing to explore the possibility of taking Guant\xc3\xa1namo detainees whom the American government won\xe2\x80\x99t send back to their countries because of security concerns.'b'Despite the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s intransigence, the White House hopes to reduce the inmate population of 107 significantly over the next few months. 'b'Seventeen detainees 'b'who have received final transfer approval are scheduled for release in the coming weeks. Officials say that as many as 30 more could be released by the summer, reducing the count to roughly 60. The smaller the number the more likely that the detainees could be moved to a prison in the United States until a final disposition can be made in their cases.'b'Pentagon officials can do a lot to thwart releases during Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s last year in office. He can make that less likely by empowering a senior official to set clear goals and deadlines, and order defense officials to meet them.'b'No one called it terrorism back then, but the angst of day-to-day existence during the Cold War was chillingly recalled with the 'b'release last month 'b'of the government\xe2\x80\x99s top-secret nuclear target list for 1959. \xe2\x80\x9cPopulation\xe2\x80\x9d was the obscenely brief title of target category No. 275 \xe2\x80\x94 population, as in the citizens of major cities who war planners estimated would necessarily die by the millions.'b'In my neighborhood, people had vague apocalyptic notions, though it felt plain crazy to believe that the doctrine known as MAD, or \xe2\x80\x9cmutual assured destruction,\xe2\x80\x9d could actually happen. Against this grim though remote possibility, the whole idea of civil defense seemed lame, when the best the government could do was to designate a few thousand of the most mundane New York apartment house basements as supposedly impenetrable \xe2\x80\x9cnuclear fallout shelters\xe2\x80\x9d for a city of millions. What \xe2\x80\x94 survival in Brooklyn on soda crackers, drums of water and aspirin?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDuck and cover\xe2\x80\x9d jokes and tight-lipped laughter became the real civil defense in the Cold War. It felt smarter to seek survival in satire like Stanley Kubrick\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDr. Strangelove.\xe2\x80\x9d Or in Mort Sahl\xe2\x80\x99s stand-up skewering of Dr. Wernher von Braun, the captured German rocket scientist, who metamorphosed into an American space-age hero. Mr. von Braun said in his best-selling autobiography that \xe2\x80\x9cI aim at the stars.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Sahl amended, \xe2\x80\x9csometimes hit London,\xe2\x80\x9d.'b'Backyard fallout shelters and bank loans to build them were promoted in the suburbs, but salesmen eventually went bust peddling doomsday. Politicians eager to guarantee protection were soon ensnared in nuances resembling today\xe2\x80\x99s bickering over carpet bombing. (Could a shelter owner morally use a gun to deter neighbors when the attack came?)'b'The man President John F. Kennedy designated as the nation\xe2\x80\x99s first nuclear civil defense chief, Steuart Pittman, was supposed to guarantee 180 million Americans shelter space stocked with two weeks of food, water and medicine. He met budget resistance in Congress and apathy from the public. \xe2\x80\x9cI hate to hear people say that they would prefer to die in a nuclear attack rather than face the horrors of survival,\xe2\x80\x9d he complained as the plan faded.'b'By 1970, ordinary citizens, though certainly still targeted by the Kremlin, had distractions like Vietnam to worry about. Then suddenly the notion of nuclear Armageddon reappeared with the discovery by the New York State Assembly during a routine session that the state, in 1963, had actually constructed a bomb shelter with 4\xc2\xbd-foot-thick walls and drawn up a list of 700 or so people who would be privileged to survive in it.'b'The long-forgotten shelter was a quiet, pet project of Gov. Nelson Rockefeller, who was also one of the era\xe2\x80\x99s chief promoters of bunkers. Immediately, questions arose among the lawmakers: Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t I know about this until now? More urgently: How do I get on the list? And from one legislator: What about my constituents?'b'As the debate prattled on, a sane voice cut through the chamber. \xe2\x80\x9cI think we\xe2\x80\x99d do better to trust in God,\xe2\x80\x9d boomed Assemblyman Guy Brewer, \xe2\x80\x9crather than put money in a hole in the ground where only a few Herrenvolk would be saved.\xe2\x80\x9d The scene faded to grim laughter, a whistling past the nuclear graveyard, the same civil defense employed by the targeted populations back home.'b'DEMOGRAPHY is destiny, or so the saying goes, but Latinos are learning this political season that destiny can take detours.'b'As their population in the United States surged from 'b'35 million in 2000'b' to nearly 57 million, Latinos became the subjects of a feel-good political story that bathed a marginalized minority in the glow of demographic triumphalism. Acting as a cohesive political force, Latinos were supposed to power Democratic majorities for decades and enshrine the welcoming immigration policies they overwhelmingly favor.'b'Instead, the 2016 campaign is showing how viscerally the paranoia of a majority can take aim at those gaining ground. Rather than a moment of triumph, this could be the year of the Latino eclipse.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cToday we march. Tomorrow we vote.\xe2\x80\x9d That chant brought more than a million people into the 'b'streets'b' in 2006 to protest tough immigration policies promoted by conservative Republicans. Since then Latinos have held to an ethnic empowerment strategy based on a single policy objective \xe2\x80\x94 citizenship for unauthorized immigrants \xe2\x80\x94 and a single tactic \xe2\x80\x94 becoming an essential constituency in presidential elections.'b'Sure enough, in 'b'2008'b' and 'b'2012'b' about two-thirds of the Hispanic electorate backed the candidate who promised a path to citizenship. But Barack Obama did not deliver, even when his party controlled both houses of Congress, and then he earned the title \xe2\x80\x9c'b'deporter in chief'b'\xe2\x80\x9d by hustling nearly 'b'two million'b' unauthorized immigrants back across the border.'b'Nonetheless, here we are again. Latinos are rolling the dice for a third time, betting most everything on one issue, one party and one candidate. Trouble is, the game has changed but the strategy hasn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Despite a decade of trying, Latinos are finding that legalization grows more remote. Immigration advocates who once demanded nothing less than citizenship for all 11 million unauthorized immigrants would now settle for the 'b'temporary reprieve'b' from deportations ordered by President Obama more than a year ago. That plan covers only about half of the unauthorized population with no guarantee of legalization, and 'b'red-state governors'b' have blocked it with a 'b'lawsuit now before the Supreme Court'b'.'b'Meanwhile, the immigration battle has produced no name-brand leaders, and despite sporadic successes, the new faces in advocacy, such as the National Day Laborer Organizing Network and United We Dream, have not developed into institutions of sustained influence. Worse, immigration advocacy has not produced powerful alliances for Latinos, but it has aroused some notable enemies.'b'In opinion polls, Latinos\xe2\x80\x99 partners in the Obama coalition say they favor legalization, but immigration gets scant resources from liberal interest groups compared with gun control, marriage equality or climate change. There is plenty of commitment and passion on the other side, however. Conservative Republicans consistently list a crackdown on unauthorized migration as a top priority, and the president\xe2\x80\x99s executive orders have imbued the issue with the extraordinarily personal animus he provokes among his foes.'b'A backlash was predictable given the vast demographic change that Latinos are part of: 'b'For the past five years, the majority of babies born have not been white.'b' Middle-class economic worries and populist anger at elites added fuel to white anxieties. Then the Washington deadlock over unauthorized migration provided a target. Still, the particular ugliness of the presidential campaign was hard to see coming. With Donald J. Trump stirring the caldron, fear of terrorism is combining with nativism to produce a strain of xenophobia as virulent as any in decades.'b'Even more surprising is the lack of a Latino response. In past election seasons young unauthorized immigrants, the Dreamers, have 'b'staged protests to demand immigration reform'b', but they have yet to take on Mr. Trump loudly. Given his vitriol, you would expect large demonstrations. Compared with Black Lives Matter protesters, Latinos seem passive. In that case, young people, loosely connected by social media and operating outside of institutions, took action that made race resurgent in politics and policy. Similar activism and strengthening of group bonds could still develop among Latinos. If not, then you have to wonder whether political analysts have assigned immigration too great a role in the Hispanic psyche.'b'More oddly still, the most prominent Latinos on the political stage are conservative Republicans who take a hard line on immigration enforcement. Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida challenge what it means to be a Latino leader by promoting policies at odds with a majority of Latino voters, but nonetheless they are the sons of Latin American immigrants. To 'b'label them \xe2\x80\x9ctraitors,\xe2\x80\x9d as some activists have done'b', renders the term \xe2\x80\x9cLatino\xe2\x80\x9d a political affiliation based on a litmus test, not an ethnicity that can claim the power of census numbers.'b'Both Mr. Cruz and Mr. Rubio are eloquent proponents of the aspirational narrative \xe2\x80\x94 my father had nothing \xe2\x80\x94 that is more universal and more intrinsic to Latino identity than the Spanish language. Both are betting that the polls are right in showing that Latinos care more about economic issues than about immigration. They\xe2\x80\x99ll try to pull Latino voters with a message of less government, more jobs. They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to get many to have an impact.'b'In their Senate elections, Mr. Cruz 'b'drew at least 35 percent of the Latino vote'b' in Texas, while Mr. 'b'Rubio got 55 percent in Florida'b'. A Republican ticket that solidly tops the roughly 40 percent share of the Latino vote captured by George W. Bush in 2004 would upend the notion that Latino population growth dooms the Republican Party. Faced with that possibility, the Democrats could hoist a Latino into the spotlight. Hillary Clinton, who 'b'backs a path to citizenship'b', has already said she\xe2\x80\x99ll 'b'\xe2\x80\x9creally look hard\xe2\x80\x9d'b' at Juli\xc3\xa1n Castro, the former San Antonio mayor and current secretary of housing and urban development, as a possible running mate.'b'By taking increasingly hard positions on enforcement and against legalization, Mr. Cruz and Mr. Rubio have further polarized the already harsh politics of immigration. They\xe2\x80\x99ve cut maneuvering room for moderate Republicans, and they have complicated choices for Latinos.'b'If either senator draws a sizable share of their votes, Latinos might gain the clout that comes with being swing voters. But that would shatter the notion of ethnic solidarity with unauthorized immigrants. Latinos might find unity by rallying against the Republican hard line on immigration, but then they will be reduced to not only one issue but also one party. If the Democrats own their votes because there is no alternative on immigration, what leverage do Latinos exercise on jobs and education, the issues they say they care about most?'b'AS the election year unfolds, a wild card looms on the Rio Grande where 'b'signs point to a renewed surge of Central American refugees'b'. So far, Mrs. Clinton has issued only a 'b'noncommittal expression of concern'b' over reports that the Obama administration 'b'plans a crackdown'b'. If women and children end up in 'b'detention centers'b', as they have in the past, and Mrs. Clinton backs the president, Latinos could find themselves with no candidate taking a fully sympathetic position on immigration.'b'Over the years, Latinos have claimed a political destiny based on their population numbers, but the numbers that count in politics are those that decide elections. On that score Latinos have a dismal record to overcome.'b'Between 'b'2000'b' and 'b'2012'b' the number of Hispanics eligible to vote grew by almost 10 million, but the number of actual voters increased by half as much. Even with immigration reform on the line, 'b'fewer than half of eligible Latino voters'b' cast ballots in the two Obama elections, compared with around two-thirds of whites and blacks. This lackadaisical approach to civic engagement extends even to the population most affected by federal immigration policies. Eligible immigrants from Mexico adopt United States citizenship 'b'at about half the rate'b' that newcomers from all other countries do.'b'Latino concerns on immigration policy, Latino candidates and Latino voters nationwide seem certain to draw significant attention this year. The demand for citizenship on behalf of unauthorized immigrants will ring hollow if people who are eligible for citizenship do not naturalize and Latino citizens do not vote. Latino voters have the potential to exert real political power. But a failure to show up on Election Day will eclipse any strength in numbers.'b'The psychiatrist and brain researcher Nora Volkow is the director of the 'b'National Institute on Drug Abuse'b'.'b''b'READING'b' 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Blazing World\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Siri Hustvedt. It\xe2\x80\x99s an incredible novel in which a female artist has great success just by having male artists present her art as theirs. The book dwells on gender bias and what is reality and what is perception in the art world.'b'Also 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOrfeo\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Richard Powers, which is about this man who is trying to generate a musical composition using patterns of nucleotides in DNA. It\xe2\x80\x99s an interesting concept. Could we use the language of biology to perpetuate music?'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cEuphoria\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Lily King is the last book I read, and it tells a fascinating story about anthropologists trying to understand the different cultures in New Guinea. It raises the question, can we really understand something that is different from us or are we just changing it, and on that basis can we really understand? It\xe2\x80\x99s the same concept that the moment you interact with anyone you are changed by that other.'b'I am from Mexico City, so also I like very much Latin American literature, particularly 'b'Mario Vargas Llosa'b' and 'b'Roberto Bola\xc3\xb1o'b', which I prefer to read in Spanish but will read in English just because sometimes it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to get my hands on.'b''b'LISTENING'b' I have had passion for 'b'Beethoven'b' and then 'b'Rachmaninoff'b', 'b'Stravinsky'b' and 'b'Shostakovich'b'. But I always come back to 'b'Bach'b'. His music speaks to my brain. It is a marvel to me the capacity of his music to elicit such strong emotion even though it\xe2\x80\x99s so old.'b''b'WATCHING'b' 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lobster,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' which is a British movie I saw with my niece when we were together in Paris. The movie challenges, in a satirical way, our inflexibility to accept other points of view, specifically around the notion that you should be married. And I also recently watched 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLeviathan,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' which is a Russian film about the bureaucratic systems we create that can destroy the spirits of men. It\xe2\x80\x99s visually very stunning and the use of metaphor is very powerful.'b''b'FOLLOWING'b' I don\xe2\x80\x99t follow anything. I am an oddity. But the National Institutes of Health provides us every day a list of key relevant items in journals. For example, a study on 'b'sleep'b', how it is a cleaning process in the brain, which changed my own research. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been obsessed to try to understand what are these mechanisms because sleep is a challenge in the treatment of people with addictions. If they can\xe2\x80\x99t sleep, they may go back to marijuana or drink alcohol to relax. Also, when we are sleep-deprived our ability to exert self-regulation is degraded, so we are more likely to take risks or binge.'b''b'RECEIVING'b' I recently received a photographic album that belonged to a dear friend who died of cancer. It was her husband who gave it to me. She was a Russian scientist who worked in my laboratory. I had known her for 15 years. She was extraordinarily curious and asked things others didn\xe2\x80\x99t question. The album was a very powerful present because I see her in ways I never saw her. She loved to go hiking in mountains. And she had grandchildren. I had never seen her interact with her grandchildren. It\xe2\x80\x99s like I have a piece of her.'b'STUART SLAVIN, a pediatrician and professor at the Saint Louis University School of Medicine, knows something about the impact of stress. After uncovering alarming rates of anxiety and depression among his medical students, Dr. Slavin and his colleagues remade the program: implementing pass/fail grading in introductory classes, instituting a half-day off every other week, and creating small learning groups to strengthen connections among students. Over the course of six years, the students\xe2\x80\x99 rates of depression and anxiety dropped considerably.'b'But even Dr. Slavin seemed unprepared for the results of testing he did in cooperation with Irvington High School in Fremont, Calif., a once-working-class city that is increasingly in Silicon Valley\xe2\x80\x99s orbit. He had anonymously surveyed two-thirds of Irvington\xe2\x80\x99s 2,100 students last spring, using two standard measures, the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory. The results were stunning: 54 percent of students showed moderate to severe symptoms of depression. More alarming, 80 percent suffered moderate to severe symptoms of anxiety.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis is so far beyond what you would typically see in an adolescent population,\xe2\x80\x9d he told the school\xe2\x80\x99s faculty at a meeting just before the fall semester began. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s unprecedented.\xe2\x80\x9d Worse, those alarming figures were probably an underestimation; some students had missed the survey while taking Advanced Placement exams.'b'What Dr. Slavin saw at Irvington is a microcosm of a nationwide epidemic of school-related stress. We think of this as a problem only of the urban and suburban elite, but in traveling the country to report on this issue, I have seen that this stress has a powerful effect on children across the socioeconomic spectrum.'b'Expectations surrounding education have spun out of control. On top of a seven-hour school day, our kids march through hours of nightly homework, daily sports practices and band rehearsals, and weekend-consuming assignments and tournaments. Each activity is seen as a step on the ladder to a top college, an enviable job and a successful life. Children living in poverty who aspire to college face the same daunting admissions arms race, as well as the burden of competing for scholarships, with less support than their privileged peers. Even those not bound for college are ground down by the constant measurement in schools under pressure to push through mountains of rote, impersonal material as early as preschool.'b'Yet instead of empowering them to thrive, this drive for success is eroding children\xe2\x80\x99s health and undermining their potential. Modern education is actually making them sick.'b'Nearly 'b'one in three'b' teenagers told the American Psychological Association that stress drove them to sadness or depression \xe2\x80\x94 and their single biggest source of stress was school. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a 'b'vast majority'b' of American teenagers get at least two hours less sleep each night than recommended \xe2\x80\x94 and 'b'research'b' shows the more homework they do, the fewer hours they sleep. At the university level, 94 percent of college counseling directors in a 'b'survey'b' from last year said they were seeing rising numbers of students with severe psychological problems.'b'At the other end of the age spectrum, doctors increasingly see children in early elementary school suffering from migraine headaches and ulcers. Many physicians see a clear connection to performance pressure.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m talking about 5-, 6-, 7-year-olds who are coming in with these conditions. We never used to see that,\xe2\x80\x9d says Lawrence Rosen, a New Jersey pediatrician who works with pediatric associations nationally. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m hearing this from my colleagues everywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What sets Irvington apart in a nation of unhealthy schools is that educators, parents and students there have chosen to start making a change. Teachers are re-examining their homework demands, in some cases reviving the school district\xe2\x80\x99s forgotten homework guideline \xe2\x80\x94 no more than 20 minutes per class per night, and none on weekends. In fact, 'b'research'b' supports limits on homework. Students have started a task force to promote healthy habits and balanced schedules. And for the past two years, school counselors have met one on one with every student at registration time to guide them toward a manageable course load.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are sitting on a ticking time bomb,\xe2\x80\x9d said one Irvington teacher, who has seen the problem worsen over her 16 years on the job.'b'A growing body of medical evidence suggests that long-term childhood stress is linked not only with a higher risk of adult depression and anxiety, but with poor physical health outcomes, as well. The 'b'ACE (Adverse Childhood Experiences) Study'b', a continuing project of the Centers for Disease Control and Kaiser Permanente, shows that children who experience multiple traumas \xe2\x80\x94 including violence, abuse or a parent\xe2\x80\x99s struggle with mental illness \xe2\x80\x94 are more likely than others to suffer heart disease, lung disease, cancer and shortened life spans as adults. Those are extreme hardships but a 'b'survey of the existing science'b' in the 2013 Annual Review of Public Health suggested that the persistence of less severe stressors could similarly act as a prescription for sickness.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMany of the health effects are apparent now, but many more will echo through the lives of our children,\xe2\x80\x9d says Richard Scheffler, a health economist at the University of California, Berkeley. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will all pay the cost of treating them and suffer the loss of their productive contributions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Paradoxically, the pressure cooker is hurting, not helping, our kids\xe2\x80\x99 prospects for success. Many college students struggle with critical thinking, a fact that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t escaped their professors, only 14 percent of whom 'b'believe'b' that their students are prepared for college work, according to a 2015 report. Just 29 percent of employers in the same study reported that graduates were equipped to succeed in today\xe2\x80\x99s workplace. Both of those numbers have plummeted since 2004.'b'Contrary to a commonly voiced fear that easing pressure will lead to poorer performance, Saint Louis medical school students\xe2\x80\x99 scores on the medical boards exams have actually gone up since the stress reduction strategy was put in place.'b'At Irvington, it\xe2\x80\x99s too early to gauge the impact of new reforms, but educators see promising signs. Calls to school counselors to help students having emotional episodes in class have dropped from routine to nearly nonexistent. The A.P. class failure rate dropped by half. Irvington students continue to be accepted at respected colleges.'b'There are lessons to be learned from Irvington\xe2\x80\x99s lead. Working together, parents, educators and students can make small but important changes: instituting everyday homework limits and weekend and holiday homework bans, adding advisory periods for student support and providing students opportunities to show their growth in creative ways beyond conventional tests. Communities across the country \xe2\x80\x94 like Gaithersburg, Md., Cadiz, Ky., and New York City \xe2\x80\x94 are already taking some of these steps. In place of the race for credentials, local teams are working to cultivate deep learning, integrity, purpose and personal connection. In place of high-stakes childhoods, they are choosing health.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 THE first time it happens is a dark winter\xe2\x80\x99s afternoon, not quite a year after her death. I\xe2\x80\x99m at my desk working, and there it suddenly is: sharp, glassy-green, with that faint, musky undertone that catches at the back of your throat.'b'I recognize it instantly: the scent that hung in our hall every time she came to supper. The perfume that clung to her coat, her scarves, detectable sometimes for hours on my babies\xe2\x80\x99 hair after she\xe2\x80\x99d been carrying and kissing them.'b'That first time, it\xe2\x80\x99s a shock. But this can\xe2\x80\x99t be done by broadly cutting benefits. In fact, there\xe2\x80\x99s mounting evidence that Social Security, which has become ever more important in retirement, needs to be expanded.'b'Currently, 36 percent of retirees rely on Social Security for 90 percent or more of their income; over all, 65 percent of retirees rely on it for more than half of their income. The Government Accountability Office 'b'recently found'b' that 52 percent of American households with someone 55 or older have nothing saved for retirement and that only half of that 52 percent will get anything from a company pension. But as the wait for his candidacy to heat up lengthens, I wonder: Could he burn out before he ever catches fire?'b'WHEN I moved my Beginning Greek course, last year, from the spring to fall semester, I did not reckon with the impact on my psyche of diminishing daylight. As the days grew shorter, my thoughts about the course grew darker. When the semester concluded, just before the winter solstice, those thoughts had also reached a nadir, giving way to the fear that I had failed, once again, in my 30-year quest to turn bright and eager undergraduates into readers, and lovers, of ancient Greek.'b'Sisyphus would sympathize with my condition. Every year I begin rolling my stone up a four-month-long hill, my hopes high. Every year I end up far closer to the bottom than the top. Some of my students still, after 120 hours of instruction, take the first noun in a sentence as its subject, no matter what form it\xe2\x80\x99s in. The experience of reading without reference to word order, once students \xe2\x80\x9cget it,\xe2\x80\x9d can be exhilarating, like being freed from a kind of gravity.'b'But for reasons I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand, some take far longer than others to \xe2\x80\x9cget it,\xe2\x80\x9d and a few never will. Lack of intelligence isn\xe2\x80\x99t the problem; it\xe2\x80\x99s more about adaptability, acceptance of change. How long should such students go on in the language, hoping for an epiphany? Should I encourage them to continue? And if I do, is it only to assuage my own sense of failure?'b'Paradoxically, the mood in my classroom brightened as the days grew darker. I counterweighted my own internal gloom with saturnalian energy and verve. Anecdotes and digressions proliferated, sometimes drawing boisterous laughter. But the levity masked a sense of unease, a fear that standards were not being met. The number of sentences that couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be cracked, or even attempted, had grown; whole pages of the workbook stood blank. The day of reckoning loomed \xe2\x80\x94 the final exam.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s at such times that Professor de Breeze swims into my thoughts. He\xe2\x80\x99s one of the useless, blinkered obsessives who populate the nihilistic landscape of Dr. Seuss\xe2\x80\x99s darkest exploration of human folly, \xe2\x80\x9cDid I Ever Tell You How Lucky You Are?'b'\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'The anapests that describe him run through my mind on a daily, sometimes hourly, basis:'b''b'How fortunate you\xe2\x80\x99re not Professor de Breeze'b''b''b'Who has spent the past thirty-two years, if you please,'b''b''b'Trying to teach Irish ducks how to read Jivanese.'b''b'Am 'b'I'b' Professor de Breeze? The span of my teaching career is rapidly approaching his. Of the scores of students to whom I have taught Beginning Greek, only a small minority learned to read it with real comprehension, and of those, only a handful still do. What did I contribute to the others, except the most laborious eight credits they ever earned?'b'Oblivious to my struggles, the textbook tries, every year, to crown my students\xe2\x80\x99 achievements by offering them long passages from Sophocles, Homer and Plato. I assigned, for last term\xe2\x80\x99s final exam, a reading from \xe2\x80\x9cAntigone\xe2\x80\x9d that contains one of my favorite Sophoclean lines: \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a warm heart for cold things,\xe2\x80\x9d says the cautious Ismene to her sister Antigone, to dissuade her from defying state decrees and burying their brother. I contemplated the satisfaction my class would get from translating this verse, which seemed to offer little difficulty, apart from the separation of \xe2\x80\x9cheart\xe2\x80\x9d from its modifier \xe2\x80\x9cwarm.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As I graded the exams, however, I found Professor de Breeze once again looking over my shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a warm heart because of the cold,\xe2\x80\x9d read one version; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have a warm heart in addition to a cold one,\xe2\x80\x9d ran another (several variants on this theme). One ingenious student came close with \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a warm heart for cold men\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a possible meaning, though it makes Antigone\xe2\x80\x99s care for her brother\xe2\x80\x99s corpse sound like necrophilia. Two out of my 10 students had understood the line. Wearily I uncapped my red pen, my sins lying heavy upon me.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s been said that, for nonstellar teachers at least, the hardest things to teach are the things one loves most. When I tried, years ago, to read \xe2\x80\x9cKing Lear\xe2\x80\x9d with a group of indifferent freshmen, I made a complete botch of things; my investment in their seeing the play as I did was too great. The same feeling afflicts me on a daily basis when teaching Greek, though I have learned better how to suppress it. \xe2\x80\x9cI will be the pattern of all patience,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lear when his daughters disappointed him, and I have long wanted to emblazon that line over the door of my classroom. No one in that room, I must remind myself, will \xe2\x80\x9chear\xe2\x80\x9d the Antigone passage as I want them to, at least not without lots of help. I must have a cold heart for warm things.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOimoi katauda,\xe2\x80\x9d Antigone screams \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cShout it to the skies!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 when Ismene urges her to keep her plan secret. That \xe2\x80\x9coimoi,\xe2\x80\x9d a cry of pain both mocking and sincere, gives vivid insight into Antigone\xe2\x80\x99s state of mind; lines like this are the best argument one can find for learning Greek. It\xe2\x80\x99s untranslatable, yet translate we must. Our textbook offers either \xe2\x80\x9cAlas\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cwoe is me,\xe2\x80\x9d and there\xe2\x80\x99s little to choose between the two. The sarcasm of \xe2\x80\x9ckatauda\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cshout it out'b'\xe2\x80\x9d'b' \xe2\x80\x94 is lost without a better sense of \xe2\x80\x9coimoi,\xe2\x80\x9d and I could tell from the exam papers that few of my students had gotten its point. Most, at least, had recognized it as an imperative form.'b'With that cry of pain, the exam, and the semester, had ended. Antigone was doomed to die, but at least had managed to spread a little dust on her brother\xe2\x80\x99s corpse. In Beginning Greek, too, one settles for small victories and accepts huge shortfalls. But giving up is not an option.'b'As I finished grading, word arrived of the results of spring registration. Eight of my 10 students had chosen to go on to next semester\xe2\x80\x99s Greek course. The news, I was surprised to find, made me unreservedly happy.'b'The solstice had passed, and the days were already brightening.'b'DO some people have a special talent for serendipity? And if so, why?'b'In 2008, an inventor named Steve Hollinger lobbed a digital camera across his studio toward a pile of pillows. \xe2\x80\x9cI wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to make an invention,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI was just playing.\xe2\x80\x9d As his camera flew, it recorded what most of us would call a bad photo. But when Mr. Hollinger peered at that blurry image, he saw new possibilities. Soon, he was building a throwable videocamera in the shape of a baseball, equipped with gyroscopes and sensors. The Squito (as he named it) could be rolled into a crawlspace or thrown across a river \xe2\x80\x94 providing a record of the world from all kinds of \xe2\x80\x9cnonhuman\xe2\x80\x9d perspectives. Today, Mr. Hollinger holds six patents related to throwable cameras.'b'A surprising number of the conveniences of modern life were invented when someone stumbled upon a discovery or capitalized on an accident: the microwave oven, safety glass, smoke detectors, artificial sweeteners, X-ray imaging. Many blockbuster drugs of the 20th century emerged because a lab worker picked up on the \xe2\x80\x9cwrong\xe2\x80\x9d information.'b'While researching breakthroughs like these, I began to wonder whether we can train ourselves to become more serendipitous. How do we cultivate the art of finding what we\xe2\x80\x99re not seeking?'b'For decades, a University of Missouri information scientist named Sanda Erdelez has been asking that question. Growing up in Croatia, she developed a passion for losing herself in piles of books and yellowed manuscripts, hoping to be surprised. Dr. Erdelez told me that Croatian has no word to capture the thrill of the unexpected discovery, so she was delighted when \xe2\x80\x94 after moving to the United States on a Fulbright scholarship in the 1980s \xe2\x80\x94 she learned the English word \xe2\x80\x9cserendipity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today we think of serendipity as something like dumb luck. But its original meaning was very different.'b'In 1754, a belle-lettrist named Horace Walpole retreated to a desk in his gaudy castle in Twickenham, in southwest London, and penned a letter. Walpole had been entranced by a Persian fairy tale about three princes from the Isle of Serendip who possess superpowers of observation. In his letter, Walpole suggested that this old tale contained a crucial idea about human genius: \xe2\x80\x9cAs their highnesses travelled, they were always making discoveries, by accident and sagacity, of things which they were not in quest of.\xe2\x80\x9d And he proposed a new word \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cserendipity\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 to describe this princely talent for detective work. At its birth, serendipity meant a skill rather than a random stroke of good fortune.'b'Dr. Erdelez agrees with that definition. She sees serendipity as something people 'b'do'b'. In the mid-1990s, she began a study of about 100 people to find out how they created their own serendipity, or failed to do so.'b'Her qualitative data \xe2\x80\x94 from surveys and interviews \xe2\x80\x94 showed that the subjects fell into three distinct groups. Some she called \xe2\x80\x9cnon-encounterers\xe2\x80\x9d; they saw through a tight focus, a kind of chink hole, and they tended to stick to their to-do lists when searching for information rather than wandering off into the margins. Other people were \xe2\x80\x9coccasional encounterers,\xe2\x80\x9d who stumbled into moments of serendipity now and then. Most interesting were the \xe2\x80\x9csuper-encounterers,\xe2\x80\x9d who reported that happy surprises popped up wherever they looked. The super-encounterers loved to spend an afternoon hunting through, say, a Victorian journal on cattle breeding, in part, because they counted on finding treasures in the oddest places. In fact, they were so addicted to prospecting that they would find information for friends and colleagues.'b'You become a super-encounterer, according to Dr. Erdelez, in part because you believe that you are one \xe2\x80\x94 it helps to assume that you possess special powers of perception, like an invisible set of antennas, that will lead you to clues.'b'A few months ago, I was having a drink in Cambridge, Mass., with a friend, a talented journalist who was piecing together a portrait of a secretive Wall Street wizard. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I haven\xe2\x80\x99t found the real story yet; I\xe2\x80\x99m still gathering string,\xe2\x80\x9d my friend told me, invoking an old newsroom term to describe the first stage of reporting, when you\xe2\x80\x99re looking for something that you can\xe2\x80\x99t yet name. Later that night, as I walked home from the bar, I realized \xe2\x80\x9cgathering string\xe2\x80\x9d is just another way of talking about super-encountering. After all, \xe2\x80\x9cstring\xe2\x80\x9d is the stuff that accumulates in a journalist\xe2\x80\x99s pocket. It\xe2\x80\x99s the note you jot down in your car after the interview, the knickknack you notice on someone\xe2\x80\x99s shelf, or the anomaly that jumps out at you in Appendix B of an otherwise boring research study.'b'As I navigated the brick sidewalk, passing under the pinkish glow of a streetlight, I thought about how string was probably hiding all around me. A major story might lurk behind the Harvard zoology museum ahead or in the plane soaring above. String is everywhere for the taking, if you have the talent to take it.'b'In the 1960s, Gay Talese, then a young reporter, declared that \xe2\x80\x9cNew York is a city of things unnoticed\xe2\x80\x9d and delegated himself to be the one who noticed. Thus, he transformed the Isle of Manhattan into the Isle of Serendip: He traced the perambulations of feral cats, cataloged shoeshine purveyors, tracked down statistics related to the bathrooms at Yankee Stadium and discovered a colony of ants at the top of the Empire State Building. He published his findings in a little book titled \xe2\x80\x9cNew York: A Serendipiter\xe2\x80\x99s Journey'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'The term \xe2\x80\x9cserendipiter\xe2\x80\x9d breathed new life into Walpole\xe2\x80\x99s word, turning serendipity into a protagonist and a practitioner. After all, those ants at the top of the Empire State Building didn\xe2\x80\x99t find themselves; Mr. Talese had to notice them, which was no easy matter. Similarly, Dr. Erdelez came up with the term super-encounterer to give us a way to talk about the 'b'people 'b'rather than just the discoveries. Without such words, we tend to become dazzled by the happy accident itself, to think of it as something that exists independent of an observer.'b'We can slip into a twisted logic in which we half-believe the penicillin picked Alexander Fleming to be its emissary, or that the moons of Jupiter wanted to be seen by Galileo. But discoveries are products of the human mind.'b'As people dredge the unknown, they are engaging in a highly creative act. What an inventor \xe2\x80\x9cfinds\xe2\x80\x9d is always an expression of him- or herself. Martin Chalfie, who won a Nobel Prize for his work connected with green fluorescent protein \xe2\x80\x94 the stuff that makes jellyfish glow green \xe2\x80\x94 told me that he and several other Nobel Prize winners benefited from a chain of accidents and chance encounters on the way to their revelations. Some scientists even embrace a kind of \xe2\x80\x9cfree jazz\xe2\x80\x9d method, he said, improvising as they go along: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of people getting good results after accidentally dropping their experimental preparations on the floor, picking them up, and working on them nonetheless,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.'b'So how many big ideas emerge from spills, crashes, failed experiments and blind stabs? One survey of patent holders (the PatVal study of European inventors, published in 2005) found that an incredible 50 percent of patents resulted from what could be described as a serendipitous process. Thousands of survey respondents reported that their idea evolved when they were working on an unrelated project \xe2\x80\x94 and often when they weren\xe2\x80\x99t even trying to invent anything. This is why we need to know far more about the habits that transform a mistake into a breakthrough.'b'IN the late 1980s, Dr. John Eng, an endocrinologist, became curious about certain animal poisons that damaged the pancreas, so he ordered lizard venom through the mail and began to play around with it. As a result of this curious exercise, he discovered a new compound in the saliva of a Gila monster, and that in turn led to a treatment for diabetes. One of Dr. Eng\xe2\x80\x99s associates (quoted in a 2005 newspaper article) remarked that he was capable of seeing \xe2\x80\x9cpatterns that others don\xe2\x80\x99t see.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Is this pattern-finding ability similar to the artistic skill of a painter like Georgia O\xe2\x80\x99Keeffe? Is it related to the string-gathering prowess of Gay Talese? We still know so little about creative observation that it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to answer such questions.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why we need to develop a new, interdisciplinary field \xe2\x80\x94 call it serendipity studies \xe2\x80\x94 that can help us create a taxonomy of discoveries in the chemistry lab, the newsroom, the forest, the classroom, the particle accelerator and the hospital. By observing and documenting the many different \xe2\x80\x9cspecies\xe2\x80\x9d of super-encounterers, we might begin to understand their minds.'b'A number of pioneering scholars have already begun this work, but they seem to be doing so in their own silos and without much cross-talk. In a 2005 paper (\xe2\x80\x9cSerendipitous Insights Involving Nonhuman Primates\xe2\x80\x9d), two experts from the Washington National Primate Research Center in Seattle cataloged the chance encounters that yielded new insights from creatures like the pigtail macaque. Meanwhile, the authors of a paper titled \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Exploitation of Serendipity in Drug Discovery\xe2\x80\x9d puzzled over the reasons the 1950s and \xe2\x80\x9960s saw a bonanza of breakthroughs in psychiatric medication, and why that run of serendipity ended. And in yet another field of study, a few information scientists are trying to understand the effects of being bombarded on social media sites with countless tantalizing pieces of \xe2\x80\x9cstring.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What could these researchers discover if they came together for one big conversation?'b'Of course, even if we do organize the study of serendipity, it will always be a whimsical undertaking, given that the phenomenon is difficult to define, amazingly variable and hard to capture in data. The clues will no doubt emerge where we least expect them, perhaps in the fungi clinging to the walls of parking garages or the mating habits of bird-watchers. The journey will be maddening, but the potential insights could be profound: One day we might be able to stumble upon new and better ways of getting lost.'b'High school graduation rates are rising, but are the students ready for college and careers?'b'To the Editor: Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'As Graduation Rates Rise, a Fear Diplomas Fall Short'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Dec. 27): As a career educator I find it disheartening to see yet another article about how poorly students are prepared for college despite a rising high school graduation rate. The explanation for these contradictory outcomes has always been obvious, and yet for years we have refused to accept it. You cannot honestly raise standards without being willing to accept a lower graduation rate. Of course, as educators we strive to improve teaching strategies as we raise standards, and the ultimate, but probably unreachable, goal is to make it possible for all students to meet these standards.'b'Certainly over the long term higher standards will improve the outcomes for all students. In many states the strategy has been to raise standards and then lower passing scores on exit exams in order to maintain or even raise the graduation rate, which means that students who are unprepared for college are given diplomas. For example, in New York State, a student needs a raw score of 30 points out of a possible 86 points (35 percent correct) on the algebra Regents in order to have a passing grade of 65'b'.'b' Similar cutoff scores are used in other subject exams as well.'b'If we are truly serious about raising standards, it seems to me that we must also be willing to accept, at least for the near term, a lower graduation rate, or tiered diplomas indicating various levels of academic achievement.'b'HOWARD BRENNER'b'Woodmere, N.Y.'b'To the Editor: Your article says of high school graduation rates, \xe2\x80\x9cStill, there is no single reason these rates have increased.\xe2\x80\x9d Yes, there is. The graduation rates increased because parents and politicians demanded that they increase. Instead of improving education, states lowered standards. For example, you report that some states \xe2\x80\x9celiminated requirements that students pass exit exams to qualify for a diploma.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Does the fact that a high school diploma is now essentially meaningless cause problems for colleges, private employers and the military? Colleges have the ACT and SAT for potential entrants; Wal-Mart, our largest private employer, has its assessment test for potential employees; and the military has the Armed Forces Qualification Test for potential recruits. The only people really harmed are the marginal students who were passed on instead of helped.'b'VIC PRESUTTI'b'Dayton, Ohio'b'To the Editor: With high school graduation rates at an all-time high, the occasion would seem right for a celebration. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, Rutgers University.'b''b''b'EVERY New Year\xe2\x80\x99s'b', in a spirit of self-examination, I try to catalog my worst blunders from the preceding year. But this year, like almost every pundit in America, I have one mistake that overshadows all the others, one confession that makes my other faults seem venial by comparison.'b''b'I underestimated Donald Trump.'b''b'To really make a clean breast on this issue, I have to reach back earlier than 2015 (some forecasts take more than a year to be disproven), to 'b'a column I wrote'b' in the far-off days of the 2012 campaign, when Mitt Romney flew to Vegas, baby, to accept an endorsement from the Donald.'b'This struck me, at the time, as a needless move by Mitt, because it left him sticky with the tar of Trump\xe2\x80\x99s birther nonsense while delivering little in return. The idea that Romney needed the kind of voters excited by Trump\xe2\x80\x99s flamethrower style, I wrote, confused \xe2\x80\x9cthe existence of a fan base (which Trump certainly has) with the existence of a meaningful constituency (which he almost certainly does not).\xe2\x80\x9d And even if there were real Trumpistas, Romney would win their allegiance eventually: \xe2\x80\x9cAnyone who thrills to Trump\xe2\x80\x99s slashing attacks on the president probably isn\xe2\x80\x99t sitting this election out.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As a third-party candidate, I went on, Trump 'b'might'b' pose some danger to Romney\xe2\x80\x99s general-election chances. Exactly how meaningful remains to be seen, but for months far more Republicans have told pollsters that they intend to vote for him than have rallied to any other banner. They may not all be Trump voters in the end, but that there is a significant Trump faction in our politics no sane observer can deny.'b'Second, that faction has turned out to include precisely the kind of voters Romney needed in 2012 and who stayed home instead: Blue-collar whites with moderate views on economics and a weak attachment to the institutional G.O.P. (So weak, 'b'a recent New York Times analysis'b' makes clear, that many are still registered Democrats.) These 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cmissing white voters\xe2\x80\x9d'b' might not have put Romney over the top, but they certainly would have helped his chances in states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan \xe2\x80\x94 all places where Trump is running strongly at the moment.'b'Third, even as he\xe2\x80\x99s wooed the disaffected and non-ideological, Trump has also won over or at least neutralized an important segment of the conservative media.
