But for the rest \xe2\x80\x94 no, I had a pretty low opinion of the right-wing entertainment complex to begin with, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not remotely surprised that the white working class would rally to a candidate 'b'running on populist and nationalist themes'b'.'b'I am very surprised, though, that Trump himself would have the political savvy, the (relative) discipline and yes, the stamina required to exploit that opening and become that populist. And for that failure of imagination, I humbly repent.'b'Of course I\xe2\x80\x99m not completely humbled. Indeed, I\xe2\x80\x99m still proud enough to continue predicting, in defiance of national polling, that there\xe2\x80\x99s still 'b'no way'b' that Trump will actually be the 2016 Republican nominee.'b'Trust me: I\xe2\x80\x99m a pundit.'b'(And I\xe2\x80\x99ll see you in the confessional next year.)'b'A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.'b'I WAS transported recently to a place that is as enchanting to me as any winter wonderland: my local post office.'b'In line, I thought fondly of the year I came to this country from Turkey as an adult and discovered the magic of reliable mail service. Dependable infrastructure is magical not simply because it works, but also because it allows innovation to thrive, including much of the Internet-based economy that has grown in the past decade. You can\xe2\x80\x99t have Amazon or eBay without a reliable way to get things to people\xe2\x80\x99s homes.'b'Of course, infrastructure is also boring, so we get used to it and forget what a gift it truly is. I never do, maybe because I discovered it so late.'b'My first year in the United States was full of surprises. I remember trying to figure out if the 24-ounce glass of ice water the waitress placed in front of me was a pitcher, to be shared by the whole table. But where was the spout? I had expected some of what I encountered \xe2\x80\x94 I had seen enough movies, and came to this country expecting big cars and big houses and wide open spaces. I got used to gigantic glasses.'b'But I didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect the post office.'b'The first time I needed to mail something, I trekked over to my campus\xe2\x80\x99s post office, looking for the line to get my envelope weighed. The staff was used to befuddled international students like me, I suppose, and one clerk took my envelope without fuss, said \xe2\x80\x9cfirst class letter,\xe2\x80\x9d and took my change.'b'Then I discovered some vending machines outside the office. People came and bought stamps. \xe2\x80\x9cSo many people must be into stamp collecting,\xe2\x80\x9d I thought to myself. Was that another weird American quirk? Otherwise, why would people waste money buying stamps in advance, without having their letters weighed?'b'Something I take for granted now just didn\xe2\x80\x99t occur to me: There were standardized rates, and you could just slap a stamp on your letter, drop it in a mailbox, and it would go to its destination.'b'I then encountered a visa service that asked me to mail in my passport. My precious, precious passport. With a self-addressed, stamped envelope for its return. I laughed at the audacity of the request. Despite being a broke student, I booked a plane trip. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t envision putting my passport in the mail. I\xe2\x80\x99ve since learned that this is a common practice, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve even done it once or twice myself. But it still does not come easy to me.'b'I noticed that Americans were a particularly patriotic bunch: So many of them had red flags on their mailboxes. Sometimes they would put those flags up. I presumed it was to celebrate national holidays I did not yet know about. But why did some people have their flags up while others did not? And why weren\xe2\x80\x99t they American flags anyway? As in Istanbul, where I grew up, I assumed patriotism had different interpretations and expressions.'b'The mystery was solved when I noticed a letter carrier 'b'emptying'b' a mailbox. I was slightly unnerved: Was the mail being stolen? He then went over to another mailbox with the flag up, and emptied that box, too. I got my hint when he skipped the mailbox with the flag down.'b'Yes, I was told, in the United States, mail gets picked up from your house, six days a week, free of charge.'b'I told my friends in Turkey about all this. They shook their heads in disbelief, wondering how easily I had been recruited as a C.I.A. agent, saying implausibly flattering things about my new country. The United States in the world\xe2\x80\x99s imagination is a place of risk taking and ruthless competition, not one of reliable public services.'b'I bit my tongue and did not tell my already suspicious friends that the country was also dotted with libraries that provided books to all patrons free of charge. They wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe me anyway since I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t believed it myself. My first time in a library in the United States was very brief: I walked in, looked around, and ran right back out in a panic, certain that I had accidentally used the wrong entrance. Surely, these open stacks full of books were reserved for staff only. I was used to libraries being rare, and their few books inaccessible. To this day, my heart races a bit in a library.'b'Over the years, I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to appreciate the link between infrastructure, innovation \xe2\x80\x94 and even ruthless competition. Much of our modern economy thrives here because you can order things online and expect them to be delivered. There are major private delivery services, too, but the United States Postal Service is often better equipped to make it to certain destinations. In fact, Internet sellers, and even private carriers, often use the U.S.P.S. as their delivery mechanism to addresses outside densely populated cities.'b'Almost every aspect of the most innovative parts of the United States, from cutting-edge medical research to its technology scene, thrives on publicly funded infrastructure. The post office is struggling these days, in some ways because of how much people rely on the web to do much of what they used to turn to the post office for. But the Internet is a testament to infrastructure, too: It exists partly because the National Science Foundation funded much of the research that makes it possible. Even some of the Internet\xe2\x80\x99s biggest companies, like Google, got a start from 'b'N.S.F.-funded research'b'.'b'Infrastructure is often the least-appreciated part of what makes a country strong, and what makes innovation take flight. From my spot in line at the post office, I see a country that does both well; not a country that emphasizes one at the expense of the other.'b'IT was the spring of 1991 \xe2\x80\x94 more than two decades before Ferguson, Mo., would become a national symbol of racism \xe2\x80\x94 when my parents took my siblings and me to visit their hometown, St. Louis. We spent the week hanging out with our cousins, with whom we were close. I was 16, too young to tag along when, the night before we were supposed to return home to Maryland, my 19-year-old brother, Tom Cummins, and our cousins, Julie and Robin Kerry, were brutally attacked by four strangers. Julie was 20, Robin, 19.'b'The strangers were young people, too. They raped my cousins and restrained my brother before forcing them off a bridge into the Mississippi River. Only my brother survived.'b'Forensic DNA analysis was in its infancy in 1991. Besides, most of that kind of evidence was destroyed by the river. Julie was in the water for three weeks before her body was recovered; Robin\xe2\x80\x99s body was never found. Still, my brother\xe2\x80\x99s testimony, combined with his identification of the perpetrators and their own incriminating statements, was damning.'b'There was also substantiating evidence: One of the men had my brother\xe2\x80\x99s watch, another left a stolen flashlight at the crime scene. The youngest, Daniel Winfrey, who was 15 at the time, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and testified against the others. Eventually, all four were convicted of murder. During the lengthy appeals process, more proof emerged: A few years ago, DNA tests conducted on the single condom in evidence 'b'verified'b' that one of the four friends, Marlin Gray, raped at least one of my cousins. He was executed in 2005.'b'When the police questioned another of the men, Reginald Clemons, in 1991, he confessed to raping (but not killing) my cousins. He was convicted of their first-degree murders in 1993. He now claims he is innocent, and in November, Missouri\xe2\x80\x99s Supreme Court ruled to 'b'vacate those convictions'b' because it determined that prosecutors might have suppressed evidence suggesting that his confession was coerced. For the purposes of clarity, let us acknowledge that \xe2\x80\x9ccoerced\xe2\x80\x9d means 'b'beaten out of him'b'.'b'This has been the elephant in our 25-year-old waiting room, and it feels cathartic to finally say: Yes, the police most likely did beat Reginald Clemons. In fact I\xe2\x80\x99m quite sure they did, because while they briefly suspected my brother, they beat him, too.'b'For the longest time, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t care that Reginald Clemons was probably beaten. I would gladly have beaten him myself, and then some. I believed that civil rights were for innocent people. But when police officers disregarded his civil rights, and then the media reduced that fact to a headline, it allowed him to leverage the noble voice of victimhood and dictate a distorted narrative that further violated my cousins and their memory.'b'I have written about this story before. But there\xe2\x80\x99s one element of it that I always avoided: race.'b'For almost 25 years, I asserted that race had no place in the discussion of what happened to my family. I still don\xe2\x80\x99t want to write about race. What I mean is, I 'b'really 'b'don\xe2\x80\x99t want to write about race. I\xe2\x80\x99m terrified of striking the wrong chord, of being vulnerable, of uncovering shameful ignorance in my psyche. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of being misinterpreted.'b'I am white. The grandmother I shared with Julie and Robin was Puerto Rican, and their father is half Lebanese. But in every practical way, my family is mostly white. I\xe2\x80\x99ll never know the impotent rage of being profiled, or encounter institutionalized hurdles to success because of my skin or hair or name. But I care about race and equality. And it\xe2\x80\x99s imperative for white people to join the conversation about racism. Discomfort is the least of our obligations.'b'When my cousins were raped and murdered five miles from Ferguson, that violence was an act of indiscriminate brutality. There is no reason to believe there was any racial element to the crime, though three out of its four perpetrators (all but Daniel Winfrey) were African-American, and their victims were white. The aftermath of that tragedy was a different story.'b'In St. Louis, the murders were big, splashy news. Privately, when I told white people what had happened, they would sometimes whisper, \xe2\x80\x9cWere the guys 'b'black'b'?\xe2\x80\x9d Publicly, the media narrative quickly deteriorated into sensationalism. On message boards and radio call-in shows, blatant racists made disturbing calls for vengeance, using awful phrases like \xe2\x80\x9cstring \xe2\x80\x99em up.\xe2\x80\x9d That ugliness prompted a backlash. Defenders of the four men used words like \xe2\x80\x9crailroaded,\xe2\x80\x9d claiming the charges and the trial were racially motivated.'b'My family ducked away from all of it because it made us sick. We didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how to respond. It\xe2\x80\x99s a cruel irony that the night they were murdered, my cousins were taking Tom to see a poem they\xe2\x80\x99d spray painted on the bridge about the horrors of racism. So yes, while my white cousins were attacked by some black men, the emphasis on race felt ludicrously, infuriatingly off topic. Sometimes a person is just guilty, not because he\xe2\x80\x99s black, but because he\xe2\x80\x99s a murderer. All the hatred began to obscure the only fact that mattered: that Julie and Robin were dead.'b'For now, Reginald Clemons is still in prison, serving a 15-year sentence for his conviction in 2007 for assaulting a guard. But in the coming weeks, prosecutors will have to decide between these two unthinkable options: the ordeal of a new murder trial, or his eventual liberation. In either case, this sequel to my family\xe2\x80\x99s nightmare was preventable.'b'When those cops put their hands on Reginald Clemons, they didn\xe2\x80\x99t just violate him; they violated the justice that Julie and Robin deserve. What happened to him doesn\xe2\x80\x99t offset his guilt.'b'Whatever comes next will now occur against the backdrop of a racially explosive Ferguson. Within that context, my family cannot submit to anyone else\xe2\x80\x99s definition of who we are. No one is allowed to co-opt my cousins\xe2\x80\x99 memory into their own racist narrative. We are not the poster family for \xe2\x80\x9cvictimized\xe2\x80\x9d white people. No one can make us bigots by grafting ignorant presumptions onto our grief.'b'THIS holiday season, there was something in the air that was even more inescapable than the scent of pumpkin spice: gratitude.'b'In November, NPR issued a number of brief exhortations to cultivate gratitude, culminating in an hourlong special on the \xe2\x80\x9cscience of gratitude,\xe2\x80\x9d narrated by Susan Sarandon. Writers in Time magazine, The New York Times and Scientific American recommended it as a surefire ticket to happiness and even better health. Robert Emmons, a psychology professor at the University of California, Davis, who studies the \xe2\x80\x9cscience of gratitude,\xe2\x80\x9d argues that it leads to a stronger immune system and lower blood pressure, as well as \xe2\x80\x9cmore joy and pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s good to express our thanks, of course, to those who deserve recognition. But this holiday gratitude is all about you, and how you can feel better.'b'Gratitude is hardly a fresh face on the self-improvement scene. By the turn of the century, Oprah Winfrey and other motivational figures were promoting an \xe2\x80\x9cattitude of gratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d Martin Seligman, the father of \xe2\x80\x9cpositive psychology,\xe2\x80\x9d which is often enlisted to provide some sort of scientific basis for \xe2\x80\x9cpositive thinking,\xe2\x80\x9d has been offering instruction in gratitude for more than a decade. In the logic of positive self-improvement, anything that feels good \xe2\x80\x94 from scenic walks to family gatherings to expressing gratitude \xe2\x80\x94 is worth repeating.'b'Positive thinking was in part undone by its own silliness, glaringly displayed in the 2006 best seller \xe2\x80\x9cThe Secret,\xe2\x80\x9d which announced that you could have anything, like the expensive necklace you\xe2\x80\x99d been coveting, simply by \xe2\x80\x9cvisualizing\xe2\x80\x9d it in your possession.'b'The financial crash of 2008 further dimmed the luster of positive thinking, which had done so much to lure would-be homeowners and predatory mortgage lenders into a speculative frenzy. This left the self-improvement field open to more cautious stances, like mindfulness and resilience and \xe2\x80\x94 for those who could still muster it \xe2\x80\x94 gratitude.'b'Gratitude is at least potentially more prosocial than the alternative self-improvement techniques. You have to be grateful to 'b'someone'b', who could be an invisible God, but might as well be a friend, mentor or family member. The gratitude literature often advises loving, human interactions: writing a \xe2\x80\x9cgratitude letter\xe2\x80\x9d to a helpful colleague, for example, or taking time to tell a family member how wonderful they are. These are good things to do, in a moral sense, and the new gratitude gurus are here to tell us that they also 'b'feel'b' good.'b'But is gratitude always appropriate? The answer depends on who\xe2\x80\x99s giving it and who\xe2\x80\x99s getting it or, very commonly in our divided society, how much of the wealth gap it\xe2\x80\x99s expected to bridge. Suppose you were an $8-an-hour Walmart employee who saw her base pay elevated this year, by company fiat, to $9 an hour. Should you be grateful to the Waltons, who are the richest family in America? Or to Walmart\xe2\x80\x99s chief executive, whose annual base pay is close to $1 million and whose home sits on nearly 100 acres of land in Bentonville, Ark.? Grateful people have been habitually dismissed as \xe2\x80\x9cchumps,\xe2\x80\x9d and in this hypothetical case, the term would seem to apply.'b'Perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that gratitude\xe2\x80\x99s rise to self-help celebrity status owes a lot to the conservative-leaning John Templeton Foundation. At the start of this decade, the foundation, which promotes free-market capitalism, gave $5.6 million to Dr. Emmons, the gratitude researcher. It also funded a $3 million initiative called Expanding the Science and Practice of Gratitude through the Greater Good Science Center at the University of California, Berkeley, which co-produced the special that aired on NPR. The foundation does not fund projects to directly improve the lives of poor individuals, but it has spent a great deal, through efforts like these, to improve their attitudes.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a safe guess, though, that most of the people targeted by gratitude exhortations actually have something to be grateful for, such as Janice Kaplan, the author of the memoir \xe2\x80\x9cThe Gratitude Diaries,\xe2\x80\x9d who spent a year appreciating her high-earning husband and successful grown children. And it is here that the pro-social promise of gratitude begins to dim. True, saying \xe2\x80\x9cthank you\xe2\x80\x9d is widely encouraged, but much of the gratitude advice involves no communication or interaction of any kind.'b'Consider this, from a yoga instructor on 'b'CNN.com'b': \xe2\x80\x9cCultivate your sense of gratitude by incorporating giving thanks into a personal morning ritual such as writing in a gratitude journal, repeating an affirmation or practicing a meditation. It could even be as simple as writing what you give thanks for on a sticky note and posting it on your mirror or computer. To help you establish a daily routine, create a \xe2\x80\x98thankfulness\xe2\x80\x99 reminder on your phone or computer to pop up every morning and prompt you.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Who is interacting here? \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cyou.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The 'b'Harvard Mental Health Letter'b' begins its list of gratitude interventions with the advice that you should send a thank-you letter as often as once a month, but all the other suggested exercises can be undertaken without human contact: \xe2\x80\x9cthank someone mentally,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckeep a gratitude journal,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccount your blessings,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmeditate\xe2\x80\x9d and, for those who are so inclined, \xe2\x80\x9cpray.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to achieve the recommended levels of gratitude without spending a penny or uttering a word. All you have to do is to generate, within yourself, the good feelings associated with gratitude, and then bask in its warm, comforting glow. If there is any loving involved in this, it is self-love, and the current hoopla around gratitude is a celebration of onanism.'b'Yet there is a need for more gratitude, especially from those who have a roof over their heads and food on their table. Only it should be a more vigorous and inclusive sort of gratitude than what is being urged on us now. Who picked the lettuce in the fields, processed the standing rib roast, drove these products to the stores, stacked them on the supermarket shelves and, of course, prepared them and brought them to the table? Saying grace to an abstract God is an evasion; there are crowds, whole communities of actual people, many of them with aching backs and tenuous finances, who made the meal possible.'b'The real challenge of gratitude lies in figuring out how to express our debt to them, whether through generous tips or, say, by supporting their demands for decent pay and better working conditions. But now we\xe2\x80\x99re not talking about gratitude, we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about a far more muscular impulse \xe2\x80\x94 and this is, to use the old-fashioned term, \xe2\x80\x9csolidarity\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'\xe2\x80\x94 'b'which may involve getting up off the yoga mat.'b'IF you are black, you\xe2\x80\x99re far more likely to see your electricity cut, more likely to be sued over a debt, and more likely to land in jail because of a parking ticket.'b'It is not unreasonable to attribute these perils to discrimination. But there\xe2\x80\x99s no question that the main reason small financial problems can have such a disproportionate effect on black families is that, for largely historical reasons rooted in racism, they have far smaller financial reserves to fall back on than white families.'b'The most recent federal survey in 2013 put the difference in net worth between the typical white and black family at $131,000. That\xe2\x80\x99s a big number, but here\xe2\x80\x99s an even more troubling statistic: About one-quarter of African-American families 'b'had less than $5 in reserve'b'. Low-income whites had about $375.'b'Any setback, from a medical emergency to the unexpected loss of hours at work, can be devastating. It means that harsh punishments for the failure to pay small debts harm black families inordinately. Sometimes, the consequence is jail. Other times, electricity is cut, or wages garnished.'b'The modern roots of the racial wealth gap can be traced back to the post-World War II housing boom, when federal agencies blocked loans to black Americans, locking them out of the greatest wealth accumulation this country has ever experienced. More recently, the bursting of the housing bubble and subsequent recession slammed minorities. In 2013, the median wealth of white households was 'b'13 times'b' the median wealth of black households, the widest gap since 1989.'b'Earlier this year, my colleague Annie Waldman and I took a close look at debt-collection lawsuits in three major American cities. We expected to see a pattern driven by income, with collectors and credit card lenders suing people most often in lower-income areas.'b'But income was just half the story. Even accounting for income, the rate of court judgments from these lawsuits was 'b'twice as high in mostly black communities as it was in mostly white ones'b'. In some neighborhoods in Newark and St. Louis, we found more than one judgment for every four residents over a five-year period. Many were families who, knocked off their feet by medical bills or job loss or other problems, had simply been unable to recover.'b'When debts turn into court judgments, plaintiffs gain the power to collect by cleaning out bank accounts and seizing wages. Federal and state laws generally don\xe2\x80\x99t protect anyone but the poorest debtors, and because judgments are valid for a decade or more, the threat of garnishment can linger for years. The paycheck from that new job may suddenly be slashed and savings may disappear.'b'Sometimes the consequence of not having the money to pay a bill is immediate: The power goes out. In a 2009 national survey of lower-income households by the federal Energy Information Administration, 9 percent of blacks reported having their electricity disconnected in the previous year because they had been unable to pay. For whites, the number was less than 4 percent, according to an analysis of the survey by the National Consumer Law Center.'b'And sometimes the consequence of unmanageable debt is to fall further into debt. In a 2013 Federal Reserve survey, about three times as many blacks reported taking out a high-interest payday loan in the previous year as did whites at the same income level. Desperate consumers turn to these loans as a way to catch up on bills, but often get tripped up by unaffordable interest payments.'b'When combined with discriminatory policing practices, the effect of the asset gap is to magnify the racial disparity. In its report on the Ferguson, Mo., Police Department, the Justice Department found that officers disproportionately stopped and ticketed black citizens. For a \xe2\x80\x9cmanner of walking\xe2\x80\x9d violation, it was $302; for \xe2\x80\x9chigh grass and weeds,\xe2\x80\x9d $531.'b'Blacks accounted for about 67 percent of Ferguson\xe2\x80\x99s population and around 85 percent of the municipal court cases. But the numbers were even more lopsided when it came to the harshest consequences. Blacks accounted for 92 percent of the cases where an arrest warrant had been issued to compel payment.'b'And this wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a problem only in Ferguson. Earlier this year, the American Civil Liberties Union sued DeKalb County, Ga., which includes part of Atlanta, for jailing citizens over unpaid court fines and unpaid fees charged by a for-profit company that runs probation services for the government. About 55 percent of DeKalb County\xe2\x80\x99s population is black, but the A.C.L.U. found that nearly all probationers jailed for failure to pay those fines and fees were black.'b'The racial wealth gap \xe2\x80\x9ccreates this cyclical effect,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nusrat Choudhury, an A.C.L.U. attorney. An unpaid speeding ticket may result in a suspended driver\xe2\x80\x99s license, which may lead to a more severe violation. Unable to pay their fines, black defendants become more crushingly entangled in debt.'b'Cori Winfield, a single mother in St. Louis, got caught up in this cycle.'b'After she was unable to keep up the payments on a subprime auto loan she took out in 2009, the car was repossessed the next year, but the consequences didn\xe2\x80\x99t stop there. Because the debt continued to be bloated by interest charges, the lender began garnishing her wages in 2012. The garnishment continues today. Because she was unable to repay, she will end up paying far more than she owed in the first place.'b'Making matters worse for Ms. Winfield, while her wages were being garnished, she was arrested for driving with a license that had been suspended because she had failed to pay a speeding ticket. She ended up spending a weekend in jail and having to pay the cost of bail.'b'Ms. Winfield has a decent clerical job, earning about $30,000 a year. But she lives month to month. When hit with an unexpected expense, she is left reeling.'b'Her vulnerability is typical. In a recent 'b'survey by the Pew Charitable Trusts'b', the typical black household earning between $25,000 and $50,000 reported having emergency savings of $400. The typical white household in that range had $2,100.'b'Black families were much more likely to report difficulty in recovering from a financial setback or to have fallen behind on a bill in the past year. This financial insecurity extended up the income scale. Of black households with income between $50,000 and $85,000, 30 percent said they had been unable to pay a bill. By contrast, only white households with incomes below $25,000 reported similar trouble paying bills; 31 percent said they had fallen behind.'b'What can be done? The best place to start is by identifying practices that are particularly damaging to black communities, and then fixing them.'b'In Missouri, for example, the attorney general recently 'b'proposed a series of reforms'b' for debt-collection lawsuits to ensure that the underlying debt was valid and that lawyers\xe2\x80\x99 fees were not excessive. Collection-industry trade groups supported the proposal.'b'Lawmakers in Missouri and other states 'b'could go further'b' and reduce the amount of income subject to garnishment. In most states (New York and New Jersey are exceptions), defendants can lose a quarter of their post-tax income, a big hit for even middle-income families.'b'Bank accounts are afforded even less protection, allowing collectors to seize funds without limit. It\xe2\x80\x99s a nonsensical system that restricts how much of a worker\xe2\x80\x99s paycheck a collector can seize, but allows collectors to take the entire amount once that check is deposited. Setting even a small dollar amount as automatically off limits to collectors would be a substantial improvement.'b'Changes like that benefit everyone, but they particularly help black families. Policy makers should pay attention. Making it easier to recover from small setbacks can make a big difference in people\xe2\x80\x99s lives.'b'Since President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande of France declared a state of emergency after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Nov. 13, more than 2,700 'b'police raids'b' have been carried out. They have yielded very little that can be linked to terrorism, but have traumatized citizens and left havoc in their wake.'b'The majority of these raids have been on Muslim homes, businesses, mosques and prayer rooms. Ethnic profiling by the police of France\xe2\x80\x99s minorities \xe2\x80\x94 condemned as discriminatory by a Paris appeals court in June \xe2\x80\x94 has returned with a vengeance, and hate crimes against Muslims are on the rise. Yasser Louati, spokesman for the Collective Against Islamophobia in France, warns: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Muslim minority in France feels like it\xe2\x80\x99s being treated as the public enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The current state of emergency gives the French government exceptional powers, including the authority to conduct houses searches without a warrant, shut down associations and restrict the right to peaceful assembly \xe2\x80\x94 all without judicial oversight. Individuals may file complaints against the government in court, but only after the fact. Many say they have no idea why they were targeted.'b'Mr. Hollande argues that France is at war with a new kind of enemy \xe2\x80\x94 the Islamist terrorist ready to strike on French soil \xe2\x80\x94 and that the government must have a free hand to tackle the threat. No doubt he has a duty to keep France safe and prevent more attacks, but he already has ample tools at his disposal to do this, including vast new surveillance and other powers conferred by a series of antiterrorism laws passed since he was elected. Nothing in France\xe2\x80\x99s current law stopped Mr. Hollande from declaring the current state of emergency on Nov. 13, or successfully securing its extension through Feb. 26 from Parliament.'b'But Mr. Hollande wants to go further, and amend France\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution to make it easier for the government to declare a state of emergency, remove the possibility of legal challenges to government actions under a state of emergency, including warrantless searches and preventive detention, and make it possible to strip French-born dual nationals convicted of terrorism-related crimes of their French citizenship. (Naturalized dual-national citizens can already be stripped of their French citizenship.)'b'The majority of the more than three million French-born dual nationals hold their second citizenship in a Muslim majority country where one or both of their parents were born. In effect, the citizenship amendment is aimed at French-born Muslims. It has provoked a storm of controversy, as it did when former French President Nicolas Sarkozy proposed it in 2010. At that time, Mr. Hollande and other prominent French Socialists roundly condemned the proposal, arguing that doing so would effectively torpedo one of the cornerstones of France\xe2\x80\x99s democracy: the equality of all citizens before the law.'b'Last month, France\xe2\x80\x99s Council of Ministers accepted the proposed changes to France\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution. The amendments will be debated in Parliament in February.'b'The Parliament should reject these unnecessary and divisive constitutional changes. The push to diminish civil liberties and end judicial oversight will only magnify the potential for the abuse of power, without making the public safer.'b'When he campaigned for the presidency of Mexico, Enrique Pe\xc3\xb1a Nieto used the title of his book, 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMexico, the Great Hope,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'to explain the record he hoped to achieve and the nation he hoped to build. More than three years into his presidency, it seems more likely that he will be remembered not as the transformational leader Mexicans thought they had elected, but as a politician who skirted accountability at every turn.'b'On Mr. Pe\xc3\xb1a Nieto\xe2\x80\x99s watch, the Mexican government has swiftly and systematically whitewashed ugly truths and played down scandals.'b'After Mexican journalists revealed that a government contractor had made a lavish home available to Mr. Pe\xc3\xb1a Nieto and his wife, the president appointed a friend to investigate the matter. Not surprisingly, the 'b'inquiry found no evidence of wrongdoing'b' by the president. The journalists, despite meticulous, unimpeachable reporting, 'b'lost their jobs. 'b''b'When the country\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful drug kingpin, Joaqu\xc3\xadn Guzm\xc3\xa1n Loera, 'b'escaped from prison'b' in July, 'b'Mexicans were rightly skeptical about'b' the official account, not least because it was Mr. Guzm\xc3\xa1n\xe2\x80\x99s second escape. The government claimed that Mr. Guzm\xc3\xa1n had slipped out through a tunnel he and his accomplices dug unbeknown to prison officials, dismissing the possibility that he had help from the inside. While some officials were arrested as a result of the prison break, the government has yet to fully explain the lapse.'b'More troubling is the government\xe2\x80\x99s botched effort at investigating 'b'the September 2014 disappearance of 43 college students, 'b'who appear to have been massacred in the rural state of Guerrero. The government claimed the students were executed and incinerated by members of a drug gang. A preliminary report issued by a group of international experts from the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights in September, citing satellite images, said it was implausible that the bodies had been incinerated.'b'Adding to public skepticism, the government has turned down repeated requests to allow the international team to interview military personnel stationed near the site of the disappearance.'b'It is not too late for the government to acknowledge that its investigation was bungled and to give the international investigators unfettered access to government personnel. That may be too little to salvage Mr. Pe\xc3\xb1a Nieto\xe2\x80\x99s reputation. But it\xe2\x80\x99s the least he can do for the victims of one of Mexico\xe2\x80\x99s worst human rights atrocities in recent history.'b'Politics, we\xe2\x80\x99re often told, is governed by rules \xe2\x80\x94 basic principles that explain not just what\xe2\x80\x99s going to happen, but what rational candidates and parties can be expected to do. Donald J. Trump seems to casually defy all these rules \xe2\x80\x94 insulting Senator John McCain, a veteran; disparaging women; and building a rhetorical wall to keep out the single demographic group that his party seems to need for its survival, Latinos.'b'And yet with each transgression, his poll numbers bubble upward.'b'Mr. Trump is not the first to test the basic assumptions about how politics works and how we predict outcomes. He may be changing the rules of the presidential primary race, but in the halls of Congress and in governors\xe2\x80\x99 mansions across the country, politicians have already acted in ways that would have been unimaginable a decade ago. By testing and breaking the rules, they have been reshaping the practice of politics since long before Mr. Trump emerged.'b'Take this familiar rule: \xe2\x80\x9cAmericans hate Congress, but love their own member of Congress.\xe2\x80\x9d For decades, members of Congress secured re-election even in districts that voted for the other party\xe2\x80\x99s presidential candidate, through slavish attention to local concerns, ranging from casework (helping constituents navigate Social Security problems) to winning earmarked appropriations for local spending projects, with the ribbon-cuttings that followed. Transactional politics of this kind then helped smooth the wheels in Congress, as leaders handed out earmarks, or federal funding specifically designated for projects in the district, in exchange for cooperation.'b'Half that rule is true: Americans really do still hate Congress. Approval ratings for Congress stood most recently at 13 percent, near a record low. People still think more highly of their own senator or representative, but that\xe2\x80\x99s changing: In 'b'Gallup polls'b' since 2013, about 40 percent disapprove of their own member of Congress, much higher than in previous periods of generalized hostility to the institution. Near majorities now say that their own member is \xe2\x80\x9cout of touch\xe2\x80\x9d and pays more attention to \xe2\x80\x9cspecial interests\xe2\x80\x9d than his or her constituents.'b'Numbers like those would normally foreshadow political doom. But 96 percent of House incumbents won re-election in 2014, and the Republican majority \xe2\x80\x94 despite its own 71 percent 'b'disapproval rating'b' on Election Day \xe2\x80\x94 expanded.'b'With this norm, politicians can effectively ignore many of their constituents without putting re-election at risk, and many have rejected the standard practices of the recent past \xe2\x80\x94 most notably earmarks.'b'Beyond that, several members even announced in 2013 that they would 'b'not assist constituents'b' with problems involving the Affordable Care Act. The idea of not just neglecting but actively refusing constituent services, for reasons of ideology, would be unimaginable to the constituent-focused members of Congress of both parties elected beginning in the 1970s.'b'Governors, too, rejected everything from infrastructure spending to federal funding for Medicaid expansion. Even when they saw their approval ratings drop into the 30s, they survived. In 2011, Rick Scott of Florida 'b'rejected $2.4 billion in federal funds'b' for a commuter rail project and yet got re-elected.'b'Underlying the old rule was a bigger one: the \xe2\x80\x9cmedian voter theorem\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the idea that the views of the typical, middle-of-the-road voter, as expressed through elections, drove parties and politicians. These are the \xe2\x80\x9cReagan Democrats\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csoccer moms\xe2\x80\x9d of recent decades. The political scientists Jacob Hacker and Paul Pierson have called this the \xe2\x80\x9cmaster theory\xe2\x80\x9d of their discipline.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not much of a theory at all anymore. Well-organized interest groups like the National Rifle Association and the National Education Association as well as large donors and ideological warriors on both sides have more clout than the median voter because they are organized and focused while most people aren\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'And in many nonpresidential elections, the median voter probably isn\xe2\x80\x99t voting at all. That\xe2\x80\x99s particularly true for low-income people: Election participation 'b'by people in households just below the median income'b' of $52,000 was around 40 percent in 2014, compared with 52 percent for voters in households earning $150,000 or more.'b'Consider another once-useful guideline, which dates to the 1960s: Americans are \xe2\x80\x9cphilosophical conservatives but operational liberals.\xe2\x80\x9d That is, we hate the idea of government, but we value the benefits we get from government \xe2\x80\x94 and politicians act accordingly.'b'Until very recently, this rule explained much of the behavior of conservative Republicans in particular: They would propose abstract cuts, such as a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution or a cap on entitlement spending. Liberals would then recast the proposal in terms of specific cuts affecting children, veterans or seniors. After a little symbolic skirmish, each side would retreat to its corner, with few of the changes to the federal budget that had been promised.'b'This principle restrained even Ronald Reagan from more radical cuts, while making Democrats cautious \xe2\x80\x94 perhaps overcautious \xe2\x80\x94 about advocating large-scale spending programs (recall President Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s announcement in 1996 that \xe2\x80\x9cthe era of big government is over\xe2\x80\x9d).'b'Representative Paul Ryan tested the limits of operational liberalism with the budgets he put forward beginning in 2011, with a plan to privatize Medicare for \xe2\x80\x9c'b'future retirees'b'\xe2\x80\x9d and specific cuts to discretionary spending programs. And at least a half-dozen governors put operational liberalism to the test by cutting state spending on education and health in ways that directly affected services. The unpopular governor Sam Brownback of Kansas nonetheless won re-election in 2014, as did Paul LePage of Maine, despite abysmal approval ratings for both, and Wisconsin, North Carolina and Ohio seem to have locked in levels of public investment on education and human services that are far lower than in the recent past and will be difficult to undo.'b'The old deal having been broken, Democrats, in turn, seem more willing to champion broad expansions of government like proposals to expand Social Security or make college free. The ideological alignment of the two parties will soon override these legacies from an earlier era when there were more conservative Democrats and moderate, or even liberal, Republicans.'b'These rules aren\xe2\x80\x99t just convenient ways to analyze politics \xe2\x80\x94 they influence how politicians behave. If politicians believe they need to win favor with the median voter or bring pork home to the district, they will do so. All the old rules lead to the same happy idea: American politics calibrates and centers itself, and it usually pulls parties and most politicians back from the extremes.'b'But in recent years, Republican politicians especially have not only defied the rules, they have also protected themselves from the consequences. Restrictions on voting, along with 'b'aggressive redistricting'b', reduce the influence of the median voter. Campaign war chests (including \xe2\x80\x9csuper PACs\xe2\x80\x9d) scare off opponents, from within their own party as well as the other. By crippling civil-society institutions such as unions and community groups, which organize middle- and lower-income voters, they sometimes avoid being held accountable. They can use ideological media to reach mostly like-minded voters.'b'And by recasting politics as a winner-take-all conflict between wholly incompatible ideologies and identities \xe2\x80\x94 as most of the presidential candidates have done \xe2\x80\x94 they help to closely align party and ideology, so that those who identify as Republican will always vote Republican and vice versa. When politicians know more or less who will vote and how, they can ignore most voters \xe2\x80\x94 including their own loyalists.'b'Long before Mr. Trump came along, the supposedly immutable laws of politics had begun to fall. Mr. Trump is taking defiance in a nervy new direction. Now that congressional leaders, governors and Mr. Trump have shown the rules and customs of American politics to be hollow and unenforceable, we need a new set of tools to understand how democracy works, or doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'You have to be seriously geeky to get excited when the Internal Revenue Service releases a new batch of statistics. Well, I\xe2\x80\x99m a big geek; like quite a few other people who work on policy issues, I was eagerly awaiting the I.R.S.\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'tax tables'b' for 2013, which were released last week.'b'And what these tables show is that elections really do have consequences.'b'You might think that this is obvious. But on the left, in particular, there are some people who, disappointed by the limits of what President Obama has accomplished, minimize the differences between the parties. Whoever the next president is, they assert \xe2\x80\x94 or at least, whoever it is if it\xe2\x80\x99s not Bernie Sanders \xe2\x80\x94 things will remain pretty much the same, with the wealthy continuing to dominate the scene. Which brings me to those I.R.S. tables.'b'For one of the important consequences of the 2012 election was that Mr. Obama was able to go through with a significant rise in taxes on high incomes. Partly this was achieved by allowing the upper end of the Bush tax cuts to expire; there were also new taxes on high incomes passed along with the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare.'b'If Mitt Romney had won, we can be sure that Republicans would have found a way to prevent these tax hikes. And we can now see what happened because he didn\xe2\x80\x99t. According to the new tables, the average income tax rate for 99 percent of Americans barely changed from 2012 to 2013, but the tax rate for the top 1 percent rose by 'b'more than four'b' percentage points. The tax rise was even bigger for very high incomes: 6.5 percentage points for the top 0.01 percent.'b'These numbers aren\xe2\x80\x99t enough to give us a full picture of taxes at the top, which requires taking account of other taxes, especially taxes on corporate profits that indirectly affect the income of stockholders. But the available numbers are consistent with 'b'Congressional Budget Office projections'b' of the effects of the 2013 tax increases \xe2\x80\x94 projections which said that the effective federal tax rate on the 1 percent would rise roughly back to its pre-Reagan level. No, really: for top incomes, Mr. Obama has effectively rolled back not just the Bush tax cuts but Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s as well.'b'The point, of course, was not to punish the rich but to raise money for progressive priorities, and while the 2013 tax hike wasn\xe2\x80\x99t gigantic, it was significant. Those higher rates on the 1 percent correspond to about $70 billion a year in revenue. This happens to be in the same ballpark as both 'b'food stamps'b' and budget office estimates of this year\xe2\x80\x99s net 'b'outlays'b' on Obamacare. So we\xe2\x80\x99re not talking about something trivial.'b'Speaking of Obamacare, that\xe2\x80\x99s another thing Republicans would surely have killed if 2012 had gone the other way. Instead, the program went into effect at the beginning of 2014. And the effect on health care has been huge: according to estimates from the 'b'Centers for Disease Control and Prevention'b', the number of uninsured Americans fell 17 million between 2012 and the first half of 2015, with further declines most likely ahead.'b'So the 2012 election had major consequences. America would look very different today if it had gone the other way.'b'Now, to be fair, some 'b'widely predicted'b' consequences of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s re-election \xe2\x80\x94 predicted by his opponents \xe2\x80\x94 didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen. Gasoline prices didn\xe2\x80\x99t soar. Stocks didn\xe2\x80\x99t plunge. The economy didn\xe2\x80\x99t collapse \xe2\x80\x94 in fact, the U.S. economy has now added more than 'b'twice as many'b' private-sector jobs under Mr. Obama as it did over the same period of the George W. Bush administration, and the unemployment rate is a full point lower than the rate Mr. Romney promised to achieve by the end of 2016.'b'In other words, the 2012 election didn\xe2\x80\x99t just allow progressives to achieve some important goals. It also gave them an opportunity to show that achieving these goals is feasible. No, asking the rich to pay somewhat more in taxes while helping the less fortunate won\xe2\x80\x99t destroy the economy.'b'So now we\xe2\x80\x99re heading for another presidential election. And once again the stakes are high. Whoever the Republicans nominate will be committed to destroying Obamacare and slashing taxes on the wealthy \xe2\x80\x94 in fact, the current G.O.P. tax-cut plans make the Bush cuts look puny. Whoever the Democrats nominate will, first and foremost, be committed to defending the achievements of the past seven years.'b'The bottom line is that presidential elections matter, a lot, even if the people on the ballot aren\xe2\x80\x99t as fiery as you might like. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let anyone tell you otherwise.'b'DESPITE the four-year drought that has parched California and led to mandatory restrictions on water use, farmers there have kept feeding the country. California produces more of 66 different food crops than any other state, 'b'$54 billion 'b'of food annually.'b'Maintaining this level of productivity has been quite a challenge in recent years and is likely to become more difficult over the next few decades as weather patterns, available water and growing seasons shift further and threats of invasive weeds, pests and pathogens rise.'b'If agriculture is to have any chance of answering these challenges, we must have new and improved techniques and technologies. The problem is that agricultural innovation has not kept pace.'b'The last time our nation was in a similar crisis was just after the Dust Bowl years in the 1940s, but the country\xe2\x80\x99s agricultural science enterprise was in much better shape. At that point, 'b'almost 40 percent'b' of American research and development spending was focused on agriculture. This ambitious embrace of research was part of the \xe2\x80\x9cgreen revolution\xe2\x80\x9d that significantly boosted agricultural output around the world.'b'Today, farm production has stopped growing in the United States, and agriculture research is no longer a priority; it constitutes only 2 percent of federal research and development spending. And, according to the Department of Agriculture, total agricultural production has slowed significantly since the turn of the century. We need another ambitious surge in agricultural science.'b'Consider the avian flu epidemic, in which more than 48 million birds were killed \xe2\x80\x94 30 million in Iowa alone \xe2\x80\x94 because the only way to control an outbreak is to eradicate a farm\xe2\x80\x99s entire flock. The Agriculture Department recorded only 219 birds that were actually sick with the flu. The 'b'$3.3 billion in losses'b' have led to a search for a better method of controlling the virus than killing a farm\xe2\x80\x99s flock because of one sick bird.'b'History has shown that science can solve the nation\xe2\x80\x99s agriculture and food production problems, but to do so, the American system of food and agricultural research must be substantially reinvigorated. Research can tackle how to grow more food with fewer resources under increasingly difficult growing conditions. But this can be accomplished only if more of the brightest minds are engaged with enough funding to pursue transformative ideas.'b'While private sector research and development in agriculture have grown over the past decade and now exceed what is federally funded, this financing is focused on shorter term benefits. On the other hand, 'b'more than 80 percent'b' of federally funded research is designed to provide the building blocks for long-term production increases to address the many problems we face in the decades ahead. These problems have been amplified by climate change and the demands of a growing global population.'b'Experience has shown that the best way forward is funding research through a competitive process, with projects selected through a peer-review procedure that excludes politics. There is a program in the Agriculture Department that embraces these tenets, the Agriculture and Food Research Initiative, and its research grants show great promise.'b''b'New, hardier varieties of corn'b' are being developed from tropical species that can better withstand heat, drought and changes to the environment. The probiotics found in fermented products like yogurt are being tested to 'b'replace antibiotics'b' used in animal husbandry. And nanotechnology and electrified micro-coatings of water are being applied to some produce, to 'b'prevent food poisoning'b'. Government research is even exploring how to double the rate of photosynthesis and eliminate the need for pesticides.'b'The potential is great, but the program has never been fully funded. Despite a $25 million increase in the omnibus budget agreement, the budget of the department\xe2\x80\x99s research initiative sits at half of what Congress authorized in 2008 when it created the program. In the 2014 fiscal year, the program\xe2\x80\x99s peer-review process identified approximately $1.1 billion in grants as worthy of funding, but the program could dispense only $270 million. We cannot kindle the next green revolution if we treat roughly three-quarters of a billion dollars in worthwhile scientific ideas as if they were table scraps.'b'Throughout humanity\xe2\x80\x99s existence, farming and food production have always benefited from innovative solutions that solved challenges and looked beyond the horizon. Now more than ever, we need to embrace 21st-century science, fund it and turn it loose so we can develop better methods of putting food on the table. Our world is changing; the way we grow and produce food needs a much richer diet of scientific ingenuity to keep pace.'b'One day last month, Dannel Malloy, the governor of Connecticut, was sitting with a small group of inmates at a New Haven jail, where he had gone to announce a new job-training program for prisoners nearing their release date.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to develop a society that\xe2\x80\x99s a little more forgiving and you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to fly right,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Malloy 'b'said to the men'b', according to The New Haven Register. Taken together, these two ideas capture the essence of the reformist philosophy Mr. Malloy has brought to Connecticut\xe2\x80\x99s criminal justice system during his five years in office.'b'Under his leadership Connecticut has 'b'repealed the death penalty'b', 'b'legalized medical marijuana'b', and passed 'b'some of the strictest gun laws'b' in the country. And over the past 12 months, the state has become a remarkably productive laboratory for justice reform as Mr. Malloy continues to push for government transparency, societal mercy and individual responsibility.'b'Last February, Mr. Malloy 'b'announced'b' his \xe2\x80\x9cSecond Chance Society\xe2\x80\x9d initiative, which is aimed at reducing the number of people going into prison and making it easier for those already in to get out and have a chance at a law-abiding life.'b'The reform plan reclassified simple drug possession from a felony to a misdemeanor and eliminated mandatory minimum sentences for nonviolent drug possession. It expedited parole hearings for people convicted of nonviolent crimes and simplified the pardon process. The 'b' state Legislature approved'b' the package in June with bipartisan support. It also passed a bill Mr. Malloy had pushed to 'b'increase police accountability'b' by providing all troopers with body cameras, recruiting more minority officers, and assigning independent investigators to cases where the police use deadly force.'b'In November, Mr. Malloy announced a new set of reforms to the juvenile justice system. He 'b'proposed'b' that Connecticut become the first state in the country to raise the age of adult criminal responsibility to 21 from 18 for all but the most serious crimes. He pointed out that most people aged 18, 19 and 20, who would be sent to the juvenile system under the plan, are arrested on misdemeanor charges. He called for a separate facility to house inmates 25 and younger, citing new research on brain development.'b'He is also tackling the state\xe2\x80\x99s unfair bail system, which keeps people awaiting trial locked up simply for lack of a few hundred dollars. In those cases, Mr. Malloy said, releasing low-risk defendants to community supervision would be more just and more cost-effective.'b'The Legislature will consider these proposals in its 2016 session.'b'Crucially, Mr. Malloy \xe2\x80\x94 himself a former prosecutor and defense lawyer \xe2\x80\x94 has the support of key figures in law enforcement. His new correction commissioner, Scott Semple, is 'b'moving quickly'b' to convert former prisons into \xe2\x80\x9creintegration centers\xe2\x80\x9d that fight recidivism by providing drug counseling, job training and other services to inmates returning to society.'b'Will any of this work? It\xe2\x80\x99s still too early to know the effect of many of the recent reforms, but earlier efforts are already paying off. For example, after lawmakers raised the age of adult criminal responsibility to 18 from 16, the number of people between 18 and 21 behind bars dropped by more than half. Overall, crime in Connecticut is at a 48-year low, and falling faster than almost anywhere in the country. The state\xe2\x80\x99s prison population is under 15,600, down from nearly 20,000 in 2008, allowing for the closing of three prisons so far.'b'For decades, the politics of crime and punishment in America has been driven by fear and vengeance. That has begun to change, thanks largely to smart and effective new experiments in both conservative and liberal states.'b'Congress may yet pass major federal sentencing reform in 2016, but if America is to reverse its decades-long incarceration boom, it will require the continued efforts of leaders like Mr. Malloy.'b''b'Leonard Strickland\xe2\x80\x99s 'b' barbaric and unnecessary death at the hands of prison guards at the Clinton Correctional Facility in upstate New York highlights the need for independent oversight of the state\xe2\x80\x99s prisons. His beating in 2010, the details of which have only recently come to light, is the latest in a long list of instances of brutality toward inmates in New York\xe2\x80\x99s prison system.'b'The state\xe2\x80\x99s inhumane practices involving solitary confinement have also generated outrage. Thousands of prisoners have been held in extreme isolation, in some cases for years, and often for minor rule violations, at great cost to their mental health and potential for rehabilitation. A settlement announced last month of a lawsuit brought by the New York Civil Liberties Union will reduce both the number of inmates held in isolation and the maximum stay, and will abolish some of the harshest conditions.'b'While this is a welcome move, it provides for only two years of monitoring once it has been implemented and does not address the many issues that affect inmate health and safety for the overwhelming number not in solitary confinement.'b'This is why additional governmental oversight is urgently needed to truly change the culture of a system that holds 53,000 inmates across 54 prisons. What goes on inside these prisons is largely hidden from view, and there is little accountability for wrongdoing.'b'The New York State Commission of Correction has longstanding authority to regulate and visit prisons. The state comptroller pointed out in a 2006 audit that the commission had essentially defaulted on that responsibility. Nine years later, little has changed. The commission investigates some inmate deaths, but it cannot be fairly described as a monitoring body.'b'The result is that New York\xe2\x80\x99s prison system operates almost entirely below the radar. This invisibility should end by setting up a system of effective independent governmental oversight to ensure the health and safety of prisoners. If harm is to be prevented in these dark places, we must know what is happening inside.'b'Nationally, the situation is not better. For example, abuse of prison inmates appears to be endemic in Florida, prison rape is widespread across the country, and the hanging death in a Texas jail cell of Sandra Bland, who was arrested after a routine traffic stop, highlighted the national problem of suicide in custody. (Her family has disputed the finding by authorities that she killed herself.)'b'While we are witnessing a movement for increased police accountability, the need for transparency and accountability is even more urgent in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s jails and prisons, given their closed environments and lack of cellphones and body cameras to capture abusive encounters. These institutions primarily confine the most powerless and vulnerable, including poor people who are disproportionally African-American and Latino, as well as people with mental illness.'b'The New York State Assembly Standing Committee on Correction recently held a hearing about the need for such oversight. We were among the experts invited to testify about what an effective system of oversight might look like.'b'The American Bar Association has 'b' provided clear guidance'b' on this issue, which we helped to develop. It calls for every state to create an independent government monitoring body for its prisons and jails that reports to the public about conditions in those facilities.'b'The State Legislature should follow the A.B.A.\xe2\x80\x99s guidance and establish a monitoring body with unfettered access to prison facilities, staff, inmates and records in announced or unannounced visits.'b'The monitor should be empowered to examine and report on all aspects of a facility\xe2\x80\x99s operations that affect inmates, including, for example: medical and mental health care; use of force; inmate violence; conditions of confinement; staffing practices; inmate discipline and use of solitary confinement; substance abuse treatment; educational and rehabilitative programming; and re-entry planning.'b'There also should be an independent investigatory body that reviews complaints and allegations of wrongdoing, including inmate grievances, abuse claims, denial of access to health care and inmate deaths.'b'At the same time, the prison system should enhance its own internal accountability measures, such as its decision to electronically log complaints to monitor accusations of staff misconduct.'b'But in light of recent events, the public is unlikely to be satisfied with a prison agency\xe2\x80\x99s pronouncements that everything is fine or trust the vindications of staff members accused of abusive behavior. Only independent monitoring and investigations can provide that level of public accountability.'b'The costs of this oversight would pale in comparison to the hundreds of millions of dollars paid out in lawsuits stemming from unconstitutional practices and the untold costs associated with ineffective programs and unnecessary use of solitary confinement.'b'Designed correctly, an oversight body can provide an early warning system about patterns of complaints against certain prison employees, assess the appropriateness of discipline meted out to staff members, address concerns about inadequate health care or protocols for dealing with mentally ill inmates, highlight programs that are ineffective, point to areas for improved staff training, and identify policies that need to be adjusted. A monitor could also identify practices worth replicating at other prisons.'b'The awareness by prison staff that a monitor could show up at any time would check employee misbehavior. The culture of a prison changes when outsiders shine a light on its operations and conditions.'b'External oversight will likely result in safer prisons for inmates and employees alike, more effective rehabilitation programs, a healthier prison culture that supports positive outcomes and taxpayer savings from fewer lawsuits and lessened recidivism.'b'Without independent oversight, we will not have a prison system worthy of our values. If further tragedies are to be avoided, the New York Legislature and its counterparts around the nation must provide for comprehensive and meaningful oversight of all correctional facilities.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Dying Alone in Prison'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Dec. 28):'b'Dr. Rachael Bedard\xe2\x80\x99s essay about compassionate release of prisoners raises the fundamental question that the American citizenry has not answered: What is the purpose of incarceration?'b'It would seem from the case of her patient that it is clearly not rehabilitation or public safety, that it must be punishment. But should it be punishment above all, even if it erodes our decency, humanity and even the public good?'b'We should explore dramatically expanding compassionate release for all prisoners with significant medical conditions who do not pose a public safety risk, not just those at the very end of their lives.'b'JOSIAH D. We don\xe2\x80\x99t, however, need to respond to the shrinking manufacturing job market by becoming all-out technophobes.'b'A few examples of solutions currently underway: In 'b'Delaware'b', high school students can participate in a program aimed at preparing them for modern manufacturing jobs.
