(\xe2\x80\x9cTrust me, Mexico will pay.\xe2\x80\x9d) And he\xe2\x80\x99s going to reduce the trade deficit with China (\xe2\x80\x9cthe single greatest theft in the history of the world \xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d). At the editorial board meeting, Trump said he\xe2\x80\x99d use his stupendous deal-making powers to force the Chinese to raise the value of their currency.'b'And what if the Chinese don\xe2\x80\x99t comply? Trump said he\xe2\x80\x99d impose a tariff. How much of a tariff? Maybe 45 percent.'b'This seemed like a new number. A few years back, Trump called for a 25 percent tariff on Chinese goods, and early in the campaign he mentioned a 35 percent tax on Mexican-built cars. Do you think he\xe2\x80\x99s been rerunning the figures during campaign flights? Another possible answer would be that he just makes this stuff up as he goes along.'b'There is, Trump says, \xe2\x80\x9ca great anger out there. \xe2\x80\xa6 A lot of people say that my campaign has picked up on that, and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do that intentionally.\xe2\x80\x9d Perhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s true, in the sense that he never sat down and wrote out an Anger Plan. He just keeps repeating whatever seems to get a rise out of his listeners. He always was a great marketer.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not all that stunning that he\xe2\x80\x99s so far ahead in the national polls, given the quality of the Republican competition. But it\xe2\x80\x99s depressing that he\xe2\x80\x99s cornered the anger franchise when his targets exclude America\xe2\x80\x99s own wealthy and powerful.'b'Donald Trump isn\xe2\x80\x99t going to be the Republican nominee.'b'Six months ago, that was a truism. Three months ago, it was the conventional wisdom. Now it\xe2\x80\x99s an assertion that inspires sympathetic glances, the kind you get when you tell friends that you think your new personal-investment strategy is sure to beat the market.'b''b'I know you really 'b'want 'b'that to be true'b', the glances say, 'b'but you just might be kidding yourself.'b''b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see why people are starting to think this way. Trump has led the national polls since last summer, and not by a little. Apart from the Ben Carson bubble, nothing has dented his advantage: It\xe2\x80\x99s actually expanded over the last month, and nobody in the G.O.P. seems to have a coherent plan to cut into his support.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBased on polling data,\xe2\x80\x9d Sam Wang of the Princeton Election Consortium 'b'wrote this week'b', \xe2\x80\x9cDonald Trump is in as strong a position to get his party\xe2\x80\x99s nomination as Hillary Clinton in 2016, George W. Bush in 2000, or Al Gore in 2000.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTRUTH BOMB,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote 'b'Politico\xe2\x80\x99s Mike Allen'b', the insider\xe2\x80\x99s insider. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you think voters will suddenly get serious \xe2\x80\x94 and that Trump is a \xe2\x80\x98lampshade candidate\xe2\x80\x99 who\xe2\x80\x99ll eventually wear out his welcome \xe2\x80\x94 you\xe2\x80\x99re running out of time to be right.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Against this combination of stable poll numbers and sands running through the primary-season hourglass, what do Trump skeptics have to offer?'b'One answer comes from 'b'Ezra Klein of Vox'b', who quotes Joe Trippi, Howard Dean\xe2\x80\x99s campaign manager in 2004, explaining why his candidate\xe2\x80\x99s Trump-like lead evaporated so quickly once the actual voting started: \xe2\x80\x9cPeople get more pragmatic the closer they get to an actual vote.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Riffing on this point, Klein writes:'b'Now I agree with Klein that this sudden-decline scenario is very plausible. But as 'b'someone who recently confessed'b' to having dramatically underestimated Trump\xe2\x80\x99s political talents, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s worth trying to do a little better, and describe how Trump could fail to get the Republican nomination even if he 'b'doesn\xe2\x80\x99t'b' have a Dean-like plunge.'b'Suppose that his support is more robust than Dean\xe2\x80\x99s, suppose that the Trump constituency doesn\xe2\x80\x99t give a fig about pragmatism. How does Trump lose then?'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s how. Yes, Trump leads all the national polls, and he keeps busting through what look like ceilings. But (unlike Dean) he 'b'doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lead in Iowa'b', and his ceiling there looks very stable: He\xe2\x80\x99s been hovering around 25 percent since September, and he\xe2\x80\x99s never broken 30 percent.'b'He does lead in New Hampshire, but there, too, his poll numbers have been relatively flat since August, and he tops out around 30 percent. Likewise South Carolina, where his polling has hovered in the 30 percent to 35 percent range since he grabbed the spotlight last summer.'b'There is no credible scenario in which a consistent 30 percent of the vote will deliver the delegates required to be the Republican nominee. So for Trump to lose, he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t actually have to collapse; he just has to fail to expand his support. And in the states where candidates are actually campaigning, voters are paying the most attention, and the polling screens for likely voters are tightening, he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t expanded his support meaningfully since he first climbed into the lead.'b'Foolish pundit that I may be, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he will. Instead, I think that Ted Cruz will continue to consolidate evangelicals as Ben Carson fades, and someone (probably Marco Rubio) will eventually consolidate the moderate-conservative vote \xe2\x80\x94 which is currently splintered among five candidates in New Hampshire, but which if it 'b'were'b' consolidated would very easily beat Trump\xe2\x80\x99s total in that state.'b'At which point \xe2\x80\x94 again, assuming that Trump doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fade or collapse \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a three-way race, one in which the Donald could still win some states, could still pile up delegates, could even have a chance of pushing the race all the way to the convention \xe2\x80\x94 but would not, could not, emerge as the nominee.'b'Think about it this way: It now looks very likely that Cruz will beat Trump in Iowa, at which point Carson\xe2\x80\x99s campaign will be pretty much finished, and Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum will disappear \xe2\x80\x94 and with Cruz suddenly ascendant, he\xe2\x80\x99s likely to pick up their supporters, pushing him up to Trump-like levels in the national polls.'b'Once that happens, would you really bet on Trump to beat Cruz in many of the evangelical-heavy Southern states that vote in late February or early March? In Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s own state of Texas? That seems unlikely.'b'And Trump has 'b'more support in the South'b' than he does in the high plains or Mountain West. So to survive a Cruz ascendancy among evangelicals, he would need to dominate in states like New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Florida.'b'But if we treat New Hampshire as a plausible template for outcomes in those states, then Trump needs Rubio and Chris Christie and Jeb Bush to all stay in the race 'b'and'b' for all of them to keep winning exactly 15 percent of the vote; then and only then would his 30 percent be sufficient to prevail.'b'That seems less than unlikely, indeed nearly impossible. At best, two of those three men will be left as viable candidates after New Hampshire, and the Republican establishment (such as it is) will simply have to pick one to rally behind by the end of March. The complexion of the race will be different if Christie somehow shoulders past Rubio \xe2\x80\x94 but either one of them should be capable of stopping Trump from sweeping the blue and purple states he needs.'b'Which is not to say that in that scenario the establishment candidate will win. Trump is a genuinely disruptive force, and if his coalition holds together it could make genuinely unlikely outcomes \xe2\x80\x94 Cruz as the most right-wing nominee since Barry Goldwater, a battle on the convention floor \xe2\x80\x94 far more plausible than they would have been without him.'b'But disruption doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get you to 'b'the 1,236 delegates'b' required for the nomination. 'b'Loki does not rule in Asgard'b'. And Donald Trump isn\xe2\x80\x99t going to be the Republican nominee.'b'On Tuesday, in an emotionally charged speech, President Obama 'b'announced a series of relatively modest executive orders'b' to aid in preventing guns from getting into the wrong hands.'b'The proposal would expand background checks through a clarification of existing regulations, increase funding for mental health care, and promote the development of smart guns.'b'The speech itself accomplished more than the executive actions are likely to accomplish. Viewed in political terms, the president injected this issue more firmly into the national debate as only a president can. Because a sitting president, even an exiting one, is always in the next presidential race: Other candidates are either running, at least in part, against his legacy or to extend it.'b'But there is one point that I was aching to hear articulated that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t covered in the president\xe2\x80\x99s speech, and is rarely mentioned in discussions about gun regulations: How our response to gun regulations is not now, nor has ever been, wholly ideological but is also ethnocentric and class-based.'b'I firmly believe that part of the current intransigence is because those gun homicides disproportionately affect poor minorities. (Gun suicides disproportionately affect white people.) Indeed, the only time that national figures seem to get fully engaged is in the wake of mass shootings that involve white people, either as shooters or victims.'b'Indeed, you have to explore the history of gun regulations to fully appreciate its racial dimensions.'b'In 2011, Adam Winkler spoke about his book \xe2\x80\x9cGun Fight,\xe2\x80\x9d and the origins of gun control, saying, according to The Wall Street Journal:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a constant pressure among white racists to keep guns out of the hands of African-Americans, because they would rise up and revolt.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He continued:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe KKK began as a gun-control organization. Before the Civil War, blacks were never allowed to own guns. During the Civil War, blacks kept guns for the first time \xe2\x80\x94 either they served in the Union army and they were allowed to keep their guns, or they buy guns on the open market where for the first time there\xe2\x80\x99s hundreds of thousands of guns flooding the marketplace after the war ends. So they arm up because they know who they\xe2\x80\x99re dealing with in the South. White racists do things like pass laws to disarm them, but that\xe2\x80\x99s not really going to work. So they form these racist posses all over the South to go out at night in large groups to terrorize blacks and take those guns away. If blacks were disarmed, they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t fight back.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It was about white terror.'b'After Prohibition and the Depression gave rise to gangsters and outlaws who posed a threat to white America\xe2\x80\x99s sense of safety, the Firearms Act of 1934 was passed. As the gun law expert Robert Spitzer, of the State University of New York at Cortland, 'b'told NPR'b' in 2013, the law required machine gun owners to pay a hefty tax, be fingerprinted and be listed on a national registry; as a result, sales of machine guns plummeted.'b'Again, white terror, but this time from other white people.'b'America was again stirred to action on gun control when, in 1967, armed members of the Black Panthers entered a largely white place of power \xe2\x80\x94 the California State Legislature. As The Times\xe2\x80\x99s film critic 'b'A. O. Scott noted in his review'b' of Stanley Nelson\xe2\x80\x99s fascinating documentary \xe2\x80\x9cThe Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution\xe2\x80\x9d:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen a group of Panthers demonstrated at the Statehouse in Sacramento carrying loaded rifles and shotguns, the organization drew national news attention and (at least temporarily) rallied many political conservatives, including Gov. Ronald Reagan, to the cause of 'b'gun control'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Reagan said of the Panthers\xe2\x80\x99 action at the time:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think that loaded guns is the way to solve a problem that should be solved between people of good will. And anyone who would approve of this kind of demonstration must be out of their mind.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'(This episode stands in stark contrast to the armed white men now occupying the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon.)'b'In response to the Panthers, the California legislature passed and Reagan signed the Mulford Act, which banned the open carry of firearms in the state. The N.R.A. supported the measure. The bill\xe2\x80\x99s author, Don Mulford, 'b'said at the time'b', \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to protect society from nuts with guns.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Edward Wyckoff Williams even 'b'claimed in The Root'b' in 2013 that \xe2\x80\x9cthe NRA actually helped craft similar legislation in states across the country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The year after the Mulford Act, the federal Gun Control Act of 1968 was passed.'b'Once again, white terror.'b'In recent decades, as the N.R.A.\xe2\x80\x99s political power has grown, it has also taken on more of an absolutist position against any new regulations and politicians largely have bowed to the group\xe2\x80\x99s stance.'b'Two notable exceptions were the 1993 Brady Bill requiring background checks for gun purchase and the assault weapons ban of 1994 \xe2\x80\x94 which has since expired \xe2\x80\x94 both of which were signed by Bill Clinton.'b'But in addition to the N.R.A.\xe2\x80\x99s influence, the face of homicides is becoming increasingly black and poor \xe2\x80\x94 two groups we have traditionally marginalized and ignored.'b'As Richard V. Reeves and Sarah Holmes of the Brookings Institution 'b'pointed out last month'b', 77 percent of white gun deaths are suicides while 82 percent of black gun deaths are homicides.'b'But even then, it\xe2\x80\x99s not the whole of the black population at risk of these homicides.'b'As William J. Wilson, also of Brookings, 'b' wrote last month'b':'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSegregation by income amplifies segregation by race, leaving low-income blacks clustered in neighborhoods that feature disadvantages along several dimensions, including exposure to violent crime. As a result, the divide within the black community has widened sharply. In 1978, poor blacks aged twelve and over were only marginally more likely than affluent blacks to be violent crime victims \xe2\x80\x94 around forty-five and thirty-eight per 1000 individuals respectively. However, by 2008, poor blacks were far more likely to be violent crime victims \xe2\x80\x94 about seventy-five per 1000 \xe2\x80\x94 while affluent blacks were far 'b'less'b' likely to be victims of violent crime \xe2\x80\x94 about twenty-three per 1000, according to Hochschild and Weaver.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is now precious little political will to further inhibit the largely white gun-buying population \xe2\x80\x94 'b'according to the Pew Research Center'b', whites are twice as likely as blacks or Hispanics to have a gun in the home \xe2\x80\x94 in order to help reduce the scourge of homicides among poor black people, particularly when the shooters are often black themselves. These killings are simply attributed to racial culture rather than to the complicated interplay between poverty, crime and gun culture.'b'And, since the federal government wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do enough to deal with this problem, local municipalities have employed other methods to get guns \xe2\x80\x94 many of them illegal \xe2\x80\x94 out of the hands of criminals. But those efforts, such as New York City\xe2\x80\x99s morally indefensible racial dragnet program called stop-and-frisk, did as much damage as good in the black communities.'b'Lawmakers refused to act, and local politicians and police departments overreacted. Poor black people were caught in the middle.'b'That, alas, is less about a response to white terror, than a nonresponse to black pain.'b'It is a familiar claim by many Second Amendment defenders \xe2\x80\x94 and, during the Obama administration, an increasingly popular one \xe2\x80\x94 that unfettered gun rights are necessary to protect American citizens against the threat of a tyrannical government.'b'In addition to being 'b'a misreading of history'b', the claim is amusing hyperbole to those who have suffered under real-life tyrants. But 'b'this week\xe2\x80\x99s armed standoff'b' at a federal wildlife sanctuary in eastern Oregon is showing how far a small, determined band of antigovernment zealots with lots of big guns will go to make their potentially deadly point.'b'Styling themselves as a militia, the group hijacked a peaceful protest over five-year prison sentences a federal court had imposed on two local ranchers for setting fires on federal land. Led by a man named Ammon Bundy \xe2\x80\x94 whose father, Cliven, instigated his own armed confrontation with federal authorities over cattle ranching in Nevada in 2014 \xe2\x80\x94 this hyperweaponized posse rolled into town and seized administrative buildings at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge on Saturday. Mr. Bundy 'b'said'b' they are willing to stay for \xe2\x80\x9cas long as necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d and that \xe2\x80\x9cif force is used against us, we would defend ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The occupation is the latest outgrowth of a 'b'long-running movement'b' by some ranchers and farmers who believe the federal government controls far too much land in Oregon, Nevada and other Western states. Mr. Bundy and his gun-toting comrades argue that a century of federal policies has 'b'driven many ranchers into poverty'b' and destroyed the rural economy.'b'This is mostly nonsense. As part of its congressional mandate to balance commercial and environmental concerns, including conservation, the federal government imposes reasonable rules on how public land can be used for mining, logging and ranching. On the whole Washington has been a 'b'benevolent, even generous landlord'b'.'b'There may be a good argument that the two ranchers in this case, Dwight Hammond and his son, Steven, were 'b'punished unreasonably harshly'b' for their crimes. But the way to have this argument is through peaceful means, such as the original protesters were doing, or as the Hammonds themselves chose to do \xe2\x80\x94 by reporting to prison and asking President Obama for clemency. Every day, citizens around the country sue or otherwise challenge the government over alleged violations of the law or the Constitution, and they do it without a rifle in their hand.'b'A democracy cannot function any other way. It thrives on principled disagreement, but it withers in the face of a loaded gun.'b'Such dangerous behavior also puts law enforcement in an 'b'impossible position'b': respond with force and people may well die; walk away \xe2\x80\x94 as Bureau of Land Management officials 'b'did with Cliven Bundy'b' \xe2\x80\x94 and the extremists are only 'b'emboldened'b'. (On Monday, 'b'according to'b' The Guardian, federal authorities said they planned to shut off power to the buildings.)'b'Mr. Bundy and his band of militants have made few friends. Local law enforcement 'b'has told them'b' to leave immediately. Many residents, even those who agree that the federal government owns and mismanages too much land, have 'b'strongly rejected'b' Mr. Bundy\xe2\x80\x99s gun-happy tactics. The Hammonds\xe2\x80\x99 own lawyer 'b'disassociated his clients'b' from the group. And while years of overheated antigovernment statements from right-wing politicians and media figures have helped to fuel exactly this sort of outburst, it is encouraging that 'b'many on the right'b' have called for the militants to stand down. When Ted Cruz 'b'says'b' you\xe2\x80\x99ve gone too far, it\xe2\x80\x99s worth listening.'b'The simple message Mr. Bundy and his band must hear is this: If everyone with a gripe against the government responded by threatening federal officials with weapons, America would no longer be a nation governed by the rule of law. Their grievances, like everyone else\xe2\x80\x99s, can be addressed. But not before they put down the guns.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Better Standard for the Use of Deadly Force'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Olevia Boykin, Christopher Desir and Jed Rubenfeld (Op-Ed, Jan. 1):'b'What difference would \xe2\x80\x9ca better standard\xe2\x80\x9d make? It\xe2\x80\x99s not academic mumbo-jumbo; a better standard would save hundreds of American lives a year. About 1,000 lives are lost each year in the United States because of police use of deadly force, while in 'b'places such as England and Germany'b' fewer than 10 are. Why?'b'Training in the use of force is at the heart of police education. Police officers are taught not only that resort to deadly force must be necessary, as the article advocates, but also that it must be 'b'proportionate'b' \xe2\x80\x94 that is, the consequences for the person affected are not out of proportion to the danger averted. Shooting at a fleeing traffic offender, as happens in the United States, is rarely proportionate.'b'JAMES R. MAXEINER'b'Baltimore'b''b'The writer is associate director of the Center for International and Comparative Law, University of Baltimore School of Law.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'During my career in law enforcement I trained many new hires, made hundreds of arrests and was involved in one on-duty shooting. But most states already have a necessity requirement in their laws regarding police use of deadly force.'b'The Op-Ed essay cites federal court decisions as evidence of the reasonableness standard and the possible rise of a necessity standard. But those cases dealt with federal civil rights suits, not prosecutions under state law. When grand juries in Missouri and New York opted not to prosecute police officers, they were in fact already considering laws that required that the police use deadly force only when \xe2\x80\x9cnecessary.\xe2\x80\x9d Ohio has a similar standard in its common law.'b'A more relevant question is: Necessary to use deadly force 'b'for what'b'? Unfortunately, some states (including Missouri) still allow police officers to use deadly force to stop a fleeing nonviolent felon rather than only when the officer reasonably believes that the person imminently threatens serious physical harm. This is a relatively uncontroversial change, and one we hope that our state and other states will make soon.'b'CHAD FLANDERS'b'JOSEPH WELLING'b'St. Louis'b''b'The writers are, respectively, an associate professor and a student at Saint Louis University School of Law, and the authors of a forthcoming law review article, \xe2\x80\x9cPolice Use of Deadly Force: State Statutes 30 Years After Garner.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The New York Times takes aim at an entire work force that puts its lives on the line every day to keep New York State safe by implying that a culture of violence is being fostered by corrections officers (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Put Reforms Into Prison Guards\xe2\x80\x99 Contract'b',\xe2\x80\x9d editorial, Dec. 26).'b'Nowhere do you mention that when the final statistics for 2015 are in, that year is set to be the most violent year on record in terms of assaults on officers by inmates, according to the Department of Corrections and Community Supervision, nor do you mention that our understaffed and overcrowded facilities house the most dangerous inmate population in state history.'b'We will continue to educate the public about the exceptional job that thousands of our men and women do every day while most New Yorkers sleep safely in the comfort of their homes.'b'MICHAEL POWERS'b'President'b'New York State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Association'b'Albany'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Thank you for the painful, illuminating and very touching article \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Women Travel Migrant Trail Rife With Risk'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 3), about the terrible violence against Syrian women refugees and the suffering it has caused them. LOWENSTEIN'b'New York'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Finally, thank you very much for putting the most fair and logical \xe2\x80\x9cfix\xe2\x80\x9d for Social Security into print (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Social Security in an Election Year'b',\xe2\x80\x9d editorial, Jan. 3).'b'Raising the ceiling on wages subject to Social Security deductions is long overdue. The current ceiling is just $118,500. Raising it, say, to $250,000 or $300,000 a year would provide long-term solvency.'b'Why should a person earning $100,000 a year have 100 percent of his wages subject to Social Security deductions, while a person earning $300,000 has just 40 percent of his wages subject to the deduction? It makes no sense whatsoever, and applying the deduction to a higher wage ceiling would not be an onerous burden on the higher wage earner.'b'Rather than make people work until they are 70 or reduce Social Security benefits or privatize the system, raising the wage ceiling makes perfect sense.'b'JAY THOMAS WATSON'b'Sonoma, Calif.'b'HOUSTON \xe2\x80\x94 IN French, the word \xe2\x80\x9cd\xc3\xa9ch\xc3\xa9ance\xe2\x80\x9d has several meanings, all of them bleak. It can refer to the fall of a civilization, or the degradation of the social fabric. More formally, it means the forfeiture of a right or a possession \xe2\x80\x94 one\xe2\x80\x99s citizenship, for example. All three meanings, carrying echoes of the country\xe2\x80\x99s experience under Vichy, resonate in a political drama unfolding in France.'b'Two weeks ago, the Socialist prime minister, Manuel Valls, delivered a stunning blow to the French revolutionary ideal that citizenship is no less indivisible than the republic itself. He announced at a news conference that his government would introduce legislation this year to amend the Constitution to allow the government to strip French citizenship from individuals who are found guilty of acts of terrorism \xe2\x80\x94 but only if they are among the three million French citizens who hold dual nationality.'b'Mr. Valls has the support of the leading conservative parties, the Republicans and the xenophobic National Front, but his own party exploded.'b'Speaking for several dozen fellow deputies, Beno\xc3\xaet Hamon, a former government minister, described the measure as \xe2\x80\x9cinspired and supported by the National Front.\xe2\x80\x9d Among the Socialists\xe2\x80\x99 erstwhile allies on the left, the outrage was even greater. Jean-Luc M\xc3\xa9lenchon, leader of the Left Party, denounced the \xe2\x80\x9ccomplete moral d\xc3\xa9ch\xc3\xa9ance\xe2\x80\x9d of the government, while C\xc3\xa9cile Duflot of the Greens called upon \xe2\x80\x9call republican consciences to awaken and refuse to step onto this slippery slope.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The news took even many in the Socialist government by surprise. The day before Mr. Valls\xe2\x80\x99s announcement, the outspoken minister of justice, Christiane Taubira, dismissed the idea of such legislation as null and void. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will fizzle out on its own,\xe2\x80\x9d she assured reporters, a statement echoed by other members of President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s inner circle.'b'Skeptical reporters could be forgiven, because the original idea came from Mr. Hollande himself. When he convened both houses of the French Parliament at Versailles three days after the Paris terrorist attacks, he came with three goals: to reassure a shaken nation, reaffirm his personal authority and restrain the right\xe2\x80\x99s ascendancy. In a Gallic variation on the Patriot Act, Mr. Hollande announced not just the extension of the state of emergency and expansion of the state\xe2\x80\x99s ability to gather intelligence, but also the constitutional wrinkle concerning terrorists\xe2\x80\x99 holding dual nationality.'b'At the time, few Socialist politicians, still in shock over events, took that last goal seriously. Mr. Hollande and Mr. Valls had vehemently opposed the same proposal when the previous president, Nicolas Sarkozy, embraced it in 2010. But with the National Front\xe2\x80\x99s dramatic electoral gains in regional elections in December, things seemed to change: Successive polls revealing an overwhelming majority of French in favor of such a law most likely persuaded Mr. Hollande, whose approval ratings remain dismal, to carry out his original promise.'b'Yet for many Socialists, already embittered by his modest efforts to \xe2\x80\x9cliberalize\xe2\x80\x9d the moribund economy, Mr. Hollande was committing both a moral crime and a political blunder. His proposal would in effect create two classes of citizens, the lesser of which would enjoy the rights and duties of citizenship, but with the proviso that they could be legally withdrawn by the state. Hence the explosion of anger when Mr. Valls worried that his Socialist critics had allowed \xe2\x80\x9cgrand values\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9clead them astray.\xe2\x80\x9d Christian Paul spoke for a growing number of Socialist deputies when he replied: \xe2\x80\x9cThose who forget their values lose their honor.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Something else has also been forgotten, however. While the question of citizenship is no small matter for any nation, it has a particularly compelling role in French history and identity. The French Revolution invented the modern conception of national citizenship and formalized the ideal of civil equality. Thanks to its revolutionary heritage, France juggles a unique combination of \xe2\x80\x9cjus sanguinis\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 where children inherit their parents\xe2\x80\x99 nationality \xe2\x80\x94 and \xe2\x80\x9cjus soli,\xe2\x80\x9d where the soil one is born on, and not the parents one is born to, determines one\xe2\x80\x99s nationality. (Children born on French soil to foreigners become citizens at age 18, if they don\xe2\x80\x99t have a criminal record and have resided continuously in the country for five years.)'b'This makes perfect sense for a country like France: not only is it a nation of immigrants, but it is also a nation supremely confident in its powers of assimilation. Until now, that is.'b'Mr. Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s decision to hold fast to his presidential word is in fact a confession of weakness, an avowal that France has failed in its republican mission. It also undermines the status of three million Frenchmen and women by adding an asterisk to their status. This step, for some critics, is not unlike stamping the word \xe2\x80\x9cJuif\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cJuive\xe2\x80\x9d on the papers of French Jews under the collaborationist regime of Vichy, not to mention its stripping of citizenship in 1940 from naturalized French Jews.'b'These historical associations will be made in the debates between now and early February, when the government presents its bill to Parliament. Already, the political parties have begun circling around one another. Tasting blood, a vice president of the National Front, Florian Philippot, has demanded that the forfeiture of citizenship be applied to other, unspecified \xe2\x80\x9cgrave crimes,\xe2\x80\x9d not just terrorism. Tacking left, a few Socialists have suggested that this punishment be extended to 'b'all'b' French citizens convicted of terrorism. (This law, however, would collide with a 1961 international convention, signed but never ratified by France, that prohibits the annulment of citizenship if it renders the interested party stateless.)'b'As the debate sharpens over the next few weeks, more than one lawmaker will wonder what the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s founder would make of it. After all, 75 years ago last month Charles de Gaulle, who had left France for England to continue the war against Nazi Germany, was shorn of his French citizenship by Vichy.'b'Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago built his career on the claim that he is at his best in times of crisis. But it will take more than political showmanship to calm the discontent that has roiled the city since November, when a Police Department video showed a white officer executing a black teenager named Laquan McDonald and exposed a cover-up by officers who had been at the scene. Chicagoans were still protesting the McDonald case on Christmas weekend when police officers responding to a domestic dispute killed two more African-Americans, one of whom was a bystander and a mother of five.'b'Public anger was focused on the Police Department. That changed on Monday, when a federal judge ruled that a veteran lawyer for the city had deliberately concealed important evidence in yet another trial about yet another fatal police shooting. The judge, Edmond Chang of United States District Court, also found that the lawyer had lied about his reasons for holding back the information in the wrongful death lawsuit. The case has raised suspicions that the city\xe2\x80\x99s Law Department itself has been soft-pedaling police misconduct cases.'b'The case focused on a 2011 traffic stop during which two officers fired their weapons, killing a black man, Darius Pinex. Mr. Pinex would be alive today had the officers simply checked his license plate number with the dispatcher, who could have told them they had the wrong car. One officer testified at trial that they approached the car with guns drawn because the dispatcher had warned that someone in the car might have a weapon.'b'That was disproved by a recording of the dispatch \xe2\x80\x94 which mentioned no weapon. But a senior Chicago corporation counsel withheld the recording until late in the trial, when it was too late for the Pinex family to make effective use of it. The jury subsequently ruled the shooting justified.'b'The federal judge overturned the verdict and wrote of the city\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer, Jordan Marsh: \xe2\x80\x9cAfter hiding the information, despite there being numerous times when the circumstances dictated he say something about it, Marsh said nothing, and even made misleading statements to the court when the issue arose.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He ordered the city and the lawyer to pay attorneys\xe2\x80\x99 fees for the Pinex family, which could easily amount to several hundred thousand dollars. As 'b'The Chicago Tribune'b' reported this week, this was the second case in less than a year for which Judge Chang ordered a new trial and penalized city lawyers for withholding evidence in a police misconduct case.'b'The judge\xe2\x80\x99s actions, which come in the wake of the McDonald shooting and 'b'damning revelations'b' about the laxness of the police disciplinary system, deepen the impression that city government has been working at several levels to shield officers from accountability. That may require replacing the deeply flawed system of police oversight with something stronger and more transparent. Mr. Emanuel will need to convince Chicagoans that he understands their anger over this issue and that 'b'his promise'b' of \xe2\x80\x9ca historic set of reforms\xe2\x80\x9d becomes a reality.'b'President Obama once 'b'said'b' this about his administration\xe2\x80\x99s deportation priorities: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll keep focusing enforcement resources on actual threats to our security. That means felons, not families. That means criminals, not children. It means gang members, not moms who are trying to put food on the table for their kids.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Encouraging words, a year ago. But a new year has dawned upon an appalling 'b'campaign of home raids'b' by the Department of Homeland Security to find and deport hundreds of would-be refugees back to Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. The targets are those who arrived in a recent surge of people fleeing shockingly high levels of gang and drug violence, hunger and poverty and who offered themselves at the border to the mercy of the United States, but ultimately lost their cases in immigration court.'b'Since New Year\xe2\x80\x99s, the administration has been sending agents into homes to make an example of the offenders and to defend the principle of a secure border. A president who spoke so movingly about the violent gun deaths of children here has taken on the job of sending mothers and children on one-way trips to the deadliest countries in our hemisphere. Mothers and children who pose no threat, actual or imaginable, to our security.'b'The Homeland Security secretary, Jeh Johnson, 'b'said in a statement'b': \xe2\x80\x9cOur borders are not open to illegal migration. If you come here illegally, we will send you back consistent with our laws and values.\xe2\x80\x9d He added: \xe2\x80\x9cThis should come as no surprise. I have said publicly for months that individuals who constitute enforcement priorities, including families and unaccompanied children, will be removed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no wonder that Donald Trump is applauding the policy, and taking credit for it.'b'But Mr. Johnson is wrong to suggest that frightened Central Americans are a border-security threat. It\xe2\x80\x99s not illegal to go to the border and seek asylum, as these families have. And his defense of our \xe2\x80\x9cvalues\xe2\x80\x9d jarringly sidesteps vital questions \xe2\x80\x94 Why are people fleeing? And if they are desperate to escape their murderous homelands, what is the best response of the United States?'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s certainly not home raids that send powerless individuals unjustly back to mortal danger and, as collateral damage, 'b'spread fear and panic'b' in immigrant neighborhoods across the country. The homicidal brutality in Central America has spawned a humanitarian disaster, but the administration has been treating it as a Texas border-security emergency, and a political headache. Perhaps this is why its efforts at deterring the migrant flow have not succeeded. Families have taken the journey anyway, not because they are determined to flout our immigration laws \xe2\x80\x94 but because they want not to be murdered.'b'The administration needs to recognize that this problem cannot be solved in backward fashion. The answer lies not in sitting idly until refugees arrive and greeting them with family prisons and prosecution. It requires addressing the root causes of the bloody violence in the region, and fixing the chaotic, underfunded legal system at the border, where migrants with no money or lawyers \xe2\x80\x94 or with bad lawyers \xe2\x80\x94 confront the infernal complexities of immigration and asylum law, and lose. The administration should have long ago begun building routes of escape for families in danger, with safe havens and in-country screening for those seeking resettlement, in the United States or elsewhere in the region.'b'While federal agents have been knocking on doors and spreading fear, advocacy groups have been scrambling to help the Central Americans. Humanitarian projects like 'b'CARA, 'b'a cooperative effort of legal services organizations, and 'b'Raices'b', which has worked for years with refugees in Central and South Texas, have placed urgent calls for funds and volunteers. Protection, due process and outstretched arms for terrorized families: That\xe2\x80\x99s an approach consistent with America\xe2\x80\x99s laws and values, not agents at the door, on the hunt for mothers and children.'b'DURING nuclear negotiations in 2005, a North Korean diplomat let slip an unexpectedly candid comment, offering valuable insight into his government\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear policy: \xe2\x80\x9cThe reason you attacked Afghanistan is because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have nukes. And look at what happened to Libya. That is why we will never give up ours.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'North Korea'b' conducted its fourth nuclear test on Wednesday, claiming that it had detonated a hydrogen bomb. The United States government disputes that, but one thing is clear: North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s leaders still believe that 'b'nuclear weapons'b' will prevent others from attacking them no matter what they do. This is fanciful. What the world needs is reality. North Korea must recognize the limitations and risks of its nuclear program, and the United States must recognize that an American response is necessary.'b'Many serious dangers come with being a nuclear power, and the North Koreans seem to recognize few of them. One is the temptation to transfer weapons, fissile material or technology to other states or terrorist groups. North Korea has a history of selling its traditional weapons systems. But the government must recognize that selling its nuclear technology could compel the United States to respond in ways that would bring an end to nearly 70 years of Communist rule.'b'There are other ways that the nuclear program makes the government less secure. Over the past several years, North Korea has degraded its conventional military capacity in order to pursue nuclear weapons. Under normal circumstances, a weaker North Korean Army would be welcome news to the rest of the world, but with a budding nuclear state it can lead to rapid escalation in the event of a conflict. This could mean either pre-emptive action by the United States, or, if North Korea ever used nuclear weapons, a massive retaliation.'b'The North also mistakenly believes that its nascent nuclear abilities will deter the United States and South Korea from responding if North Korean forces carry out low-level military actions intended to extort food, fuel or other benefits. It is wrong. South Korea and the United States are unlikely to remain passive in response to future violence like the 'b'2010 sinking'b' of a South Korean naval ship.'b'The Obama administration cannot punt to the next administration the problem of North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s growing stockpiles of fissile material, sophisticated weapons designs and long-range delivery ability.'b'No one should take comfort in skepticism about whether Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s test was a success. If North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s burgeoning nuclear weapons stockpile leads it to miscalculate American resolve, there will be horrible consequences. And at that point the whole world will wonder why no nation \xe2\x80\x94 especially the United States \xe2\x80\x94 stopped North Korea before it was too late.'b'A new approach to persuading the North to abandon its nuclear program must focus on asymmetric pressure points. A look at recent history helps to outline such a strategy. In our experience working on North Korea policy, the government in Pyongyang has seemed truly caught off guard only twice: in September 2005 when the Treasury Department\xe2\x80\x99s sanctions led to a freezing of its bank accounts in Macau; and in February 2014 when a 'b'United Nations'b' commission 'b'called for'b' the Security Council to refer the North\xe2\x80\x99s leadership to the International Criminal Court for a long list of crimes against humanity.'b'The United States and the United Nations should immediately increase sanctions. A new Security Council resolution will most likely emerge soon, providing one opportunity for this. Another comes in the form of the presidential executive order created after the cyber attack on Sony Pictures last year. These should include targeted financial sanctions; travel bans and indictments against officials working on the nuclear program, human rights abusers and cyber criminals; as well as secondary sanctions on anyone doing business with North Korean companies.'b'But sanctions are only one part of the strategy. Many observers believe, credibly, that slave labor bankrolls the nuclear weapons program. The United Nations must also continue to hold individuals in the government directly accountable for crimes against humanity, and all countries, including 'b'China'b' and Russia, should be pressured to stop accepting North Korean laborers.'b'Even if China\xe2\x80\x99s government has made clear that it is unhappy with North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s behavior, Beijing won\xe2\x80\x99t abandon its ally anytime soon. But the United States can \xe2\x80\x94 and should \xe2\x80\x94 push for Beijing to dial back its support. China could instruct Chinese companies to curtail business with North Korea, and the government could reject any calls from North Korea for new economic projects until the government returned to negotiations. China could also agree to not obstruct any Security Council discussions on human rights abuses in the North. Washington must frame cooperation on North Korea as a cornerstone of United States-China relations.'b'North Korea thinks that nuclear weapons make it more secure. That\xe2\x80\x99s wrong. North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s only path away from isolation and insecurity will require negotiation on all issues, including security, human rights and economics. In order to help it understand this, the United States must use the nuclear test Wednesday to force the North back to the table.'b'Most of the ranchers I know are decent folks, men and women of a few well-chosen words, slow to rouse, distrustful of a show horse on four legs or two. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s the armed gang who seized an Oregon bird sanctuary \xe2\x80\x94 Y\xe2\x80\x99all Qaeda, as the twittersphere has dubbed them.'b'The leader, Ammon Bundy, is the son of Cliven Bundy, the deadbeat rancher and Fox News hero who still owes more than $1 million in unpaid grazing fees. The elder Bundy says he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t recognize the government. The younger Bundy recognized it enough to get a federal loan guarantee for his fleet repair business in the rugged sprawl of Phoenix.'b'Ammon Bundy says God drove him to break into the offices of an agency that works on behalf of pileated woodpeckers, yellow warblers and other avian wonders. Bundy\xe2\x80\x99s not leaving, he says, until land that we own \xe2\x80\x94 that is, every American citizen \xe2\x80\x94 is taken from us and given to some unnamed private entity.'b'Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s comical \xe2\x80\x94 white privilege mixed with a \xe2\x80\x9cHee Haw\xe2\x80\x9d parody. The only thing Bundy and his fellow burglars have accomplished thus far is to leave behind enough evidence for prosecutors to file numerous criminal charges against them.'b'But this Gang That Can\xe2\x80\x99t Protest Straight is not far removed from a better-dressed crowd in Congress pushing for radical change in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s public land endowment. The locked-and-loaded crazies in the Oregon high desert are using the same language as Republican legislators who want to take away an American birthright.'b'On Wednesday, leading Republicans in Washington expressed sympathy for the ideas behind the criminal takeover. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a frustration that they feel the federal government is not listening to them anymore,\xe2\x80\x9d said Representative Ra\xc3\xbal Labrador of Idaho, a Tea Party favorite.'b'The goal of Labrador and other far-right politicians from the West is similar to the demands of the Bundy gang. Earlier this year a group led by Representative Rob Bishop, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, announced plans to \xe2\x80\x9cdevelop a legislative framework for transferring public land to local ownership and control.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Bishop said he wanted to find a way \xe2\x80\x9cto return these lands back to their rightful owners.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s the identical language used by the militants. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have research teams finding out who this land was taken from and who it needs to be sent back to,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the occupiers, Jon Rizheimer.'b'Um, the Indians? Well, yes, Paiutes had been living on the well-watered desert sanctuary for at least 6,000 years, until whites kicked them off. This week the Paiutes told the Bundy gang to go away, and said they looked to the federal government as protectors of their cultural artifacts.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt just rubs me in the wrong way that we have a bunch of misinformed people in here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charlotte Rodrique, the tribal chairwoman. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not the original owners.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s beyond the historical literacy of the anti-public-lands crowd to understand that. But they do understand the greater stakes. \xe2\x80\x9cThe idea is power,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ryan Payne, another one of the occupiers in Oregon. \xe2\x80\x9cLand is power.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s talk about that power. The media shorthand for this staged event is an outdated stereotype of a Sagebrush Rebellion. In truth, an overwhelming majority of Westerners enjoy their public lands for all the things that the federal government protects for them \xe2\x80\x94 recreation, wildlife, history, open space, clean water.'b'The 47 million bird watchers in this country spend $40 billion a year to follow creatures whose lives are dependent on federal wildlife refuges. Imagine if a bunch of birders, lathered in sunscreen, their heads covered in floppy hats, took over a federal facility to protest the innumerable predations of wildlife habitat by cattle ranchers.'b'Birders generate 660,000 jobs, through trips and retail sales, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service. By contrast, grazing allotments on federal public land number a bit more than 20,000. For those ranchers, the deal is a steal \xe2\x80\x94 about 90 percent cheaper than the market rate on private land in 16 Western states. We subsidize the ranchers, while a majority of our public land users generate hundreds of thousands of jobs, and never threaten to kill a forest ranger.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why only a handful of ranchers \xe2\x80\x94 Cliven Bundy being the best-known culprit \xe2\x80\x94 refuse to pay what most others do. But why, then, the push to privatize our great open spaces? It goes back to power.'b'Teddy Roosevelt framed the struggle in terms of the people against the exploiters. It was Roosevelt who created the wildlife refuge in Oregon, angering white squatters. The Supreme Court twice upheld the right of the government to protect the high desert.'b'The extremists, in Congress and the snows of Oregon, want to return to a 19'b''b'th century world where blunt force \xe2\x80\x94 against Indians, wildlife, the public good \xe2\x80\x94 prevails. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fantasy, costumed in western wear, except that the guns are real.'b'Last month Fox News 'b'released a poll'b' showing Hillary Clinton leading Bernie Sanders in Iowa by 14 points. But the amazing part of the poll was the generation gap. Among likely caucusgoers under 45, Sanders was crushing Clinton 56 to 34 percent. Among the older voters, Clinton was leading 59 to 24.'b'When you look at numbers like that you get the impression that this millennial generation, having endured the financial crash and stagnant wages, is ready to lead a big leftward push.'b'Indeed, a 'b'Harvard Institute of Politics poll'b' of Americans 18 to 29 found that 56 percent want a Democrat to win the White House while only 36 percent favor a Republican. The leftward shift is striking even within the G.O.P. According to the Pew Research Center, young Republicans are much more moderate than older Republicans. Among millennials who lean Republican, only 31 percent have consistently conservative views. About 51 percent have a mixture of liberal and conservative views.'b'But philosophically millennials are harder to pin down. According to the Harvard Public Opinion Project, 37 percent of 18- to 29-year-olds identify as liberal and 35 percent identify as conservative.'b'If you look at how millennials actually live, you certainly don\xe2\x80\x99t see a progressive counterculture. In fact, you see what you\xe2\x80\x99d expect from a generation that lived through a financial crisis, family instability and political dysfunction. You see an abstract celebration of creative transformation but a concrete hunger for order, security and stability.'b'According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 'b'millennials change jobs less'b' frequently than people in other generations. And a study of 25,000 millennials in 22 countries by Jennifer J. Deal and Alec Levenson found that at least 40 percent expect to stay with their current employer for at least nine years. Forty-four percent said they would be happy to spend the rest of their career at their current organization.'b'Millennials travel and move less than earlier generations. They are less likely to have cars, and their relative lack of driving time is not compensated for by the use of other modes of transportation.'b'Another glaring feature of millennial culture is they have been forced to be self-reliant and to take a loosely networked individualism as the normal order of the universe. Millennials have extremely 'b'low social trust'b'. According to Pew Research, just 19 percent say most people can be trusted, compared with 40 percent of boomers.'b'This leads to detachment from large entities. Just 32 percent of millennials 'b'say America is the greatest country'b' on earth, compared with 50 percent of boomers. Millennials are very suspicious of organized religion. Thirty-five percent say they are 'b'unaffiliated with any religious group'b', compared with 23 percent of Generation X (born between 1965 and 1980).'b'Just 26 percent of millennials 'b'are married'b', compared with 48 percent of boomers at that age. Only 42 percent plan to have kids. They are also having less sex. A study in the Archives of Sexual Behavior projected that millennials would have eight 'b'sexual partners by middle age'b' while boomers had 10 or 11. According to a survey from the online dating service Match, 49 percent of people in their 20s have not had sex in the past year.'b'The general impression one gets is of a generation that is stressed, energetic, creative, skeptical and in the middle of redefining, and thinning out, the nature of affiliation. Its members have been thrust into a harsher world where it is necessary to be guarded, and sensitive to risk. They want systemic change but there is no compelling form of collective action available. Their only alternative, which is their genius, is to try to fix their lives themselves, through technology and new forms of social interaction, rather than mass movements.'b'Their attitudes toward Social Security perfectly reflect this stance. Most millennials expect to see no Social Security benefits by the time they retire. But they oppose reforms to take money away from older workers to distribute it downward. They just figure they\xe2\x80\x99ll take care of retirement individually, often using 'b'algorithm-based investment vehicles'b' like Wealthfront.'b'Politically, this means that millennials may lean Democratic, but unless Barack Obama (or Bernie Sanders) is on the ticket, they don\xe2\x80\x99t strongly attach to the party and it is not clear that they will vote. They didn\xe2\x80\x99t in the 2014 midterm elections. It could be they are more interested in improving their lives by having richer experiences, and not through the sort of income transfers that come out of Washington.'b'My own guess is that millennials will be a muted political force, at least in 2016. But there will be some giant cultural explosion down the road. You just can\xe2\x80\x99t be as detached from solid supporting structures as millennials now are and lead a happy middle-aged life. Something is going to change.'b'So, will China\xe2\x80\x99s problems cause a global crisis? The good news is that the numbers, as I read them, don\xe2\x80\x99t seem big enough. The bad news is that I could be wrong, because global contagion often seems to end up being worse than hard numbers say it should. And the worse news is that if China does deliver a bad shock to the rest of the world, we are remarkably unready to deal with the consequences.'b'For those just starting to pay attention: It has been obvious for a while that China\xe2\x80\x99s economy is in big trouble. How big is hard to say, because nobody believes official Chinese statistics.'b'The basic problem is that China\xe2\x80\x99s economic model, which involves very high saving and very low consumption, was only sustainable as long as the country could grow extremely fast, justifying high investment. This in turn was possible when China had vast reserves of underemployed rural labor. But that\xe2\x80\x99s no longer true, and China now faces the tricky task of transitioning to much lower growth without stumbling into recession.'b'A reasonable strategy would have been to buy time with credit expansion and infrastructure spending while reforming the economy in ways that put more purchasing power into families\xe2\x80\x99 hands. Unfortunately, China pursued only the first half of that strategy, buying time and then squandering it. The result has been rapidly rising debt, much of it owed to poorly regulated \xe2\x80\x9cshadow banks,\xe2\x80\x9d and a threat of financial meltdown.'b'So the Chinese situation looks fairly grim \xe2\x80\x94 and new numbers have reinforced fears of a hard landing, leading not just to a 'b'plunge in Chinese stocks'b' but to sharp declines in stock prices worldwide.'b'O.K., so far so bad. And some smart people think that the global implications are really scary; George Soros is 'b'comparing it to 2008'b'.'b'As I suggested above, however, I have a hard time making the numbers for that kind of catastrophe work. Yes, China is a big economy, accounting in particular for about a 'b'quarter of world manufacturing'b', so what happens there has implications for all of us. And China buys more than $2 trillion worth of goods and services from the rest of the world each year. But it\xe2\x80\x99s a big world, with a 'b'total gross domestic product 'b' 'b'excluding China'b' of more than $60 trillion. Even a drastic fall in Chinese imports would be only a modest hit to world spending.'b'What about financial linkages? One reason America\xe2\x80\x99s subprime crisis turned global in 2008 was that foreigners in general, and European banks in particular, turned out to be badly exposed to losses on U.S. securities. But China has capital controls \xe2\x80\x94 that is, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t very open to foreign investors \xe2\x80\x94 so there\xe2\x80\x99s very little direct spillover from plunging stocks or even domestic debt defaults.'b'All of this says that while China itself is in big trouble, the consequences for the rest of us should be manageable. But I have to admit that I\xe2\x80\x99m not as relaxed about this as the above analysis says I should be. If you like, I lack the courage of my complacency. Why?'b'Part of the answer is that business cycles across nations often seem to be more synchronized than they \xe2\x80\x9cshould\xe2\x80\x9d be. For example, Europe and the United States export to each other only a small fraction of what they produce, yet they often have recessions and recoveries at the same time. Financial linkages may be part of the story, but one also suspects that there is psychological contagion: Good or bad news in one major economy affects animal spirits in others.'b'So I worry that China may export its woes in ways back-of-the-envelope calculations miss, that the Middle Kingdom\xe2\x80\x99s troubles will one way or another have the effect of depressing investment spending in America and Europe as well as in other emerging markets. And if my worries come true, we are woefully unready to deal with the shock.'b'After all, who would respond to a China shock, and how? Monetary policy would probably be of little help. With interest rates still close to zero and inflation still below target, 'b'the Fed'b' would have limited ability to fight an economic downdraft in any case, and it has probably reduced its effectiveness further by signaling its eagerness to raise rates at the first excuse. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank is already pushing to the limits of its political mandate in its own so far unsuccessful effort to raise inflation.'b'And while fiscal policy \xe2\x80\x94 essentially, spending more to offset the effects of China spending less \xe2\x80\x94 would surely work, how many people believe that Republicans would be receptive to a new Obama stimulus plan, or that German politicians would look kindly on a proposal for bigger deficits in Europe?'b'Now, my best guess is still that things won\xe2\x80\x99t be that bad \xe2\x80\x94 nasty in China, but just a bit of turbulence elsewhere. And I really, really hope that guess is right, because we don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to have a plan B anywhere in sight.'b'Donald Trump seems to view his role as the person who dredges up what nobody else wants to talk about. According to the 'b'E.P.A.'b', \xe2\x80\x9colder, more polluting school buses can lead to significant health risks for students who typically ride these buses for one-half to two hours a day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Replace these buses, and children\xe2\x80\x99s health improves. In a study published last June, researchers at the Universities of Michigan and Wisconsin reported 'b'finding 'b'that having cleaner air on school buses led to improved lung capacity and substantial reductions in absenteeism, particularly among children with asthma.'b'By replacing old school buses, in addition to fixing the affected cars, Volkswagen can make up for the damage it did to the environment and improve the lives of many thousands of children in the process. Eventually, the company would be able to say that its net impact on air pollution in the United States, at least as measured by nitrogen oxides, was actually negative.'b'With help from Kirsten Koehler, an assistant professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, we did the math. In September, the E.P.A. directed Volkswagen to recall 'b'around 480,000'b' polluting diesel cars, each of which produces roughly between 'b'10 and 40 times'b' more nitrogen oxides than allowed. The cumulative impact of the Volkswagen deception has been estimated at 'b'about 46,000'b' tons since 2008.'b'We estimate there are about 250,000 school buses still on the road that were manufactured before stringent emissions regulations took effect in 2007. Using the E.P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'diesel emissions quantifier'b', we calculated that replacing one in 10 of these buses, a total of 25,000, would save about 5,000 excess tons of pollution in the first year, and the benefits would continue as long as the buses were on the road. In fact, replacing 25,000 old school buses would eventually make up for the cumulative total of 46,000 excess tons of nitrogen oxides from the polluting Volkswagens.'b'With a new school bus costing about $80,000, this bus-replacement effort would run Volkswagen about $2 billion, around 10 percent of its potential federal liability. We would welcome the company\xe2\x80\x99s replacing even more old buses.'b'With authorization from Congress, the company could simply write a check to the E.P.A., which already runs a program under the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act that helps local governments retrofit or upgrade their fleets. This program is in desperate need of greater investment. The E.P.A. recently 'b'announced 'b'just over $7 million in grants to fix or replace buses in 85 localities, a small fraction of the applications. The program has the capacity to give out much more to support school districts across the country.'b'Because of the diffuse nature of environmental pollution, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to point to a specific individual and conclude that a Volkswagen car caused his or her asthma attack. But it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be hard to find thousands of schoolchildren who would benefit from new school buses. As the air pollution expert Dr. Robert J. Laumbach of the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Jersey recently 'b'wrote'b', \xe2\x80\x9cEfforts to clean up diesel engine emissions from school buses are likely to have tremendous societal benefits.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Linking the Volkswagen scandal to the replacement of old school buses would also make the larger point that there are opportunities all around us to clean up our air and protect our health.'b'As owners of diesel-powered VW\xe2\x80\x99s, we\xe2\x80\x99re not looking for big payouts. Perhaps the agency can add our proposal to the topics up for discussion.'b'If Volkswagen doesn\xe2\x80\x99t step up voluntarily and accept the corporate responsibility that fits the evidence, forcing the company to pay to replace a large number of old school buses strikes us as a punishment that fits the crime.'b'Just when 'b'President Obama'b' was attempting a reasoned debate on gun control this week, Donald Trump was engaged in his latest pandering to the gun rights crowd \xe2\x80\x94 vowing as president to strike down laws that bar firearms from schools. \xe2\x80\x9dMy first day, it gets signed, O.K.?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Trump told a campaign rally in Vermont on Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cMy first day. China\xe2\x80\x99s central government orchestrated that binge by pumping billions of dollars into the economy in the aftermath of the 2008 global financial crisis and by failing to enact needed reforms that would make it easier for private and foreign companies to compete with inefficient state-owned enterprises.'b'Beginning last year, Chinese officials also used state-owned media to 'b'encourage individual investors'b' to pour their savings and borrowed money into the stock market, leading to a massive bubble. This is important because China can no longer grow by taking people off the farm and putting them to work in factories. It needs to move people into white-collar jobs. CRANK'b'Lawrence, Kan.'b'THE crisis of painkiller addiction is becoming increasingly personal: Sixteen percent of Americans know someone who has died from a prescription painkiller overdose, according to a recent Kaiser Family Foundation survey; 9 percent have seen a family member or close friend die.'b'Addictive opioid painkillers were once reserved for extreme situations like terminal cancer. But opioids like Vicodin and OxyContin are now widely prescribed for common conditions like arthritis and lower back pain. The consequences have been catastrophic: In 2013, prescription painkillers caused nearly 7,000 emergency room visits and 44 deaths every day.'b'How do we tackle this crisis? We often hear about efforts to clamp down on abuse, for example by regulating pain clinics and monitoring prescription patterns. But these won\xe2\x80\x99t dent the demand for opioids unless we can find better ways to treat the hundred million Americans said to suffer from chronic pain. Simply switching to other drugs isn\xe2\x80\x99t the answer. Few new painkillers are being approved, and existing ones, like Motrin and Tylenol, come with their own risks when used long-term, and some appear to be less effective than we once thought.'b'Help might instead come from an unexpected corner: the placebo effect.'b'This phenomenon \xe2\x80\x94 in which someone feels better after receiving fake treatment \xe2\x80\x94 was once dismissed as an illusion. People who are ill often improve regardless of the treatment they receive. But neuroscientists are discovering that in some conditions, including pain, placebos create biological effects similar to those caused by drugs.'b'Taking a placebo painkiller dampens activity in pain-related areas of the brain and spinal cord, and triggers the release of endorphins, the natural pain-relieving chemicals that opioid drugs are designed to mimic. Even when we take a real painkiller, a big chunk of its effect is delivered not by any direct chemical action, but by our expectation that the drug will work. Studies show that widely used painkillers like morphine, buprenorphine and tramadol are markedly less effective if we don\xe2\x80\x99t know we\xe2\x80\x99re taking them.'b'Placebo effects in pain are so large, in fact, that drug manufacturers are finding it hard to beat them. Finding ways to minimize placebo effects in trials, for example by screening out those who are most susceptible, is now a big focus for research. But what if instead we seek to harness these effects? Placebos might ruin drug trials, but they also show us a new approach to treating pain.'b'It is unethical to deceive patients by prescribing fake treatments, of course. But there is evidence that people with some conditions benefit even if they 'b'know 'b'they are taking placebos. In a 2014 study that followed 459 migraine attacks in 66 patients, honestly labeled placebos provided significantly more pain relief than no treatment, and were nearly half as effective as the painkiller Maxalt. (The study also found that a placebo labeled \xe2\x80\x9cplacebo\xe2\x80\x9d was 60 percent as effective as Maxalt if it was labeled \xe2\x80\x9cplacebo.\xe2\x80\x9d If the placebo was labeled \xe2\x80\x9cMaxalt,\xe2\x80\x9d it was again 60 percent as effective as the real drug under its real label.)'b'With placebo responses in pain so high \xe2\x80\x94 and the risks of drugs so severe \xe2\x80\x94 why not prescribe a course of \xe2\x80\x9chonest\xe2\x80\x9d placebos for those who wish to try it, before proceeding, if necessary, to an active drug?'b'Another option is to employ alternative therapies, which through placebo responses can benefit patients even when there is no physical mode of action. A series of large trials in Germany published between 2005 and 2009 compared real and sham acupuncture (in which needles are placed at nonacupuncture points) with either no treatment or routine clinical care, for chronic pain conditions including migraine, tension headaches, lower back pain and osteoarthritis. Patients who received the acupuncture, real or sham, reported a similar amount of pain relief \xe2\x80\x94 and more than those who received no treatment or routine care that included pain medication.'b'Rather than relying on dummy pills and treatments, however, a broader hope is that teasing out why and when placebos work \xe2\x80\x94 and for whom \xe2\x80\x94 will help to maximize the effectiveness of drugs, and in some cases allow us to do without them.'b'The available funding for such research is minuscule compared with the efforts poured into developing new drugs. But a key ingredient is expectation: The greater our belief that a treatment will work, the better we\xe2\x80\x99ll respond.'b'Individual attitudes and experiences are important, as are cultural factors. Placebo effects are getting stronger in the United States, for example, though not elsewhere. Researchers reported last year that in trials published in 1996, drugs for chronic pain produced on average 27 percent more pain relief than placebos. By 2013, that advantage had slipped to just 9 percent. Likely explanations include a growing cultural belief in the effectiveness of painkillers \xe2\x80\x94 a result of direct-to-consumer advertising (illegal in most other countries) and perhaps the fact that so many Americans have taken these drugs in the past.'b'These findings have implications for deciding which patients are likely to benefit from drugs \xe2\x80\x94 someone who has strong faith in painkillers\xe2\x80\x99 effectiveness is more likely to benefit than someone who is suspicious of conventional medicine \xe2\x80\x94 as well as how physicians explain the benefits and side effects of treatments they prescribe. Trials show, for example, that strengthening patients\xe2\x80\x99 positive expectations and reducing their anxiety during a variety of procedures, including minimally invasive surgery, while still being honest, can reduce the dose of painkillers required and cut complications.'b'Placebo studies also reveal the value of social interaction as a treatment for pain. Harvard researchers studied patients in pain from irritable bowel syndrome and found that 44 percent of those given sham acupuncture had adequate relief from their symptoms. If the person who performed the acupuncture was extra supportive and empathetic, however, that figure jumped to 62 percent.'b'Placebos tell us that pain is a complex mix of biological, psychological and social factors. We need to develop better drugs to treat it, but let\xe2\x80\x99s also take more seriously the idea of relieving pain without them. With dozens of Americans dying every day from prescription painkillers, we need all the help we can get.'b'Readers respond to an essay about \xe2\x80\x9cgratitude\xe2\x80\x99s rise to self-help celebrity status.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To the Editor: Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Selfish Side of Gratitude,'b'\xe2\x80\x9d by Barbara Ehrenreich (Sunday Review, Jan. 3): What a beautifully cogent way to frame the onset of another year.
