If that means political struggle against the entitled, then so be it.'b'JOHN PLOTZ'b'Hayward, Calif.'b'A QUARTER-CENTURY ago, Newark and nearby Union City epitomized the failure of American urban school systems. Students, mostly poor minority and immigrant children, were performing abysmally. Graduation rates were low. Plagued by corruption and cronyism, both districts had a revolving door of superintendents. New Jersey officials threatened to take over Union City\xe2\x80\x99s schools in 1989 but gave them a one-year reprieve instead. Six years later, state education officials, decrying the gross mismanagement of the Newark schools, seized control there.'b'In 2009, the political odd couple of Chris Christie, the Republican governor-elect, and Cory Booker, Newark\xe2\x80\x99s charismatic mayor, joined forces, convinced that the Newark system could be reinvented in just five years, in part by closing underperforming schools, encouraging charter schools and weakening teacher tenure. In 2010 they persuaded Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s chief executive, to invest $100 million in their grand experiment. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can flip a whole city!\xe2\x80\x9d the mayor enthused, \xe2\x80\x9cand create a national model.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'No one expected a national model out of Union City. Without the resources given to Newark, the school district there, led by a middle-level bureaucrat named Fred Carrigg, was confronted with two huge challenges: How could English learners, three-quarters of the students, become fluent in English? And how could youngsters, many of whom came from homes where books were rarities, be turned into adept readers?'b'Today Union City, which opted for homegrown gradualism, is regarded as a poster child for good urban education. Newark, despite huge infusions of money and outside talent, has struggled by comparison. In 2014, Union City\xe2\x80\x99s graduation rate was 81 percent, exceeding the national average; Newark\xe2\x80\x99s was 69 percent.'b'What explains this difference? The experience of Union City, as well as other districts, like Montgomery County, Md., and Long Beach, Calif., that have beaten the demographic odds, show that there\xe2\x80\x99s no miracle cure for what ails public education. What business gurus label \xe2\x80\x9ccontinuous improvement,\xe2\x80\x9d and the rest of us call slow-and-steady, wins the race.'b'Slow-and-steady was anathema to Mr. Booker and Mr. Christie, who had big dreams for Newark. But as Dale Russakoff writes in her absorbing account \xe2\x80\x9cThe Prize,\xe2\x80\x9d the politicians\xe2\x80\x99 optimism proved misplaced. What went wrong had as much to do with their top-down approach as with the proposals themselves.'b'The mayor pledged to involve the public before making any decisions, but efforts at community engagement, orchestrated by out-of-town advisers, proved shambolic. The only recommendations that got traction \xe2\x80\x94 closing 11 public schools, opening charters and themed high schools \xe2\x80\x94 were advanced by consultants, who gobbled up more than $20 million in fees.'b'In 2011, Mr. Christie appointed 39-year-old Cami Anderson \xe2\x80\x94 a Teach for America alumna \xe2\x80\x94 superintendent. She introduced some solid ideas, like replacing the weakest performers with \xe2\x80\x9crenew schools\xe2\x80\x9d and persuading charters to enroll more poor kids. But she ran into trouble with parents when she did away with neighborhood schools and laid off hundreds of workers to pay for her initiatives.'b'Her hurry-up style made matters worse. \xe2\x80\x9cShe didn\xe2\x80\x99t listen,\xe2\x80\x9d contends Ms. Russakoff. \xe2\x80\x9cShe said her plan \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9816-dimensional chess\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x94 was too complex for parents.\xe2\x80\x9d After repeated heckling by teachers and parents, Ms. Anderson stopped attending board meetings.'b'One of Mr. Booker\xe2\x80\x99s goals was to make Newark the nation\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ccharter school capital,\xe2\x80\x9d and he largely succeeded. While these schools have recorded higher test scores and graduation rates than the traditional schools, money explains much of that gap. Freed from the district\xe2\x80\x99s bureaucracy, the charters have nearly a third more dollars to spend on each student, $12,650 versus $9,604, which buys additional teachers, tutors and social workers.'b'The push to expand charters angers activists like Junius Williams, director of the Abbott Leadership Institute at Rutgers University. \xe2\x80\x9cCharters have drained resources necessary to teach most Newark students,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me.'b'In 1989, with one year to shape up Union City, Mr. Carrigg, with a cadre of teachers and administrators, devised a multipronged strategy: Focus on how kids learn best, how teachers teach most effectively and how parents can be engaged. Non-English speakers had previously been expected to acquire the language through the sink-or-swim method. So the district junked its old approach. Instead, English learners are initially taught in their own language, mainly Spanish, and then are gradually shifted to English. The system started hiring more teachers who spoke Spanish or had E.S.L. (English as a Second Language) training.'b'The bilingual approach went beyond the classroom. Even though many parents speak only Spanish, meetings had been conducted and written information prepared only in English. In the new era, bilingualism quickly became the norm. Parents, made to feel welcome in the schools, were conscripted to help with their children\xe2\x80\x99s homework and reinforce the schools\xe2\x80\x99 high expectations for them.'b'To get students excited about reading, the schools became word-soaked environments, with tons of reading and daily writing assignments linked even to subjects like art and science that traditionally don\xe2\x80\x99t require as much writing.'b'The Union City reformers opted to focus initially on the youngest children, whose potential for improvement was greatest. When New Jersey began to fund preschool for poor urban districts in the late 1990s, the district seized on the opportunity to devise a state-of-the-art program that enrolled almost every 3- and 4-year-old in the community.'b'Teachers rethought skill-and-drill instruction, instead emphasizing hands-on learning and group projects. Help came, in the form of coaches \xe2\x80\x94 veteran teachers \xe2\x80\x94 working side by side with newbies and time set aside for teachers to collaborate. Students were frequently assessed, not to punish teachers but to pinpoint areas where help was needed.'b'Stable leadership proved essential. In the years preceding the state\xe2\x80\x99s near-takeover, superintendents were hired and fired based on their politics; during the past quarter-century there have been just three superintendents, all of them products of the district. Nationwide, the average tenure of a city schools chief is only three years.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe real story of Union City is that it 'b'didn\xe2\x80\x99t'b' fall back,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Carrigg told me. \xe2\x80\x9cIt stabilized and has continued to improve.\xe2\x80\x9d Recent changes include the introduction of Mandarin Chinese from preschool on, a STEM-focused elementary school and a nursery for young parents in high school.'b'Newark\xe2\x80\x99s big mistake was not so much that the school officials embraced one solution or another but that they placed their faith in the idea of disruptive change and charismatic leaders. Since the appointment in 2015 of Christopher Cerf, formerly New Jersey\xe2\x80\x99s education commissioner, as Newark\xe2\x80\x99s superintendent, more attention is being paid to the positive side of the school district ledger. They\xe2\x80\x99re asking: \xe2\x80\x98What do we need to do to save traditional public schools?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'Aside from the barbarism and injustice of 'b'Saudi Arabia\xe2\x80\x99s execution'b' of 47 men on Jan. 2, the state-sponsored killings \xe2\x80\x94 some by beheading \xe2\x80\x94 bucked a strong trend against capital punishment in most of the world. According to the annual report of 'b'Amnesty International'b', executions were carried out in 22 countries in 2014, the year covered; there were 25 in 2004. The total number of people known to have been executed also fell. To its disgrace, the United States was still among the five countries that most often used capital punishment \xe2\x80\x94 alongside China, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Iraq \xe2\x80\x94 but the number of executions in America continued to decline.'b'Amnesty\xe2\x80\x99s report said an \xe2\x80\x9calarming number\xe2\x80\x9d of countries that carried out the death penalty in 2014 were responding to perceived threats to state security, the major factor in most of the Saudi executions. Pakistan resumed the execution of civilians after an attack by the Taliban on a Peshawar school, and China \xe2\x80\x94 which is thought to have the most executions of any country but keeps the number secret \xe2\x80\x94 used the death penalty in response to ethnic violence in the Xinjiang region. In Sunni-ruled Saudi Arabia and in Shiite-ruled Iran, death sentences often derive from a stern interpretation of Islamic law.'b'But there is no compelling evidence that the death penalty deters crime, whether murder or terrorism. And absent deterrence, what remains is just vengeance.'b'In the United States, that is rendered all the more absurd by efforts to make death seem humane through lethal injections. There is considerable evidence in America, moreover, that racism, unscrupulous prosecutors and shoddy public defenders account for a large number of dubious or blatantly unjust impositions of capital punishment. More than 150 wrongfully convicted people have been freed since 1973. As the case against capital punishment builds, the numbers of executions and death sentences have steadily declined, reaching their lowest level in at least two decades in 2015, according to the 'b'Death Penalty Information Center'b', with 93 percent of the executions carried out in only four states \xe2\x80\x94 Texas, Missouri, Georgia and Florida.'b'What that suggests, as does the Amnesty report, is that in the end, it may not be the debates about whether capital punishment is legal, effective, just, moral or, in the case of the United States, constitutional, that determine how long it persists. It is the fact that the people of the world, including Americans, are increasingly coming to recognize the death penalty for what it is: morally unacceptable, inhuman, barbaric, unjust and useless.'b'A case the Supreme Court 'b'will hear on Monday morning'b' threatens to undermine a four-decade-old ruling that upheld a key source of funding for public-sector unions, the last major bastion of unionized workers in America.'b'In the 1977 decision 'b'Abood v. Detroit Board of Education'b', the justices ruled that public unions may charge all employees \xe2\x80\x94 members and nonmembers alike \xe2\x80\x94 for the costs of collective bargaining related to their employment. For nonmembers, these are known as \xe2\x80\x9cfair-share fees.\xe2\x80\x9d But nonmembers may not be compelled to pay for the union\xe2\x80\x99s political or ideological activities.'b'The Abood ruling was a sensible compromise between the state\xe2\x80\x99s interest in labor peace and productivity and the individual worker\xe2\x80\x99s interest in his or her freedom of speech and association. Before the decision, strikes and labor unrest in the public sector were far more common, as workers struggled to have their voices heard in the absence of meaningful organized representation.'b'Stronger unions have not only helped ensure that essential public services are more efficient and effective; they have also led to higher wages and better benefits for workers. According to a 'b'report'b' by the Economic Policy Institute, public employees in states with fair-share fees enjoy nearly the same compensation as their private-sector counterparts, while those in states that have banned such fees get 9 percent less.'b'But leaders of the \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d movement \xe2\x80\x94 which is funded largely by corporate interests and has helped 'b'25 states'b' ban fair-share fees \xe2\x80\x94 have been gunning from the start to overturn the Abood decision. Today they have a good friend on the court in Justice Samuel Alito Jr., who has written two majority opinions since 2012 calling the ruling into serious doubt.'b'The 'b'latest challenge'b' targets the California public-school teachers\xe2\x80\x99 union, which gets fair-share fees from about 29,000 employees, or a little under 10 percent of the work force. After Justice Alito 'b'suggested in 2012'b' that he would be open to striking down all fair-share fees, the anti-union activists rushed their case through the lower courts.'b''b'The plaintiffs say'b' being required to pay anything at all to the union violates their First Amendment rights. And when the government is the employer, they argue, all union activities are inherently political.'b'The court rejected these arguments in Abood, in part because the government has more leeway when it acts as an employer, and in part because unions are required by law to represent all employees. As Justice Antonin Scalia 'b'explained in a 1991 case'b', \xe2\x80\x9cwhere the state creates in the nonmembers a legal entitlement from the union, it may compel them to pay the cost.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In other words, mandatory fees eliminate the problem of free riders \xe2\x80\x94 employees who enjoy raises and other benefits negotiated by the union without paying for them. In a 2014 ruling, Justice Alito 'b'dismissed the free-rider concern'b' and claimed that those who support a union will willingly pay its dues, but this is contradicted by both common sense and 'b'experience'b'.'b'States should continue to be free to fashion their own arrangements for handling labor relations. For now, she will have to deal with that old show business saw: Exit, pursued by a bear.'b'IT is tempting to dismiss the antigovernment gunmen who took control of an animal refuge in Oregon on Jan. 2 as fanatics working at the fringes of American politics. But if the methods used by the rancher Ammon Bundy to seize the federal property were radical, the ideological roots of the operation were somewhat more mainstream.'b'By storming the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge and vowing to return it \xe2\x80\x94 by force of arms, if necessary \xe2\x80\x94 to the people of Harney County, Mr. Bundy and his men were echoing the teachings, if not the tactics, of the Wise Use movement: a conservative land-use doctrine that has been a part of the national discourse for nearly 30 years.'b'A successor to the Sagebrush Rebellion of the 1970s (itself a successor to the anti-national parks Boomers project of the early 1900s), Wise Use answers the question of who should own the West by granting moral primacy to natural resource companies and to logging and ranching families like the Bundys, some of which have worked the land since the pioneer expansion.'b'Though composed of many activists and scores of organizations, Wise Use found its voice in the late 1980s when a timber industry adviser named Ron Arnold published \xe2\x80\x9cThe Wise Use Agenda.\xe2\x80\x9d The manifesto offered an expansive plan to gut environmental regulation, increase private ownership of public land and compel the federal government to open its holdings to mining, oil and logging companies and to the unrestricted use of off-road vehicles.'b'Mr. Arnold adopted the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cwise use\xe2\x80\x9d from Gifford Pinchot, the first head of the United States Forest Service (who said that \xe2\x80\x9cconservation is the wise use of resources\xe2\x80\x9d). In 1988 he held a conference, bringing together the likes of Exxon and the National Cattlemen\xe2\x80\x99s Association, with the goal of seeding the West with grass-roots groups that could wrest control of federal land and give a local flavor to his Reaganite aims.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cArnold sent organizers into distressed rural communities to set up front groups with environmentally friendly sounding names that whipped up hostility against the government,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tarso Ramos, the executive director of Political Research Associates, a research group that studies right-wing movements. What resulted, Mr. Ramos said, was a \xe2\x80\x9ccoalition of natural-resource companies, property developers and conservative activists working with a network of community organizations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This coalition achieved success in pushing its agenda. By the early 1990s, politicians friendly to the Wise Use cause had introduced or passed legislation in nearly 30 states giving local governments and citizens expanded powers to lay claim to federal land. Among those politicians was Representative Helen Chenoweth-Hage, an Idaho Republican, who became notorious for mocking the Endangered Species Act by holding what she called 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cendangered salmon bakes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' There was also Gale A. Norton, the interior secretary under President George W. Bush, who once worked as a lawyer for the Mountain States Legal Foundation, which has billed itself as \xe2\x80\x9cthe litigation arm of Wise Use.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Wise Use crowd got very close to the centers of power,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Ramos said.'b'It also got close to the militia movement, experts say. In 1994, 'b'the National Federal Lands Conference'b', a Wise Use group that maintained that county governments should control federal land, published an article in its newsletter that bore the title \xe2\x80\x9cWhy There Is a Need for the Militia in America.\xe2\x80\x9d Around the same time, Wise Use rallies often featured pamphlets from groups like the Militia of Montana, said David Helvarg, the author of the \xe2\x80\x9cWar Against the Greens.\xe2\x80\x9d Nor was it a coincidence, said James McCarthy, a professor of geography at Clark University, that militia members in camouflage fatigues conducted armed exercises in the very federal forests in New Mexico that the Wise Use movement was trying at the time to pry away from Washington\xe2\x80\x99s control.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere were many people who were active simultaneously in the Wise Use and militia movements and who saw them as different manifestations of the same larger cause,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. McCarthy said. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever, it is also true that many Wise Use activists were uncomfortable with the militia coming into their fold.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In an email titled, \xe2\x80\x9cWise Use and property rights activists v. Wackos,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Arnold denied that his movement was connected to men like Ammon Bundy, who stood down the government two years ago in a similar engagement over cattle-grazing rights at his father\xe2\x80\x99s ranch in Nevada. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see any Wise Use-ish \xe2\x80\x98doctrine\xe2\x80\x99 in anything that\xe2\x80\x99s been called \xe2\x80\x98patriot militia,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Arnold wrote.'b'And yet the question stands as to why vigilantes with AR-15 rifles have repeatedly confronted the government on behalf of local landowners in the West \xe2\x80\x94 a classic Wise Use principle, if not a Wise Use tactic. This spring, gunmen from the Oath Keepers militia group 'b'helped the owners of an Oregon gold mine chase away federal agents'b' who were trying to enforce a stop-work order. A few months later, another Oath Keeper tactical team stopped the government from 'b'shutting down a mine in a national forest in Montana'b'.'b'Part of the answer is that, in a region where the ground itself is largely owned by agencies in Washington, the Wise Use and militia movements share \xe2\x80\x9cthe same seething resentment at federal overreach,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jeffrey St. Clair, a journalist who has written about environmental politics in the West for 30 years. (\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d I imagine her asking him as he screamed. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought you said you liked them.\xe2\x80\x9d) Then there\xe2\x80\x99s St. Olga of Kiev, whose feast day is my birthday. She had them all buried alive.'b'After another disastrous visit with the man in Berlin, I got on a plane and came to \xc3\x81vila, Spain, on a pilgrimage to St. Teresa, the 16th-century mystic nun and philosopher. The town was celebrating her 500th birthday with banners of her poetry and a whole year of events. She did not have to remove any body parts to stay unmarried, nor murder scores of men. She did have to defy her family, though. As well as what she thought she wanted out of life, which was love. But she had watched her mother slowly die through pregnancy after pregnancy, her body weakening with each child, and she saw that this was her wifely duty.'b'Teresa did not want to be reduced to merely a body, bred and sacrificed for the sake of her husband and children. So she entered the church \xe2\x80\x94 the only way a woman could become a philosopher.'b'I am in \xc3\x81vila instead of at home, because my sister is in my home. A sister who, after 15 years of sacrificing all of her dreams, her comforts, her desires to a husband that she supported financially and emotionally, suddenly woke up and found she had nothing left, not even an idea of what she wanted to do with the rest of her life. After leaving him, she also had no home. So I opened my door to her.'b'This is my family default, or the default for the women: the sacrifice of everything for the husband. Women in my family have given up homes, friends, careers, the pursuit of advanced degrees within months of completion to become housewives, stay-at-home moms, or to work in jobs they never would have chosen to pay their male partner\xe2\x80\x99s way.'b'I understand that this was my female relatives\xe2\x80\x99 choice. Can you be both a psychologist and a writer?'b'When you look at the world as a psychologist, you see it as a set of phenomena that can be subjected to scientific inquiry: identified, tested and either verified or discarded. When you look at the world as a writer, you see it as a set of phenomena to be captured, contemplated, transformed and set down for others to recognize and absorb.'b'Although it\xe2\x80\x99s often presented as a dichotomy (the apparent subjectivity of the writer versus the seeming objectivity of the psychologist), it need not be. In fact, as I realized when I left the world of psychology behind to become that horror of all horrors (to an academic psychologist) \xe2\x80\x94 someone who wrote for a general audience \xe2\x80\x94 that neat separation is not just unwarranted; it\xe2\x80\x99s destructive.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA writer must be as objective as a chemist,\xe2\x80\x9d Anton Chekhov wrote in 1887. \xe2\x80\x9cHe must abandon the subjective line; he must know that dung heaps play a very reasonable part in a landscape.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Chekhov\xe2\x80\x99s chemist is a naturalist \xe2\x80\x94 someone who sees reality for what it is, rather than what it should be. In that sense, the starting point of the psychologist and the writer is the same: a curiosity that leads you to observe life in all its dimensions. Only in writing, you have the flexibility to explore the implications of your observations without the immediate necessity of experimental design.'b'Depending on whom you ask, 'b'Sigmund Freud'b' was either a pioneer who made much of modern psychology possible or a villain who was wholly misguided. The same mind advanced the field in unanticipated ways (Freud was decades ahead, for instance, when it came to defense mechanisms) and pushed it in a direction that seems, at best, simplistic (his insistence on sexuality as the cause of everything led to a number of therapies with little empirical grounding that are still in use to this day). How is that possible?'b'At the turn of the century, psychology was a field quite unlike what it is now. The theoretical musings of William James were the norm (a wry commenter once noted that William James was the writer, and his brother Henry, the psychologist). Psychologists could theorize without the immediate need for quantification, although in James\xe2\x80\x99s case he did establish one of the first psychological laboratories in the United States. Freud was a breed of psychologist that hardly exists anymore: someone who saw the world as both writer and psychologist, and for whom there was no conflict between the two. That boundary melding allowed him to posit the existence of cognitive mechanisms that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be empirically proved for decades, but it also led him astray in problematic, ultimately hurtful ways.'b'Freud got it brilliantly right and brilliantly wrong. The rightness is as good a justification as any of the benefits, the necessity even, of knowing how to look through the eyes of a writer. The wrongness is part of the reason that the distinction between writing and experimental psychology has grown far more rigid than it was a century ago.'b'When I was working on 'b'my new book'b', I discovered a pervasive set of folk theories about liars. Most were not as extreme as the profile of a poisoner from a 900 B.C. Vedic papyrus I chanced upon \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cHe does not answer questions, or gives evasive answers; he speaks nonsense, rubs the great toe along the ground, and shivers; his face is discolored; he rubs the roots of his hair with his fingers\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 but they did include a number of strands that will be familiar to any aficionado of the police procedural.'b'When an international team of researchers asked some 2,300 people in 58 countries to respond to a single question \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cHow can you tell when people are lying?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 one sign stood out: In two-thirds of responses, people listed gaze aversion. A liar doesn\xe2\x80\x99t look you in the eye. Twenty-eight percent reported that liars seemed nervous, a quarter reported incoherence, and another quarter that liars exhibited certain little giveaway motions.'b'It just so happens that the common wisdom is false \xe2\x80\x94 and we need psychologists in order to make that determination. What researchers who study ways of detecting deception, like Leanne ten Brinke, a psychologist at the University of California, Berkeley, will tell you is that the signs people associate with liars often have little empirical evidence to support them. Therein lies the psychologist\xe2\x80\x99s distinct role and her necessity. As a writer, you look in order to describe, but you remain free to use that description however you see fit. As a psychologist, you look to describe, yes, but also to verify.'b'Without verification, we can\xe2\x80\x99t always trust what we see \xe2\x80\x94 or rather, what we think we see. Take, once again, lying. Why do we think we know how liars behave? Liars should divert their eyes. They should feel ashamed and guilty and show the signs of discomfort that such feelings engender. And because they should, we think they do.'b'The desire for the world to be what it ought to be and not what it is permeates experimental psychology as much as writing, though. There\xe2\x80\x99s experimental bias and the problem known in the field as \xe2\x80\x9cdemand characteristics\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 when researchers end up finding what they want to find by cuing participants to act a certain way. It\xe2\x80\x99s also visible when psychologists choose to study one thing rather than another, dismiss evidence that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mesh with their worldview while embracing that which does. The subjectivity we tend to associate with the writerly way of looking may simply be more visible in that realm rather than exclusive to it.'b'IN 1932, when he was in his 70s, Freud gave a series of lectures on psychoanalysis. I left psychology behind because I found its structural demands overly hampering. It\xe2\x80\x99s in the merging not simply of ways of seeing but also of modes of thought that a truly whole perception of reality may eventually emerge. Or at least that way we can realize its ultimate impossibility \xe2\x80\x94 and that\xe2\x80\x99s not nothing, either.'b'Though it would have been inconceivable just a few years ago, among the most popular gifts this past holiday season was the drone. The scientific community loves to toss around the term \xe2\x80\x9ctransparency,\xe2\x80\x9d but it mostly remains a buzzword.'b'Last August, a colleague and I 'b'wrote an article'b' on the importance of transparency in science for one of the blogs of the science journal publisher PLOS. The argument was fairly simple: When research is paid for by the public, the public has a right to demand transparency and to have access to documents related to the research. This might strike most people as reasonable.'b'One of our examples focused on a small nonprofit, 'b'U.S. Right to Know'b', which advocates for the labeling of food containing genetically modified organisms. Try thinking more about your impending demise.'b'Years ago on a visit to Thailand, I was surprised to learn that Buddhist monks often contemplate the photos of corpses in various stages of decay. The Buddha himself recommended corpse meditation. \xe2\x80\x9cThis body, too,\xe2\x80\x9d students were taught to say about their own bodies, \xe2\x80\x9csuch is its nature, such is its future, such its unavoidable fate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Paradoxically, this meditation on death is intended as a key to better living. It makes disciples aware of the transitory nature of their own physical lives and stimulates a realignment between momentary desires and existential goals. In other words, it makes one ask, \xe2\x80\x9cAm I making the right use of my scarce and precious life?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In fact, most people suffer grave misalignment. In a 2004 article in the journal Science, a team of scholars, including the Nobel Prize winner Daniel Kahneman, surveyed a group of women to compare 'b'how much satisfaction they derived from their daily activities'b'. Among voluntary activities, we might expect that choices would roughly align with satisfaction. Not so. The women reported deriving more satisfaction from prayer, worship and meditation than from watching television. Yet the average respondent spent more than five times as long watching TV as engaging in spiritual activities.'b'If anything, this study understates the misalignment problem. The American Time Use Survey from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that, in 2014, 'b'the average American adult spent four times longer watching television'b' than \xe2\x80\x9csocializing and communicating,\xe2\x80\x9d and 20 times longer on TV than on \xe2\x80\x9creligious and spiritual activities.\xe2\x80\x9d The survey did not ask about hours surfing the web, but we can imagine a similar disparity.'b'This misalignment leads to ennui and regret. I\xe2\x80\x99m reminded of a friend who was hopelessly addicted to British crossword puzzles (the ones with clues that seem inscrutable to Americans, such as, \xe2\x80\x9cThe portly gentleman ate his cat, backwards\xe2\x80\x9d). A harmless pastime, right? My friend didn\xe2\x80\x99t think so \xe2\x80\x94 he was so racked with guilt after wasting hours that he consulted a psychotherapist about how to quit. (The advice: Schedule a reasonable amount of time for crosswords and stop feeling guilty.)'b'While few people share my friend\xe2\x80\x99s interest, many share his anxiety. Millions have resolved to waste less time in 2016 and have already failed. I imagine some readers of this article are filled with self-loathing because they just wasted 10 minutes on a listicle titled \xe2\x80\x9cCelebrities With Terrible Skin.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some might say that this reveals our true preferences for TV and clickbait over loved ones and God. But I believe it is an error in decision making. Our days tend to be an exercise in distraction. We think about the past and future more than the present; we are mentally in one place and physically in another. Without consciousness, we mindlessly blow the present moment on low-value activities.'b'The secret is not simply a resolution to stop wasting time, however. It is to find a systematic way to raise the scarcity of time to our consciousness.'b'Even if contemplating a corpse is a bit too much, you can still practice some of the Buddha\xe2\x80\x99s wisdom resolving to live as if 2016 were your last year. Then remorselessly root out activities, small and large, that don\xe2\x80\x99t pass the \xe2\x80\x9clast-year test.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There are many creative ways to practice this test. For example, if you plan a summer vacation, consider what would you do for a week or two if this were your last opportunity. With whom would you reconnect and spend some time? Would you settle your soul on a silent retreat, or instead spend the time drunk in Canc\xc3\xban, Mexico?'b'If this year were your last, would you spend the next hour mindlessly checking your social media, or would you read something that uplifts you instead? Would you compose a snarky comment on this article, or use the time to call a friend to see how she is doing? Hey, I\xe2\x80\x99m not judging here.'b'Some might think that the last-year test is impractical. As an acquaintance of mine joked, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had one year to live, I\xe2\x80\x99d run up my credit cards.\xe2\x80\x9d In truth, he probably wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. 'b'In a new paper'b' in the science journal PLOS One, two psychologists looked at the present value of money when people contemplated death. One might assume that when reminded of death, people would greatly value current spending over future spending. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not how it turned out. Considering death actually made respondents 'b'less'b' likely to want to blow money now than other scenarios did.'b'Will cultivating awareness of the scarcity of your time make you grim and serious? Two scholars in 2013 published an academic paper 'b'detailing research in which they subliminally primed people to think about either death or pain'b', and then asked them to caption cartoons. Outside raters found the death-primed participants\xe2\x80\x99 captions to be funnier.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s still time to rethink your resolutions. Forget losing weight and saving money. But a big reason you will not often hear is that Americans and the international community have a comic book image of North Korea. Their official media \xe2\x80\x94 hyperbolic pronouncements, constant threats and worshipful praise of the leader \xe2\x80\x94 magnifies a cultlike image. And most of all, their leaders look strange to us \xe2\x80\x94 for example, Kim Jong-il with his funny hairdo and dark glasses. Senator Ted Cruz typified this perception of the North recently, 'b'labeling'b' the current leader, Kim Jong-un, as a \xe2\x80\x9ccrazy nutcase\xe2\x80\x9d with a nuclear bomb.'b'I have been meeting with North Korean government officials for more than two decades in their country, Europe and Asia, and I can tell you that they are neither nutcases nor comic book characters. They are a diverse group, from hidebound apparatchiks to bureaucrats who teach themselves English by listening to foreign radio broadcasts. Some of them, military men especially, are hard-line, patriotic and, above all, anti-American.'b'I found that out firsthand in the 1990s, while leading a team on an inspection of a military-run underground facility that we thought might violate the 1994 United States-North Korea denuclearization agreement. My team was locked in a room surrounded by soldiers with bayonets drawn after one member of our team violated the inspection procedures. Many of us thought we were going to be killed. Eventually, we managed to extricate ourselves, but as we left the base in an old school bus, the military men followed us in a truck with a loudspeaker blaring anti-American slogans. I asked our North Korean civilian escort if they were going to follow us for the whole ride back to our hotel \xe2\x80\x94 two hours over bumpy roads. He responded with a smile: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you want them to?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Americans might find it surprising that many North Korean officials take a nonideological view of foreign affairs. Indeed, we would call them realists. They are well aware of their national interests and are dedicated to safeguarding them, a dedication that is based on a keen understanding of the outside world. A case in point: At one meeting, I was sitting next to a well-connected North Korean official who wanted to talk about Hillary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s book \xe2\x80\x9cIt Takes a Village.\xe2\x80\x9d (I was embarrassed to say I had not read it.) The North Koreans have demonstrated to me during many meetings that they are well versed in the particulars of political, economic and other developments in China, South Korea and Japan.'b'It shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprising that North Koreans are realists. For decades, Americans thought Mao Zedong was an irrational, unstable dictator. But when the chips were down, he also turned out to be a serious realist by opening better relations with President Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger after his relationship with Moscow deteriorated. In fact, I have been present several times when North Korean officials have met privately with Mr. Kissinger. They seemed to view those sessions as unprecedented opportunities to learn at the feet of an American statesman whom they deeply respect and admire.'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t get me wrong. The North Koreans may know a lot about the outside world, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t know everything, even about the United States, their main adversary. In one meeting, an official asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do the president and secretary of state keep saying that the United States will not allow North Korea to have nuclear weapons when in fact you are not doing much to stop us?\xe2\x80\x9d He deduced that there must be a hidden agenda. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s because you want us to have nuclear weapons as an excuse to tighten your grip on South Korea and Japan, your two allies.\xe2\x80\x9d We responded that there was no hidden agenda and that the United States really did not want the North to have those weapons. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure we convinced him.'b'What does all of this mean for America\xe2\x80\x99s future policy toward North Korea? Immediate, strong responses to provocations are fine. So are public statements of indignation; bigger and better sanctions; more pressure on the North\xe2\x80\x99s Chinese allies to support these measures; military steps to show the North Koreans and our allies that we are resolute. These are all warranted. But the North Koreans are in this for the long haul. They feel that their country and its government\xe2\x80\x99s survival is at stake. Unless Americans take them seriously and formulate a long-term strategy for stopping this threat, rather than adopting ad hoc tactical responses, when North Korea conducts its fifth nuclear test a few years from now, the United States will find itself, like Captain Renault in \xe2\x80\x9cCasablanca,\xe2\x80\x9d rounding up the usual suspects.'b'AMERICANS work some of the longest hours in the Western world, and many struggle to achieve a healthy balance between work and life. As a result, there is an understandable tendency to assume that the problem we face is one of 'b'quantity'b': We simply do not have enough free time. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could just get a few more hours off work each week,\xe2\x80\x9d you might think, \xe2\x80\x9cI would be happier.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This may be true. But the situation, I believe, is more complicated than that. As I discovered in a 'b'study'b' that I published with my colleague Chaeyoon Lim in the journal Sociological Science, it\xe2\x80\x99s not just that we have a shortage of free time; it\xe2\x80\x99s also that our free time, in order to be satisfying, often must align with that of our friends and loved ones. We face a problem, in other words, of 'b'coordination'b'. Work-life balance is not something that you can solve on your own.'b'Our study, which drew on data from more than 500,000 respondents to the Gallup Daily Poll, examined the day-to-day fluctuations and patterns in people\xe2\x80\x99s emotions, week after week. Two facts about emotional well-being emerged \xe2\x80\x94 one that was intuitive, the other surprising.'b'The intuitive finding was that people\xe2\x80\x99s feelings of well-being closely tracked the workweek. As measured by things such as anxiety, stress, laughter and enjoyment, our well-being is lowest Monday through Thursday. The workweek is a slog. Well-being edges up on Friday, and really peaks on Saturday and Sunday. We are, in a real sense, living for the weekend.'b'The surprising finding was that this is also true of unemployed people. We found that the jobless showed almost exactly the same day-to-day pattern in emotional well-being as working people did. Their positive emotions soared on the weekend, and dropped back down again on Monday.'b'It seems obvious why working people cherish the weekend: It\xe2\x80\x99s a respite from work. But why is the weekend also so important to the unemployed?'b'The key to answering this question is to recognize that not all time is equal. Time is, in many ways, what sociologists call a \xe2\x80\x9cnetwork good.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Network goods are things that derive their value from being widely shared. Take your computer: Its value depends in large measure on how many other people also have a computer. This is because you use your computer as, among other things, a communication technology: for Internet access, email, Facebook and file sharing. When everyone you know has a computer, the technology is indispensable. But if you were the only person with a computer, its value would be limited.'b'Free time is also a network good. The weekend derives much of its importance from the fact that so many people are off work together.'b'To help demonstrate this, my colleague and I conducted a second study, this time using the American Time Use Survey, which tracks how much time people spend doing various activities. We found that the weekly cycle in well-being from our previous study was mirrored in the pattern of time that people spent with family and friends \xe2\x80\x94 which was roughly double on weekends what it was during the week. According to our calculations, this increase of social time on the weekend accounted for roughly half the spike in weekend well-being.'b'Again, this was the same for the jobless. Monday to Friday offers five days when the unemployed are off work by themselves, searching job ads, doing household chores and so on. While the jobless have \xe2\x80\x9cfree time\xe2\x80\x9d during the week, their friends and family still have to go to work. The weekend is when the jobless fall back into sync with society.'b'The weekend, then, is not just a respite from work, but also gives similar relief from unemployment. It is a time when people can get what they\xe2\x80\x99ve been missing: time together.'b'This conclusion points to a key feature of the work-life problem: You cannot get more \xe2\x80\x9cweekend\xe2\x80\x9d simply by taking an extra day off work yourself. If we were to take more time off as individuals, we would be likely to spend that time, as the jobless do, waiting for other people to finish work. We are stuck \xe2\x80\x9cat work,\xe2\x80\x9d in a sense, by the work schedules of our family and friends.'b'Over the past few years, many workplaces have looked for ways to create more flexibility in individual work schedules. There is no question that doing so has many benefits. But my research suggests that a disadvantage of these efforts is that they may lead us even further from a weekend-like system of coordinated social time. They threaten, ultimately, to exacerbate the decline in civic engagement and social contact known as the \xe2\x80\x9cbowling alone\xe2\x80\x9d problem.'b'The solution might be found in a form of constraint: more standardization of the time for work and the time for life.'b'AS a lifelong devotee of fashion and tabloid magazines, I\xe2\x80\x99ve read dozens of \xe2\x80\x9cBeautiful/Sexy at Any Age\xe2\x80\x9d features. Fits of this seemingly irrational generosity, called a universal basic income or U.B.I., are becoming surprisingly common. The Swiss will vote in a referendum on basic income this year. The Dutch city of Utrecht will soon 'b' start'b' a basic-income pilot program. Canada\xe2\x80\x99s ruling Liberal Party recently adopted a resolution calling for a similar experiment.'b'Still, it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t happen here. Or could it? Over the past few years, a case for the U.B.I. has emerged that could make it appealing not just to the poor, who don\xe2\x80\x99t vote in great numbers, but to women, who do.'b'The feminist argument for a U.B.I. is that it\xe2\x80\x99s a way to reimburse mothers and other caregivers for the heavy lifting they now do free of charge. Roughly one-fifth of Americans have children 18 or under. Many also attend to ill or elderly relatives. They perform these labors out of love or a sense of duty, but still, at some point during the diaper-changing or bedpan cleaning, they have to wonder why their efforts aren\xe2\x80\x99t seen as \xe2\x80\x9cwork.\xe2\x80\x9d They may even ask why they have to pay for the privilege of doing it, by cutting back on their hours or quitting jobs to stay home.'b'Disproportionately, of course, these caregivers are women. Notwithstanding the advent of the stay-at-home dad, it\xe2\x80\x99s still mothers who do most of the invisible labor of cleaning, schlepping, scheduling and listening.'b'To the extent that mainstream feminism has paid attention to pocketbook issues over the past few decades, it has focused on the workplace: the wage gap, absence of family leave and weak \xe2\x80\x9cinfrastructure of care,\xe2\x80\x9d to use Anne-Marie Slaughter\xe2\x80\x99s phrase. These family-unfriendly facts of life on the job do yank success further out of the reach of women who combine career and children. But the problem is not that employers hate women and children. It\xe2\x80\x99s that they make a common assumption about motherhood: It\xe2\x80\x99s a lifestyle choice, not a wage-worthy job, and no one other than parents should pay for it. Wages for child rearing and housework? When one feminist collective took up that cry in the 1970s, it was more or less drummed out of the second-wave feminist movement, which aimed to get women into the work force, not pay them to stay out of it.'b'If mothers are glorified hobbyists who produce less value than nonmothers, it follows that they\xe2\x80\x99re getting a free ride on everyone else\xe2\x80\x99s labor. This can lead to tensions between colleagues, and also colors relations between breadwinning husbands and stay-at-home wives, who notoriously have less bargaining power in their households.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99d argue that this view of motherhood gets it exactly backward. Actually, it\xe2\x80\x99s society that\xe2\x80\x99s getting a free ride on women\xe2\x80\x99s unrewarded contributions to the perpetuation of the human race. As Marx might have said had he deemed women\xe2\x80\x99s work worth including in his labor theory of value (he didn\xe2\x80\x99t), \xe2\x80\x9creproductive labor\xe2\x80\x9d (as feminists call the creation and upkeep of families and homes) is the basis of the accumulation of human capital. I say it\xe2\x80\x99s time for something like reparations.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s an odd kind of reparations, you may object, that goes to fathers as well as mothers, the unattached as well as those with family responsibilities. But entertain this radical proposition: The universal basic income is a necessary condition for a just society, for it recognizes the fact that most of us \xe2\x80\x94 men, women, parents and nonparents \xe2\x80\x94 do a great deal of unpaid work to sustain the general well-being. If we\xe2\x80\x99re not raising children, then we may be going to school, or volunteering around the neighborhood.'b'Politically, the U.B.I. looks a lot more plausible than a subsidy aimed only at mothers, because, as Social Security and Medicare make clear, policies have more staying power when perceived as general entitlements rather than free cash for free riders. Critics on the right would dismiss a mothers\xe2\x80\x99 annuity as a handout to welfare queens. Critics on the left might see it as enshrining traditional gender norms. A universal basic income would sidestep both of these objections.'b'I do not want to create the impression that feminists dominate this debate. On the contrary: They\xe2\x80\x99re an overlooked part of a much larger conversation that has been going on for centuries.'b'In 1797, Thomas Paine declared that nations should give every 21-year-old a lump sum because those who inherit land have an unfair advantage over those who don\xe2\x80\x99t. By the middle of the last century, economists and leaders on both sides of the political spectrum were proposing minimum incomes.'b'The libertarian hero Friedrich A. Hayek supported \xe2\x80\x9ca sort of floor below which nobody need fall.\xe2\x80\x9d Milton Friedman called for a negative income tax in which, if you reported less than a certain amount, the Internal Revenue Service would pay you'b'. ('b'Our current earned-income tax credit resembles Friedman\xe2\x80\x99s plan, but only for people who, well, earn income. The negative income tax would have gone to the unemployed as well.) In 1969, President Richard Nixon proposed the Family Assistance Plan, a small annual stipend in lieu of welfare \xe2\x80\x94 $1,600 and some $800 in food stamps for a family of four. His bill was passed by the House of Representatives but died in the Senate Finance Committee.'b'Basic income proposals are sprouting up again, from the right as well as the left. 'b'Charles Murray'b' of the American Enterprise Institute thinks a guaranteed income could replace the welfare state. Libertarians want to get the government out of the private lives of the poor. Andy Stern, the former head of the Service Employees International Union, who has a book coming out soon on universal basic income, argues that it would offer the economic stability that the labor movement won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to provide as jobs disappear \xe2\x80\x94 though not, he says, if Social Security and Medicare are also cut.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see why basic income proposals are gaining steam right now. For one thing, the gap between rich and poor Americans is the 'b'widest on record'b'.'b'For another, smart machines and the \xe2\x80\x9cgig economy\xe2\x80\x9d seem poised to throw millions out of work. A 'b'2013 Oxford University study 'b' concluded that computers would replace humans in nearly half of all occupations in the United States within as little as two decades. We\xe2\x80\x99re not just talking about blue-collar jobs. Computers able to perform nonroutine cognitive tasks could wipe out middle-management positions such as accountant or transportation inspector, as well as many skilled service jobs, some of them typically associated with women. The Oxford study lists restaurant hostess and legal secretary, among others.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why some members of the Silicon Valley elite, better known for their contempt for government, advocate all-inclusive, no-strings-attached cash grants. In November, 'b'Robin Chase'b', the co-founder and former chief executive of Zipcar, called for a basic income. Venture capitalists like 'b'Albert Wenger'b' of Union Square Ventures and 'b'John Lilly of Greylock Partners'b', which invests in LinkedIn and Airbnb, have said that it\xe2\x80\x99s time to starting thinking about a U.B.I. The founder of 'b'HowStuffWorks.com'b', Marshall Brain, even wrote a basic-income novel called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Manna.'b'\xe2\x80\x9d It contrasts a nightmare world in which robots are managers and workers slaves with a utopian settlement in the Australian desert in which citizens receive a guaranteed share of the wealth created by such robots and devote themselves to dreaming up innovative new technologies. It\xe2\x80\x99s the Silicon Valley version of heaven.'b'THIS is all very nice, skeptics say, but the U.B.I. still represents a moral hazard. Give people money for nothing, and the lazy will grow lazier and the rest of us will be bankrupted.'b'But that does not appear to be the case. On the contrary: The U.B.I. gives workers less reason to loll about at home than do perversely disincentivizing policies like the one whereby a dollar earned is a dollar cut from a welfare check. Research suggests that, rather than weaken the will to work, unconditional regular disbursements let people manage their careers more wisely.'b'In five famous studies on the negative income tax conducted in the United States and Canada in the 1970s, a minimum income did bring down work hours a bit, partly because the unemployed took longer to find new jobs. Researchers speculate that they were holding out for positions that better matched their skills. In the United States, male breadwinners scaled back by as much as 9 percent a year. In Canada, they hardly cut back at all. In both countries, teenagers stayed in school longer. And women with children did spend up to 30 percent less time on the job.'b'The U.B.I. has feminist critics as well as supporters, and they don\xe2\x80\x99t like that finding. The U.B.I. would encourage women to drop out of the work force, they say, ceding the ground feminism has fought so hard for. But that concern strikes me as, well, paternalistic. Women should have more choices, not fewer. So should men. Equality between the sexes should not require everyone to conform to traditionally male patterns of employment.'b'Besides, basic income policies have been shown to mitigate specifically female kinds of poverty.'b'When cash-transfer experiments were conducted in poor towns in India, girls gained more weight and increased the time they spent at school at greater rates than boys, probably because when cash is scarce, the girls get less to eat and are kept home more.'b'In the United States, as Kathryn J. Edin and H. Luke Shaefer showed in their book on extreme poverty, \xe2\x80\x9c$2.00 a Day,\xe2\x80\x9d the process of qualifying for food stamps and Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, the welfare-to-work program created in 1996, can be so demanding, bewildering and degrading that many applicants simply give up. And who are the patient souls who wait in those daylong lines, pee into cups for drug tests or go home empty-handed? Women, more often than not, since there are more than four times as many families run by single mothers as by single fathers, and a third more households headed by women are on the dole than those run by men.'b'As for stay-at-home mothers supported by their partners, a basic income would let them put aside money of their own. Most retirement-savings instruments are linked to paychecks, which means that so-called nonworking parents have no way to pay into Social Security, 401(k)\xe2\x80\x99s or I.R.A.s. A basic income would let them save for old age. For nonwage-earning mothers trapped in abusive relationships, cash would make it easier for them to leave.'b'How much the basic income can accomplish depends on how it\xe2\x80\x99s configured. A truly universal guaranteed minimum income would be expensive. Say the U.B.I. was 'b'$12,000 a year per citizen over 18, and $4,000 per child'b'. At that rate, we\xe2\x80\x99d need about $3 trillion, roughly 80 percent of the total federal budget. The program would be even more effective, and more just, if children qualified for full stipends, since child rearing drives so many people \xe2\x80\x94 so many women! \xe2\x80\x94 into poverty. (It\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely that this would produce a baby boom, since even a handsome payout would hardly cover what children cost these days.)'b'The price tag for these cash transfers would be partly offset by savings. Most anti-poverty programs would become redundant. Bureaucracies tasked with weeding out cheaters would melt away (though, unfortunately, so would the jobs devoted to weeding). The better-off would pay back parts of their grants in taxes in proportion to their earned income. Moreover, a basic income would reduce the ill effects of poverty and therefore the cost to society of bad public health, crime and incarceration. Basic-income experiments have shown that recipients make greater use of medical services and break the law less often than nonrecipients. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s the boost to the economy that would result from poor people with cash in hand buying more goods.'b'Some of the many strategies proposed for raising the rest of the money include a relatively high flat tax; the closing of tax loopholes; a value-added tax; the elimination of middle-class entitlements such as the mortgage-interest deduction and retirement benefits; a careful paring back of Social Security; a tax on speculative financial transactions; and a carbon tax. We could also remit money reaped from the exploitation of public resources. Alaska, which already pays its citizens something very like a basic income, sends every adult and child a varying annual dividend of around $2,000 from a fund that invests royalties paid to the state by oil and natural gas producers.'b'The truth, though, is that the U.B.I. is \xe2\x80\x94 yes \xe2\x80\x94 a form of redistribution. We\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to afford it only when we decide it\xe2\x80\x99s worth affording. But that\xe2\x80\x99s just what we ought to decide. We should cut back on military spending if we have to, or raise taxes on the rich. The political will for such a huge restructuring of our economy would require a fundamental reassessment of the relationship between the state and the people. Maybe, like Thomas Paine, we\xe2\x80\x99d start to think of these wealth transfers as a right of citizenship instead of an insurance policy against financial disaster.'b'Even if we started small to get people used to the idea by offering way-below-poverty-level sums ($6,000, say), these would still buoy American families struggling not to slip underwater.'b'The U.B.I. would also edge us toward a more gender-equal world. The extra cash would make it easier for a dad to become the primary caregiver if he wanted to. A mom with a job could write checks for child care and keep her earnings, too. Stay-at-home parents would have money in the bank, more clout in the family, and the respect that comes from undertaking an enterprise with measurable value. And we\xe2\x80\x99d have established the principle that the work of love is not priceless at all, but worth paying for.'b'Donald J. Trump, reality television star and real estate mogul, is different in many ways from major political figures in our past. But there are striking similarities between Mr. Trump and George C. Wallace, the Deep South politician who ran for president each opportunity he got from 1964 through 1976. The connections between the two \xe2\x80\x94 their rhetoric and their ability to fire up crowds \xe2\x80\x94 give us a better sense of what Trumpism will mean once he is gone from the campaign stage. After all, political losers as well as winners can shape the future.'b'Mr. Trump started his business career with what he called a \xe2\x80\x9csmall loan\xe2\x80\x9d of a million dollars from his father. Mr. Wallace, the son of a struggling South Alabama farmer, clawed his way to power with hard work and a political antenna always ahead of the next public opinion poll.'b'And despite his reputation as a belligerent speechmaker, the insecure Mr. Wallace privately sought to ingratiate himself with friends and foes alike. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine the egotistic Mr. Trump beginning a call to a hostile newspaper editor by cheerfully explaining, as Mr. Wallace once did, \xe2\x80\x9cI just called up to kiss your ass some more.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What both share is the demagogue\xe2\x80\x99s instinctive ability to tap into the fear and anger that regularly erupts in American politics.'b'Mr. Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s 1963 inaugural address as governor of Alabama (\xe2\x80\x9cSegregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever!\xe2\x80\x9d) and his \xe2\x80\x9cStand in the Schoolhouse Door\xe2\x80\x9d that same year seemed to limit his role to that of a strictly regional figure, part of Dixie\xe2\x80\x99s long tradition of racist politicians. His presidential candidacy in 1964 and surprising strength in Democratic primaries in Wisconsin, Indiana and Maryland did little to change that national image. In April 1967, when Mr. Wallace told a Syracuse, N.Y., audience that he had decided to run for president as a third-party candidate, the television networks ignored his announcement, as did most of the major newspapers'b'. 'b''b'But in 1968, against a backdrop of urban riots, a war in Vietnam that dragged on inconclusively, tumultuous antiwar demonstrations and the assassinations of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy, a fiery Mr. Wallace began to draw interest across the nation; by September the crowds at his rallies rivaled those for his two main opponents, Richard M. Nixon and Hubert H. Humphrey. Mindful of his reputation as a defender of segregation, the Alabama governor avoided explicitly racist language. He was a pioneer in the use of code words to attack African-Americans while seldom mentioning race, instead condemning \xe2\x80\x9casinine\xe2\x80\x9d school busing, the \xe2\x80\x9cbloc vote\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cthugs\xe2\x80\x9d from America\xe2\x80\x99s inner cities who supposedly stalked the nation\xe2\x80\x99s streets.'b'Uncertain of what to make of the political upstart, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s print media initially played down their coverage of Mr. Wallace rather \xe2\x80\x9clike parents who refuse to look when their child is doing something naughty for fear it might encourage him to show off,\xe2\x80\x9d in the words of one British journalist.'b'As his poll numbers rose from single digits in the spring to more than 20 percent by the fall, it was no longer possible to ignore Mr. Wallace, and the major newsmagazines and largest newspapers attacked him with a barrage of thinly veiled invective: He was \xe2\x80\x9csimplistic\xe2\x80\x9d; he had not \xe2\x80\x9cone constructive proposal to offer a troubled nation\xe2\x80\x9d; he sought \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical profit in fear and hate.\xe2\x80\x9d Attacks by the mainstream media only strengthened his support. As one of Mr. Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s followers told a newspaper reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cI could care less what Time magazine thinks; I only use it once a day in the outhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The hypersensitive Mr. Trump obviously cares a lot more about Time\xe2\x80\x99s opinion. When the magazine failed to choose him as its 2015 Person of the Year, he 'b'complained that'b', despite being \xe2\x80\x9cthe big favorite,\xe2\x80\x9d Time had snubbed him in favor of Germany\xe2\x80\x99s Angela Merkel, \xe2\x80\x9cwho is ruining Germany!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Hostility to the civil rights movement was only a part of Mr. Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s rhetorical repertoire. He was a \xe2\x80\x9cpopulist\xe2\x80\x9d of sorts, defending good, hard-working (white) Christian Americans, but his enemies were not the economic bankers and monopolists of his 19th-century forebears. He had found new dragons to slay.'b'On paper his speeches were stunningly disconnected, at times incoherent. But videotapes of those 1968 rallies captured a performance'b'.'b' A wild energy seemed to flow back and forth between Mr. Wallace and his audience as he called out their mutual enemies: bearded hippies, pornographers, sophisticated intellectuals who mocked God, traitorous anti-Vietnam War protesters, welfare bums, cowardly politicians and \xe2\x80\x9cpointy-head college professors who can\xe2\x80\x99t even park a bicycle straight.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For the television networks the spectacle became irresistible, particularly since rallies often erupted into violent chair-throwing confrontations between Mr. Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s supporters and angry demonstrators. Hunter S. Thompson understood that George Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s followers were not interested in position papers on banking regulations or the pros and cons of thermal energy. Watching the Alabama governor perform was awe-inspiring to the gonzo journalist, who likened the rallies to a Janis Joplin concert \xe2\x80\x9cin which the bastard had somehow levitated himself and was hovering over us.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Both George Wallace and Donald Trump are part of a long national history of scapegoating minorities: from the Irish, Catholics, Asians, Eastern European immigrants and Jews to Muslims and Latino immigrants. During times of insecurity, a sizable minority of Americans has been drawn to forceful figures who confidently promise the destruction of all enemies, real and imagined, allowing Americans to return to a past that never existed.'b'At the same time, the rejection of the euphemisms of polite political rhetoric is part of the great appeal of such figures. He\xe2\x80\x99s standing up and fighting for real Americans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'George Wallace was never going to be president; neither is Donald Trump. American officials were not terribly optimistic that Mr. Kagame would cede power this year, not least because he faces 'b'the prospect of being prosecuted for war crimes'b' at some point in the future. But they nonetheless have continued to criticize him for his authoritarian style.'b'Mr. Kagame\xe2\x80\x99s record is mixed, and some of his accomplishments have earned him praise in the international community. Under his watch, Rwanda, which was devastated by the bloodletting in 1994, has become one of the safest countries in the region and'b' its economy has grown 'b'steadily in recent years. The nation\xe2\x80\x99s gross domestic product has grown between 7 and 8 percent per year since 2003, significantly reducing he number of impoverished Rwandans.'b'But those gains have come as government critics have been unlawfully detained and forced into exile. Some have been killed in custody. In its most recent 'b'annual human rights report'b', the State Department last year noted an increase in \xe2\x80\x9cpolitically motivated abductions\xe2\x80\x9d in Rwanda and said that local human rights groups had stopped investigating such cases as a result of government pressure.'b'Mr. Kagame\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'international champions'b' include former President Bill Clinton, former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. Like many international leaders, they have been heartened by the remarkable progress Rwanda has made since 1994. They should, however, acknowledge and speak out against the government\xe2\x80\x99s continuing abuses. To ignore them simply because they play out largely out of sight does nothing for the liberties of Rwanda\xe2\x80\x99s citizens or the health of its politics.'b'The United States should lift sanctions on Iran; no, it should impose new sanctions on Iran. The short answer is that the Obama administration should do both.'b'The sanctions imposed to press Iran to negotiate curbs on its nuclear program should be lifted as promised when the recent nuclear agreement goes into effect, maybe as early as next week. The Obama administration is wisely planning a separate set of new sanctions in response to Iran\xe2\x80\x99s two recent tests of ballistic missiles, which violated United Nations resolutions.'b'Critics of Iran and the nuclear deal say the missile tests are proof that the agreement failed. But ending Iran\xe2\x80\x99s production of ballistic missiles was not the focus of the agreement. The greater threat by far has always been Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program, which was coming closer to producing a bomb until the agreement halted the process.'b'That does not mean the missile tests in October and November should not be addressed. Iran is advancing the range and mobility of its ballistic missiles and vowing to accelerate production. Most worrisome is a collaboration with North Korea, which has nuclear weapons and provided Iran with many of its first missiles, and still supplies 'b'key components. 'b' A recent 'b'Congressional Research Service report 'b'called their cooperation \xe2\x80\x9csignificant and meaningful.\xe2\x80\x9d Iran has long rejected the United Nations Security Council\xe2\x80\x99s attempts to curb the ballistic program, saying it is vital for defense.'b'To his credit, President Hassan Rouhani is moving quickly to implement the nuclear deal. With a crucial election in February, he is desperate for the economic boost that is expected once sanctions are lifted. As required, Iran has already shipped its stockpile of enriched uranium to Russia. Once Iran meets the other demands of the deal, like disassembling more than 13,000 centrifuges, the major powers agreed they would give it access to $100 billion in frozen assets from oil sales and allow it to do business again with the world.'b'House Republicans, who opposed the nuclear deal, have begun a new effort to kill it by 'b'pushing a bill'b' to restrict the administration\xe2\x80\x99s ability to lift sanctions on Iranian banks. That would mean reneging on America\xe2\x80\x99s commitments, and President Obama would veto the bill.'b'In October, Iran\xe2\x80\x99s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Iran would walk away from the nuclear deal if new sanctions of any kind were imposed. But the administration has been clear that even after the most onerous sanctions are lifted under the nuclear deal, it would enforce those pertaining to Iran\xe2\x80\x99s missile, terrorism and human rights activities. The nuclear deal 'b'lifts'b' United Nations ballistic missile sanctions on Iran within eight years, but American sanctions on firms that sell arms to Iran will remain.'b'The administration told Congress that missile-related sanctions were coming, 'b'then held back'b', infuriating many lawmakers. While the delay was not explained, this is a delicate moment, and it may make sense to wait because Iran is on the verge of implementing the nuclear deal. Also, an Iranian official 'b'told Reuters'b' last week that negotiations are again underway on the possible release of the Washington Post journalist Jason Rezaian and other Americans held by Iran. That should not be so onerous that Iran would walk away from the economic relief it stands to gain from the nuclear deal. And it is an important and necessary way of keeping pressure on Iran to cease its unacceptable activities.'b'Fairhope, Ala. \xe2\x80\x94 ON New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve my wife and I, Democrats in one of the most Republican states in the nation, attended a Cotton Bowl party near Mobile Bay. How, though, with dialogue at the national level ever more confrontational and strident, do we talk to our neighbors?'b'Sometimes it seems impossible. A lost job can mean a lost home, a disabled child without adequate support or a spouse who is suddenly burdened with the full support of the family.'b'To remedy such inequities, age discrimination laws must be strengthened and enforced, and gender discrimination acknowledged as a continuing workplace concern. Employers rarely admit, even to themselves, that their choices and actions are discriminatory. It is up to the voters, and the courts, to mandate equal treatment.'b'RITA C. We hope that reason will prevail.'b'RIO DE JANEIRO \xe2\x80\x94 A S\xc3\xa3o Paulo judge sent shock waves across 'b'Brazil'b' last month with a ruling that required Brazilian telecommunications operators to block the use of the instant messaging platform WhatsApp for 48 hours. Less than 13 hours later, another S\xc3\xa3o Paulo judge reversed the decision, restoring service. But in the meantime, as many as 'b'100 million'b' Brazilians had been seriously inconvenienced, and civil libertarians around the world looked on with dismay.'b'Brazilians take their social media very seriously. The country has one of the fastest growing populations of Internet users in the world. Online tools like Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp are used not only to express opinions; they are an affordable alternative to exorbitantly priced Brazilian telecom providers. One recent study in Brazil found that WhatsApp was used by 93 percent of those surveyed who had Internet access.'b'The official reason for the judge\xe2\x80\x99s decision to suspend WhatsApp was because its parent company, Facebook, refused to comply with requests to provide personal information and communications records to prosecutors in an investigation into organized crime and drug trafficking. This is not the first time that the Brazilian authorities have jousted with tech companies. Notwithstanding the seriousness of the crimes being investigated, the judge\xe2\x80\x99s action was reckless and represents a potentially longer-term threat to the freedoms of Brazilians.'b'The ruling was not entirely out of the blue. Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s Congress has been considering legislation that would roll back key provisions of the country\xe2\x80\x99s freshly minted digital bill of rights, known as the Marco Civil da Internet, which was passed in 2014. The new proposal is expected to make it easier for prosecutors to access citizens\xe2\x80\x99 personal information without the nuisance of having to obtain a court order.'b'Described by critics as \xe2\x80\x9cthe big spy bill,\xe2\x80\x9d it would require Brazilians to register personal details like their home address, telephone number and other private information when accessing websites. It would also expose citizens to possible charges of libel for comments made on social media. At a time when political dissent is vigorous, this bill would surely chill debate.'b'A key architect of the spy bill is the president of Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s lower house of Congress, Eduardo Cunha. Mr. Cunha was a leading opponent of the Marco Civil and teamed up with the Congress\xe2\x80\x99s evangelical caucus to take it down. Complicating matters, Mr. Cunha is under federal police investigation for corruption and taking bribes, charges he vehemently denies. That aside, groups like the 'b'Center for Technology and Society'b', a think tank based at the Funda\xc3\xa7\xc3\xa3o Getulio Vargas law school, argue that the proposed legislation is probably unconstitutional.'b'These latest efforts to reduce Brazilians\xe2\x80\x99 digital rights are in stark contrast to the country\xe2\x80\x99s former reputation as a champion of Internet freedom. In the wake of scandals over the United States\xe2\x80\x99 National Security Agency\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'collection'b' of Brazilian citizens\xe2\x80\x99 communications and 'b'phone-tapping'b' of top government officials in 2013, Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s president, Dilma Rousseff, projected the digital freedom agenda onto the global stage \xe2\x80\x94 even 'b'raising'b' the issue at the United Nations.'b'When Brazilian legislators passed the Marco Civil, the government signaled to its citizens and the international community that it took \xe2\x80\x9c'b'net neutrality'b'\xe2\x80\x9d and digital sovereignty seriously. It was, in effect, declaring that the democratic principles of freedom, privacy and human rights were equally applicable in cyberspace as in the physical world.'b'That ethos continued in 2014, when Brazil hosted the 'b'NETmundial'b', an Internet governance conference. And just a few months ago, Brazil played host to the 'b'Internet Governance Forum'b', showcasing its \xe2\x80\x9cmulti-stakeholder approach\xe2\x80\x9d as a model for other countries.'b'Although WhatsApp was soon back online, the damage was done. Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s aspirations to Internet freedom have come into clear conflict with the authorities\xe2\x80\x99 plans to expand the digital surveillance state. And while Brazil boasts on the global stage of its open Internet, it is progressively 'b'militarizing'b' its cybersecurity and defense infrastructure.'b'Consider the response of the authorities to the huge street protests of 2013: The Brazilian Intelligence Agency and the Army\xe2\x80\x99s cybersecurity command actively 'b'monitored'b' civilian protesters and politicians. And the government now regularly clashes with tech companies like 'b'Apple'b' and 'b'Google'b' over access to users\xe2\x80\x99 personal data. Every government deals with similar tensions, but each must strive to strike a balance between protecting civil liberties on one hand, and the possible overreach of a country\xe2\x80\x99s security apparatus on the other.'b'Having emerged from authoritarian rule just 'b'30 years ago'b', Brazilians are especially sensitive to encroachments on their basic freedoms, including digital ones. People still remember, for example, how 'b'habeas corpus'b' was suspended in the wake of the 1964 military coup. Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s politicians and judges should be more conscious than most of the slippery slope of curbing fundamental rights.'b'Last month\xe2\x80\x99s judicial injunction, together with retrograde proposals like the spy bill, set a dangerous precedent. For a while, the country looked to be a progressive voice for digital freedom. No one expected Brazil to become a leader in cyber surveillance and censorship.'b''b' 'b''b'After haunting pictures and stories of starving civilians showed up on international news sites and social media, food and other desperately needed aid were finally allowed into the Syrian town of 'b'Madaya on Monday'b'. Yet this should not be a cause for celebration or complacency. The aid convoys and their supplies offer only a respite in the slow-motion agony that is destroying Syria and its people.'b'What is needed, and has long been needed, is an immediate end to the civil war. The obstacles are daunting. The chaos enabled the Islamic State to move in and seize territory, making the conflict even worse.'b'Although Madaya is only an hour\xe2\x80\x99s drive from downtown Damascus, residents and international aid workers say much of the 'b'town is starving'b'. Other reports suggest dozens have died from starvation or lack of medical care.'b'The United Nations has said that in all, 4.5 million Syrians live in hard-to-reach areas, including 400,000 in 15 besieged towns like Madaya that are denied access to food and medicine. That means the number of people at risk has nearly doubled since the United Nations Security Council ordered the warring parties to allow aid deliveries in 2014.
