Using food as a weapon violates international law, and the United States, Europe, Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iran, which all have influence with different proxy groups in Syria, have a responsibility to ensure that civilians have unconditional access to basic supplies.'b'Much of what these powers are doing in Syria, including American and Russian airstrikes, has complicated the relief effort. If negotiations on Jan. 25 to achieve a broad political settlement continue to falter, the outside powers should declare a cease-fire and find a way to impose it on their Syrian proxies.'b'IF the questions that came up during oral argument in Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association on Monday are any guide, the ruling bloc of conservative justices 'b'appears ready'b' to render a decision later this year that would significantly weaken public sector labor unions.'b'By stripping these unions of key financial resources \xe2\x80\x94 their fair share of fees provided by nonmembers \xe2\x80\x94 the court would upend a longstanding precedent. A decision in favor of the plaintiff would effectively slam the door on an era in which some conservatives joined liberals in recognizing that vibrant unions help make our democracy work. This is radicalism, not conservatism.'b'Public sector unions \xe2\x80\x94 representing teachers, firefighters and the like \xe2\x80\x94 are the remaining bright spot in America\xe2\x80\x99s once-thriving trade union movement. In the case before the 'b'Supreme Court'b', Rebecca Friedrichs, a dissident teacher in Southern California, argues that she should be able to accept the higher wages and benefits the union negotiates, but not help pay for the costs.'b'Relying on the First Amendment, Ms. Friedrichs says that she shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be forced by the government to support political causes with which she disagrees. But almost four decades ago, the Supreme Court came to a sensible compromise on this issue, written by an Eisenhower appointee, Justice Potter Stewart: No public sector worker can be compelled to join a union or to pay for its political efforts. However, the state may require that every worker pay fair share fees to support the costs of collective bargaining over bread-and-butter issues like wages, benefits and working conditions.'b'That 1977 ruling appears in real danger of being overturned. Doing so, David C. Frederick, a lawyer representing the union, told the court, \xe2\x80\x9cwould substantially disrupt established First Amendment doctrine and labor management systems in nearly half the country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. suggested that losing fair share fees would not pose much of a problem; if workers really support collective bargaining, the so-called free rider problem someone like Ms. Friedrichs represents would be \xe2\x80\x9creally insignificant.\xe2\x80\x9d But humans enjoy getting benefits for nothing. In states that recognize a duty to bargain but prohibit fair share fees, 'b'34 percent of teachers are free riders'b'.'b'Because today\xe2\x80\x99s conservatives are typically hostile to unions, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to forget that they were not always opposed to unionism or fair share fees. If conservatism is supposed to stand for anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s the idea that there is no such thing as a free lunch. In a 1991 case, Justice Antonin Scalia backed fair share fees, citing the legal duty unions have to represent the interests of nonmembers as well as members. Unless dissidents like Ms. Friedrichs want to return the raises, health care and retirement benefits that unions negotiate, conservative values suggest that they should contribute like everyone else.'b'During the Cold War, Republicans as well as Democrats fought for union endorsements and recognized that unions were critical civic organizations because they serve as a check on arbitrary government power; help sustain a middle-class society necessary for a stable democracy; serve to acculturate workers to democratic norms; and, in the case of teachers unions, support a public school system that helps children become thoughtful and reflective citizens.'b'Conservatives are fond of citing Alexis de Tocqueville, who was famously struck by the thriving civic associations that keep American democracy vitalized; for the past century, unions have been a critical part of that framework. In 1980, Ronald Reagan, then the Republican Party\xe2\x80\x99s presidential candidate, championed the role of Polish unions in challenging dictatorial rule by the Communist Party. In a Labor Day speech that year, Reagan declared, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere free unions and collective bargaining are forbidden, freedom is lost.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Democracies are also more likely to thrive when a vibrant middle class can support them, an insight that goes all the way back to Aristotle. Large inequalities of wealth can create political inequality, and vice versa. Theodore Roosevelt warned of the dangers of having \xe2\x80\x9ca small class of enormously wealthy and economically powerful men, whose chief object is to hold and increase their power.\xe2\x80\x9d Strong unions ameliorate extreme inequalities.'b'Unions serve as what Robert Putnam, a political scientist at Harvard, calls \xe2\x80\x9cschools for democracy.\xe2\x80\x9d Being involved in workplace decisions and the give and take of collective bargaining, voting on union contracts and voting for union leadership are all important drivers of \xe2\x80\x9cdemocratic acculturation.\xe2\x80\x9d Union members also staff phone banks and canvass voters door to door, which actually increases civic participation among union members and nonmembers alike.'b'Teachers unions are strong champions of American public schooling, which undergirds our democracy. The 19th-century educator Horace Mann, who advocated fiercely for the common school system that became America\xe2\x80\x99s experiment with public education, made this point metaphorically: \xe2\x80\x9cA republican form of government, without intelligence in the people, must be, on a vast scale, what a mad-house, without superintendent or keepers, would be on a small one.\xe2\x80\x9d While some critics claim teachers unions have a detrimental effect on academic achievement, careful studies actually find higher achievement in states with strong teachers unions.'b'With the Supreme Court split, unions cling to a thin hope that one of the conservative justices will resist partisan pressure to tilt the political playing field against Democrats. I hope they\xe2\x80\x99re right. Unions aren\xe2\x80\x99t faultless, but they are a crucial source of stability and strength for our democracy.'b'Durham, N.C. \xe2\x80\x94 THE release last month of \xe2\x80\x9cMaking a Murderer,\xe2\x80\x9d a 10-part documentary from Netflix, capped a year in which popular culture\xe2\x80\x99s portrayal of the criminal justice system seems to have shifted. Out with the old tropes about truth-seeking investigators and tidy resolutions; in with the disquieting, dysfunctional reality of many courtrooms and police stations.'b'The documentary, which has captivated viewers and critics, chronicles the trials of Steven Avery and his nephew Brendan Dassey for the 2005 killing of Teresa Halbach. But what happened to them happens to low-status criminal defendants across the country all the time.'b'Searing images of law enforcement abuses in Chicago, Cleveland and elsewhere have eroded the public\xe2\x80\x99s trust in police power on the street. At the same time, serialized true-crime programs, such as \xe2\x80\x9cMaking a Murderer\xe2\x80\x9d and the first season of the podcast \xe2\x80\x9cSerial,\xe2\x80\x9d are bringing the failures of due process into focus: careless police work, flawed forensics, forceful interrogations, unreliable witnesses and the woeful condition of state-funded criminal defense.'b'It takes hours rather than seconds to appreciate this procedural violence. That hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stopped listeners and viewers. \xe2\x80\x9cSerial\xe2\x80\x9d was downloaded some 75 million times. (Netflix doesn\xe2\x80\x99t release any audience statistics, but \xe2\x80\x9cMaking a Murderer\xe2\x80\x9d has generated widespread discussion in social and traditional media.) A spinoff from the \xe2\x80\x9cSerial\xe2\x80\x9d podcast, sponsored by the defendant\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers, updates listeners on appellate claims and advocates for a retrial.'b'Why wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t Americans want a satisfying finale? Our culture is steeped in procedural crime dramas. Hundreds of \xe2\x80\x9cLaw and Order\xe2\x80\x9d episodes concluded with definitive guilty verdicts, punctuated by a signature sound effect. CBS\xe2\x80\x99s hit show \xe2\x80\x9cCSI: Crime Scene Investigation\xe2\x80\x9d suggested that instant forensics always yielded definitive results.'b'The desire for closure is understandable, but a tidy conclusion is rarely attainable, and all of the Internet sleuthing and speculating can be distracting. Yes, post-conviction DNA testing and the work of Innocence Projects around the country have exonerated 'b'more than 1,700'b' defendants. Those cases heighten awareness of potential errors and demonstrate that wrongful convictions happen. But Americans shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t expect certainty about innocence. Sometimes the focus on finding new evidence to exonerate distracts from the question of whether or not the old evidence proved guilt.'b'Mr. Avery, the focus of \xe2\x80\x9cMaking a Murderer,\xe2\x80\x9d had a 1985 sexual assault conviction overturned after forensic proof of his innocence emerged. In the closing line of the documentary, he says, \xe2\x80\x9cThe truth always comes out sooner or later.\xe2\x80\x9d That line feels unfortunately misplaced. We may never know the facts behind the gruesome murder of which Mr. Avery was accused. Nor did \xe2\x80\x9cSerial\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csolve\xe2\x80\x9d the 1999 murder case it exhaustively explored.'b'The lack of resolution may be as valuable a lesson as the evidence of law enforcement misconduct. When I was a federal prosecutor, I had the luxury of working only on carefully screened cases with strong evidence. But fewer than 70,000 federal felonies are prosecuted each year, while roughly 2.5 million felonies proceed through the state courts. Many state cases involve near-simultaneous investigation and prosecution. One rarely finds out \xe2\x80\x9cwhat really happened.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The prosecutor in Mr. Avery\xe2\x80\x99s trial argued in his closing statement that \xe2\x80\x9creasonable doubts are for innocent people.\xe2\x80\x9d They are not. And procedural protections like access to defense counsel and freedom from coerced interrogations extend to both the innocent and the guilty. The real contribution of these documentaries is not to ask \xe2\x80\x9cwhodunit\xe2\x80\x9d but to reveal what was done to the defendants.'b'As listeners and viewers consume these stories, they are reminded of the humanity of the individuals involved \xe2\x80\x94 and they learn to see the defendants as more than abstractions. That knowledge should lead people to understand that resolution and justice are not the same thing. And whether or not the truth of these crimes ever comes out, shows, podcasts and narrative articles can make the public aware of distortions that occur in the legal process.'b'The United States\xe2\x80\x99 criminal justice system needs fewer guilt-assuming interrogation tactics, more disclosure of potentially exculpatory information to the defense, expanded oversight units within prosecutors\xe2\x80\x99 offices to investigate potential miscarriages of justice, and fuller appellate scrutiny of convictions.'b'The moment is ripe for reform, culturally and politically. Indeed, the cost of not doing so is far too high.'b'An article in 'b'The Times Magazine'b' on Sunday has laid bare the unconscionable decades-long efforts of the DuPont company to hide the dangers of an obscure chemical and bamboozle regulators into allowing toxic pollution to continue long after the dangers were known to the company. The article by Nathaniel Rich described how a corporate lawyer, Rob Bilott, built a devastating case against DuPont, based on the company\xe2\x80\x99s own studies and internal documents. The case illustrates the urgent need for Congress to complete its efforts to reform the Toxic Substances Control Act, which has allowed tens of thousands of untested chemicals to remain on the market with little more than the manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s say-so that they are safe.'b'The chemical that DuPont was protecting is known as PFOA, or perfluorooctanoic acid. It is used in the production of Teflon for non-stick frying pans, a huge source of profits for DuPont. When the Toxic Substances Control Act was enacted in 1976, PFOA was one of a multitude of untested chemicals allowed to remain on the market. The act also made it extremely difficult for the Environmental Protection Agency to require safety tests or crack down on chemicals known to be hazardous. Only a handful have been restricted over the past 40 years.'b'In the case of PFOA, DuPont brazenly dumped its toxic waste into a creek that ran through a pasture where farmers grazed and watered their cows, causing grotesque malformations and deaths among the animals. Meanwhile, the company hid evidence that the chemical had contaminated the local water supply well beyond what the company\xe2\x80\x99s own scientists considered safe and far beyond what independent scientists considered safe.'b'The Senate and the House have passed bills that would go a long way toward preventing such tragedies. What remains is for the two chambers to 'b'reconcile their versions'b' into one bill that can be sent to the president for his signature. The Senate bill is the stronger of the two. Both would make it harder for companies to hide information from the public and from federal or state agencies by claiming it is confidential business information. Both bills would require companies to justify claims of confidentiality, but the stronger Senate bill would also require the E.P.A. to review such claims. The Senate bill would also require full public disclosure of any chemical that was found to be hazardous in testing.'b'The Senate bill would eliminate a \xe2\x80\x9cCatch-22\xe2\x80\x9d provision in existing law that says the E.P.A. can\xe2\x80\x99t require safety testing unless it has evidence, which companies often try to hide, that a chemical may present an unreasonable risk. That is virtually impossible to demonstrate without the data that required testing would provide.'b'For regulatory purposes, the existing law divides chemicals into two groups \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cexisting chemicals,\xe2\x80\x9d more than 60,000, that were on the market when the first Toxic Substances Control Act was established in 1979, and \xe2\x80\x9cnew chemicals,\xe2\x80\x9d more than 20,000, that entered commerce after 1979.'b'Although the law theoretically gave the E.P.A. authority to review \xe2\x80\x9cnew chemicals\xe2\x80\x9d before they entered the market, it allowed companies to sell an untested chemical within 90 days if the overburdened agency didn\xe2\x80\x99t challenge them, as was usually the case. The Senate bill, but not the House version, would mandate that the E.P.A. find the chemical safe before it can be marketed.'b'The current law has no requirements for the E.P.A. to review the safety of existing chemicals. The Senate bill would require it to prioritize all chemicals in active commerce and set deadlines for their review. The House bill would largely leave the status quo untouched.'b'Both bills would allow industry to nominate chemicals for priority review, but the House bill would require the E.P.A. to evaluate any chemical a manufacturer submits, potentially eating up all of the agency\xe2\x80\x99s time and effort, whereas the Senate bill caps industry requests and gives the E.P.A. greater power to set its own priorities.'b'There is strong bipartisan support in Congress to reform the existing law. The frightening DuPont saga is further reason for Congress to choose the strongest possible reform.'b'In Donald J. TV loves airing ads, because you know what ads are? TV.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Willie Horton ad did not single-handedly win the election for Mr. Bush. It simply capitalized on the fears of (mostly white) American voters at that time. In this election cycle, no candidate has taken more advantage of those types of fears than Mr. Trump, according to Tali Mendelberg, a politics professor at Princeton and author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Race Card: Campaign Strategy, Implicit Messages, and the Norm of Equality.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRepublicans win largely with support from white voters, so they have incentives to rally their base around racial fears and resentments,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only trick to that strategy is not to run afoul of norms of racial equality that prohibit sounding explicitly racist. Trump more than anyone else in modern American history is loosening that norm.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Willie Horton ad, then, is a clear example of how political debates can be won: through the precise, tactical application of fear, no matter the moral consequences. And that line of attack isn\xe2\x80\x99t likely to die out anytime soon.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRace is effective because it divides,\xe2\x80\x9d Scott Reed, a Republican consultant, 'b'wrote'b' of the ad in 2004. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not looking to boost turnout and include people in your campaign. You\xe2\x80\x99re hoping to actually send people home.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The debate surrounding sanctuary cities offers a more modern example of racially charged rhetoric like the Horton ad. In the 1980s, sanctuary city policies caught on around the country. The policies 'b'were intended'b' to encourage people to report a crime, enroll their children in school, or go to the emergency room without the fear of being asked about their immigration status. There is evidence that sanctuary cities 'b'tend to be safer'b' than non-sanctuary cities.'b'This past summer, the topic of sanctuary cities gained new political life among Republicans. In July, 32-year-old Kathryn Steinle was shot in San Francisco by Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, an undocumented immigrant who had been deported five times before. Evidence 'b'suggests'b' that the shooting was an accident, but that didn\xe2\x80\x99t stop it from becoming politicized. After the shooting, both Mr. Cruz and Senator Rand Paul introduced bills to block sanctuary cities. Mr. Trump has called for a ban on sanctuary cities, saying he is the \xe2\x80\x9conly one who can fix\xe2\x80\x9d the situation, while Ms. Steinle\xe2\x80\x99s brother 'b'complained'b' that Mr. Trump politicized his sister\xe2\x80\x99s death.'b'The Republican candidates\xe2\x80\x99 implied reasoning here is that illegal immigrants pose a threat to city dwellers\xe2\x80\x99 safety. John Sides, a professor of political science at George Washington University, said the rhetoric of the Willie Horton ad mirrors the rhetoric candidates have taken with regard to illegal immigration.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot disentangle Horton from his race,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot disentangle sanctuary cities from Latinos and Hispanics, for the most part. They\xe2\x80\x99re parallel in that sense.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As humans, we tend to 'b'fear the wrong things'b', assigning more risk to scarier-sounding dangers and less risk to quotidian ones. We are more afraid of being in a plane crash than a car accident driving to work, even though the latter is 'b'much more likely'b' to happen.'b'Depressingly, appealing to voters\xe2\x80\x99 fears is often a 'b'savvy political strategy'b'; 'b'a recent survey conducted by Chapman University'b' found that nearly a quarter of Americans have voted for a political candidate out of fear. And reading the subject lines of some 'b'fund-raising emails'b', you\xe2\x80\x99d think a $3 donation was the one thing standing between your favored candidate and his or her certain death.'b'When we allow one bad actor to color our entire opinion of a sweeping policy, be it furlough programs or sanctuary cities, that\xe2\x80\x99s an example of the fear fallacy grinding into motion. We have a tendency to let our fears outweigh the level of risk they represent. And come election season, we see those fears laid bare, in a 60-second television spot.'b'In 1997, Michael Wayne Haley was arrested after stealing a calculator from Walmart. This was a crime that merited a maximum two-year prison term. But prosecutors incorrectly applied a habitual offender law. Neither the judge nor the defense lawyer caught the error and Haley was sentenced to 16 years.'b'Eventually, the mistake came to light and Haley tried to fix it. Ted Cruz was solicitor general of Texas at the time. Instead of just letting Haley go for time served, Cruz took the 'b'case to the Supreme Court'b' to keep Haley in prison for the full 16 years.'b'Some justices were skeptical. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there some rule that you can\xe2\x80\x99t confess error in your state?\xe2\x80\x9d Justice 'b'Anthony Kennedy asked'b'. The court system did finally let Haley out of prison, after six years.'b'The case reveals something interesting about Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s character. Ted Cruz is now running strongly among evangelical voters, especially in Iowa. But in his career and public presentation Cruz is a stranger to most of what would generally be considered the Christian virtues: humility, mercy, compassion and grace. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s behavior in the Haley case is almost the dictionary definition of pharisaism: an overzealous application of the letter of the law in a way that violates the spirit of the law, as well as fairness and mercy.'b'Traditionally, candidates who have attracted strong evangelical support have in part emphasized the need to lend a helping hand to the economically stressed and the least fortunate among us. Such candidates include George W. Bush, Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum.'b'But Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s speeches are marked by what you might call pagan brutalism. There is not a hint of compassion, gentleness and mercy. Instead, his speeches are marked by a long list of enemies, and vows to crush, shred, destroy, bomb them. When he is speaking in a church the contrast between the setting and the emotional tone he sets is jarring.'b'Cruz lays down an atmosphere of apocalyptic fear. America is heading off \xe2\x80\x9c'b'the cliff to oblivion'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d After one Democratic debate 'b'he said'b', \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re seeing our freedoms taken away every day, and last night was an audition for who would wear the jackboot most vigorously.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the Republican strategist 'b'Curt Anderson observed'b' in Politico, there\xe2\x80\x99s no variation in Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s rhetorical tone. As is the wont of inauthentic speakers, everything is described as a maximum existential threat.'b'The fact is this apocalyptic diagnosis is ridiculous. The Obama administration has done things people like me strongly disagree with. But America is in better economic shape than any other major nation on earth. Crime is down. Abortion rates are down. Fourteen million new jobs have been created in five years.'b'Obama has championed a liberal agenda, but he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t made the country unrecognizable. In 2008, federal spending accounted for about 20.3 percent of gross domestic product. In 2015, it accounted for about 20.9 percent.'b'But Cruz manufactures an atmosphere of menace in which there is no room for compassion, for moderation, for anything but dismantling and counterattack. And that is what he offers. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s programmatic agenda, to the extent that it exists in his speeches, is to destroy things: destroy the I.R.S., crush the \xe2\x80\x9cjackals\xe2\x80\x9d of the E.P.A., end funding for Planned Parenthood, reverse Obama\xe2\x80\x99s executive orders, make the desert glow in Syria, destroy the Iran nuclear accord.'b'Some of these positions I agree with, but the lack of any positive emphasis, any hint of reform conservatism, any aid for the working class, or even any humane gesture toward cooperation is striking.'b'Ted Cruz didn\xe2\x80\x99t come up with this hard, combative and gladiatorial campaign approach in isolation. He\xe2\x80\x99s always demonstrated a tendency to bend his position \xe2\x80\x94 whether immigration or trade \xe2\x80\x94 to what suits him politically. This approach works because in the wake of the Obergefell v. Hodges court decision on same-sex marriage, many evangelicals feel they are being turned into pariahs in their own nation.'b'Cruz exploits and exaggerates that fear. But he reacts to Obergefell in exactly the alienating and combative manner that is destined to further marginalize evangelicals, that is guaranteed to bring out fear-driven reactions and not the movement\xe2\x80\x99s highest ideals.'b'The best conservatism balances support for free markets with a Judeo-Christian spirit of charity, compassion and solidarity. Cruz replaces this spirit with Spartan belligerence. He sows bitterness, influences his followers to lose all sense of proportion and teaches them to answer hate with hate. This Trump-Cruz conservatism looks more like tribal, blood and soil European conservatism than the pluralistic American kind.'b'Evangelicals and other conservatives have had their best influence on American politics when they have proceeded in a spirit of personalism \xe2\x80\x94 when they have answered hostility with service and emphasized the infinite dignity of each person. They have won elections as happy and hopeful warriors. Ted Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s brutal, fear-driven, apocalypse-based approach is the antithesis of that.'b'It has been distressing these past weeks to watch Poland, long the poster child of Eastern European states that shed the Kremlin\xe2\x80\x99s suffocating embrace, adopting dictatorial measures of its own, not least a right-wing, nationalistic assault on the country\xe2\x80\x99s media and judiciary. The European Commission is scheduled to examine possible sanctions on Wednesday, but it is unlikely to take any, in part because Hungary and other governments sympathetic to Poland would veto them and also because they would serve only to deepen Warsaw\xe2\x80\x99s hostility to the European Union.'b'Nonetheless, it should be made clear to the Polish government that its 'b'retreat'b' from the fundamental values of liberal democracy is reprehensible and foolish.'b'Since its victory in national elections in late October, the nationalistic, euroskeptic Law and Justice Party led by the former prime minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski has moved rapidly on 'b'its conservative agenda'b', packing the highest court with malleable judges, reducing the court\xe2\x80\x99s ability to block legislation, imposing greater government 'b'control'b' over the state-owned media, choosing a party stalwart previously convicted of abusing power to oversee the police and intelligence agencies and purging European Union flags from government press briefings.'b'This rightward swing, which mimics the politics of Mr. Kaczynski\xe2\x80\x99s friend, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, has inspired grumbling in the bloc about the way former Soviet vassals rushed to join the union and tap into its largess only to turn against its core values. Poland\xe2\x80\x99s shift is all the more frustrating because the Law and Order Party already had a crack at power under Mr. Kaczynski and his twin, Lech Kaczynski,'b''b' 10 years earlier, only to be ousted after two tumultuous years.'b'But however deplorable Poland\xe2\x80\x99s politics may be, they also reflect the enormous difficulties East Europeans have faced in assimilating the free-market economics and social liberties of Western societies from which they were forcibly separated for decades. Those challenges have been compounded by the sense of injustice that East Europeans feel at lagging, even now, well behind their Western neighbors in living standards.'b'These grievances are not unique to East Europe. Liberal democracy and its institutions elsewhere in Europe (and even, to some extent, in the United States) have been threatened by people frightened by the influx of large numbers of refugees and by economic uncertainty. Poland\xe2\x80\x99s Law and Justice Party is only one of many such reactionary movements that have cropped up in mature democracies.'b'The problem is that Mr. Kaczynski, and others who similarly perceive the European Union or the institutions of liberal democracy as a threat to their way of life, fail to understand that a union of shared values and liberties, and independent institutions to safeguard them, is the surest defense against the sort of dictatorship they endured under Communism.'b'Punishing Poland through sanctions would be counterproductive and even hypocritical, given the proliferation of like-minded parties across Europe. But that does not preclude European Union leaders from making clear to the Poles that Mr. Kaczynski\xe2\x80\x99s politics are a damaging deviation from the democracy Poland so ardently embraced 25 years ago.'b'Since the early 1970s, the right has conducted a sustained drive to gain power and set policy in the 50 states. The left, by contrast, has been far less effective at the state-level.'b'The sustained determination on the part of the conservative movement has paid off in an unprecedented realignment of power in state governments.'b'Seven years ago, 'b'Democrats had 'b'a commanding lead in state legislatures, controlling both legislative chambers in 27 states, nearly double the 14 controlled by Republicans. They held 4082 state senate and house seats, compared to the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 3223.'b'Sweeping Republican victories at the state level in 2010 and 2014 transformed the political landscape.'b'By 2015, there were 'b'Republican majorities'b' in 70 percent \xe2\x80\x94 68 of 98 \xe2\x80\x94 of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s partisan state houses and senates, the highest number 'b'in the party\xe2\x80\x99s history.'b' (Nebraska isn\xe2\x80\x99t counted in because it has a non-partisan, unicameral legislature.) Republicans controlled the legislature and governorship in 23 states, more than triple the seven under full Democratic control.'b'What drove the right to invest so heavily at the state and local level, while the left fell behind?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe civil rights movement taught the left the lesson that one could win in \xe2\x80\x98one fell swoop\xe2\x80\x99 by going for national level changes,\xe2\x80\x9d Frank Baumgartner, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina, wrote me in an email. Baumgartner\xe2\x80\x99s view was echoed by a number of other scholars I contacted.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt comes purely from a strategic political calculus,\xe2\x80\x9d according to Thad Kousser, a professor of political science at the University of California, San Diego:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s changed seems to be the result of the relatively recent nationalization of state campaign financing,\xe2\x80\x9d Morgan Kousser, a professor of history at Caltech (and, as it happens, Thad Kousser\xe2\x80\x99s father), wrote in an email:'b'Liberal foundations, in the view of Lee Drutman, a senior fellow at the 'b'New America'b' foundation,'b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'How the Right Trounced Liberals in the States'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Alexander Hertel-Fernandez and Theda Skocpol, in the Winter edition of the journal 'b'Democracy'b', documents the failure of the left to keep pace with the substantial investments by the right in building local organizations.'b'Liberals, according to Hertel-Fernandez, a graduate student at Harvard, and Skocpol, a professor of government and sociology there, \xe2\x80\x9chave left behind little more than a litany of abandoned acronyms.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The authors provide several examples of such failures: The National Conference on Alternative State and Local Policies \xe2\x80\x9cfaded and by the 1980s, CASLP\xe2\x80\x99s founder had moved on to other projects.\xe2\x80\x9d The Center for Policy Alternatives \xe2\x80\x9cclosed its doors in 2008.\xe2\x80\x9d The Progressive States Network \xe2\x80\x9cnever reached the levels attained by\xe2\x80\x9d its conservative counterparts. They go on to note that left initiatives have lost traction'b'Why do trends at the local level contrast with trends at the national level, where Democrats have made substantial gains in the competition for political money?'b'Sixteen years ago, in 2000, the Republican National, Senatorial and Congressional Committees outraised their Democratic counterparts 'b'by nearly $300 million'b', $923 million to $631 million. George W. Bush spent $172.1 million to Al Gore\xe2\x80\x99s $127.1 million.'b'Four years ago, in 2012, the 'b'Democratic national committees raised'b' $1.07 billion to the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 $1.02 billion. The 'b'Obama'b' campaign spent $632 million to Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s $389 million.'b'Away from the national level, the commitment of conservative donors to support a power shift in state government illustrates the determination of the right to eliminate regulatory and legal constraints on markets where their money has proven most productive.'b'Attempts to control the White House have become far more risky with the rise of a strong Democratic presidential coalition. In 2012, conservative groups 'b'put $700 million in a bid to win the presidency'b', two and a half times as much as liberal groups, but Obama still won decisively.'b'The states, it turns out, are more receptive to the drive of the Koch Companies and their corporate allies to protect their business interests.'b''b'The Koch brothers\xe2\x80\x99 have invested in such 'b'state-regulated areas as refining, chemicals, biofuels and ingredients; forest products; fertilizers; polymers and fibers. For the extractive industries, in particular, along with chemical, pharmaceutical, and lumber concerns, Republican-led deregulatory efforts can increase profits.'b'Wealthy liberal donors, on the other hand, are driven by ideological convictions that can be volatile and vulnerable, as Hertel-Fernandez and Skocpol put it, \xe2\x80\x9cto shifting donor fashions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In addition, investing in such national liberal causes as refugee resettlement, climate change, gay marriage, and voting rights has the appeal of participation on a high visibility issue \xe2\x80\x94 with the likelihood of public acclaim. Investing in state organizations provides far fewer public rewards.'b'The willingness of conservatives to weather difficulty and to endure prolonged delay has been demonstrated repeatedly over the past decades.'b'In 1973, as the Watergate scandal was closing in on the Nixon administration, conservatives financed the creation of two institutions: the 'b'Heritage Foundation'b' to counter the left on national policy, and the 'b'American Legislative Exchange Council'b' (ALEC) to foster state-based conservative lobbies, interest groups and foundations.'b'There was no short term advantage. 'b'In 1974'b', Republicans lost 48 seats in the House and four in the Senate. Republicans also 'b'lost over 700 seats in state legislatures'b', leaving them at their lowest level since 1938. After the election of Jimmy Carter in 1976, Democrats were back in power in Washington.'b'Conservative donors were undaunted. ALEC and Heritage continued to grow. When the right came back in full force in the election of 1980, Heritage was ready 'b'to offer a guiding hand'b'. Once Ronald Reagan took office, the Heritage Foundation\xe2\x80\x99s legislative blueprint, \xe2\x80\x9cMandate for Leadership,\xe2\x80\x9d became the Reagan administration\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'policy bible'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The elections of 2006 and 2008, in turn, were interpreted as sounding the death knell for conservatism. \xe2\x80\x9cThe new Democratic majority assembled by Obama represents the emergence of a Great Society electoral coalition,\xe2\x80\x9dPhilip Klinkner and Thomas Schaller, political scientists at Hamilton and the University of Maryland\xe2\x80\x94Baltimore County, 'b'argued 'b' in the January 2009 edition of 'b'The Forum'b'.'b'Nonetheless, conservatives maintained their investment in building state-level infrastructure, not only in ALEC but in the 'b'State Policy Network'b' and the interlocking foundations created by 'b'Charles and David Koch'b'.'b'The total investment of the right in state and local organizations now reaches well into the hundreds of millions.'b'In 2013, ALEC had a relatively modest 'b'budget'b' of $7.3 million. That figure, however, distracts from a much larger investment by the right.'b'When the 'b'State Policy Network 'b'was founded in 1986, it had 12 affiliated state-based groups and a goal of creating an \xe2\x80\x9cinterstate freedom network\xe2\x80\x9d to spread \xe2\x80\x9cthe growth of freedom across America until a permanent freedom majority is built.\xe2\x80\x9d Today, there are 'b'one or more affiliated organizations'b' in every state.'b'An examination of IRS reports from all of these conservative groups shows total spending in just one year, 2013, of $142.2 million, with the Texas Public Policy Foundation\xe2\x80\x99s $8.9 million the largest expenditure.'b'The State Policy Network\xe2\x80\x99s single year total of $142.2 million is dwarfed by the network of foundations financed by Charles and David Koch and allied donors, individual and corporate.'b'The complex transactions between the foundations in the Koch Brothers network obscure the dollar amount of their investments in state and local organizations. But the Koch Companies\xe2\x80\x99 'b'June Quarterly Newsletter'b' notes that the Koch brothers \xe2\x80\x9chope to raise $889 million by the end of 2016, about two-thirds of which will help support research and education programs, scholarships and other efforts designed to change policies and promote a culture of freedom in the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When Republicans swept the House and Senate in 2010, the earlier investments paid off. ALEC, the State Policy Network and the Koch foundations had 'b' a ready-made conservative agenda'b' for newly empowered Republican legislators and governors, an agenda that has produced 'b'an upheaval'b' in environmental regulation, labor law, voting rights and reproductive rights.'b'Conservatives have some inherent advantages in building a state and local infrastructure.'b''b'Rob Stein'b', a founder of the 'b'Democracy Alliance'b' \xe2\x80\x94 a \xe2\x80\x9cpartnership\xe2\x80\x9d of liberal donors established in 2005 \xe2\x80\x94 pointed out in a phone interview that the right can tap into an embedded'b'Stein, who has worked in the field for decades, said that the result for conservatives is that'b'By comparison, Stein argued, \xe2\x80\x9cprogressives don\xe2\x80\x99t have these community based, indigenous resources to educate, organize and mobilize troops anymore.\xe2\x80\x9d With the exception of unions, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have fewer local places to gather and belong.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While organized labor remains influential in state elections, membership has 'b'collapsed to 6.6 percent in the private sector'b', and 'b'public sector unions'b' are under sustained assault. California Teachers Association'b'.'b'In 2004, major liberal donors 'b'financed two new national groups created specifically for the 2004 presidential election'b' \xe2\x80\x94 Americans Coming Together ($79,795,487) and the Joint Victory Committee ($71,811,666).'b'Despite the investment, the Democratic nominee, John Kerry, lost. At that point, the liberal donor community came to general agreement that the left needed a secure a permanent infrastructure at the national level to compete with such conservative institutions as the Chamber of Commerce, the American Enterprise Institute, Americans for Tax Reform and Heritage.'b'A year later, Democracy Alliance established its goal of building a \xe2\x80\x9cprogressive infrastructure that could help counter the well-funded and sophisticated conservative apparatus in the areas of civic engagement, leadership, media, and ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'At a national level, the alliance has played a significant role in the development of such groups as the 'b'Center for American Progress'b', a liberal think tank;'b' Catalist'b', which builds and maintains voter lists; and 'b'Media Matters'b', which seeks to document and discredit \xe2\x80\x9cconservative misinformation throughout the media.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Last year, the alliance initiated a program to direct a portion of members\xe2\x80\x99 contributions to state and local groups. I emailed Gara LaMarche, the president of the alliance, to ask how reliable alliance members are in continuing their support of relatively low-visibility state organizations. His answer:'b'LaMarche described the response as encouraging, noting that the alliance aims \xe2\x80\x9cto at least double the contributions to the funds in 2016.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'LaMarche voiced some confidence that \xe2\x80\x9cDA donors will stay the course.\xe2\x80\x9d He acknowledged that'b'During our conversation, Stein, who had helped start the organization, raised some doubts:'b'How, Stein asked, \xe2\x80\x9ccould we have lost that? How does a communitarian world view lose its communitarian sense of self?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The short answer to Stein\xe2\x80\x99s question may be that the nature of political liberalism has changed.'b'The liberalism of the 1930s and 1940s was shaped by the Great Depression, and the response was, in many respects, communitarian: the strengthening of unions, the provision of jobs and government benefits to the poor and unemployed and the creation of a safety net to provide a modicum of security.'b'The left has, in part, shifted focus, with more stress on the values of self-expression and self-fulfillment, on individual liberation from the constraints of traditional morality, especially sexual morality \xe2\x80\x94 what my colleague Ross Douthat calls \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Liberalism of Adult Autonomy'b'\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthe morality of rights.\xe2\x80\x9d Economic liberalism \xe2\x80\x93 despite progress on the minimum wage - has lost salience.'b'Instead of communitarian principles, the contemporary progressive movement \xe2\x80\x94 despite its advocacy of local issues like community policing \xe2\x80\x94 has produced a counterpart to conservative advocacy of free markets: the advocacy of personal freedom.'b'Insofar as liberals continue to leave the state-level organization to conservatives, they are conceding the most productive policy arenas in the country.'b'The federal government, currently immobilized by partisan division, is now incapable of enacting major new initiatives, left or right. The passage of Obamacare in 2010 was the last such initiative. States are the place where new programs and policies'b' are emerging'b' on an almost weekly basis.'b'As left interests are being cut out of this process, the 'b'groundbreaking work is being done'b' on the right. The losses for the Democratic Party and its allies include broken unions, defunded Planned Parenthood, lost wetlands and forests, restrictive abortion regulations and the proliferation of open-carry gun laws.'b'While the presidential race captures our attention \xe2\x80\x93 and as the left has withdrawn from low-level combat \xe2\x80\x94 conservatives have overseen the drawing of legislative and congressional districts that will keep Republicans in power over the next decade. In this way, through the 'b'most effective'b' 'b'gerrymandering'b' of legislative and congressional districts in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s history, the right has institutionalized a dangerous power vacuum on the left.'b'NEARLY 20 years ago, I was a social worker in a county jail where I first began to understand just how frequently the police deal with people with mental illnesses. Run-ins with the police were a regular occurrence for many of my clients, with officers often knowing them by name. They were overwhelmingly poor, and poor people with mental illnesses are also likely to experience homelessness and 'b'substance abuse'b' \xe2\x80\x94 issues that place them at increased risk of police contact and incarceration.'b'All too often, those interactions can end in violence and death, as was the case with 19-year-old Quintonio LeGrier, who was shot and killed by a Chicago police officer last month. Responding to a 911 call made by Mr. LeGrier\xe2\x80\x99s father, officers found Mr. LeGrier wielding a baseball bat, and one officer quickly opened fire.'b'This was not Mr. LeGrier\xe2\x80\x99s first encounter with law enforcement. He\xe2\x80\x99d had several confrontations with the police at the university he\xe2\x80\x99d attended in recent months \xe2\x80\x94 at least one of these incidents involved officers\xe2\x80\x99 guns being drawn. His experience bears a striking resemblance to that of one of my former clients who was a college student in the late 1990s and who had several tense exchanges with the police as his symptoms worsened.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable is that, even about 20 years later, the police remain the primary responders to 'b'mental health'b' crises like these. According to data compiled by The Washington Post, of nearly 1,000 people shot and killed by police officers in the United States in 2015, 'b'25 percent displayed signs of mental illness.'b' And about 14 percent of individuals in American jails and prisons have a serious mental illness, which means that, for most officers, interacting with individuals with mental illness is an almost daily occurrence.'b'There are two simultaneous national crises \xe2\x80\x94 one of police violence and the other of inadequate mental health treatment \xe2\x80\x94 and we are making a mistake if we focus blame only on the police. They have become, by default, the way in which our society chooses to deal with people with mental illness in crisis, particularly in poor and minority communities. We need also to address the declining state of mental health services across the country.'b'Right now, we are moving in the opposite direction. Between 2009 and 2011, Mr. LeGrier\xe2\x80\x99s home state, Illinois, 'b'eliminated more than $113'b' million in community mental health treatment services. In Chicago, the number of public mental health clinics was 'b'cut in half'b' \xe2\x80\x94 to 6 from 12 \xe2\x80\x94 in 2012 as a cost-saving measure. Illinois\xe2\x80\x99s path follows the 'b'national trend of funding cuts for mental health services'b'. And of course these cutbacks primarily affect people living in poverty, who are 'b'already at heightened risk'b' of suffering from mental illnesses.'b'So that leaves the police as our de facto front line. To date, the dominant police model has been the Crisis Intervention Team (C.I.T.), which provides training on responding to mental health emergencies. 'b'Current research is as yet inconclusive'b' on whether this training actually reduces the use of force, and police departments struggle with training and dispatching trained officers to the right calls. About 15 percent of Chicago police officers are C.I.T. trained, while experts recommend training for at least 25 percent.'b'But training alone will not solve the problem of police violence against people with mental illnesses. A few cities, 'b'like San Antonio'b', have made strides in building a better system by integrating mental health services with law enforcement. We need to invest more broadly in a mental health crisis system to work in conjunction with the police.'b'For example, in domestic disturbance cases like Mr. LeGrier\xe2\x80\x99s, a triage mental health worker could quickly gather pertinent information, assess risk of harm and engage family members as part of a coordinated effort. A crisis team could respond to the call, with police assistance if needed, to determine the safest and most clinically appropriate disposition. A responsive system would have suitable support available, such as a triage center or respite beds to provide urgent services, which would offer a clinically driven alternative to the more typical choices of jail, the emergency room or the morgue.'b'This is tricky terrain \xe2\x80\x94 even promising new approaches won\xe2\x80\x99t completely eliminate fraught interactions between the police and people with mental illnesses, or the chance of violence on either side. But they provide a wider and more fitting array of responses that could go a long way to averting future violence or incarceration. They certainly would have helped many of the clients I worked with in jail.'b'We also need to wrestle with our own complicated attitude toward people with mental illness. Mr. LeGrier\xe2\x80\x99s death is a rare case of national attention being paid to a person with mental illness being gunned down by the police, perhaps because a bystander, Bettie Jones, was also killed. Just 10 days after the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., and only a few miles away, a young man with mental illness named Kajieme Powell was fatally shot by the police in St. Louis. Mr. Brown\xe2\x80\x99s death incited widespread protests, but despite the fact that Mr. Powell\xe2\x80\x99s shooting was actually 'b'captured on video'b', his senseless death went largely unnoticed.'b'If we are to prevent future tragedies, then we should be ready to invest in a more responsive mental-health system and relieve the police of the burden of being the primary, and often sole, responders. For the sake of individuals like Quintonio LeGrier, Kajieme Powell and many of the clients I\xe2\x80\x99ve served, I hope we are.'b'LAST month, at the urging of Gov. 'b'Andrew M. Cuomo'b', New York\xe2\x80\x99s Board of Regents suspended the use of state tests to evaluate teachers. This is a wise first step, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t improve our schools unless we go further and build a professionalized system of support that views teachers as learners and challenges them to improve their classroom practices.'b'The national push over the last decade to strengthen how we evaluate teachers was rooted in studies that suggested that consecutive years with an ineffective teacher did lasting damage to a child\xe2\x80\x99s life chances. In response, many teachers\xe2\x80\x99 evaluations have been tied to how their students perform on state tests.'b'In 2010, New York began to develop a new teacher evaluation system, new tests and curriculums aligned with the Common Core standards. Most teachers agree that the standards are a step forward, because they ask students to think critically, write persuasively and solve real-world problems creatively. But New York\xe2\x80\x99s tests are still dominated by multiple-choice questions that don\xe2\x80\x99t measure this deeper learning. In many parts of the state, teachers did not have time to adapt their curriculums before new tests were used to evaluate them.'b'This created a crisis of confidence for parents, teachers and principals. Last year, an astonishing 20 percent of families opted out of the state exams. Parents worry that pressure to raise test scores makes school boring and stressful for their children. In many schools, there is still too much time spent on test prep, too much focus on students\xe2\x80\x99 weaknesses and not enough time for the in-depth learning the Common Core standards were meant to inspire.'b'Teachers don\xe2\x80\x99t trust the data being used to evaluate them. The evaluation system relies on tests designed for one task (measuring student learning) and uses them for another (measuring each teacher\xe2\x80\x99s impact). Good data is important but we have to use it for what it can actually tell us, not for what we wish it could tell us. Teachers regularly see margins of error of 25 points in the scores they receive based on their students\xe2\x80\x99 test results.'b'Even more troubling, the evaluation system has sent the message to principals that we don\xe2\x80\x99t trust their judgment. Principals are now required to follow a complex formula embedded in state law to arrive at teachers\xe2\x80\x99 ratings. If neither principals nor teachers trust the data in front of them, the process becomes a joke. In a system that was supposed to be more rigorous, fewer than 1 percent of teachers were rated ineffective last year.'b'In schools, the way adults learn always defines the way the students learn. Evaluations should have teeth, but that\xe2\x80\x99s not the mechanism that will put a strong teacher in every classroom. Schools need to nurture our students and our teachers.'b'How do we do this? We need to invest in teacher preparation and development. We hire thousands of new teachers every year, but many spend less than six weeks practicing as a student teacher and are never mentored by a strong educator before they start teaching.'b'High quality training for aspiring teachers would combine mastery of content and child development with a one-year residency alongside a master teacher. High-performing countries provide public funding to address this need. We need to make the same investment here.'b'We also need dedicated time weekly for teachers to meet in teams to improve their work. When teachers don\xe2\x80\x99t examine students\xe2\x80\x99 work together and discuss how to improve their teaching, they stop growing. When teachers stop growing, classrooms become dead zones where everyone is watching the clock. In contrast, when educators are actively learning with their colleagues, they understand their students more deeply, they hone lessons in response to their students\xe2\x80\x99 needs and they bring that lively thinking into their classrooms.'b'We must change the tests, too. Our current assessments still prioritize rote learning. If we want our children to use their minds well, our assessments must send a different signal to educators. Through the Smarter Balanced consortium, California and other states have developed assessments that adapt to students\xe2\x80\x99 levels and include assignments where students apply their knowledge to real-world problems. Here in New York, the state has granted waivers to a group of high schools where students defend research papers and scientific experiments in lieu of state exams. New York should examine both models closely before it spends millions more on new tests.'b'Finally, principals need the power to evaluate their teachers. It makes no sense to trust principals with the safety and educational future of children every day but refuse to allow them to fully supervise their teachers. School leaders need support to help teachers learn and the authority to act when teachers aren\xe2\x80\x99t succeeding. We must stop constraining them with rigid mandates.'b'We can\xe2\x80\x99t regulate our way to higher teacher quality, but we can teach our way there.'b'If you go to The Guardian\xe2\x80\x99s website these days you can find a section that is just 'b'labeled \xe2\x80\x9cProtest.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' So now, with your morning coffee, you can get your news, weather, sports \xe2\x80\x94 and protests. I found stories there headlined, \xe2\x80\x9cFive Fresh Ideas for the Street Art Agitator in 2016,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cMuslim Woman Ejected From Donald Trump Rally After Silent Protest\xe2\x80\x9d and, appropriately, \xe2\x80\x9cWe Are Living in an Age of Protest.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We sure are. This week alone Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany faced huge protests after her justice minister declared that Arab immigrants \xe2\x80\x94 let in under Merkel\xe2\x80\x99s liberal refugee policy \xe2\x80\x94 were largely responsible for the mass sexual assaults on women in Cologne on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve and used social networks to coordinate their attacks. President Obama actually cried \xe2\x80\x94 that was his unique protest \xe2\x80\x94 while trying to channel his outrage, and many other people\xe2\x80\x99s, into fixing our nation\xe2\x80\x99s crazy gun laws.'b'In my view, this age of protest is driven, in part, by the fact that the three largest forces on the planet \xe2\x80\x94 globalization, Moore\xe2\x80\x99s law and Mother Nature \xe2\x80\x94 are all in acceleration, creating an engine of disruption that is stressing strong countries and middle classes and blowing up weak ones, while superempowering individuals and transforming the nature of work, leadership and government all at once.'b'When you get that much agitation in a world where everyone with a smartphone is now a reporter, news photographer and documentary filmmaker, it\xe2\x80\x99s a wonder that every newspaper doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a \xe2\x80\x9cProtest\xe2\x80\x9d section.'b'I asked 'b'Dov Seidman'b', the author of the 'b'book \xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x9d'b' and C.E.O. of LRN, which advises companies all over the world on leadership and how to build ethical cultures, for his take on this age of protest.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPeople everywhere seem to be morally aroused,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seidman. \xe2\x80\x9cThe philosopher David Hume argued that \xe2\x80\x98the moral imagination diminishes with distance.\xe2\x80\x99 It would follow that the opposite is also true: As distance decreases, the moral imagination increases. Now that we have no distance \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s like we\xe2\x80\x99re all in a crowded theater, making everything personal \xe2\x80\x94 we are experiencing the aspirations, hopes, frustrations, plights of others in direct and visceral ways.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed, we\xe2\x80\x99re being intimately exposed to footage of outrageous police brutality, terrorism victims jumping from the windows of a Paris theater and racially biased/sexist corporate emails revealed by hackers. Who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be aroused?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThink about this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seidman: \xe2\x80\x9cA dentist from Minnesota shoots a cherished lion in Zimbabwe named Cecil, and days later everyone in the world knows about it, triggering a tsunami of moral outrage on Twitter and Facebook. As a result, some people try to shut down his dental practice by posting negative reviews on Yelp and spray paint \xe2\x80\x98Lion Killer\xe2\x80\x99 on his Florida vacation home. Almost 400,000 people then sign a petition in one day on Change.org demanding that Delta Air Lines change their policy of transporting trophy kills. Delta does so and other airlines follow. And then hunters who contribute to Zimbabwe\xe2\x80\x99s tourism industry protest the protest, claiming that they were being discriminated against.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That we are becoming more morally aroused \xe2\x80\x9cis generally a good thing,\xe2\x80\x9d argued Seidman. Institutionalized racism in police departments, or in college fraternities, is real and had been tolerated for way too long. That it\xe2\x80\x99s being called out is a sign of a society\xe2\x80\x99s health \xe2\x80\x9cand re-engagement.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But when moral arousal manifests as moral outrage, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cit can either inspire or repress a serious conversation or the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d There is surely a connection between the explosion of political correctness on college campuses \xe2\x80\x94 including Yale students demanding the resignation of an administrator whose wife defended free speech norms that might make some students uncomfortable \xe2\x80\x94 and the ovations Donald Trump is getting for being crudely politically incorrect.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf moral outrage, as justified as it may be, is followed immediately by demands for firings or resignations,\xe2\x80\x9d argued Seidman, \xe2\x80\x9cit can result in a vicious cycle of moral outrage being met with equal outrage, as opposed to a virtuous cycle of dialogue and the hard work of forging real understanding and enduring agreements.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Furthermore, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen moral outrage skips over moral conversation, then the outcome is likely going to be acquiescence, not inspired solutions,\xe2\x80\x9d Seidman added. It can also feed the current epidemic of inauthentic apologies, \xe2\x80\x9csince apologies extracted under pressure are like telling a child, `Just say you\xe2\x80\x99re sorry,\xe2\x80\x99 to move past the issue without ever making amends.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'With all of this moral arousal, it\xe2\x80\x99s as if \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99re living in a never-ending storm,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Alas, though, resolving moral disputes \xe2\x80\x9crequires perspective, fuller context and the ability to make meaningful distinctions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That requires leaders with the courage and empathy \xe2\x80\x9cto inspire people to pause to reflect, so that instead of reacting by yelling in 140 characters they can channel all this moral outrage into deep and honest conversations.\xe2\x80\x9d If we can do that \xe2\x80\x94 a big if \xe2\x80\x94 Seidman concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can be truly great again because we\xe2\x80\x99ll be back on our journey towards a more perfect union.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For a mayor happy to boast about his city\xe2\x80\x99s record low crime rates, Bill de Blasio has spent a lot of time lately talking about gun violence. Gun court starts from a different premise, explained recently by Police Commissioner William Bratton: \xe2\x80\x9cThey need to be treated with every ounce of justice system that we can apply to them, to basically get them off the streets and keep them away from us.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x9d being repeat offenders, often young men in street gangs, who are relatively few in number but blamed by the police for most gun violence. Justice was seen as slow, inefficient and inconsistent.'b'Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s revived plan, an aide said, has the same motives: \xe2\x80\x9cto identify the strongest cases out of the gate\xe2\x80\x9d and to send them to two judges in two courtrooms in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. This violated the Sixth Amendment\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'guarantee'b' of a jury trial \xe2\x80\x94 specifically, that any fact that makes a person eligible for death must be determined by a jury. \xe2\x80\x9cA jury\xe2\x80\x99s mere recommendation is not enough,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Sotomayor wrote.'b'The defendant in 'b'the case'b', Timothy Lee Hurst, was convicted of murdering a co-worker, Cynthia Harrison, in 1998. Arizona'b', which held that only juries may make the factual findings that expose a person to execution. In a 'b'1999 case'b','b''b' the court called trials by jury \xe2\x80\x9cthe grand bulwark\xe2\x80\x9d of liberty, quoting William Blackstone, the 18th-century British jurist whose treatises are a foundation of American law. Meah, Pearland, Tex.'b''b'BEIJING \xe2\x80\x94 In 2010, I moved onto the 11th floor of a new Beijing apartment complex, lured into paying tens of thousands of extra renminbi by the promise of rare, unobstructed views. But over the past two years, Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s worsening smog has wrapped my apartment in a permanent haze. I envy the people living on the lower floors of what\xe2\x80\x99s called the Horizon Apartment Complex \xe2\x80\x94 at least they still see the trees and pedestrians outside. All I see is a gloomy, unhealthy fog. When the smog has been at its worst in recent weeks, no one in my family dared to venture outside.'b'Unfettered views of the horizon were possible five years ago because the complex is in a neighborhood on the edge of Beijing near an airport flight path, a swath of protected areas of farmland and villages where the government strictly controls land from being sold to developers. Residents are attracted to these parts by traditional rural scenes \xe2\x80\x94 fields, tree-lined roads, flowers and birds.'b'The cheap housing in villages like this one on the capital\xe2\x80\x99s outskirts has attracted high numbers of migrant workers who have come to the city from all parts of 'b'China'b' to work in factories. As a result, once-spacious courtyard homes are now divided into smaller crammed houses or sheds that are rented out cheaply to poor migrant workers. The city\xe2\x80\x99s outlying villages are big and growing.'b'I often see smoke rising up from these neighborhoods. At a distance, it can look as though the whole neighborhood is on fire. Only as I get closer can I make out the columns of smoke billowing from individual homes.'b'Last month, as Beijing was going through one of its worst ever spells of pollution, the government issued a report ranking domestic coal burning \xe2\x80\x94 for household cooking, heating stoves and water boilers \xe2\x80\x94 as the primary source of the city\xe2\x80\x99s pollution. But the report was only an official reminder of what we Beijingers have known for a long time.'b'As far back as 2000, in an attempt to reduce coal pollution, the government unveiled a plan to replace coal-fired boilers and cooking stoves with electric heating by subsidizing the conversion to electric appliances and electricity rates. Yet 16 years on, only some 310,000 homes in central Beijing have clean heat. This is a small number considering the central district covers an area that\xe2\x80\x99s less than 5 percent of Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s total area and accounts for just a tenth of Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s total population.'b'Without government subsidies, the mostly poorer residents living in Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s outskirts cannot afford to convert to electric appliances. For those who can scrape together enough money to buy an electric stove or heater, high electric bills are another deterrent.'b'Why does the government fail to act? One problem is skewed incentives. A main source of government and private wealth is the state\xe2\x80\x99s sale of village land to real estate developers. With Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s rapid population growth \xe2\x80\x94 from around 11 million in 2000 to 21.5 million in 2014 \xe2\x80\x94 and soaring housing prices, government officials have a financial incentive to move peasants and migrants from these townships in order to sell the land.'b'Razing villages to make room for expensive high-rise apartments will temporarily stop migrants from using coal, of course, but they end up just moving to other peripheral villages, where they use more coal. The government is reluctant to invest in these outlying villages because they\xe2\x80\x99re going to be demolished anyway. In addition, improved infrastructure could spur villagers to demand higher compensation for relocation when the time comes to sell the land for new development.'b'Thus, the problem is the result of an interplay of the real estate market, greedy officials and the rapid urbanization of cities like Beijing.'b'As a temporary measure to improve air quality, the government has encouraged residents to switch from cheap, untreated smoky coal to smokeless coal with lower sulfate emissions. But smokeless coal is still coal. And many continue to use untreated coal, which scientists say discharges 10 times more pollutants than electric power plants.'b'China has made impressive strides in cutting coal emissions, with coal consumption down more than 5 percent in 2015, compared with a close to 3 percent decrease in 2014. Still, we are shunning coal at a much slower rate than many other developing nations. Not only do we still consume an annual four billion tons of coal, accounting for half the world total, our national target to limit the use of coal to no more than 65 percent of total energy consumption by 2017 also falls short when you consider that the world average already stands at just 40 percent.'b'In Beijing, replacing coal-fired boilers with electric heating systems has been proven an effective way of tackling air pollution in the city center. In November, the government expanded the program to an additional 74,000 households in a few select suburban counties. But it\xe2\x80\x99s far from enough. It only makes sense to roll out the same benefits to all people living in the villages on Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s periphery, so that they too can enjoy the advantages of electric heating \xe2\x80\x94 and so the whole city can breathe better air.'b'When the plan to subsidize electric appliances and electricity rates was first introduced 16 years ago, China was a poorer nation with shortages of electricity. Today we have surplus electricity, surplus construction materials and plentiful labor due to slower economic growth. Meanwhile, the price of coal has declined sharply over the past two years and yet the government has not reduced the price of electricity. If our government could only let market forces determine electricity rates, and stop prioritizing the demolition of Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s rural villages, and instead oversee their rapid shift to electric heating, we could achieve both stable growth and a cleaner environment at the same time.'b'In the early phase of the Communist revolution, Mao Zedong advocated starting his ideological crusade in the villages before moving into the cities. That might be a lesson for the nation\xe2\x80\x99s current leaders: Start a Green Revolution in the villages.'b'Sofia, Bulgaria \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cVLADIMIR VLADIMIROVICH, is war coming?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The question is asked in the first frame of \xe2\x80\x9cMyroporyadok\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cWorld Order\xe2\x80\x9d), a manifesto-style documentary aired in the last days of December on Russian state television.
