There\xe2\x80\x99s an inescapable he-said/she-said dynamic, but one need not be a \xe2\x80\x9cbelieve all rape allegations\xe2\x80\x9d absolutist to find her claim persuasive.'b'If she\xe2\x80\x99s telling the truth, then Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s sexual past becomes something more predatory. The slippage between a powerful man\xe2\x80\x99s dalliances and straightforward predation is something that 'b'could'b' happen just once. But looked at in the light of a credible rape allegation, there are all sorts of Clinton stories \xe2\x80\x94 the Willey and Jones cases, the rumors collected by Jones\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers, the old tales of state troopers being used as procurers, the 2002 globetrotting on the jet of a billionaire who\xe2\x80\x99s also a convicted statutory rapist \xe2\x80\x94 that could suggest a darker pattern, tending toward the Cosby-esque.'b'The truth about Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s past, then, is that we don\xe2\x80\x99t actually know the truth. And even in our tabloid-driven age, it\xe2\x80\x99s quite possible that we simply never will.'b'But if the question is, \xe2\x80\x9cDoes Bill\xe2\x80\x99s past matter for Hillary\xe2\x80\x99s campaign?,\xe2\x80\x9d the answer depends less on what we know right now than on what might be waiting to come out.'b'LAST fall, as student activists around the country protested racism on their campuses, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas 'b'dismissed'b' secular universities as havens for \xe2\x80\x9cleftist, coddled kids.\xe2\x80\x9d The protests proved that these schools teem with \xe2\x80\x9cpsychotic Marxists,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'declared'b' \xe2\x80\x9cThe Daily Caller,\xe2\x80\x9d a conservative website.'b'When conservative Christians map the culture wars, they cast secular universities to the far left periphery \xe2\x80\x94 the region that medieval cartographers would have marked \xe2\x80\x9chere be dragons.\xe2\x80\x9d A cottage industry of books with titles like \xe2\x80\x9c'b'How to Stay Christian in College'b'\xe2\x80\x9d has long warned pious 18-year-olds that college is a place where the \xe2\x80\x9cPrince of Deception\xe2\x80\x9d will set \xe2\x80\x9cspiritual snares.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'American evangelicals have a venerable tradition of painting the ivory tower as the bastion of unbelief and leftist ideology. As mainstream culture becomes more diverse and moves further away from traditional Christian teachings on matters like sexuality, we might expect evangelical students on elite secular campuses to feel more embattled than ever. Yet that\xe2\x80\x99s not what I found when I spoke to a range of students and recent graduates.'b'Contrary to conservatives\xe2\x80\x99 warnings about the oppressive secularism of the modern university, these students have taken advantage of their campuses\xe2\x80\x99 multicultural marketplace of ideas. They have created a network of organizations and journals that engage non-Christian ideologies head-on. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that many schools\xe2\x80\x99 nondiscrimination policies have made life more difficult for Christian ministries that require student leaders to assent to a statement of faith. But some students have seized on this challenge as an opportunity.'b'Since 2010, when the Supreme Court upheld a policy at the University of California, Hastings College of the Law that requires student groups to accept all students regardless of their beliefs, several universities have 'b'stripped'b' InterVarsity Christian Fellowship and other Christian groups of their status as recognized campus organizations. At Vanderbilt, Bowdoin and other schools, the groups lost access to campus space, student fees and activity fairs \xe2\x80\x94 on the grounds that requiring student leaders to affirm a statement of faith violated the schools\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9call comers\xe2\x80\x9d policy. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat our students have said is that it\xe2\x80\x99s clear the administration doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want us here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Greg Jao, InterVarsity\xe2\x80\x99s director of campus engagement.'b'Yet 'b'some'b' evangelicals have poured their energies into a different sort of Christian organization, one that has been proliferating quietly for decades at universities around the country: Christian study centers. These are not ministries, exactly, and what they do is not old-fashioned evangelism. Typically they occupy private buildings off campus and exist independently from the university, beyond the reach of nondiscrimination policies. The first study centers appeared in the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s, but their numbers have mushroomed since 2000. The Consortium of Christian Study Centers 'b'counts'b' 20 members \xe2\x80\x94 a small but significant number considering that many are embedded in the most prestigious universities around the country.'b'The centers position themselves as forums where students can hash out the tensions between their faith and the assumptions of secular academia \xe2\x80\x94 the same assumptions that have assailed more traditional ministries. They are, in a sense, spiritual \xe2\x80\x9csafe spaces\xe2\x80\x9d that offer cozy 'b'libraries'b', reading groups and public lectures, and sometimes advertise their ethos with names that honor Christian intellectuals who embraced the life of the mind (Chesterton House at Cornell is named for the English writer and lay theologian; Rivendell Institute at Yale evokes the world of J.R.R. Tolkien\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLord of the Rings\xe2\x80\x9d trilogy, which many Christians read as a subtle tribute to its author\xe2\x80\x99s faith).'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe overall message is that the Christian faith is a viable thing in the world we live in, that it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to live faithfully and think hard about whatever topic we\xe2\x80\x99re discussing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jay McCabe, a staff member at the Center for Christian Study at the University of Virginia.'b'Undergraduate journals of Christian thought, publications like the Harvard Ichthus and The Logos at Yale, have also multiplied on elite campuses in recent years. When Andrew Schuman arrived at Dartmouth in 2006, he and some like-minded freshmen founded Apologia, a semiannual journal that 'b'aims'b' \xe2\x80\x9cto think critically, question honestly, and link arms with anyone who searches for truth and authenticity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA lot of students who weren\xe2\x80\x99t Christian were excited by its appearance,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Schuman told me. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of us have spiritual questions, but we\xe2\x80\x99re uncertain how to ask them. The journal draws on a millennia-old tradition of faith and reason to give a vocabulary for those questions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The staff and students involved in these study centers and journals position themselves not as evangelists, but as conveners of a conversation meant to grapple with the ideological divides that secular liberalism\xe2\x80\x99s mantra of tolerance so often elides: How do people with clashing assumptions about what is real and good communicate and coexist?'b'To Philip Jeffery, a junior at Columbia, this question is at the heart of the recent wave of student activism \xe2\x80\x94 although he says older observers rarely seem to understand. \xe2\x80\x9cI keep seeing these articles about \xe2\x80\x98coddling,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you ask the question, what are the assumptions about human nature that are driving these things, you realize it\xe2\x80\x99s more than people wanting a safe space to talk about trigger warnings.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Jeffery has tried to bring those conflicting assumptions to the surface of campus debate through Columbia\xe2\x80\x99s Christian journal Crown &amp; Cross as well as his work for the Veritas Forum, an international organization that sponsors Christian speakers and interfaith dialogue on college campuses.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe thing you\xe2\x80\x99ll run into with any of the campus activists that I\xe2\x80\x99ve encountered is this idea that human nature is a collection of identity categories, that I as a human being am composed of a gender identity, a sexual identity, a racial identity and so forth,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cTheir perception of Christians, or of religious people more generally, is: \xe2\x80\x98O.K., these are people who have this one identity category, religion, and the religion they identify as is overstepping its bounds. It\xe2\x80\x99s telling my gender or sexual identity how to act.\xe2\x80\x99 The Christian response has to be: There\xe2\x80\x99s something more to what a human being is than just these collective attributes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Most of the young evangelicals I spoke to had sympathy for the protests, and some had participated themselves. Today\xe2\x80\x99s evangelical students are all over the political map. Christian groups are often among the most racially diverse on campus \xe2\x80\x94 38 percent of InterVarsity members are nonwhite (another 14 percent are international students), and many local chapters are racially mixed. But they question the premises of secular identity politics, which they say is the lens that some university administrators mistakenly apply to religion.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVanderbilt didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand religious groups,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tish Harrison Warren, who worked for InterVarsity at Vanderbilt before events there led her to relocate to the University of Texas. \xe2\x80\x9cThey wanted to make us social groups, like fraternities who weirdly talk about Jesus, or service groups, or groups for the academic study of religion. But there is a proclamatory function. We are proclaiming a message to others.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIdentity politics\xe2\x80\x9d is shorthand for the left\xe2\x80\x99s effort to empower oppressed groups by elevating the authority of their experience as women, queer people or visible minorities. These identities are inborn or socially constructed (or both), depending on what kind of liberal you ask. But they often come with a tacit agreement to refrain from all but the most anodyne universal truth claims: to each identity her own.'b'Many religions \xe2\x80\x94 especially evangelical Christianity, which has a penchant for truth claims \xe2\x80\x94 are an awkward fit. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re realizing that the future of the university has to lie with something like a principled pluralism. Exactly how to do that? How should they accommodate freedom of expression for those who condemn homosexuality or otherwise dissent from liberal values? As evangelical students have watched the penalization of Christian ministries on the basis of policies, like 'b'Vanderbilt\xe2\x80\x99s'b', that explicitly include religion among the categories protected from discrimination, they have witnessed firsthand the contradictions and ambiguities of liberal ideology.'b'Today many evangelical leaders are fond of proclaiming American Christians\xe2\x80\x99 new status as a 'b'moral minority'b', but these students and campus ministers are the ones who are actually living that reality. It has prodded them to seek serious conversation about humans\xe2\x80\x99 profound disagreements over morality and the nature of truth \xe2\x80\x94 questions that campus liberals, despite their professed concern for dialogue and critical thinking, often avoid in the name of tolerance and inclusion.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe think it\xe2\x80\x99s more constructive to talk about differences,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Jeffery. Minority status sometimes has a funny way of turning people into more thoughtful critics of the culture around them.'b'FOR those of us who argue in favor of gun safety laws, there are a few inconvenient facts.'b'We liberals are sometimes glib about equating guns and danger. In fact, it\xe2\x80\x99s complicated: The number of guns in America has increased by more than 50 percent since 1993, and in that same period the gun homicide rate in the United States has dropped by half.'b'Then there are the policies that liberals fought for, starting with the assault weapons ban. A 'b'113-page study'b' found no clear indication that it reduced shooting deaths for the 10 years it was in effect. That\xe2\x80\x99s because the ban was poorly drafted, and because even before the ban, assault weapons accounted for only 2 percent of guns used in crimes.'b'Move on to open-carry and conceal-carry laws: With some 'b'13 million Americans now licensed'b' to pack a concealed gun, many liberals expected gun battles to be erupting all around us. In fact, the most rigorous analysis suggests that all these gun permits caused neither a drop in crime (as conservatives had predicted) nor a spike in killings (as liberals had expected). Liberals were closer to the truth, for the increase in carrying loaded guns does appear to have led to more aggravated assaults with guns, but the fears were overblown.'b'One of the puzzles of American politics is that most voters want gun regulation, but Congress resists. One poll found that 74 percent 'b'even of N.R.A. members'b' favor universal background checks to acquire a gun. Likewise, the 'b'latest New York Times poll'b' found that 62 percent of Americans approved of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s executive actions on guns this month.'b'So why does nothing get done? One reason is that liberals often inadvertently antagonize gun owners and empower the National Rifle Association by coming across as supercilious, condescending and spectacularly uninformed about the guns they propose to regulate. A classic of gun ignorance: New York passed a law three years ago banning gun magazines holding more than seven bullets \xe2\x80\x94 'b'without realizing'b' that for most guns there is no such thing as a magazine for seven bullets or less.'b'And every time liberals speak blithely about banning guns, they boost the N.R.A. Let\xe2\x80\x99s also banish the term \xe2\x80\x9cgun control\xe2\x80\x9d: the better expression is \xe2\x80\x9cgun safety.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet this, too, must be said: Americans are absolutely right to be outraged at the toll of guns. Just since 1970, 'b'more Americans have died'b' from guns than all the Americans who died in wars going back to the American Revolution (about 1.45 million vs. 1.4 million). That gun toll includes suicides, murders and accidents, and these days it amounts to 92 bodies a day.'b'We spend billions of dollars tackling terrorism, which killed 229 Americans worldwide from 2005 through 2014, according to the State Department. In the same 10 years, including suicides, some 310,000 Americans 'b'died from guns'b'.'b'So of course we should try to reduce this carnage. But we need a new strategy, a public health approach that treats guns as we do cars \xe2\x80\x94 taking evidence-based steps to make them safer. That seems to be what President Obama is trying to do.'b'Research suggests that the most important practical step would be to keep guns away from high-risk individuals, such as criminals, those who abuse alcohol, or those who beat up their domestic partners.'b'That means universal background checks before somebody acquires a gun. 'b'New Harvard research'b' confirms a long-ago finding that 40 percent of firearms in the United States are acquired without a background check. That\xe2\x80\x99s crazy. Why empower criminals to arm themselves?'b'Some evidence supports steps that seem common sense. 'b'More than 10 percent 'b' of murders in the United States, for example, are by intimate partners. The riskiest moment is often after a violent breakup when a woman has won a restraining order against her ex. Prohibiting the subjects of those restraining orders from possessing a gun reduces these murders by 10 percent, one study found.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf you can keep a gun from someone at that moment of threat, that is very important,\xe2\x80\x9d notes Daniel W. Let\xe2\x80\x99s make America\xe2\x80\x99s gun battles less ideological and more driven by evidence of what works. If the left can drop the sanctimony, and the right can drop the obstructionism, if instead of wrestling with each other we can grapple with the evidence, we can save thousands of lives a year.'b'IF your very candidacy and identity rest on your supposed talent for victory, can you survive a defeat?'b'Can you continue to call yourself a winner if you\xe2\x80\x99ve been a loser \xe2\x80\x94 and if \xe2\x80\x9closer\xe2\x80\x9d is your favorite way of closing the book on someone, your final word, the workhorse in your brimming lexicon of slurs, exiting your mouth so reflexively that it\xe2\x80\x99s essentially your exhalation, your carbon dioxide: \xe2\x80\x9closer,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9closer,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9closer.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Donald Trump has a problem that the other candidates for the Republican nomination don\xe2\x80\x99t. (Remember that laughable 'b'physician\xe2\x80\x99s report'b'?)'b'Neither his image nor his ego leaves any room for a setback, any allowance for second place. After all, he\xe2\x80\x99s winning!'b'But by that reasoning, losing wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be just a fluke, just a failure of the body politic to recognize and reward majesty when they behold it. It would destroy the brand\xe2\x80\x99s foundation.'b'His bid for the presidency is all triumphalism, all superlatives. It rejects any humility. It forbids any humbling \xe2\x80\x94 especially the first time that voting becomes actual instead of theoretical and Iowans crown a champ.'b'When he kicked off his campaign from the gilded throne of Trump Tower last June, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t merely say that he\xe2\x80\x99d create jobs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI will be the greatest jobs president that God ever created,\xe2\x80\x9d he decreed, emphasizing a divine patrimony.'b'On the day when he and his hair move into the White House, \xe2\x80\x9cunbelievable\xe2\x80\x9d blessings will rain down on this parched land of ours. They are always wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Except we weren\xe2\x80\x99t, not about this. A transcript and an audio recording of the meeting unequivocally demonstrate as much.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99re probably losers anyway. It\xe2\x80\x99s where the losers are rounded up and publicly flogged.'b'And his go-to arguments for why someone is a loser, a dope or a dummy is that he or she has made erroneous predictions or been repudiated by the ratings, the marketplace, the audience. How can Trump dismiss the precise kind of judgment and measurement with which 'b'he 'b'dismisses everyone else?'b'Lately he\xe2\x80\x99s started to hedge, alternating prophecies that he\xe2\x80\x99ll win Iowa with statements that he hopes to. I\xe2\x80\x99ll say.'b'For other candidates a loss is a part of the process, a prompt for self-examination, a cause for a reset and maybe an embarrassment. It\xe2\x80\x99s a middle seat in coach for a titan with his own planes \xe2\x80\x94 plural. (His own helicopters, too.) If he\xe2\x80\x99s wedged into it, he\xe2\x80\x99ll come unglued. I mean, more than he already has.'b'When he 'b'appeared'b' on the late-night talk show \xe2\x80\x9cJimmy Kimmel Live\xe2\x80\x9d last month, Kimmel teased him by claiming to have written a children\xe2\x80\x99s book for Trump. Its title? \xe2\x80\x9cWinners Aren\xe2\x80\x99t Losers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is my point, and this is Trump\xe2\x80\x99s pickle. If Iowa\xe2\x80\x99s voters don\xe2\x80\x99t swoon for him, it erases the whole gaudy prelude to that moment. He ceases to be the best, the most, the greatest. Trump will have been trumped, which means he\xe2\x80\x99s not the same Trump at all.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99M a climate scientist who has just been told I have Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.'b'This diagnosis puts me in an interesting position. I\xe2\x80\x99ve spent much of my professional life thinking about the science of 'b'climate change'b', which is best viewed through a multidecadal lens. At some level I was sure that, even at my present age of 60, I would live to see the most critical part of the problem, and its possible solutions, play out in my lifetime. Now that my personal horizon has been steeply foreshortened, I was forced to decide how to spend my remaining time. Was continuing to think about climate change worth the bother?'b'After handling the immediate business associated with the medical news \xe2\x80\x94 informing family, friends, work; tidying up some finances; putting out stacks of unread New York Times Book Reviews to recycle; and throwing a large \xe2\x80\x9cLimited Edition\xe2\x80\x9d holiday party, complete with butlers, I had some time to sit at my kitchen table and draw up the bucket list.'b'Very quickly, I found out that I had no desire to jostle with wealthy tourists on Mount Everest, or fight for some yardage on a beautiful and exclusive beach, or all those other things one toys with on a boring January afternoon. Instead, I concluded that all I really wanted to do was spend more time with the people I know and love, and get back to my office as quickly as possible.'b'I work for 'b'NASA'b', managing a large group of expert scientists doing research on the whole 'b'Earth'b' system (I should mention that the views in this article are my own, not NASA\xe2\x80\x99s). This involves studies of climate and weather using space-based observations and powerful computer models. These models describe how the planet works, and what can happen as we pump carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The work is complex, exacting, highly relevant and fascinating.'b'Last year was the warmest year on record, by far. I think that future generations will look back on 2015 as an important but not decisive year in the struggle to align politics and policy with science. This is an incredibly hard thing to do. On the science side, there has been a steady accumulation of evidence over the last 15 years that climate change is real and that its trajectory could lead us to a very uncomfortable, if not dangerous, place. On the policy side, the just-concluded climate conference in Paris set a goal of holding the increase in the global average temperature to 2 degrees Celsius, or 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, above preindustrial levels.'b'While many have mocked this accord as being toothless and unenforceable, it is noteworthy that the policy makers settled on a number that is based on the best science available and is within the predictive capability of our computer models.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful that we\xe2\x80\x99ll hold the line at 2 degrees Celsius, but we need to give it our best shot. With scenarios that exceed that target, we are talking about enormous changes in global precipitation and temperature patterns, huge impacts on water and food security, and significant sea level rise. As the predicted temperature rises, model uncertainty grows, increasing the likelihood of unforeseen, disastrous events.'b'All this as the world\xe2\x80\x99s population is expected to crest at around 9.5 billion by 2050 from the current seven billion. Pope Francis and a think tank of retired military officers have drawn roughly the same conclusion from computer model predictions: The worst impacts will be felt by the world\xe2\x80\x99s poorest, who are already under immense stress and have meager resources to help them adapt to the changes. They will see themselves as innocent victims of the developed world\xe2\x80\x99s excesses. Looking back, the causes of the 1789 French Revolution are not a mystery to historians; looking forward, the pressure cooker for increased radicalism, of all flavors, and conflict could get hotter along with the global temperature.'b'Last year may also be seen in hindsight as the year of the Death of Denial. Globally speaking, most policy makers now trust the scientific evidence and predictions, even as they grapple with ways to respond to the problem. And most Americans \xe2\x80\x94 70 percent, according to a recent 'b'Monmouth University poll'b' \xe2\x80\x94 believe that the climate is changing. So perhaps now we can move on to the really hard part of this whole business.'b'The initial heavy lifting will have to be done by policy makers. I feel for them. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to take a tough stand on an important but long-term issue in the face of so many near-term problems, amid worries that reducing emissions will weaken our global economic position and fears that other countries may cheat on their emissions targets.'b'Where science can help is to keep track of changes in the Earth system \xe2\x80\x94 this is a research and monitoring job, led by NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and their counterparts elsewhere in the world \xe2\x80\x94 and use our increasingly powerful computer models to explore possible futures associated with proposed policies. The models will help us decide which approaches are practicable, trading off near-term impacts to the economy against longer-term impacts to the climate.'b'Ultimately, though, it will be up to the engineers and industrialists of the world to save us. They must come up with the new technologies and the means of implementing them. The technical and organizational challenges of solving the problems of clean energy generation, storage and distribution are enormous, and they must be solved within a few decades with minimum disruption to the global economy. This will likely entail a major switch to nuclear, solar and other renewable power, with an electrification of our transport system to the maximum extent possible. These engineers and industrialists are fully up to the job, given the right incentives and investments. You have only to look at what they achieved during World War II: American technology and production catapulted over what would have taken decades to do under ordinary conditions and presented us with a world in 1945 that was completely different from the late 1930s.'b'What should the rest of us do? Two things come to mind. First, we should brace for change. It is inevitable. It will appear in changes to the climate and to the way we generate and use energy. Second, we should be prepared to absorb these with appropriate sang-froid. Some will be difficult to deal with, like rising seas, but many others could be positive. New technologies have a way of bettering our lives in ways we cannot anticipate. There is no convincing, demonstrated reason to believe that our evolving future will be worse than our present, assuming careful management of the challenges and risks. History is replete with examples of us humans getting out of tight spots. The winners tended to be realistic, pragmatic and flexible; the losers were often in denial of the threat.'b'As for me, I\xe2\x80\x99ve no complaints. I\xe2\x80\x99m very grateful for the experiences I\xe2\x80\x99ve had on this planet. As an astronaut I spacewalked 220 miles above the Earth. Floating alongside the International Space Station, I watched hurricanes cartwheel across oceans, the Amazon snake its way to the sea through a brilliant green carpet of forest, and gigantic nighttime thunderstorms flash and flare for hundreds of miles along the Equator. From this God\xe2\x80\x99s-eye-view, I saw how fragile and infinitely precious the Earth is. I\xe2\x80\x99m hopeful for its future.'b'And so, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to work tomorrow.'b'NORMALLY, I would have finished this column weeks ago. But I kept putting it off because my New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolution is to procrastinate more.'b'I guess I owe you an explanation. Sooner or later.'b'We think of procrastination as a curse. Over 80 percent of college students are 'b'plagued'b' by procrastination, requiring epic all-nighters to finish papers and prepare for tests. Roughly 20 percent of adults 'b'report'b' being chronic procrastinators. We can only guess how much higher the estimate would be if more of them got around to filling out the survey.'b'But while procrastination is a vice for productivity, I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned \xe2\x80\x94 against my natural inclinations \xe2\x80\x94 that it\xe2\x80\x99s a virtue for creativity.'b'For years, I believed that anything worth doing was worth doing early. In graduate school I submitted my dissertation two years in advance. In college, I wrote my papers weeks early and finished my thesis four months before the due date. My roommates joked that I had a productive form of obsessive-compulsive disorder. Psychologists have coined a term for my condition: 'b'pre-crastination'b'.'b'Pre-crastination is the urge to start a task immediately and finish it as soon as possible. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a serious pre-crastinator, progress is like oxygen and postponement is agony. When a flurry of emails land in your inbox and you don\xe2\x80\x99t answer them instantly, you feel as if your life is spinning out of control. When you have a speech to give next month, each day you don\xe2\x80\x99t work on it brings a creeping sense of emptiness, like a dementor is sucking the joy from the air around you (look it up \xe2\x80\x94 now!).'b'In college, my idea of a productive day was to start writing at 7 a.m. and not leave my chair until dinnertime. I was chasing \xe2\x80\x9c'b'flow'b',\xe2\x80\x9d the mental state described by the psychologist 'b'Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi'b' in which you are so completely absorbed in a task that you lose a sense of time and place. I fell so deeply into that zone of concentration that my roommates once gave a party while I was writing and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even notice.'b'But procrastinators, as the writer Tim Urban describes it on the blog 'b'Wait But Why'b', are at the mercy of an Instant Gratification Monkey who inhabits their brains, constantly asking questions like \xe2\x80\x9cWhy would we ever use a computer for work when the Internet is sitting right there waiting to be played with?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re a procrastinator, overcoming that monkey can require herculean amounts of willpower. But a pre-crastinator may need equal willpower to 'b'not 'b'work.'b'A few years ago, though, one of my most creative students, Jihae Shin, questioned my expeditious habits. She told me her most original ideas came to her after she procrastinated. I challenged her to prove it. She got access to a couple of companies, surveyed people on how often they procrastinated, and asked their supervisors to rate their creativity. Procrastinators earned significantly higher creativity scores than pre-crastinators like me.'b'I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t convinced. So Jihae, now a professor at the University of Wisconsin, designed some experiments. She asked people to come up with new business ideas. Some were randomly assigned to start right away. Others were given five minutes to first play Minesweeper or Solitaire. Everyone submitted their ideas, and independent raters rated how original they were. The procrastinators\xe2\x80\x99 ideas were 28 percent more creative.'b'Minesweeper is awesome, but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the driver of the effect. When people played games before being told about the task, there was no increase in creativity. It was only when they first learned about the task and then put it off that they considered more novel ideas. It turned out that procrastination encouraged divergent thinking.'b'Our first ideas, after all, are 'b'usually'b' our most conventional. My senior thesis in college ended up replicating a bunch of existing ideas instead of introducing new ones. When you procrastinate, you\xe2\x80\x99re more likely to let your mind wander. That gives you a better chance of stumbling onto the unusual and spotting unexpected patterns. Nearly a century ago, the psychologist Bluma Zeigarnik found that people had a 'b'better memory'b' for incomplete tasks than for complete ones. When we finish a project, we file it away. But when it\xe2\x80\x99s in limbo, it stays active in our minds.'b'Begrudgingly, I acknowledged that procrastination might help with everyday creativity. But monumental achievements are a different story, right?'b'Wrong. Steve Jobs procrastinated constantly, several of his collaborators have told me. Bill Clinton has been 'b'described'b' as a \xe2\x80\x9cchronic procrastinator\xe2\x80\x9d who waits until the last minute to revise his speeches. Frank Lloyd Wright spent almost a year procrastinating on a commission, to the point that his patron drove out and insisted that he produce a drawing on the spot. It became Fallingwater, his masterpiece. Aaron Sorkin, the screenwriter behind \xe2\x80\x9cSteve Jobs\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe West Wing,\xe2\x80\x9d is known to put off writing until the last minute. When Katie Couric asked him about it, he 'b'replied'b', \xe2\x80\x9cYou call it procrastination, I call it thinking.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So what if creativity happens not in spite of procrastination, but because of it? I decided to give it a try. The good news is that I am no stranger to self-discipline. So I woke up one morning and wrote a to-do list for procrastinating more. Then I set out to achieve the goal of not making progress toward my goals. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t go excellently.'b'My first step was to delay creative tasks, starting with this article. I resisted the temptation to sit down and start typing, and instead waited. While procrastinating (i.e., thinking), I remembered an article I had read months earlier on pre-crastination. It dawned on me that I could use my own experiences as a pre-crastinator to set the stage for readers.'b'Next, I drew some inspiration from George Costanza on \xe2\x80\x9cSeinfeld,\xe2\x80\x9d who made it a habit to 'b'quit on a high note'b'. When I started writing a sentence that felt good, I stopped in the middle of it and walked away. When I returned to writing later that day, I was able to pick up where I had left the trail of thought. Mitch Albom, author of \xe2\x80\x9cTuesdays With Morrie,\xe2\x80\x9d uses the same trick. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you quit in the middle of a sentence, that\xe2\x80\x99s just great,\xe2\x80\x9d he 'b'told me'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t wait to get back to it the next morning.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Once I did finish a draft, I put it away for three weeks. When I came back to it, I had enough distance to wonder, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat kind of idiot wrote this garbage?\xe2\x80\x9d and rewrote most of it. To my surprise, I had some fresh material at my disposal: During those three weeks, for example, a colleague had mentioned the fact that Mr. Sorkin was an avid procrastinator.'b'What I discovered was that in every creative project, there are moments that require thinking more laterally and, yes, more slowly. My natural need to finish early was a way of shutting down complicating thoughts that sent me whirling in new directions. I was avoiding the pain of divergent thinking \xe2\x80\x94 but I was also missing out on its rewards.'b'Of course, procrastination can go too far. Jihae randomly assigned a third group of people to wait until the last minute to begin their project. They weren\xe2\x80\x99t as creative either. They had to rush to implement the easiest idea instead of working out a novel one.'b'To curb that kind of destructive procrastination, science offers some useful guidance. First, imagine yourself failing spectacularly, and the ensuing frenzy of anxiety 'b'may jump-start'b' your engine. Second, lower your standards for what counts as 'b'progress'b', and you will be less paralyzed by perfectionism. Carving out small windows of time can help, too: The psychologist Robert Boice helped graduate students 'b'overcome writer\xe2\x80\x99s block'b' by teaching them to write for 15 minutes a day. My favorite step is 'b'pre-commitment'b': If you\xe2\x80\x99re passionate about gun control, go to the app 'b'stickK'b' and fork over some cash in advance. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t meet your deadline, your money will be donated to the National Rifle Association. The fear of supporting a cause you despise can be a powerful motivator.'b'But if you\xe2\x80\x99re a procrastinator, next time you\xe2\x80\x99re wallowing in the'b' dark playground of guilt and self-hatred'b' over your failure to start a task, remember that the right kind of procrastination might make you more creative. And if you\xe2\x80\x99re a pre-crastinator like me, it may be worth mastering the discipline of forcing yourself to procrastinate. You can\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid of leaving your work un'b'Rocco Casagrande, a former United Nations biological weapons inspector, is managing director of 'b'Gryphon Scientific'b', a consulting company that last week delivered a federally commissioned report identifying the risks and benefits of allowing research that could make certain viruses, like influenza, SARS or MERS, more dangerous.'b''b'READING'b' Of course, there\xe2\x80\x99s reading for work. The report we just delivered has 2,979 references just on the footnotes page. But I recently read two sci-fi books from the 'b'Laundry Files series'b' by Charles Stross. They were sort of a cross between 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHitchhikers Guide\xe2\x80\x9d'b' and 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe X-Files.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' This inspired me to read the collected weird tales of H. P. Lovecraft, a horror/sci-fi writer from the 1930s, which led me to the 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe King in Yellow\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Robert Chambers, which is similar, but from the late 1800s and some of the stories are set in the far future year of 1920.'b''b'LISTENING'b' Well, this week, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been listening to some Bowie because he just died and I liked his music a lot. But I typically listen to harder rock, including some modern stuff \xe2\x80\x94 'b'Mastodon'b' and 'b'Wolfmother'b' \xe2\x80\x94 but also bands from the \xe2\x80\x9990s like 'b'Soundgarden'b' and earlier classic metal. I think classic metal is the most like opera of all the pop forms because of the way it prizes male virtuosity, the themes having to do with demons and the theatricality.'b''b'WATCHING'b' I like to watch cartoons, which is probably some weird holdover from when I was a kid and got really disappointed at 5 p.m. when the UHF channels would switch from cartoons to 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGilligan\xe2\x80\x99s Island\xe2\x80\x9d'b' and 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThree\xe2\x80\x99s Company.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRick and Morty\xe2\x80\x9d'b' is my current favorite, followed by 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cArcher\xe2\x80\x9d'b' and then 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSouth Park\xe2\x80\x9d'b' and 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFuturama.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' And there\xe2\x80\x99s also 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cVenture Bros.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' in which David Bowie is one of the main villains and they quote his songs in the show.'b''b'FOLLOWING'b' 'b'XKCD'b', which is a nerdy web comic, and I am anxiously awaiting the next installment of 'b'What If?'b' on the site, which closely mirrors our interview questions at my company. They ask physics questions, while ours are more life sciences and toxicology questions, like, how much would a pregnant woman have to drink before she got her baby drunk? Our company got included with places like Google and Microsoft for, like, the 10 weirdest interview questions ever.'b''b'PLAYING'b' I love to play, since I was a kid, board games. They can be strategy games, puzzle games, cooperative games. My favorite one right now is called 'b'Le Havre'b' and involves playing a businessman in a port city who buys and sells companies, buys and ships cargo, pays workers. There are a lot of games that are not Milton Bradley or about war.'b''b'CHOPPING'b' My biggest hobby and my only exercise is chopping wood. I would like lifting weights if it was for a purpose. With chopping wood, I feel like I\xe2\x80\x99ve accomplished something. Using my woodstove, I can heat my house to a very decadent warm temperature that I would feel way too guilty doing if it were heating with gas or oil. Chopping wood is also a sensuous experience \xe2\x80\x94 it smells nice, makes a great sound, and you\xe2\x80\x99re outdoors. Since June, I think I have chopped and stacked about nine tons of wood.'b'BRETT SMILEY was no 'b'David Bowie'b'.'b'In fact, the album the 18-year-old Mr. Smiley made with the Rolling Stones producer Andrew Loog Oldham in 1974, \xe2\x80\x9cBreathlessly Brett,\xe2\x80\x9d didn\xe2\x80\x99t even see the light of day until 40 years had passed.'b'But he was someone you should know. And in what seemed like some sort of cosmic coincidence, he died on Jan. 8, just two days before his immeasurably more successful contemporary.'b'The failure of Mr. Smiley \xe2\x80\x94 or Brett, as I came to know him \xe2\x80\x94 to take his own place in the pantheon of 1970s glam legends wasn\xe2\x80\x99t because of a lack of effort. He was young, American, gorgeous and wrote compelling songs delivered in a breathy, achingly vulnerable voice. Some $100,000 had been invested in starting his career. Disco magazine declared him \xe2\x80\x9cthe Most Beautiful Boy in the World.\xe2\x80\x9d He was poised, on the precipice, ready for his close-up.'b'But \xe2\x80\x9cBreathlessly Brett\xe2\x80\x9d was shelved. \xe2\x80\x9cI just refused to let them release the album,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Oldham said recently in an email. \xe2\x80\x9cI knew it would be a disaster, and we\xe2\x80\x99d already had one \xe2\x80\x94 the 45 r.p.m. release of \xe2\x80\x98Space Ace,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d a song from the record.'b'The astronaut-themed \xe2\x80\x9cSpace Ace,\xe2\x80\x9d with its military-style snare drum rolls, \xe2\x80\x9claunchpad\xe2\x80\x9d sound effects and lush strings might have been titled \xe2\x80\x9cNot Quite Space Oddity.\xe2\x80\x9d The up-tempo, catchy B-side, \xe2\x80\x9cVa Va Va Voom,\xe2\x80\x9d would have made a much better debut. Either way, Brett\xe2\x80\x99s glam career crash-landed, and Mr. Bowie \xe2\x80\x94 and the rest of the world \xe2\x80\x94 moved on.'b'In 1977, Brett landed a part in \xe2\x80\x9cCinderella,\xe2\x80\x9d a low-budget soft-porn flick. Appearing in a movie wasn\xe2\x80\x99t such a big stretch; he had understudied the lead role in \xe2\x80\x9cOliver\xe2\x80\x9d on Broadway for a little over a month in 1965. But it was the last major gasp from Brett, who like so many in the hedonistic \xe2\x80\x9970s and \xe2\x80\x9980s was wooed by assorted mind-altering substances. And off he went.'b'By the time I met Brett in Central Park in 1988 while playing Frisbee, his time had passed. To me he was a skinny, friendly, vaguely beat-up-looking man who, like me, carried a guitar everywhere he went. We talked, we jammed, he played me one of his new songs \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cFrom the Head to the Heart\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and he told me to throw out one line of a new song I had just written called \xe2\x80\x9cQuittin\xe2\x80\x99 Time.\xe2\x80\x9d It was good advice.'b'We kept seeing each other in the park on weekends and then one last time, for a few hours, at a mutual friend\xe2\x80\x99s house. Eventually, he told me the story of his 15 minutes of almost-stardom, but I didn\xe2\x80\x99t really care. There was no Internet and I could not look up photos, hear recordings or see his and Mr. Oldham\xe2\x80\x99s appearance on Russell Harty\xe2\x80\x99s British TV show. (But 'b'you can.)'b''b'I just liked the guy; he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a dude or a bro, but neither was he overly touchy-feely. I was aching at the time for guidance, particularly with music, and Brett gave it to me without being asked. There was something lovable about him. Such is the nature of born stars, whether they become famous or not; you just want to be around them.'b'When Brett suddenly disappeared and I eventually made inquiries, I was told he\xe2\x80\x99d succumbed again to drugs and had fled to California. I soon left New York to live in an Indian ashram. The past rapidly seemed a millennium away, and the \xe2\x80\x9980s were cemented in pop culture almost as soon as they were over.'b'I remembered Brett all through the next three decades, though \xe2\x80\x94 his face, his manner and especially the fact that he never complained about his faded career or his drug addiction; he didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to feel sorry for himself.'b'Shaken to the core in the wake of David Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s death last week, I thought of glam and decided, after all these years, to Google Brett Smiley.'b'I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised, knowing his history, to see the headline \xe2\x80\x9cBrett Smiley Dies at 60,\xe2\x80\x9d but was gobsmacked to see he\xe2\x80\x99d died in his Brooklyn apartment just 48 hours before Mr. Bowie. He\xe2\x80\x99d been found, the obituaries said, by family members and a friend who had been unable to contact him by phone.'b'And thus I spent the better part of the day getting to know the Brett I had never known and falling in love with the tiny, beautiful creature on the cover of \xe2\x80\x9cBreathlessly Brett\xe2\x80\x9d as one might have in 1974 \xe2\x80\x94 in the den with friends gathered around a turntable or in one\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom. There was also Andrew Loog Oldham and a nervous Brett Smiley debuting on British TV with \xe2\x80\x9cSpace Ace,\xe2\x80\x9d which Brett had expected to mime but had to perform live. His songs have played nonstop on my iPod since I downloaded them two days ago. It\xe2\x80\x99s all Brett, all the time.'b'David Bowie, by contrast, does not need me to mourn him. I saw the 1976 film \xe2\x80\x9cThe Man Who Fell to Earth\xe2\x80\x9d when it came out (though I didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand it). I pulled my car over to listen to \xe2\x80\x9cAshes to Ashes\xe2\x80\x9d in 1980 the first time it came over the radio because the snapping bass guitar opening the song was so compelling; I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know it was Mr. Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s song until he started singing. I watched him at Live Aid during a break from the restaurant I was working at near Washington Square Park in 1985, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve sung the words \xe2\x80\x9cThis is ground control to Major Tom\xe2\x80\x9d in public about 500 times since I was 15. I\xe2\x80\x99ve given him more than 40 years of my life, and the world will no doubt see to his legacy without my help.'b'But maybe Brett Smiley does need me to mourn him. I asked Mr. Oldham for his thoughts, and they were kind. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was an irresistible spirit, a warrior, superb writer and chronicler of his and our times,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Oldham said. \xe2\x80\x9cA good person to have as a friend, a lovable rogue. He will be missed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Brett wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Ziggy Stardust, the Thin White Duke or Major Tom, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t end up getting to record and hang out with John Lennon and Mick Jagger and he didn\xe2\x80\x99t make millions of dollars \xe2\x80\x94 not even close. But he was the Space Ace, as well as a talented, slightly mysterious guy who was nice to me when he had no reason to be. Brett Smiley didn\xe2\x80\x99t change the world, but he\xe2\x80\x99s left it now. He lived a life, and it mattered.'b'JOHN YOUNG was born into slavery, on July 4, 1855. By 15 he was a free man and an electrifying orator, recruiting black voters around his native South Carolina to the Republican Party with \xe2\x80\x9cpyrotechnical\xe2\x80\x9d rhetoric and mustache-waggling jokes. In the late 1860s, it looked as if he might help his party make real change in the post-Civil War South.'b'But soon Young noticed white Northerners losing interest, more concerned with corruption in Washington than freedom in Charleston. His former allies, distracted by scandals, \xe2\x80\x9cjust sat back\xe2\x80\x9d and let the South \xe2\x80\x9cskin us out of our rights,\xe2\x80\x9d he later said. By the late 1870s, anger at government had helped kill Reconstruction, punishing the most vulnerable for the crimes of the most crooked. We should be wary of this today, as we grapple with race and populist rage yet again.'b'Just as in the 1870s, America is struggling against racial inequity 'b'and'b' seething at our political establishment. The two issues appear unrelated, but they have a perverse connection: Anger makes Americans dismiss government and politics altogether \xe2\x80\x94 and that dismissal makes it harder to tackle racial injustice.'b'This was certainly the case, on a far larger scale, in the 1870s, when sentiment against politicians eclipsed black political rights. Reconstruction was a moment of racial promise such as this country had never seen: A generation of former slaves became landowners, teachers, voters and elected officeholders. From 1865 to the early 1870s, the country passed constitutional amendments promising them liberty, citizenship and voting rights. Federal agents helped build schools and banks, and 'b'even crushed the Ku Klux Klan'b'.'b'But reforms in the South depended on the political will of the two-thirds of Americans living outside the region to enforce them. Ohio was typical. It furnished the generals who won the war, and the politicians who made the peace. Yet Ohio was 98.8 percent white. Each reform required persuading voters in Ohio to care about John Young in South Carolina.'b'For a time, a majority of white Northerners supported Reconstruction. Especially in the dominant Republican Party, many let their rage at the former Confederacy push them to back greater racial equality. They were especially proud of their government: The Union that had crushed secession might genuinely improve Americans\xe2\x80\x99 lives, in the South and elsewhere.'b'Political cartoons capture this triumphant faith. In the late 1860s, artists drew black characters in Union Army uniforms \xe2\x80\x94 icons of the powerful nation that had won the war. Instead of using petty politicians to represent the government, cartoonists sketched the proud, classically robed 'b'Columbia'b' (whose name endures but whose role as an avatar of strong government has disappeared).'b'Then came the scandals. In the early 1870s, President Ulysses S. Grant\xe2\x80\x99s buddies were caught stealing and bribing, speculating on gold and dodging whiskey taxes. The New York Times exposed Tammany Hall\xe2\x80\x99s Boss Tweed for stealing as much as $45 million. Tweed was a Democrat, but his thefts made the entire establishment look worse.'b'The avalanche of corruption left Americans blaming what the reformer 'b'Lydia Maria Child'b' called the \xe2\x80\x9cgeneral cussedness of governments.\xe2\x80\x9d The fiery Minnesota stump speaker Ignatius Donnelly went further, condemning politicians as \xe2\x80\x9ca genus of shysters and scalawags \xe2\x80\x94 small, mean, tricky little wire-pullers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Who was blamed for white politicians\xe2\x80\x99 dirty tricks? Black leaders. A new type of racist cartoon emerged in the 1870s, depicting black officeholders in gaudy jewelry. Journalists sent accounts north from majority-black regions, mocking \xe2\x80\x9csavage\xe2\x80\x9d African-American leaders, comparing them to Tammany Hall bosses.'b'Northern whites began to give up on the idea that the federal government could or should improve race relations. Horace Greeley, once America\xe2\x80\x99s most influential abolitionist editor, ran against Grant in 1872, combining anger at politicians with hostility toward Reconstruction. He lost, terribly, but not before claiming that blacks \xe2\x80\x9cassume that they need more help from outside than they actually do.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This was how the 'b'elephant'b' came to symbolize the Republican Party, as a criticism of an organization that looked bloated and bullying. Former slaves pictured a different beast: Their Republican Party was a war elephant, protecting them from the guerrilla campaign terrorizing black voters. The dispute questioned the fundamental role of parties in American democracy: Were they alliances, protecting the rights of constituents, or \xe2\x80\x9crings,\xe2\x80\x9d conspiring to loot the public?'b'Angry at politicians, and spurred by the crushing depression of 1873, voters gave the Democrats control of Congress in 1874. It was one of the largest landslide shifts in party control in American history. Reconstruction, on the ground, was mostly finished after that. Federal soldiers and agents largely withdrew from the South, and political support for black politicians dried up. The abandonment, wrote a slave-turned-politician in Mississippi, felt \xe2\x80\x9cpathetic in the extreme.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'No generation of Americans had more reason to go after the crooks in government, and no generation misplaced its rage so devastatingly. But anger at politicians did not stop with Reconstruction. In the Gilded Age, faith in leadership dimmed even further. Gone was the triumphant Columbia, replaced by caricatures of thieving officeseekers stuffing their pockets with public money. Government stepped back from protecting those rights it had promised after the war.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve got nothing on the 1870s today. That era saw the largest terrorist conspiracy in our history, suppressing black voters and killing hundreds if not thousands, while corrupt officials stole millions of dollars. But themes from that era \xe2\x80\x94 suspicion of government, struggles over race \xe2\x80\x94 run through American history. And sometimes, one issue blares so loudly that it drowns out the rest.'b'In 2016, political outrage again threatens to overwhelm calls for racial change. If we\xe2\x80\x99re serious about addressing ingrained inequality, from schools to prisons to workplaces, Americans will need to trust government to make reforms, and support the kind of leadership we\xe2\x80\x99ve come to view so cynically. Otherwise, our tendency toward vague, angry rhetoric will discourage risk-taking, and ultimately maintain the racial status quo.'b'Yet our era, like the years after the Civil War, also presents a rare moment of possibility. If we keep both issues in focus, Americans might bring unprecedented racial change 'b'and'b' clean up government. We could use the momentum of one to affect the other, joining the new crop of black activists with older white voters mobilized against business as usual. We might achieve what John Young had been working for all along.'b'TWO of our most vital industries, health care and education, have become increasingly subjected to metrics and measurements. Of course, we need to hold professionals accountable. But the focus on numbers has gone too far. We\xe2\x80\x99re hitting the targets, but missing the point.'b'Through the 20th century, we adopted a hands-off approach, assuming that the pros knew best. Most experts believed that the ideal \xe2\x80\x9cproducts\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 healthy patients and well-educated kids \xe2\x80\x94 were too strongly influenced by uncontrollable variables (the sickness of the patient, the intellectual capacity of the student) and were too complex to be judged by the measures we use for other industries.'b'By the early 2000s, as evidence mounted that both fields were producing mediocre outcomes at unsustainable costs, the pressure for measurement became irresistible. In health care, we saw hundreds of thousands of deaths from medical errors, poor coordination of care and backbreaking costs. In education, it became clear that our schools were lagging behind those in other countries.'b'So in came the consultants and out came the yardsticks. In health care, we applied metrics to outcomes and processes. Did the doctor document that she gave the patient a flu shot? That she counseled the patient about smoking? In education, of course, the preoccupation became student test scores.'b'All of this began innocently enough. But the measurement fad has spun out of control. There are so many different hospital ratings that 'b'more than 1,600 medical centers'b' can now lay claim to being included on a \xe2\x80\x9ctop 100,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chonor roll,\xe2\x80\x9d grade \xe2\x80\x9cA\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbest\xe2\x80\x9d hospitals list. Burnout rates for doctors top 50 percent, far higher than other professions. A 2013 study found that the electronic health record was a dominant culprit. Another 2013 study found that emergency room doctors clicked a mouse 4,000 times during a 10-hour shift. The computer systems have become the dark force behind quality measures.'b'Education is experiencing its own version of measurement fatigue. Educators complain that the focus on student test performance comes at the expense of learning. Art, music and physical education have withered, because, really, why bother if they\xe2\x80\x99re not on the test?'b'At first, the pushback from doctors and teachers was dismissed as whining from entitled and entrenched guilds spoiled by generations of unfettered autonomy. It was natural, went the thinking, that these professionals would resist the scrutiny and discipline of performance assessment. Of course, this interpretation was partly right.'b'But the objections became harder to dismiss as evidence mounted that even superb and motivated professionals had come to believe that the boatloads of measures, and the incentives to \xe2\x80\x9clook good,\xe2\x80\x9d had led them to turn away from the essence of their work. In medicine, doctors no longer made eye contact with patients as they clicked away. In education, even parents who favored more testing around Common Core standards worried about the damaging influence of all the exams.'b'Even some of the measurement behemoths are now voicing second thoughts. Last fall, the Joint Commission, the major accreditor of American hospitals, announced that it was suspending its annual rating of hospitals. At the same time, alarmed by the amount of time that testing robbed from instruction, the Obama administration called for new limits on student testing. Last week, Andy Slavitt, Medicare\xe2\x80\x99s acting administrator, announced the end of a program that tied Medicare payments to a long list of measures related to the use of electronic health records. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have to get the hearts and minds of physicians back,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Slavitt. \xe2\x80\x9cI think we\xe2\x80\x99ve lost them.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Thoughtful and limited assessment can be effective in motivating improvements and innovations, and in weeding out the rare but disproportionately destructive bad apples.'b'But in creating a measurement and accountability system, we need to tone down the fervor and think harder about the unanticipated consequences.'b'Measurement cannot go away, but it needs to be scaled back and allowed to mature. We need more targeted measures, ones that have been vetted to ensure that they really matter. In medicine, for example, measuring the rates of certain hospital-acquired infections has led to a greater emphasis on prevention and has most likely saved lives. On the other hand, measuring whether doctors documented that they provided discharge instructions to heart failure or asthma patients at the end of their hospital stay sounds good, but turns out to be an exercise in futile box-checking, and should be jettisoned.'b'We also need more research on quality measurement and comparing different patient populations. The only way to understand whether a high mortality rate, or dropout rate, represents poor performance is to adequately appreciate all of the factors that contribute to these outcomes \xe2\x80\x94 physical and mental, social and environmental \xe2\x80\x94 and adjust for them. It\xe2\x80\x99s like adjusting for the degree of difficulty when judging an Olympic diver. We\xe2\x80\x99re getting better at this, but we\xe2\x80\x99re not good enough.'b'Most important, we need to fully appreciate the burden that measurement places on professionals, and minimize it. In health care, some of this will come through advances in natural language processing, which may ultimately allow us to assess the quality of care by having computers \xe2\x80\x9cread\xe2\x80\x9d the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s note, obviating the need for all the box-checking. In both fields, simulation, video review and peer coaching hold promise.'b'Whatever we do, we have to ask our clinicians and teachers whether measurement is working, and truly listen when they tell us that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t. Today, that is precisely what they\xe2\x80\x99re saying.'b'Avedis Donabedian, a professor at the University of Michigan\xe2\x80\x99s School of Public Health, was a towering figure in the field of quality measurement. He developed what is known as Donabedian\xe2\x80\x99s triad, which states that quality can be measured by looking at outcomes (how the subjects fared), processes (what was done) and structures (how the work was organized). In 2000, shortly before he died, he was asked about his view of quality. What this hard-nosed scientist answered is shocking at first, then somehow seems obvious.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe secret of quality is love,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Our businesslike efforts to measure and improve quality are now blocking the altruism, indeed the love, that motivates people to enter the helping professions. While we\xe2\x80\x99re figuring out how to get better, we need to tread more lightly in assessing the work of the professionals who practice in our most human and sacred fields.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Arguably, the world is changing faster than at any point in history \xe2\x80\x94 in global warming, migration, technology, terrorism, national borders and genetics. The overriding challenge for the next president will be to coolly assess, prioritize and act on these daunting threats and opportunities.'b'Our first instinct is to recoil from change, taking refuge in a simpler, more prosperous time, 1950s Middle America, for example. The Constitution also looms large as a touchstone, to which literalists brook no challenge. If we can just turn back the clock following the letter of its 1787 precepts, change can be held at bay.'b'Yet the founding fathers were not at all terrified by change, but instead embraced it in the Constitution. They would, no doubt, be appalled by the political discourse of today and by those who claim to be disciples asserting a monopoly over their thinking and masterpiece. Their genius lay precisely in knowing that future crises could not be imagined in their time, leaving us the flexibility to respond to change and avoiding the pitfalls of rigid prescriptions.'b'Overreaction to change can also sap our strength. American exceptionalism, once shorthand for our can-do spirit and self-confidence, has been stood on its head as a bulwark against change on immigration, taxes and health. Seen from abroad, where I served for three decades, it conveys arrogance and a belief that entities like the World Court, and treaties on the Law of the Sea, the environment and human rights, simply don\xe2\x80\x99t apply to us.'b'Our next president must not shrink from long overdue reforms, but must lead with them. Both the president and Congress must keep in mind Chief Justice John Marshall\xe2\x80\x99s 1821 dictum that \xe2\x80\x9ca constitution is framed for ages to come, and is designed to approach immortality as nearly as human institutions can approach it.\xe2\x80\x9d Put differently, effective governance lies somewhere between revisionism and textualism.'b'RICHARD L. From 1994 to 2014, the number of farmers markets throughout the country increased almost fivefold. Many consumers frequent these markets because they believe that the foods they purchase there are healthier and safer than the same items sold at supermarkets, posing less risk of food-borne illness.'b'Yet no one really knows whether what is sold at farmers markets is less likely to make you sick. For one thing, the publicly available data on food-borne illness from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are limited: Only the location where the food was prepared is available, and even that is not always recorded. You cannot use these data to link an outbreak or case of food-borne illness to the specific place where the food was purchased.'b'But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that you can\xe2\x80\x99t look for intriguing correlations. Two colleagues and I recently assembled a data set that matched the number of cases and outbreaks of food-borne illness with the number of farmers markets in each state and in each year for 2004, 2006, and 2008 to 2013.'b'As we will report in an updated version of an unpublished 'b'working paper'b' released last summer, we found correlations that, in statistical parlance, are too robust to ignore. First, we found a positive correlation between the number of farmers markets per capita in a given state and in a given year and the number of reported outbreaks, regardless of type, of food-borne illness per capita in that state that year. Then, we found a similar positive correlation between farmers markets per capita and reported individual cases of food-borne illness per capita.'b'More interestingly, we found similar positive correlations between farmers markets per capita and outbreaks per capita of 'b'norovirus'b', a common cause of gastroenteritis. Likewise, we found a similar positive correlation between farmers markets per capita and outbreaks per capita of 'b'Campylobacter jejuni'b', a bacterium typically found in animal feces that is also a common cause of gastroenteritis.'b'Our analysis also uncovered a number of dogs that did not bark. We found no statistically significant relationship between farmers markets per capita in a given state in a given year and reported outbreaks or cases of salmonella, E. coli or staph.'b'Throughout our analyses, we controlled for those factors that remain constant over time for each state. For a case of food-borne illness to show up in our data, for example, the person who becomes ill must consult a doctor. That doctor then has to notify county health authorities. Finally, county health authorities have to notify the Centers for Disease Control.'b'States, however, vary in how assiduously they report food-borne illness to the C.D.C. Controlling for constant factors allows us to rule out the possibility that our results are driven by states that both are better at reporting food-borne illness and have more farmers markets per capita.'b'Similarly, our analyses control for income per capita and, because the consumers who shop at farmers markets tend to be more educated than those who do not, for the proportion of college graduates in each state and in each year.'b'My co-authors and I are applied economists, not farmers, food scientists or epidemiologists. It is important to emphasize that our findings are correlations and that correlation does not necessarily imply causation. Given available data and methods, we can\xe2\x80\x99t say whether the rise of farmers markets has actually caused an increase in the number of cases and outbreaks of food-borne illness.'b'And even if our results did identify a causal relationship between farmers markets and food-borne illness, it would not be possible to identify the precise mechanisms through which this happens, and it would be a critical mistake to conclude that the foods sold at farmers markets are themselves to blame. That is because most cases of illness are caused by consumers who undercook or fail to wash their food. Indeed, our results may suggest that many people erroneously believe that food bought at farmers markets needn\xe2\x80\x99t be washed because it is \xe2\x80\x9cnatural.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Farmers markets are now part and parcel of the American food landscape. The correlations we have identified certainly constitute an issue that farmers, distributors, vendors, consumers and academics should look into more closely. Though more research is needed to identify any possible causes, policy prescriptions could be as simple as encouraging patrons of farmers markets to wash their produce more thoroughly.'b'Lawrence, Kan. \xe2\x80\x94 I TOOK my first secretarial job in college, where I worked down the hall from a Triga Mark II nuclear reactor. I lasted just two lonely weeks, waiting to answer nonexistent phone calls and compulsively checking my radiation exposure badge.'b'Three years and three secretarial jobs later, my new employers referred to me as an \xe2\x80\x9cadministrative assistant.\xe2\x80\x9d They seemed to believe that the new title conferred greater respect for my work; yet no one has ever suggested that the secretary of state should be called the administrative assistant of state.'b'About the same time that I became an administrative assistant, I finished my master\xe2\x80\x99s degree in creative writing. My mother, who named me after a college I would never attend, expected me to pursue a doctorate and become a professor. My grandmother knew better. After all, she was the one who trained me to be a secretary.'b'For most of my childhood, my after-school day care involved walking the five blocks over to the law office where my grandmother worked. There, I sat in the back room and read library books while my grandmother answered phones, took dictation and typed letters. She would not have looked out of place on the set of \xe2\x80\x9cMad Men\xe2\x80\x9d: poised, perfectly coifed, lipsticked and imperturbable. The quintessential secretary.'b'Her manicured nails produced a delicious clicking against the keys of her new electric typewriter that roused me from my reading. When I made my first attempts at it, I barely had the strength to depress the keys and engage the steel trap of its type hammers.'b'Other women, on hearing my first tentative pecks, might have shooed me away, but my grandmother gave me a stack of discarded paper and showed me how to spool it into the typewriter. From there, I was hooked. Not just on the mechanical pleasures of keys striking paper and leaving a mark, but on what it all was for: the words on the page.'b'By then, Grandma was using an IBM Selectric II typewriter, producing mountains of onionskin legal filings from that humming, chattering beast at 120 words per minute. When Grandma deemed my typing adequate, she gave me real letters to practice on. When they were perfect, they went to the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s desk for his signature. Even then, it was clear to me that without a secretary, the lawyer wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been able to do much lawyering if he had also needed to type briefs, answer the phone and make his own coffee.'b'The other thing I understood was that this was how books were made. I\xe2\x80\x99d seen photos of Ernest Hemingway and Pearl Buck at work on their novels, and I knew if I was going to be a writer, I would need to be able to type. This is a good step that should help law enforcement agencies crack down on money laundering, tax evasion and other crimes. But the program should be broadened to cover the whole country, and it must be forcefully carried out.'b'In recent years, oligarchs, corrupt politicians, business executives and suspected criminals have stashed billions of dollars of wealth in the United States by buying condominiums, mansions and other costly assets. As 'b'documented by The Times'b' last year, these purchases are generally made through limited liability corporations that are not required to disclose their owners or beneficiaries. The secrecy is so complete that even law enforcement officials say they are often unable to identify the true owners.'b'The crux of the problem is that states \xe2\x80\x94 especially Delaware, Nevada and Wyoming \xe2\x80\x94 have made it easy for people to set up shell companies without providing any personal information. While limited liability corporations have many legitimate purposes, there is no justification for allowing owners to shield their identities even from law enforcement and regulators. These states appear to be mainly motivated by a desire to earn corporation filing fees, legal costs and related revenue.'b'Unfortunately, efforts by lawmakers like Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, and Representative Carolyn Maloney, Democrat of New York, to require greater disclosure have been thwarted by lobbying from the financial and real estate industries and state governments. That makes it even more important that the Treasury Department take stronger action than it has so far.'b'The department currently requires mortgage lenders to know the identities of the true owners of shell companies in transactions that 'b'involve loans. 'b' Lenders also have to report suspicious activity to the department. Under the new policy, the department\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Financial Crimes Enforcement Network 'b'will require real estate title companies to report to it the true owners of limited liability companies that buy properties without loans. However, the order applies only to Manhattan and Miami-Dade County, and will be effective for only 180 days, starting in March.'b'At the end of that period, after studying trends and activities, the agency will decide whether to extend and broaden the program. It is absurd that regulators would not require such basic transparency as a matter of course. The current system practically condones money laundering and tax evasion. It lays out the welcome mat for foreigners hiding assets from their governments, making the United States one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'biggest tax havens'b'.'b'For the same reasons, the Treasury Department should adopt 'b'pending regulations'b' that would require banks, brokerages and other financial firms to know who owns the limited liability companies whose accounts they manage. Both the driver and I were outraged at the other\xe2\x80\x99s ineptitude. In 'b'China'b', if you want to avoid being hit, you keep your head down and avoid eye contact with the oncoming driver, since looking at him would signal that you saw the car and know you should let it pass. In the United States, the opposite rule applies: Making eye contact confirms that the driver has seen you and should yield to the vulnerable pedestrian.'b'Something similar is occurring now between China and global financial markets. Billions in renminbi and dollars could be lost while trying to untangle the lines of communication.'b'Chinese bureaucrats believe that they have the right to intervene in their country\xe2\x80\x99s economy whenever they want, not only to promote certain industries but also to prevent sudden downturns and reduce volatility. Officials believe that they don\xe2\x80\x99t have to defend or explain their decisions in real time to market participants. In fact, being opaque preserves their discretion to make changes on the fly.'b'This approach goes against the operating principles of global financial markets: clarity and timely transparency. Intervention should be the exception, not the norm.'b'The job of regulators should be to ensure a fair market, but China\xe2\x80\x99s stock market is worse than a casino, as Chinese regulators\xe2\x80\x99 goals and the basic rules of the game can shift without warning. With China\xe2\x80\x99s housing market in disarray in 2014, authorities invited investors to shift their capital to the stock market and then took a series of steps to facilitate high returns. When the market started to nose-dive last summer, officials wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let the bubble that had inevitably formed fully burst. Instead they suspended trading for some companies, mopped up shares, ordered large shareholders not to sell and accused market analysts of spreading false rumors.'b'Regulators were at it again earlier this month, delaying the trading of stocks that had been frozen since last summer and even suddenly declaring that the market would temporarily halt trading if the Shanghai index rose or fell 5 percent. All this did was give investors just enough time to hit the sell button when markets restarted. About four days after it was started, this tool was abandoned without apology. Some investors have lost their shirts, but no regulators have lost their jobs.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s currency missteps have been equally maddening. The market suggests that the renminbi is overvalued because a strengthening or even stable renminbi is inconsistent with the country\xe2\x80\x99s expanding debt burden and slowing economic growth. China\xe2\x80\x99s central bank has taken some steps to liberalize the exchange rate, measuring the renminbi against a broader basket of currencies instead of the dollar. But because Chinese officials continue to publicly assert the renminbi is not overvalued, they are intervening daily to prop up the currency. And they have imposed a range of capital controls.'b'Based on my interviews, Chinese officials believe these steps are preserving economic stability and facilitating gradual change, while investors who see policies change constantly with little apparent rationale have had their confidence in officials\xe2\x80\x99 ability badly shaken.'b'Frustration with China has prompted calls for a regulatory response. Trump has advocated for a 45 percent across-the-board tariff on Chinese imports. But given that China is not trying to depress its currency to make its products more competitive, penalties are not justified. Private insurers played a major part in killing health reform in the early 1990s, so this time around reformers went for a system that preserved their role and gave them plenty of new business.'b'Second, single-payer would require a lot of additional tax revenue \xe2\x80\x94 and we would be talking about taxes on the middle class, not just the wealthy.
