We have yet to see that.'b'Oakland, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 ACROSS the country, some 400,000 women, mostly immigrants, work in agriculture, toiling in fields, nurseries and packing plants. Such work is backbreaking and low-paying. But for many of these women, it is also a nightmare of sexual violence.'b'In a 2010 study from the University of California, Santa Cruz, more than 60 percent of the 150 female farmworkers interviewed said they had experienced some form of sexual harassment. In a 2012 report, 'b'Human Rights Watch 'b' surveyed 52 female farmworkers; nearly all of them had experienced sexual violence, or knew others who had. One woman told investigators that her workplace was called the \xe2\x80\x9cfield de calz\xc3\xb3n,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cfield of panties.\xe2\x80\x9d As an Iowa immigrant farmworker told her lawyer, \xe2\x80\x9cWe thought it was normal in the United States that in order to keep your job, you had to have sex.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The reasons behind this epidemic aren\xe2\x80\x99t hard to fathom. Fields are vast and sparsely monitored; workers are often alone. It\xe2\x80\x99s particularly bad for immigrant workers: The Department of Labor estimates that about half of farmworkers 'b'don\xe2\x80\x99t have legal immigration papers'b', which makes them especially vulnerable.'b'So do low wages and competition for jobs: Male farmworkers make an estimated $16,250 a year and female ones $11,250 a year. With depressed wages and so many workers competing for the same job, women are hesitant to complain.'b'The problem is hardly a secret. Two decades ago the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, along with California Rural Legal Assistance, a legal service program that promotes the interests of migrant laborers and the rural poor, created a joint project to concentrate on sexual harassment in the fields.'b'In 2005, 'b'the commission won a $994,000 victory for Olivia Tamayo'b', a worker at one of California\xe2\x80\x99s largest cattle-feeding operations, who was repeatedly raped by her supervisor. \xe2\x80\x9cHe took advantage because he knew I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to say anything,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'she told Ms. Magazine.'b' \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a trauma that followed me everywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In September, in one of the largest settlements of its kind, the commission won over $17 million for five farmworkers in Florida who had accused their supervisors of rape and harassment. Some 18 similar cases nationally after 2009 'b' have given women farmworkers $4 million'b'.'b'Yet these cases involve only a tiny percentage of women who work in agriculture. Research shows that harassment and abuse are much more widespread \xe2\x80\x94 and case-by-case litigation isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough to change that.'b'When women do file complaints, investigations can takes months, even years, which can discourage other women from speaking up. And even when a case is won, 'b'criminal prosecution of the harasser or rapist'b' rarely follows.'b'There are several steps we can take to slow this scourge. Education and outreach are critical \xe2\x80\x94 not just for women working in the industry, but also for consumers who can put pressure on the industry to crack down. At the same time, employers themselves often don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in their own fields.'b'Still, many employers do know \xe2\x80\x94 and use threats and intimidation to keep their workers quiet. We need stronger laws against retaliation, and protections for undocumented workers who come forward.'b'The administrative barriers to complaints must also be addressed. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has few offices in rural areas; they\xe2\x80\x99re usually open only when women are working; and the staff often don\xe2\x80\x99t speak Spanish, much less indigenous languages. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, many government agencies require complaints to be filed online. Many farmworkers do not have access to computers. The commission could make filing complaints easier by setting up a 24/7 hotline in multiple languages, with an actual person answering the phone, instead of automated messages.'b'Criminal prosecution of sexual assault cases needs to increase as well. District attorneys and state prosecutors must step in, making indictments and fining bosses who tolerate harassment. Women will feel safer filing complaints if they know their attackers can\xe2\x80\x99t just walk away. There has been some success along these lines, including a recent conviction in San Benito.'b'But perhaps the biggest impediment to fighting harassment in the fields is America\xe2\x80\x99s immigration policy itself. Federal regulations forbid legal aid organizations like California Rural Legal Assistance from directly representing undocumented people, and the illegal nature of their work situations makes it difficult for them to come forward. Finding a path toward documentation and legal employment for these women would also empower them to report those who rape and harass them.'b'Last year, California Rural Legal Assistance settled a $1.3 million case for a farmworker who was assaulted in a raspberry field, and then sent back to work in her bloody and ripped clothes. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the saddest thing that has happened to me in my life \xe2\x80\x94 for me it\xe2\x80\x99s like a wound that\xe2\x80\x99s there,\xe2\x80\x9d our client said during the sentencing phase of the case. \xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to get out of this trauma.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Lawmakers who oppose taking action to lower greenhouse gas emissions by putting a price on carbon often argue that doing so would hurt businesses and consumers. But the energy policies adopted by some American states and Canadian provinces demonstrate that those arguments are simply unfounded.'b'Around the world, nearly 40 nations, including the 28-member European Union, and many smaller jurisdictions are engaged in some form of carbon pricing. In this hemisphere, British Columbia, Quebec, California and nine Northeastern states have raised the cost of burning fossil fuels without damaging the economy. 'b'Alberta'b', Canada\xe2\x80\x99s biggest oil and gas producer, and 'b'Ontario'b' have said they will adopt similar policies.'b'Carbon pricing comes in two forms: a direct tax on emissions or a cap on emissions. British Columbia, for instance, has levied a tax on emissions from fuels like gasoline, natural gas and heating oil. California and Quebec, which are working together, place a ceiling on overall emissions and allow utilities, manufacturing plants, fuel distributors and others to buy and sell permits that entitle them to emit greenhouse gases. Like the cap itself, the number of permits decline over time, becoming more expensive.'b'Many economists regard carbon taxes as the simpler and more elegant solution, and cap-and-trade systems like the one that failed in the United States Congress as complex and hard to explain. But both systems effectively raise the price of using fossil fuels, which encourages utilities and other producers to generate more energy from low-carbon sources like solar, wind and nuclear power.'b'British Columbia, which is home to 4.7 million people, has placed the highest price on emissions in North America, taxing a ton of carbon emitted at 30 Canadian dollars, or about $21. By comparison, emission permits in California and Quebec are 'b'trading'b' at about $13 a ton. And permits sold for $7.50 a ton in a 'b'December auction'b' in the Northeastern trading system known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. That system covers emissions from power plants in nine states that include Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts.'b'British Columbia started taxing emissions in 2008. One big appeal of its system is that it is essentially revenue-neutral. People pay more for energy (the price of gasoline is up by about 17 cents a gallon) but pay less in personal income and corporate taxes. And low-income and rural residents get special tax credits. The tax has raised about $4.3 billion while other taxes have been cut by about $5 billion. Researchers 'b'have found'b' that the tax helped cut emissions but has had no negative impact on the province\xe2\x80\x99s growth rate, which has been about the same or slightly faster than the country as a whole 'b'in recent years'b'.'b'Meanwhile, jurisdictions using the cap-and-trade approach like 'b'California'b', the nine Northeastern states and 'b'Quebec'b' are investing the revenue generated by auctioning emission permits in mass transit, energy efficiency, renewable energy and other strategies to reduce carbon emissions. Some of the revenue is also dedicated to helping low-income families cope with higher energy costs.'b'In recent months, the leaders of Ontario and 'b'Manitoba'b' said they would join the California-Quebec cap-and-trade system. In October, Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York said he was interested in 'b'linking'b' the Northeastern system to the California-Quebec trading platform.'b'In Alberta, a new government announced in November that it would impose a tax of 30 Canadian dollars on most greenhouse gas emissions by the 'b'start of 2018'b'. The province\xe2\x80\x99s leaders also said they would phase out the use of 'b'coal power plants'b' and impose caps on carbon and methane emissions from Alberta\xe2\x80\x99s oil and gas industry.'b'These actions deserve applause. But their real value may lie in providing a template for the rest of the world. Broad participation is essential to keeping warming below a point of no return; as a practical matter, it is also essential to keep companies from moving their operations to nations that do not impose a cost on carbon emissions.'b'In that context, China\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'announcement last year'b' that it would set up a national cap-and-trade system was hugely encouraging \xe2\x80\x94 the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest emitter agreeing to tax itself to help solve a problem that, only a few years ago, it barely acknowledged. Yet Congress has refused to act even as it becomes clear that putting a price on greenhouse gas emissions is the most direct and cost-effective way to address climate change.'b'A vaguely written \xe2\x80\x9cgay propaganda\xe2\x80\x9d law passed in 2013 created a toxic environment for gay men and lesbians in Russia. He writes that many conservatives viewed the 2011 failure of the solar-panel manufacturer Solyndra as demonstrating the solar industry\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cshaky future and the danger of government efforts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'They are wrong. Climate change is an existential challenge. The aim should be to support game-changing, wild-eyed, risky ideas. If the government did actually support such ideas, we should expect at least half of the ideas to fail. To me as an energy expert, the dearth of failures shows government\xe2\x80\x99s lack of sufficient response to the magnitude of the challenge.'b'GORDON AUBRECHT'b'Delaware, Ohio'b''b'The writer is a professor of physics at Ohio State University.'b''b'EARLIER this month, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida opened up on a subject he had once 'b'chided reporters'b' for asking about: his daughter, Noelle, who, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwas addicted to drugs.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a 'b'video'b' released by the campaign, Mr. Bush speaks plainly about his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s struggle, her time in jail and drug court, and her recovery. \xe2\x80\x9cI can look in people\xe2\x80\x99s eyes and I know that they\xe2\x80\x99ve gone through the same thing that Columba and I have,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, referring to his wife.'b'Mr. Bush is not the only candidate to share this sort of painful personal experience. 'b'Carly Fiorina'b', the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has spoken out about losing her stepdaughter, Lori Ann Fiorina, to \xe2\x80\x9cthe demons of addiction\xe2\x80\x9d at the age of 35. And Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke candidly and emotionally about a 'b'law school friend'b' who died of a Percocet overdose.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s behind this newfound willingness on the candidates\xe2\x80\x99 part to talk about the personal toll of addiction?'b'New Hampshire, and the sobering statistics on drug overdoses there, is probably part of the answer.'b'Every day, 44 people in the United States die as a result of 'b'overdose'b' on prescription painkillers. Every day, nearly 7,000 people are treated in emergency rooms for abusing painkillers. Overdose deaths have been creeping upward since the beginning of the 21st century \xe2\x80\x94 especially deaths from opiate abuse. In New Hampshire, overdose deaths linked to opiate abuse have 'b'more than doubled'b' over the past two years.'b'Ted Gatsas, the Republican mayor of Manchester, N.H., said he had had many opportunities to talk to Republican candidates, including Mr. Bush, Mr. Christie, Donald J. Trump, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, about the heroin and prescription-painkiller abuse in his state. He thinks that the overdose problem has been severely underestimated, not just in his city and state, but nationwide.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t think anybody, until you put the numbers and talk to them about it, knows that it\xe2\x80\x99s this bad across this country,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Nearly 50 years into the \xe2\x80\x9cwar on drugs,\xe2\x80\x9d which both Republican and Democratic leaders have waged in various ways, with various disastrous outcomes, drug overdoses reached a 'b'record high'b' in 2014. From 2001 to 2014, the United States had more than a 'b'threefold increase'b' in deaths from opioid pain relievers, and a sixfold increase in heroin overdoses, according to the National Institutes of Health. During the same period, overdose deaths from prescription drugs like Valium and Klonopin \xe2\x80\x94 sedatives called benzodiazepines \xe2\x80\x94 increased by five times.'b'In speaking about their own experiences, Republican candidates are not only allowing themselves to be vulnerable in front of voters, they\xe2\x80\x99re also straying from the just-say-no message of Ronald Reagan, whose legacy includes a tough legislative stance on drugs and drug sentencing. They\xe2\x80\x99re also hoping that voters, especially in early primary states, will empathize.'b'Grant Smith, a lobbyist with 'b'Drug Policy Action'b', said it was remarkable how much airtime addiction was getting. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you look over the last two decades, we\xe2\x80\x99ve definitely seen a transformation in how elected officials talk about people who use drugs,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Now there\xe2\x80\x99s more empathy, less scolding. He is glad to see the new rhetoric about addiction, but notes that candidates have become more open about this issue as it has started to take a real toll on largely white communities.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no question that the shift in who is being impacted by overdose and the attendant harms of drug use to rural and suburban communities has made lawmakers as well as candidates for office more comfortable talking about these issues,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just that African-American communities have endured high overdose rates for decades, and few lawmakers in Washington cared.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'At a forum at Southern New Hampshire University earlier this month, Governor Kasich 'b'spoke'b' with refreshing candor about what some call this \xe2\x80\x9cgentrification of addiction.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes I wonder how African-Americans must have felt when drugs were awash in their community and nobody watched,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow it\xe2\x80\x99s in our communities, and now all of a sudden we\xe2\x80\x99ve got forums, and God bless us, but think about the struggles that other people had.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So far, the proposed plans from the candidates to combat addiction have remained frustratingly vague. Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s plan is one exception: It would 'b'increase'b' access to drug courts, which allow some nonviolent drug offenders to undergo medical treatment instead of serving jail time, and would also reduce some mandatory minimum sentences.'b'Beyond criminal justice reform, there is the public health aspect of providing assistance. The idea that the G.O.P. can march into the 21st'b''b' century intentionally alienating every person of color is borderline insane.'b'Worse is the prospect that one of them might somehow win. Very few presidents are so terrible that they genuinely endanger their own nation, but Trump and Cruz would go there and beyond. Trump is a solipsistic branding genius whose \xe2\x80\x9cpolicies\xe2\x80\x9d have no contact with Planet Earth and who would be incapable of organizing a coalition, domestic or foreign.'b'Cruz would be as universally off-putting as he has been in all his workplaces. He\xe2\x80\x99s always been good at tearing things down but incompetent when it comes to putting things together.'b'So maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s time for governing Republicans to actually do something. Yes, I\xe2\x80\x99m talking to you state legislators, or local committeepersons, or members of Congress and all your networks of donors and supporters. If MoveOn can organize, if the Tea Party can organize, if Justin Bieber can build a gigantic social media movement, why are you incapable of any collective action at all?'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s needed is a grass-roots movement that stands for governing conservatism, built both online and through rallies, and gets behind a single candidate sometime in mid- to late February. In politics, if A (Trump) and B (Cruz) savage each other then the benefits often go to Candidate C. You know who you are.'b'Please don\xe2\x80\x99t go quietly and pathetically into the night.'b'If you think Congress is hopelessly divided on party lines on every issue, think again. When it comes to regulating \xe2\x80\x94 more precisely, deregulating \xe2\x80\x94 corporate America, Republicans and Democrats are all too eager to find common ground.'b'This week a bipartisan group of senators \xe2\x80\x94 four Republicans, three Democrats and one independent \xe2\x80\x94 is expected to introduce legislation that would slow and complicate the already laborious process by which federal regulations are issued and enforced.'b'The winners would be big banks and big businesses. The losers would be ordinary Americans who would be deprived of timely and effective protection from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and other bank regulators, as well as from agencies that oversee consumer product safety, nuclear safety, investor safeguards, workplace rights and a host of other issues and activities. These agencies are supposed to work independently, with Congress providing oversight. Under the legislation, however, Congress would actively interfere in the rule-making process.'b'One provision would require that the Congressional Budget Office review and approve the costs and benefits of proposed rules. The C.B.O. has no particular expertise in regulation; its reviews could indefinitely delay the process. Besides, the rule-making process already allows for public comment on proposals as well as legal challenges to final rules.'b'Another provision would establish a commission of political appointees to advise Congress on regulations that should be modified or repealed. That would undermine the authority of regulators because it would effectively create a political hit list. It\xe2\x80\x99s important to review regulations that are on the books \xe2\x80\x94 and regulatory agencies routinely do so. Such reviews are aimed not only at relieving unnecessary burdens but also at strengthening regulations where necessary. Much of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, for example, is devised to create or improve rules authorized before the financial crisis but never properly developed or enforced. A regulatory review commission whose aim is to curtail or end regulation would be a step backward.'b'This is not what Americans need. Regulation is essential in today\xe2\x80\x99s complex economy, as demonstrated by the financial crisis and by a number of corporate failures \xe2\x80\x94 fatal ignition switches, poisoned food, environmental pollution, invasions of privacy. Proponents of deregulation invariably claim that regulation kills jobs, but lack of regulation has killed more jobs and people than regulation ever has.'b'The Democrats behind the effort are Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Mark Warner of Virginia and Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, joined by Angus King Jr., an independent from Maine. Happily, he was able to stay for the children who needed him most.'b'EILEEN ADAMEC'b'Minneapolis'b'Palo Alto, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 THE dramatic events of this past weekend mark a potential turning point in the modern history of the Middle East. Estranged for the last three and a half decades, the American and Iranian governments are talking and working with each other once again.'b'The 'b'implementation'b' of the nuclear deal and the lifting of sanctions on 'b'Iran'b', as well as the prisoner exchange, combined to make it a rare, hopeful day for Washington and Tehran. But Iran remains a powerful adversary of America across nearly all the conflicts of the Middle East. 'b'President Obama'b' and his successor in the White House will be tested by whether they can find the right balance between cooperation on nuclear issues and containment of Iranian aggression.'b'The deal will have multiple consequences. With the lifting of sanctions, Iran becomes a major player in global energy markets. It will also cease to be a political pariah in much of the world. Most important, a possible third major Middle East war has been averted and Iran\xe2\x80\x99s bid for 'b'nuclear weapons'b' stymied, at least for now. At a time of upheaval in the region, this is an unusual piece of positive news.'b'Despite criticism of the agreement from congressional opponents, there are clear benefits for American security. Iran\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'nuclear program'b' will be frozen for 10 to 15 years now that its plutonium production and uranium enrichment facilities have been largely dismantled. A vast majority of its enriched uranium has been 'b'shipped'b' abroad. Tehran will be subject to tight international supervision and monitoring.'b'The commitments made by Tehran\xe2\x80\x99s lead negotiator, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, will be difficult to disavow in the future without major costs to Iran\xe2\x80\x99s global reputation. If it tries to trim or cheat on its obligations, the world will be watching.'b'The return of diplomacy as a preferred tool of American strategy is another of the deal\xe2\x80\x99s most promising results. Mr. Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry can take much credit. Their decision to engage in a risky two-year negotiation with arguably our most difficult regional adversary has paid off. By emphasizing the primacy of diplomacy in the wake of the interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq, Mr. Obama believes he is redefining American leadership in the world in a more constructive and realistic way.'b'Despite the nuclear deal\xe2\x80\x99s many promises, however, the road to a more normal American-Iranian relationship will be long and rocky. That is how I saw it when I helped to negotiate sanctions against Iran for the Bush administration a decade ago. It remains true today.'b'One immediate challenge will be to deal with two Iranian governments at once. Mr. Kerry pounded out the agreement with the American-educated Mr. Zarif, who was backed by Iran\xe2\x80\x99s reformist president, Hassan Rouhani. But real power still rests with Iran\xe2\x80\x99s supreme leader, Ayatollah 'b'Ali Khamenei'b', a recluse who is supremely distrustful of all things American and closer to the hard-line Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps than to the reformists.'b'The guards corps\xe2\x80\x99s influence over Iran\xe2\x80\x99s national security strategy has been visible since the nuclear deal was announced. In recent weeks, Iran 'b'tested'b' ballistic missiles in defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions and fired rockets close to American warships in the Strait of Hormuz. After detaining American sailors last week, Iran 'b'released'b' a demeaning video of the incident.'b'The guards corps is also driving Iran\xe2\x80\x99s continued support for Houthi rebels in Yemen, Hezbollah in Lebanon and Syria and the bloody government of President Bashar al-Assad. It is the guards corps that may be tempted to cheat on Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear obligations and return to taking American hostages.'b'Dealing with these rival camps will be a challenge. Mr. Kerry is right to test whether Iran will be more cooperative in the negotiations to end the war in Syria and in the fight against the Islamic State. But the administration will need to be equally determined to contain the worst aspects of Iran\xe2\x80\x99s aggression in the region.'b'The president made a start Sunday by 'b'announcing'b' sanctions against Iran for its missile tests. Mr. Obama will also need to repair our damaged relationships with Israel and Saudi Arabia to limit the mayhem Iran may yet cause in Syria. He should also counter any Iranian attempt to encourage its clients Hezbollah and Hamas to resume rocket attacks on Israel.'b'This will be a difficult set of issues to manage in a polarized election year. Is it too much to hope that some G.O.P. leaders might drop their opposition and help implement the deal? Or that more Democrats will back a tough-minded approach to Iran\xe2\x80\x99s troublemaking?'b'One thing is clear: The United States will face a major strategic challenge from Iran this year and next. In order to realize the long-term benefits of this historic deal, the United States must continue to balance engagement with deterrence.'b'Some people cannot stand good news. It troubles their fixed view of the world. These would include Senator Marco Rubio, the Republican presidential candidate, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who were cast into a huff by the confirmed reversal of 'b'Iran'b'\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'nuclear program'b' and its release of several Americans, including Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post.'b'Try a smile, guys. Toughness is no more than empty aggression when it will not admit to misjudgment. Diplomacy delivers.'b'Rezaian is coming home after a year and a half of groundless imprisonment. An American pastor and a former Marine will be reunited with their families. Iran had more than 19,000 first-generation centrifuges installed; that number is now 6,104. Its advanced centrifuges have been slashed from over 1,000 to zero. Its low-enriched uranium stockpile has been cut to 660 pounds from over 19,000.'b'The plutonium route to a bomb has been cut off. Iran is subject to what President Obama called \xe2\x80\x9cthe most comprehensive, intrusive inspection regime ever negotiated to monitor a nuclear program.\xe2\x80\x9d The country\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cbreak-out\xe2\x80\x9d time \xe2\x80\x94 the period needed to rush for a bomb \xe2\x80\x94 has been extended to a year from two to three months.'b'The trauma-induced Iranian-American psychosis, ongoing since the birth of the Islamic Republic in 1979, has been overcome. Two tireless diplomats, Secretary of State John Kerry and the University of Denver-educated Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, speak when needed. American sailors who strayed into Iranian waters are released within 24 hours. A financial dispute outstanding since 1981 is resolved. The world\xe2\x80\x99s 18th-largest economy is about to rejoin the world at a time when the sinking global economy sure could use a jolt. The nuclear deal, even in these early days, is not hermetic. It opens doors.'b'To all of which Rubio responds that Obama has put \xe2\x80\x9ca price on the head of every American abroad\xe2\x80\x9d when he should have used \xe2\x80\x9ccrippling sanctions\xe2\x80\x9d (oh, please, not that crippled phrase again). Netanyahu actually claims that if it were not for Israel \xe2\x80\x9cleading the way\xe2\x80\x9d on sanctions, \xe2\x80\x9cIran would have had a nuclear weapon long ago.\xe2\x80\x9d Iran, he baritones, \xe2\x80\x9chas not relinquished its ambition to obtain 'b'nuclear weapons'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That may be \xe2\x80\x94 or not. A big nation is open for business again, back in the global financial system and world oil market.'b'Netanyahu, Rubio and their ilk believe Iran will use the windfall to do its worst. That cannot be discounted. The United States and Iran remain hostile on most fronts, from Syria to Israel. Revolutionary Guard hard-liners have not drunk the Kool-Aid at the Rouhani-Zarif school of diplomacy. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s imposition of mild new sanctions for banned missile tests was a reminder of differences.'b'But if the developments of recent days demonstrate one thing, it is that Iran, 37 years from its revolution, is delicately poised between hard-liners and reformers, neither of whom can dictate the country\xe2\x80\x99s course, each of whom need the other for now. Imminent parliamentary elections may indicate which camp is ascendant. Whatever happens, it is hard to argue that greater contact with the world will be bad for the large, modernizing, highly educated younger generation. Iran is a pro-American country with a tired anti-American refrain. It has a successful diaspora community ready to help revive the country \xe2\x80\x94 if allowed to do so.'b'The breakthrough with Iran is Obama\xe2\x80\x99s greatest foreign policy achievement, one that may have a transformative effect on the region. It noted that \xe2\x80\x9cthe prospects in a post-deal Iran are vast.\xe2\x80\x9d The country is not \xe2\x80\x9can oil-soaked rentier state,\xe2\x80\x9d like some of its neighbors, but a \xe2\x80\x9cregional power with an industrial economy\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 if a grossly mismanaged one. Its population of 80 million is well-educated, its oil and gas reserves enormous. The country\xe2\x80\x99s pent-up need for foreign investment may amount to $1 trillion. Iran, it concluded, is \xe2\x80\x9cpreparing for takeoff.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Try saying the word Iran without saying the word \xe2\x80\x9cnuclear.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s time. In fact, it\xe2\x80\x99s past time, even if good news is too much for some.'b'SINGAPORE \xe2\x80\x94 The attack that killed four civilians and four terrorists in central Jakarta last Thursday may be a harbinger of more violence to come. It certainly suggests that 'b'ISIS'b', which claimed responsibility, has already transformed the terrorism threat in 'b'Indonesia'b', after years of mostly foiled plots.'b'Indonesia, the country with the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest Muslim population, has a tiny jihadist movement relative to its size. Many factors have kept radicalism in check: a stable, democratic government, little internal conflict, peaceful neighbors and tolerance for advocates of Islamic law. It also has an effective counterterrorism police unit, set up after the 2002 Bali bombings.'b'The Bali bombings, which killed more than 200 people, marked the high point of terrorist capacity in Indonesia. The bombers were from Jemaah Islamiyah (JI), trained on the Afghan-Pakistani border and funded by Al Qaeda. Although those attacks were carried out in the name of the global jihad, most JI members \xe2\x80\x94 like many other local extremist groups \xe2\x80\x94 were focused on avenging the deaths of Muslims in Christian-Muslim fighting in two areas of eastern Indonesia, Maluku and Poso. The groups involved in that struggle in the late 1990s and early 2000s laid the basis for the extensive network of jihadist cells that exists in Indonesia today.'b'With the arrests that followed the Bali attacks and the end of local wars, the jihadist movement weakened and fragmented. But it did not disappear. By the mid-2000s, JI decided violence was largely counterproductive and redirected its efforts toward rebuilding its membership through religious outreach and education. Other extremist groups, some of them splinters from JI, remained committed to jihad, but they lacked JI\xe2\x80\x99s training regimen, indoctrination process and discipline. From 2010 until last week, out of dozens of attempted bomb attacks in Indonesia, not one bomb worked as intended, and three suicide attacks killed only the attackers themselves.'b'But then ISIS emerged, and suddenly there was the potential for Indonesian extremists to go to Syria and get military training, combat experience, ideological indoctrination and international contacts. What had become a low-level threat became more serious again.'b'Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s attacks were reportedly organized and funded by Bahrun Naim, an Indonesian computer expert said to be in Syria. Last August, three men were arrested in Solo, in central Java, for planning to bomb a police post, a church and a Chinese temple on Mr. Naim\xe2\x80\x99s instructions. (The temple was targeted as retaliation for Buddhist violence against Muslims in Myanmar.) In December, four more of Mr. Naim\xe2\x80\x99s men were picked up for plotting attacks against senior police officials and Shiite institutions.'b'Even as terrorist activity has picked up in the last year, Indonesia has been shielded from its effects by the incompetence of would-be attackers, as well as police vigilance. In 2015, the total death toll from terrorism was just eight people; in 2014, it was four. The terrorists of the Solo plot, for example, apparently couldn\xe2\x80\x99t figure out the right chemicals to make explosives. Last Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s attacks could have been much deadlier had the perpetrators been better trained.'b'This weakness could lead Mr. Naim or other terrorists in the Middle East to send operatives back to Indonesia to instruct local extremists. And if the Jakarta attack did not cause the mass casualties its organizers were hoping for, the saturation news coverage it generated may turn that near-failure into a success of sorts, and encourage more attacks. Other ISIS sympathizers in Indonesia may want to strike in the hope of attracting similar attention. The rivalry between the two men who are said to be vying for the leadership of Indonesian fighters in Syria, Bahrumsyah and Abu Jandal, could blow back to Indonesia in the form of lethal competition among their supporters.'b'The need for more preventive measures has therefore become pressing. One necessity is plugging the holes in Indonesia\xe2\x80\x99s anti-terrorism law, which at present does not ban membership in ISIS or similar organizations, or participation in terrorist-training camps abroad. Even when the Indonesian police know that individuals are actively recruiting for ISIS, they have few legal tools to stop them.'b'Another necessary step is to improve supervision and post-release monitoring of convicted terrorists. Pro-ISIS networks are able to disseminate information and contacts in Indonesian prisons, in part because almost every inmate has ready access to a smartphone. At any one time, some 300 individuals are either in prison or police custody awaiting trial on terrorism charges \xe2\x80\x94 many of them still in regular communication with peers on the outside. Dozens are released every year after serving their sentences, and the state authorities do not monitor them afterward.'b'The government must also develop a program for deportees who have been returned to Indonesia. So far some 200 Indonesians who tried to join ISIS have been sent back by Turkish authorities, some 60 percent of them women and minors, and if there ever was a target population for a deradicalization program, this is it. These people, often especially the women, have proved their determination to go to Syria or Iraq, and they may try to do so again. Their whereabouts are known, at least for the moment, and many need assistance because they sold everything before leaving. The Ministry of Social Affairs provides them temporary shelter, but no structured program assists them beyond that. The Indonesian government must work with local civil society organizations to draw these people into new social networks.'b'Finally, Indonesia needs to engage young, computer-savvy Indonesians to develop anti-ISIS messaging on social media and online, where Mr. Naim and other radical groups are actively spreading ISIS propaganda.'b'So far, the combination of Indonesia\xe2\x80\x99s moderate majority, good police work and the incompetence of Indonesian extremists has kept the death toll from terrorist attacks low. But with ISIS now clearly present as a new threat, the government must urgently develop more programs to prevent its appeal from spreading.'b'A 'b'Hong Kong'b' publisher specializing in books banned in 'b'China'b' has disappeared mysteriously, sowing fear among Hong Kongers that the Chinese government is growing bolder about encroaching on their liberties. As the saga continues to unfold, Beijing is reacting bizarrely, and in ways that suggest that the story is the extension of a long-running power struggle at the highest levels of the Chinese Communist Party.'b'Mighty Current is an obscure Hong Kong publishing company that churns out gossipy titles about China and its top leaders. On Dec. 30, Lee Bo, 65, an editor at the company, received a phone order for a dozen books, including several about the private life of President Xi Jinping. That evening he went to get the books in a warehouse in a quiet part of town. He never returned. Two of the company\xe2\x80\x99s co-owners and two employees had disappeared before him, one after the other, beginning last October.'b'Within days of his disappearance, Mr. Lee called his wife, and faxed a message to colleagues saying he was \xe2\x80\x9cO.K.\xe2\x80\x9d and had gone to China \xe2\x80\x9cin his own way.\xe2\x80\x9d This was ominous, for his wife had found Mr. Lee\xe2\x80\x99s travel documents at home; she began to worry that he had been abducted and forcibly brought to the mainland by Chinese government operatives.'b'Concern deepened after the mainstream Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao reported that the local police were in possession of footage from surveillance cameras at the book warehouse showing Mr. Lee being shadowed by strangers as he walks into an elevator. A witness claims to have seen him being forced into a car by several men and driven off.'b'Gui Minhai, one of Mr. Lee\xe2\x80\x99s missing colleagues, who left his home in Thailand under extremely suspicious circumstances a few months ago, appeared earlier this week on Chinese state TV, in China, looking sullen and mouthing an implausible mea culpa about voluntarily returning to the mainland because of a deadly car accident many years ago.'b'The case of the disappearing booksellers has touched a nerve in Hong Kong: Once again, the Chinese authorities seem willing to violate the territory\xe2\x80\x99s Basic Law, its mini constitution since 1997, which guarantees Hong Kongers various political rights, many unavailable in China. Those rights include freedom from arbitrary arrests, especially by Chinese law enforcement agents. They also include the right to eventually elect Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s top leader, the chief executive, by universal suffrage: It was Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s attempt to undermine that right that set off the Umbrella Movement in 2014.'b'Leung Chun-ying, the current chief executive, who is widely regarded as a Communist Party minion, has done little to quiet Hong Kongers\xe2\x80\x99 anxieties. Several articles and editorials in the Global Times, an ultranationalistic Communist Party newspaper in Beijing, have claimed that the Hong Kong publishers violated Chinese law and were subject to arrest for selling books banned in China that were then brought to the mainland. (Communist Party officials themselves are known to be avid readers of such political gossip.)'b'The Global Times has also argued that China\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ccoercive power-wielding departments\xe2\x80\x9d could resort to covert, extraterritorial enforcement so long as they did not \xe2\x80\x9ctie up a captive like a major criminal, manhandle him into a car and drive across the border.\xe2\x80\x9d The statement came across as another expression of the Chinese government\xe2\x80\x99s blatant disregard for the Basic Law, and it further fanned anti-Beijing passions in Hong Kong.'b'Then the story took an intriguing turn. During and after his long tenure as the party\xe2\x80\x99s general secretary and China\xe2\x80\x99s president, Jiang Zemin was known to be at odds with Hu Jintao and Wen Jiabao, later the country\xe2\x80\x99s president and prime minister, respectively. Tensions carried over to Mr. Xi, who in turn became president with the backing of Mr. Hu and Mr. Wen.'b'Bo Xilai, a princeling and Jiang prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9, was purged during the final days of the Hu-Wen rule. Is the Communist Party simply becoming more ruthless in quashing dissenting voices, or is its political judgment slipping?'b'It was inevitable that the prisoner exchange with 'b'Iran'b' would be questioned as soon as it was announced \xe2\x80\x94 and not just by Republicans who mechanically assail anything 'b'President Obama'b' does. The notion of making concessions to a hostile adversary to secure the release of one\xe2\x80\x99s fellow citizens has always been controversial, pitting the innate longing to win their freedom against the risk that handing over money or releasing prisoners in exchange will only encourage the captors to seize more. This dilemma has bedeviled many presidents and governments through history, with no simple or single answer. In this case, President Obama did the right thing.'b'It was right because the negotiations that led to the prisoner exchange were part of a diplomatic process that also produced the landmark agreement on 'b'Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program'b' that has lessened at least one source of tension in a very dangerous corner of the world. The problem is that China accounted for 34 percent of global growth, and the nation\xe2\x80\x99s multiplier effect on emerging markets takes that number to over 50 percent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What if the $100-a-barrel oil price era is over and all these countries whose economies were directly or indirectly propped up by those prices will have to learn to grow the old-fashioned way \xe2\x80\x94 by making goods and services others want to buy? Thanks to steady technological advances in America for fracking, horizontal drilling and using big data to identify deposits, 'b'OPEC'b'\xe2\x80\x99s pricing power has disappeared. Countries that have set their budgets based on $80- to $100-a-barrel oil will find themselves vastly underfunded just when their populations \xe2\x80\x94 in places like Iran, Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Indonesia and Venezuela \xe2\x80\x94 have surged.'b'What if average is over for countries? During the Cold War you could be an average, newly independent state with artificial borders drawn by colonial powers. There were two superpowers ready to throw foreign aid at you, educate your kids in America or Moscow, build up your armed forces and security services and buy your crummy manufactured exports or commodities.'b'But what if the rise of robots, software and automation mean that these countries can\xe2\x80\x99t rely on manufacturing to create mass labor anymore, that the products they can make and sell can\xe2\x80\x99t compete with Chinese goods, that 'b'climate change'b' is pressuring their ecosystems and that neither Russia nor America wants to have anything to do with them because all either wins is a bill?'b'Many of these frail, artificial states don\xe2\x80\x99t correspond to any ethnic, cultural, linguistic or demographic realities. 'b'Reuters reported'b' this week that Germany is telling other E.U. countries that if they don\xe2\x80\x99t prevent the influx of more refugees into Europe from the Mediterranean and \xe2\x80\x9crelieve Berlin of the lonely task of housing refugees, Germany could shut its doors.\xe2\x80\x9d Some Germans even want a border fence. He\xe2\x80\x99s also the author of research that was one motivation for it \xe2\x80\x94 specifically, 'b'a survey'b' of more than 10,000 middle- and high-school students that asked them what mattered most: high individual achievement, happiness or caring for others. Only 22 percent said caring for others.'b'The new report contemplates how the admissions process contributes to that psychology and how it might be changed. Some of those alterations would simultaneously level the playing field for kids applying to college from less advantaged backgrounds.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cColleges spend a huge sum each year sending signals that influence the behavior of millions of students,\xe2\x80\x9d the report notes. Why not rethink those signals to reshape that behavior?'b'The report recommends less emphasis on standardized test scores, which largely correlate with family income.'b'It asks colleges to send a clear message that admissions officers won\xe2\x80\x99t be impressed by more than a few Advanced Placement courses. Poorer high schools aren\xe2\x80\x99t as likely to offer A.P. courses, and a heavy load of them is often cited as a culprit in 'b'sleep deprivation'b', anxiety and depression among students at richer schools.'b'The report also suggests that colleges discourage manic r\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 padding by accepting information on a sharply limited number of extracurricular activities; that they better use essays and references to figure out which students\xe2\x80\x99 community-service projects are heartfelt and which are merely window dressing; and that they give full due to the family obligations and part-time work that some underprivileged kids take on.'b'Stephen Farmer, the vice provost for enrollment and undergraduate admissions at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, praised the report as consistent with his school\xe2\x80\x99s desire \xe2\x80\x9cto be humbler and more alert to the many ways in which people can stake a claim on a place here.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said that the school had already, for example, downgraded the importance of \xe2\x80\x9cA.P. everything,\xe2\x80\x9d which doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily measure true ability or intellectual hunger.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJust making people jump through hoops because we can \xe2\x80\x94 we don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do that,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me, especially when some hoops are so arbitrary that \xe2\x80\x9cwe might as well be admitting these people on the basis of their height or the size of their neck.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTurning the Tide\xe2\x80\x9d follows other reexaminations of the admissions process. A growing number of colleges have made the SAT or ACT optional. And late last year, more than 80 colleges, including all eight in the Ivy League, announced 'b'the formation'b' of the Coalition for Access, Affordability and Success, which is developing a website and application process intended in part to diversify student bodies.'b'Colleges are becoming more conscious of their roles \xe2\x80\x94 too frequently neglected \xe2\x80\x94 in social mobility. They\xe2\x80\x99re recognizing how many admissions measures favor students from affluent families.'b'They\xe2\x80\x99re realizing that many kids admitted into top schools are emotional wrecks or slavish adherents to soulless scripts that forbid the exploration of genuine passions. And they\xe2\x80\x99re acknowledging the extent to which the admissions process has contributed to this.'b'But they still need to stop filling so much of each freshman class with specially tagged legacy cases and athletes and to quit worrying about rankings like those of U.S. News and World Report. Only then will the tide fully turn.'b'The United States and European nations lifted oil and financial sanctions on Iran on Saturday.'b'Tel Aviv \xe2\x80\x94 The Israeli novelist Dorit Rabinyan has hit the jackpot: First, her latest book, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Borderlife'b',\xe2\x80\x9d became an issue of fierce debate and controversy. Then it became a symbol of liberty and progress. And then, of course, it became a 'b'best seller'b'.'b'What spurred Ms. Rabinyan\xe2\x80\x99s good fortune? A bureaucratic decision of little importance. In December, the Ministry of Education decided not to include \xe2\x80\x9cBorderlife\xe2\x80\x9d on its list of required reading for the matriculation exams.'b'Many books are not included in the list of required reading for high school students, of course. But the decision to skip Ms. Rabinyan\xe2\x80\x99s book became an issue of national discussion. \xe2\x80\x9cBorderlife\xe2\x80\x9d chronicles a love story between a Jewish Israeli woman and a Muslim 'b'Palestinian'b' man. \xe2\x80\x9cMarrying a non-Jew is not what the education system wishes to endorse,\xe2\x80\x9d a ministry official 'b'said'b'.'b'The political brouhaha that followed was somewhat predictable. The head of the opposition, the Labor Party leader Isaac Herzog, said he had purchased \xe2\x80\x9cseveral copies\xe2\x80\x9d of the novel. Minister of Education Naftali Bennett of the Jewish Home party defended his ministry\xe2\x80\x99s decision by claiming that the book smears the 'b'Israel'b' Defense Forces. (It does not.) On the left, the decision to keep the book off the reading list became yet another sign of the looming end of our democracy, courtesy of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s right-wing and religious factions. A representative from the left-wing Meretz Party called the Ministry of Education\xe2\x80\x99s decision \xe2\x80\x9cracist censorship.\xe2\x80\x9d On the right, the attack on the ministry was seen as proof that the left does not care about Israel\xe2\x80\x99s Jewish character.'b'Nothing in this war of words was particularly interesting on its own. But the incident brought to light Israel\xe2\x80\x99s confused approach to Jewish identity and the question of assimilation. It showed that many Israelis felt the need to adhere to one of two artificial choices: Either support banning the book or endorse marriages between Jews and non-Jews.'b'In some ways, this gets at a question at the heart of the state of Israel. Jews 'b'account for'b' one-fifth of 1 percent of the world\xe2\x80\x99s population. Jews in Israel are a tiny minority in a vast Muslim region, and Jews in other countries are a tiny minority among Christians. The Jewish fear of demographic calamity is well founded and deeply embedded in the Jewish psyche. Jews know that in bad times they are persecuted, and so their ability to thrive as a distinct group is challenged. And they know that in good times, when Jews are welcomed and integrated, their ability to thrive as a distinct group is challenged in a different way.'b'The creation of a Jewish state was supposed to address both of these challenges, giving Jews a place where they are the majority in power, saving them from hatred and discrimination, and giving them a place where they are the majority culture, saving them from assimilation.'b'There have been complications, but as a rule, it has worked. Jews in Israel are safe from persecution and \xe2\x80\x94 unlike their brethren in other countries \xe2\x80\x94 do not assimilate. They can\xe2\x80\x99t assimilate because they are about 80 percent of the population, and they don\xe2\x80\x99t intermarry because the vast majority of other citizens of Israel are Arabs, with whom Jews have contentious relations. Also, marriage between a Jew and a non-Jew is not even legally possible.'b'This is a blessing for Jewish continuity \xe2\x80\x94 but apparently it\xe2\x80\x99s also a curse for Jewish self-awareness in Israel. When the flap over \xe2\x80\x9cBorderlife\xe2\x80\x9d forced Israeli Jews to take a position on the highly complicated matter of assimilation and intermarriage, many of them proved unequipped to deal with it.'b'On one hand were those who comically overreacted to a fictional story of unfulfilled love. Granted, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the first time the issue had come up. There have been occasional eruptions of hysterical responses to isolated incidents of interfaith relationships in the past. So, clearly, the fear of assimilation is very much alive in Israel. This suggests that many Jewish Israelis have forgotten that living in a Jewish state was supposed to rid them of this fear. If even a Jew in Israel cannot enjoy not having to worry too much about the Jewishness of his or her grandchildren, then one of the most compelling arguments for the country\xe2\x80\x99s existence becomes hollow.'b'On the other hand were those who proved unable to simultaneously reject the ministry\xe2\x80\x99s idiotic rationale for not including the book on its reading list while still accepting as reasonable the position that a Jewish state does not wish to encourage assimilation. Students should be exposed to controversial books, but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean the ministry\xe2\x80\x99s decision symbolized what bigoted country Israel had become. Many seem to have forgotten that a Jewish state is a place where the natural and healthy aspiration for Jewish continuity can and should be unapologetic.'b'But there was one person who refused the binary choice dominating the public discourse: Ms. Rabinyan. While she is no doubt a critic of many of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s policies, she is also a staunch Zionist. It is ridiculous for the ministry to try to portray her as a proponent of assimilation.'b'She didn\xe2\x80\x99t intend \xe2\x80\x9cto endorse romantic relations between Arabs and Jews,\xe2\x80\x9d she told me recently. She also said that she deemed it critically important to have a Jewish majority in Israel \xe2\x80\x94 a reason many Israelis, Ms. Rabinyan included, call for ending the occupation of the Palestinian population in the West Bank. Toney, Union, N.J.'b''b'Provost and vice president for academic affairs, Kean University'b'BENGALURU, India \xe2\x80\x94 The green benches of the lower house of 'b'India'b'\xe2\x80\x99s Parliament were mostly empty on the afternoon of Dec. 18. It was late in the winter session. An earnest but unhurried debate was taking place between Nishikant Dubey, a member of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party, and Shashi Tharoor, a writer, former diplomat and opposition M.P., who was introducing a bill.'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t until the vote was called, and a sudden clamor filled the hall, that the significance of the law became apparent: It proposed to decriminalize gay sex. Dozing M.P.s jumped to their feet and barked across the room. One voice was heard jeering, \xe2\x80\x9cTharoor only needs this bill for himself!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The final tally was 24 votes in favor and 71 votes against, and the bill was sent back to Mr. Tharoor\xe2\x80\x99s drafting table. Yet the debate itself was a hopeful development: Two years after sexual minorities in India were dealt a terrible setback by the Supreme Court, more elected politicians are stepping up for L.G.B.T. rights.'b'Unlike the courts, the politicians speak for constituents. Their statements come from and travel back to the hundreds of thousands of voters they represent \xe2\x80\x94 a national conversation that could do more than any learned court ruling to stop prejudice against L.G.B.T. Indians.'b'Mr. Tharoor intends to change Section 377 of India\xe2\x80\x99s penal code, a Victorian-era provision that punishes \xe2\x80\x9cwhoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal\xe2\x80\x9d with life imprisonment. Convictions are rare, but the law is sometimes used to harass and blackmail gay men and transgenders.'b'In a country where every kind of sexual preference permeates cultural heritage and lived reality, Section 377 is both antiquated and incongruous. Mr. Tharoor\xe2\x80\x99s bill proposed to rewrite the provision, penalizing only intercourse with minors and nonconsensual sex.'b'For many years, the campaign against Section 377 focused on challenging the provision in court. And the strategy seemed to be succeeding: In 2009, an enlightened ruling from the Delhi High Court found that the clause violated the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s promise of equality.'b'But on Dec. 11, 2013, a panel of the Supreme Court reversed that decision, adopting an unusual position on judicial restraint. It was a bewildering abdication of the court\xe2\x80\x99s role as a guardian of civil rights, and devastating news for L.G.B.T. activists.'b'A few days later, I joined an angry gathering on the steps of the town hall in Bengaluru, the city at the heart of India\xe2\x80\x99s technology industry. Just one year earlier, the local Pride March had ended on these stairs \xe2\x80\x94 an especially colorful and buoyant parade, with veteran participants and fearless trans-folk joined by giggling tech geeks hoisting banners branded by Google and Goldman Sachs. After the Supreme Court decision, however, the protesters wore black, and chanted, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re criminal and you know it, clap your hands!\xe2\x80\x9d The occasion was called the Day of Rage.'b'Soon, though, the insurgent anger mixed with astonishment at the outpouring of solidarity. On Twitter, even self-described \xe2\x80\x9cHindu far/extreme-right-winger patriot-capitalist-conspicuous-consumers\xe2\x80\x9d called for Section 377 to be revised by executive ordinance. The evening of the protest, the prime-time news shows were thundering against the Supreme Court decision, and inviting politicians to state their positions on it.'b'Through the gloom there was a glimmer of consolation: The action had just shifted out of the courts and into popular politics.'b'The first formal statement against the ruling came from the maverick Aam Aadmi Party, which had recently captivated the urban middle class with its campaign against corruption and politics-as-usual. It was followed by the Congress Party. Rahul Gandhi, the Congress\xe2\x80\x99s vice-president, said that sexual preferences \xe2\x80\x9cshould be left to individuals\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a mild but unprecedented statement from a leader of India\xe2\x80\x99s then-ruling party.'b'That declaration pushed the Congress\xe2\x80\x99 main rival, the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, to endorse the Supreme Court verdict. The B.J.P. won the 2014 general election, and today, after a year and a half in power, its leaders have softened their position on L.G.B.T. rights. At a literary festival in November, Arun Jaitley, the minister of finance conceded, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen millions of people the world over have alternative sexual preferences, it is too late in the day to propound a view that they should be jailed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Section 377 remains for now, and as Mr. Tharoor learned, India\xe2\x80\x99s dysfunctional Parliament is still some way from changing it. But the gradual accretion of support for reform from politicians of various persuasions is creating what a wise judicial decision might well have pre-empted: a national conversation about accepting and respecting different sexual lifestyles.'b'A progressive Supreme Court ruling would have revised the law all at once, but it would have done relatively little to change the social stigma and institutional hostility faced by sexual minorities. When major political parties affirm their support for L.G.B.T. Indians, it sends a different kind of writ to both their supporters and officials under their control.'b'In the spring, Mr. Tharoor will reintroduce his bill. He hopes that a full discussion in Parliament will be an opportunity to broadcast that L.G.B.T. rights are \xe2\x80\x9cnot about sex but about freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d The chances of the bill\xe2\x80\x99s passing are still slim, at least until the B.J.P.\xe2\x80\x99s more liberal voices prevail over the bigoted ones. Indian politicians can be expected to prevaricate, pass the buck or pander to religious conservatives in their base.'b'But some elected politicians have already begun to grapple with their responsibility toward sexual minorities, and thanks to the parallel efforts of activists, a small but growing legislative agenda for queer rights has become evident. A new bill protecting the rights of transgenders has passed in the upper house of Parliament and will be presented in the lower house this year. Last January, Madhu Bai Kinnar was elected mayor of Raigarh \xe2\x80\x94 the first transgender elected to run any Indian city.'b'Unlike in the United States, where L.G.B.T. rights are an issue too hot for many politicians to touch, in India homophobia is diffuse, and hardly features in our culture wars. And so the prospect grows brighter that Section 377 will eventually be changed through legislation \xe2\x80\x94 through a process that appeals not just to India\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution, but to its society as well.'b''b'The New York Times Opinion section presents three groundbreaking virtual reality films from the Sundance New Frontier lineup. These videos explore a range of topics and new approaches to nonfiction storytelling.'b''b'__'b'DANFUNG DENNIS'b''b'No matter how'b' enlightened any one of us may be, we are fundamentally limited to our own points of view \xe2\x80\x94 but it is human nature to try to broaden our perspective. For me, that\xe2\x80\x99s where V.R. comes in. I have found that the medium has an extraordinary capacity to convey the kinds of feelings of presence and place I\xe2\x80\x99ve always aspired to capture through photojournalism.'b'As a young photographer, I was transfixed by the iconic wartime images of great photographers like Robert Capa and James Nachtwey. Their vision of the world far transcended my own. Hoping to emulate their effect, I trained myself to follow in their footsteps, covering the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan as a freelance photojournalist for The New York Times and Newsweek.'b'But I found that my photographs were not having the impact that I had hoped. There was something too abstract and flat about them, a quality that allowed anyone viewing them to remain distant from images of suffering. Frustrated by the barriers, I built a camera that could shoot steady, cinematic video in a war zone, and I made a feature-length film following a United States Marine in Afghanistan.'b'While the film provided a glimpse into the brutal reality of war, it was only a small window into that world. I wanted to go further, to pull people through that window onto the front lines and let them witness it firsthand.'b'I started the technology company Condition One in order to build a new camera to shoot in stereoscopic 3D, 360-degree video. We want to initiate a new generation of viewers jaded by flat images into the visceral emotions of being immersed in a whole new world.'b'The power of virtual reality is its command of presence \xe2\x80\x94 its ability to transport the viewer into another world, and have him feel present in it. These experiences are technically difficult to create and require significant computing power, but once presence is achieved and sustained, it is breathtaking.'b'One of the first tests I did with our prototype V.R. camera was leaving it in the path of a herd of wild American bison. When I viewed the result through a V.R. headset, I watched them walk straight up to me, snort in my ear and look me straight in the eye. I felt the strong presence of this massive animal, a descendant of a species that was once ruthlessly hunted to the brink of extinction. And I found that I cared about this bison in a much deeper way than I had before.'b'In V.R., we instinctively feel a surge of empathy for those whose experiences we are immersed in. The suffering of people in war zones becomes our suffering, just as the killing of animals in the wild and in factory farms becomes a source of our pain as well.'b'Referencing his own limitations of perspective, Einstein once wrote of grief, \xe2\x80\x9cOur task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our circle of compassion to embrace all living creatures and the whole of nature in its beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Through V.R., we now have a chance to do just that.'b''b'Danfung Dennis is the chief executive and founder of Condition One. His documentary film \xe2\x80\x9cHell and Back Again\xe2\x80\x9d won the 2011 Sundance Grand Jury Prize and was nominated for a 2012 Academy Award. This work is adapted from Condition One\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'virtual reality film'b' that is having its premiere at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival.'b''b'__'b'NONNY DE LA PE\xc3\x91A'b''b'I had my first'b' \xe2\x80\x9cwalk around\xe2\x80\x9d virtual reality experience in 2009, with researchers studying the \xe2\x80\x9cbystander effect\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the phenomenon whereby the presence of others supposedly discourages any one individual from intervening in an emergency situation. There was no way they could study these findings in a controlled setting: You can\xe2\x80\x99t expose subjects to real violence. So instead they turned to V.R., building a scenario where a young man walks into a bar and finds himself violently confronted by a drunk hooligan supporting a rival team.'b'As I walked around the scene wearing goggles, I became deeply absorbed in the drama. Suddenly, I realized that the cable on my headset was straining as I tried to move closer in order to \xe2\x80\x94 intervene? Wow. It was like nothing I had ever experienced before.'b'As a journalist, I knew immediately that this was a space where important stories could be told. As a documentary filmmaker, I had often faced the challenge of having to build a visual recreation of an event from the past. And so I began to experiment: Could I use virtual reality to offer a better understanding of how events transpired, and to make people connect to stories they might otherwise ignore? Could I reach younger audiences who are accustomed to digital worlds and gaming platforms, and help them become informed global citizens? To me, these are the ultimate goals of journalism.'b'I dedicated the next seven years of my life to finding out, using sound as a foundation for storytelling. With my film \xe2\x80\x9cHunger in Los Angeles,\xe2\x80\x9d the first V.R. documentary shown at the Sundance Film Festival, in 2012, I used real audio from a food bank where a man waiting in the long line collapsed into a diabetic coma before he received food. At the premiere, I watched with amazement as my audience tried to walk around the \xe2\x80\x9cseizure victim\xe2\x80\x9d on the ground, while many emerged from the goggles crying.'b'I pushed further with \xe2\x80\x9cUse of Force,\xe2\x80\x9d using cellphone video to recreate a scene in which United States Border Patrol officers beat and Tasered a migrant to death. I brought a witness to a lab, where I motion-captured her bodily and facial movements while she recalled her memories of the night. Rather than watching a video of her telling you what happened, you hear and see her own re-creation through her body as much as her words. The story is visceral.'b'I kept experimenting with what this remarkable medium can do, concentrating on the kind of socially consequential topics that are sometimes difficult to keep an audience focused on with traditional journalism techniques. With \xe2\x80\x9cProject Syria,\xe2\x80\x9d you stand inside a thoroughly researched re-creation of a street in Aleppo as a bomb goes off. The segment is based on video and audio captured before and after the real event, photographs of the location and Google Earth maps. In \xe2\x80\x9cOne Dark Night,\xe2\x80\x9d about the shooting of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman, you see only the events that were documented by 911 calls, within a simulation based on architectural plans of the condominium complex and Mr. Zimmerman\xe2\x80\x99s videotaped police testimony.'b'We were able to push even further with \xe2\x80\x9cKiya,\xe2\x80\x9d a tragic story of a domestic violence homicide that you see here. In this film, two sisters try to save a third sister from being shot by her former boyfriend. It uses Freedom of Information Act material gathered after the homicide; interviews with the sisters and the police; and most important, recordings of two 911 calls that captured the entire sequence of events to re-enact a tragedy and bring new attention to the issue of domestic violence.'b'I have now seen tens of thousands of people respond to these pieces, and I know that they work. They tell important stories in an entirely new way, and they use the immersive power of virtual reality \xe2\x80\x94 its ability to generate intense empathy on the part of the viewer \xe2\x80\x94 to wring from the audience the intense emotional connection that these stories deserve. Kiya\xe2\x80\x99s story still haunts me, and I hope that you are moved by it, too.'b''b'Nonny de la Pe\xc3\xb1a is an immersive journalist in Los Angeles and the chief executive of Emblematic, a company that makes virtual reality content. \xe2\x80\x9cKiya\xe2\x80\x9d is her fourth work at the Sundance Film Festival.'b''b'__'b'GABO ARORA and CHRIS MILK'b''b'In 2014'b', throughout the United States, the fear of Ebola was everywhere, magnified by constant media coverage and the vague promise that no one was immune. But we were mostly thinking of ourselves, not those who were actually dying on faraway soil.'b'In Liberia, Ebola was real, killing people by the thousands. But no matter how much information our round-the-clock news coverage provided, nothing on TV could convey the sensation of being there and experiencing the crisis. So we decided to create \xe2\x80\x9cWaves of Grace.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Whereas traditional media conveys information \xe2\x80\x94 often stoking fear and sensationalism in the process \xe2\x80\x94 V.R. can convey connection and empathy for our fellow human beings.'b'We knew right away that the story should be told in the voice of a survivor, so we sought out Decontee Davis, who was already emerging as a survivor advocate. At first she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t convinced, so we put her in a V.R. headset and played one of our previous films for her, about a refugee. Right away she understood the unique potential of V.R. to summon emotion in the viewer.'b'Through this medium, you not only hear Ms. Davis\xe2\x80\x99s story of survival, but you feel it. It is overwhelming, a physical force that radiates from her, detectable only by humans\xe2\x80\x99 sixth sense: empathy. After we met her, we realized that telling her story wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t just be better in V.R. It was only wholly tellable in V.R. We were able to tell not only her own unique story, but Liberia\xe2\x80\x99s as well. People need to know \xe2\x80\x94 not simply watch \xe2\x80\x94 what it feels like to find hope amid death and disease.'b'We want \xe2\x80\x9cWaves of Grace\xe2\x80\x9d to add a new perspective to the Ebola crisis: your own. Rather than swarm the viewer with fear-inducing stats and information, through V.R. this film opens a door for the viewer. The experience welcomes you into another person\xe2\x80\x99s life to share her heartaches and healing. Ms. Davis taught us how to persevere in the face of abject despair. She brought hope into our lives that we\xe2\x80\x99ll take with us long after the containment of the Ebola crisis. We hope that after experiencing her story, you will feel the same.'b''b'Gabo Arora is a filmmaker and the founder of 'b'UNVR.org'b', the United Nations\xe2\x80\x99 virtual reality lab. Chris Milk is the founder and chief executive of the virtual reality company Vrse, and creative director of the V.R. production studio Vrse.works. \xe2\x80\x9cWaves of Grace\xe2\x80\x9d was originally published in the 'b'Vrse app'b'.'b''b'EVER since I became a conservative as a teenager growing up in the city of Flint, Mich., I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard again and again from Republican leaders about their commitment to minorities and the poor. Nobody has ever wanted to hear about what was happening in Flint.'b'This is not just any town but one of Michigan\xe2\x80\x99s largest. The location of one of the first sit-down strikes in the United States. The once proud home of General Motors. And it was where I was born and went to school.'b'My memories of growing up in that sad-sack town in the 1980s are vivid. Living near notorious drug houses. Being mugged for a bottle of soda when I was 12. Being stopped by the police at 16 because they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe a white person lived in my neighborhood. Even back then, Flint was considered one of the worst major cities in America.'b'In the decades since, nothing has seemed to go right. Because nothing has gone right. Houses collapsed, as if the earth was slowly swallowing up the town.'b'We had the nation\xe2\x80\x99s highest arson rate and could afford only one full-time arson inspector. The city has long been listed among the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most violent. There were divisive recall elections and new mayors \xe2\x80\x94 almost all of them Democrats \xe2\x80\x94 were ushered in with new promises.'b'But the Republicans were never there, until 2011, that is, when the first of four state-appointed emergency managers was brought in by the Snyder administration to address the city\xe2\x80\x99s financial woes. Why aren\xe2\x80\x99t they in Flint today, shipping in water bottles and holding fund-raisers for kids now condemned to lowered expectations because their brains were poisoned by lead?'b'It cannot be, as the left would tell us, because Flint has a large African-American population. It\xe2\x80\x99s not easy to go to a place where nobody knows you or likes you. It\xe2\x80\x99s not easy to make change.'b'I do not for a moment question the sincerity of those voices in the party who call for a new approach to persistent poverty or who seek to welcome African-Americans and others into the fold. I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible for conservatives to help a place like Flint. But first you have to show up.'b'Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders don\xe2\x80\x99t agree on much. Nor do the Black Lives Matter movement, the Occupy Wall Street protests and the armed ranchers who seized public lands in Oregon. But in the insurgent presidential campaigns and in social activism across the spectrum, a common thread is people angry at the way this country is no longer working for many ordinary citizens.'b'And they\xe2\x80\x99re right: The system is often fundamentally unfair, and ordinary voices are often unheard.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easy (and appropriate!) to roll one\xe2\x80\x99s eyes at Trump, for a demagogic tycoon is not the natural leader of a revolution of the disenfranchised. But the populist frustration is understandable. One of the most remarkable political science studies in recent years upended everything rosy we learned in civics classes.'b'Martin Gilens of Princeton University and Benjamin I. Page of Northwestern University 'b'found'b' that in policy-making, views of ordinary citizens essentially don\xe2\x80\x99t matter. They examined 1,779 policy issues and found that attitudes of wealthy people and of business groups mattered a great deal to the final outcome \xe2\x80\x94 but that preferences of average citizens were almost irrelevant.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the United States, our findings indicate, the majority does 'b'not'b' rule,\xe2\x80\x9d they concluded. \xe2\x80\x9cMajorities of the American public actually have little influence over the policies our government adopts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One reason is that our political system is increasingly driven by money: Tycoons can\xe2\x80\x99t quite buy politicians, but they can lease them. Elected officials are hamsters on a wheel, always desperately raising money for the next election. And the donors who matter most are a small group; just 158 families and the companies they control 'b'donated almost half the money'b' for the early stages of the presidential campaign.'b'That in turn is why the tax code is full of loopholes that benefit the wealthy. This is why you get accelerated depreciation for buying a private plane. It\xe2\x80\x99s why the wealthiest 400 American taxpayers (all with income of more than $100 million) ended up paying 'b'an average federal tax rate of less than 23 percent'b' for 2013, and 'b'less than 17 percent'b' the year before.'b'Conversely, it\xe2\x80\x99s why the mostly black children in Flint, Mich., have been poisoned by lead coming out of the tap: As Hillary Clinton 'b'noted Sunday 'b'in the Democratic debate, this wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have happened in an affluent white suburb.
