Some 535,000 children across the country suffer lead poisoning, 'b'according to'b' the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.'b'Those kids never have a chance \xe2\x80\x94 not just because of the lead, but also because they don\xe2\x80\x99t matter to the American political system. American politicians are too busy chasing campaign donors to help them.'b'There are solutions \xe2\x80\x94 more about that in a moment \xe2\x80\x94 but a starting point is to recognize that this public mood of impotence and unfairness is rooted in something real. Median wages have stalled or dropped. Mortality rates for young white adults 'b'are rising,'b' partly because so many self-medicate with painkillers or heroin. Blacks have been protected from this phenomenon by another unfairness: Studies indicate that doctors discriminate against black patients and are less likely to prescribe them painkillers.'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s political and economic inequalities feed each other. The richest 1 percent in the U.S. now own substantially 'b'more wealth'b' than the bottom 90 percent.'b'Solutions are complex, imperfect and uncertain, but the biggest problem is not a lack of tools but a lack of will. A basic step to equalize opportunity would be to invest in education for disadvantaged children as the civil rights issue of the 21st'b''b' century.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think any candidate seriously aiming to reduce inequality would have a mild increase in tax on the rich to fund higher school spending,\xe2\x80\x9d says Nicholas Bloom, a Stanford 'b'expert on inequality'b'. I would add that investments in education should begin early, with high-quality prekindergarten for at-risk children.'b'We also need political solutions to repair our democracy so that ordinary citizens count along with the affluent. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no magic bullet that will set things right, but meaningful campaign finance reform must be at the center of a reform agenda,\xe2\x80\x9d Gilens says. \xe2\x80\x9cStates and cities are leading the way. Arizona, Maine and Connecticut have had statewide, publicly funded \xe2\x80\x98clean election\xe2\x80\x99 systems for some time with varying degrees of success.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One step toward transparency: 'b'President Obama could require'b' federal contractors to disclose political contributions.'b'Right now, the bitterness at America\xe2\x80\x99s grass roots is often channeled in ways that are divisive and destructive: at immigrants, say, or at Muslims. The challenge will be to leverage the populist frustration into constructive postelection policy. But it has been done before.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cReforms were adopted in the first Gilded Age, an era similarly plagued by government dysfunction, political corruption and enormous economic inequality,\xe2\x80\x9d Gilens notes. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps they will be again.\xe2\x80\x9d For the sake of our country, let\xe2\x80\x99s work for an encore.'b'On Wednesday, the 'b'Supreme Court'b' gave an important victory to regular Americans, ruling that companies may not avoid class-action lawsuits by offering to buy off the individual plaintiffs before they can establish a class of similarly harmed people.'b'The 6-to-3 decision was a surprising break from a long line of 'b'extremely pro-business and anti-class-action rulings'b' by the five conservative justices, led by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr.'b'Class-action suits are a critical type of litigation that allows people with relatively small claims to band together to hold corporations liable for wrongdoing. A single lawsuit by one individual is often not worth a lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s time, even if a company has violated the rights of large numbers of people. That\xe2\x80\x99s why it\xe2\x80\x99s crucial to allow all those harmed to seek the same relief in a single suit.'b'Obviously, companies want to evade such litigation at all costs, and with the help of sympathetic justices they have devised all sorts of ways to do that. Over the last decade, the court\xe2\x80\x99s conservatives have consistently made it harder for 'b'consumers'b' and 'b'workers'b' to vindicate their rights, either by increasing the requirements for bringing a class action or by 'b'eliminating the option altogether'b' through 'b'strict arbitration clauses'b'.'b'This 'b'case, Campbell-Ewald Co. v. Gomez,'b' started in 2006, when Jose Gomez received a text message from Campbell-Ewald, a company the United States Navy had hired to recruit young people who had consented to getting such messages. Mr. Gomez was nearly 40 at the time and had not consented. He sued the company for $1,500 \xe2\x80\x94 the maximum remedy under a federal law that protects people against unwanted telephone solicitations. He also began the process of bringing a class-action lawsuit to represent thousands of people who had been sent the same messages without permission.'b'Rather than fight, Campbell-Ewald offered to pay Mr. Gomez what he asked for, but declined to admit it had broken the law. He refused the money, and proceeded with his class action. The company argued that its offer ended the lawsuit, and thus the basis for a class action, since there was no longer any controversy for a court to rule on.'b'The Supreme Court disagreed. In an 'b'opinion'b' written by Justice 'b'Ruth Bader Ginsburg'b', the court ruled that a plaintiff\xe2\x80\x99s legal claim is not voided if he or she does not accept a defendant\xe2\x80\x99s offer, even if the offer is exactly what the plaintiff requested. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen a plaintiff rejects such an offer \xe2\x80\x94 however good the terms \xe2\x80\x94 her interest in the lawsuit remains just what it was before. And so too does the court\xe2\x80\x99s ability to grant her relief,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Ginsburg wrote.'b'This was the right outcome. Had the court ruled the other way, it would have allowed companies to make settlement offers just to head off class-action suits \xe2\x80\x94 preventing many class actions from ever getting through the courthouse door. Chief Justice Roberts, who was joined in dissent by Justices Antonin Scalia and Samuel Alito Jr., was not concerned with deeply damaging the class-action process. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the defendant is willing to give the plaintiff everything he asks for, there is no case or controversy to adjudicate, and the lawsuit is moot,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote. But following that reasoning \xe2\x80\x9cwould place the defendant in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s seat,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Ginsburg replied, since it costs a company virtually nothing to pay off an individual plaintiff.'b'The court left open the question of whether a company could still dodge liability by depositing the full amount of a plaintiff\xe2\x80\x99s claim in an account, leading a trial court to rule in favor of the plaintiff. Under the logic of Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s ruling, the justices should close that loophole when corporations try to exploit it and protect what remains of the class action from the unrelenting efforts of business to undermine it.'b'IN his vitriolic dissent last June from the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'same-sex marriage decision'b', Justice Antonin Scalia accused the majority of having carried out a \xe2\x80\x9cjudicial putsch.\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Scalia should know. He and his four conservative colleagues were then in the process of executing one themselves.'b'On June 30, four days after handing down the marriage decision, Obergefell v. Hodges, the court announced that it would hear a major challenge to the future of public-employee labor unions. That case, 'b'Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association'b', was argued last week. As was 'b'widely reported'b', the outcome appears foreordained: the court will vote 5 to 4 to overturn 'b'a precedent'b' that for 39 years has permitted public-employee unions to charge nonmembers a \xe2\x80\x9cfair-share\xe2\x80\x9d fee representing the portion of union dues that go to representing all employees in collective bargaining and grievance proceedings. As the exclusive bargaining agent, a union has a legal duty to represent everyone in the unit, whether members or not; the fee addresses the problem of \xe2\x80\x9cfree riders\xe2\x80\x9d and the resentment engendered by those who accept the union\xe2\x80\x99s help while letting their fellow workers foot the bill.'b'The stakes are obviously high for the millions of workers and thousands of contracts covered by these arrangements in the 23 states that now permit them. If the court accepts the argument that the mandatory fees amount to compelled speech in violation of the objecting employees\xe2\x80\x99 First Amendment rights, public-employee unions would forfeit hundreds of millions of dollars in dues revenue. New York and 20 other states filed a brief in support of California, which is defending its fair-share system, to argue that these provisions \xe2\x80\x9care important to ensuring a stable collective-bargaining partner with the wherewithal to help devise workplace arrangements that promote labor peace.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I want to focus here, however, not on the implications the Friedrichs case holds for the public workplace, but on what it means for the Supreme Court. Actually, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t express my concern better than Justice Stephen G. Breyer did last week when he questioned Michael A. Carvin, the lawyer for the 10 California teachers who are challenging the state\xe2\x80\x99s labor law. Justice Breyer was referring to the compromise at the heart of the 1977 precedent, Abood v. Detroit Board of Education, that Mr. Carvin was asking the court to overrule. The court in that case upheld the constitutionality of the fair-share fee as long as it was limited to the union\xe2\x80\x99s collective-bargaining expenses and did not subsidize the union\xe2\x80\x99s political or other \xe2\x80\x9cnonchargeable\xe2\x80\x9d activities.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, in your mind,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Breyer asked Mr. Carvin, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you can say from the point of view of this court\xe2\x80\x99s role in this society in that if \xe2\x80\x94 of course, we can overrule a compromise that was worked out over 40 years and has lasted reasonably well \xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d The justice ruminated for a moment on his own practice of filing dissenting opinions, and then returned to his point: \xe2\x80\x9cYou start overruling things, what happens to the country thinking of us as a kind of stability in a world that is tough because it changes a lot?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed. Exactly seven years ago, in a public-employee labor case from Maine, Justice Breyer wrote an opinion that cited the Abood decision and included this sentence: \xe2\x80\x9cThe First Amendment permits the government to require both public sector and private sector employees who do not wish to join a union designated as the exclusive collective-bargaining representative at their unit of employment to pay that union a service fee as a condition of their continued employment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The opinion continued: \xe2\x80\x9cThe court has determined that the First Amendment burdens accompanying the payment requirement are justified by the government\xe2\x80\x99s interest in preventing free riding by nonmembers who benefit from the union\xe2\x80\x99s collective bargaining activities and in maintaining peaceful labor relations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The case was 'b'Locke v. Karass'b'. The decision was unanimous.'b'What changed since 2009? How could the court go from unquestioning acceptance of a long-lived precedent to a situation in which all that remains in doubt is whether that same precedent will be overturned in early June or late June? In the answer to that question lie some disturbing observations about the Roberts court.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no secret that in recent years, major segments of the Republican Party have declared open season on public employee unions \xe2\x80\x94 selectively, of course. Police unions and correctional officers\xe2\x80\x99 unions, which have stood in the way of reform-minded policy initiatives in states and cities across the country, have been exempt as targets. Conservative and Tea Party ire has instead been focused on teachers\xe2\x80\x99 unions. It\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'not an accident'b' that when Mr. Carvin (a leading figure behind the two failed challenges to the Affordable Care Act) and the right-wing foundations supporting his lawsuit set out to recruit plaintiffs, they looked for teachers and not prison guards.'b'Reading the 'b'transcript'b' of last week\xe2\x80\x99s argument, I felt as though I had stumbled into the inner sanctum of 'b'Wisconsin\xe2\x80\x99s union-busting governor'b', Scott Walker. Both Justice Scalia and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy suggested that when it comes to public employment, there can be no real distinction between a union\xe2\x80\x99s workplace activities and its political activities.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe problem is that everything that is collectively bargained with the government is within the political sphere, almost by definition,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice Scalia said, addressing Edward C. Dumont, California\xe2\x80\x99s solicitor general.'b'Justice Kennedy elaborated at length: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s almost axiomatic. When you are dealing with a governmental agency, many critical points are matters of public concern. And is it not true that many teachers strongly, strongly disagree with the union position on teacher tenure, on merit pay, on merit promotion, on classroom size?\xe2\x80\x9d He continued: \xe2\x80\x9cThe term is \xe2\x80\x98free rider.\xe2\x80\x99 The union basically is making these teachers \xe2\x80\x98compelled riders\xe2\x80\x99 for issues on which they strongly disagree.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s about as unconstrained and revealing a rant as I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard from the Supreme Court bench. It happens also to be based on some false premises. California labor law does not in fact permit collective bargaining over teacher tenure or standards for termination or budget-driven layoffs. I\xe2\x80\x99m no expert on California labor law; I read it in the 'b'union\xe2\x80\x99s brief'b'. But the details hardly matter. What matters is the glaring anti-union animus and the obvious fact that if everything a public employee union does is deemed political, the Abood compromise, based on a distinction between collective-bargaining activities and everything else, necessarily collapses.'b'And what exactly is it about the California teachers union\xe2\x80\x99s activities that the plaintiffs find objectionable? Impossible to say. The initial complaint referred only to their dislike of \xe2\x80\x9cmany of the union\xe2\x80\x99s public policy positions, including positions taken in collective bargaining,\xe2\x80\x9d but the plaintiffs refused to be more specific or to cooperate with the union in developing an evidentiary record. Instead, the plaintiffs under Mr. Carvin\xe2\x80\x99s direction sought to lose the case as quickly as possible, to speed it on its way to the Supreme Court. They asked the Federal District Court to rule against them, which it did, and they then asked the United States Court of Appeals to affirm that negative judgment, which it promptly did in a two-page summary opinion, observing that the outcome was \xe2\x80\x9cgoverned by controlling Supreme Court and Ninth Circuit precedent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To call this litigation pathway unusual is an understatement. But it was hardly a shot in the dark. In majority opinions in 'b'2012'b' and again in 2014, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. \xe2\x80\x94 yes, the same Justice Alito who signed Justice Breyer\xe2\x80\x99s opinion back in 2009 \xe2\x80\x94 suggested that he was ready and willing to revisit the Abood precedent. In the more recent case, 'b'Harris v. Quinn'b', he called Abood \xe2\x80\x9ctroubling\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cquestionable on several grounds.\xe2\x80\x9d But neither of those two cases offered a target for a direct hit. The current case was manufactured to serve that role.'b'If the political atmosphere surrounding public employee unions has changed, so has the court\xe2\x80\x99s vision of the role of the First Amendment. The court issued the 'b'Citizens United decision'b', with its embrace of a First Amendment right to unlimited corporate (and union) political spending, a year to the day after Justice Breyer\xe2\x80\x99s opinion in the Maine labor case. In the intervening six years, the Roberts court has waved the First Amendment banner ever higher to undermine long-accepted governmental regulatory authority. Not too long ago, it was federalism \xe2\x80\x94 states\xe2\x80\x99 rights \xe2\x80\x94 that seemed to energize conservatives on the Supreme Court. The Abood regime is in fact more than respectful of states\xe2\x80\x99 rights: states are enabled but not required to adopt a fair-share fee system, and 22 states have chosen against it. But federalism can\xe2\x80\x99t save the unions from the ever more powerful First Amendment.'b'So what we have here are the majority\xe2\x80\x99s policy preferences conveniently clad in First Amendment armor. But even the best armor is vulnerable, and as the court strides recklessly into a danger zone, I\xe2\x80\x99m left with Justice Breyer\xe2\x80\x99s question: What\xe2\x80\x99s the country to think?'b'In November, I was the guest speaker at the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan\xe2\x80\x99s annual dinner. Before I spoke, the group called to the stage a longtime investigative journalist who had done tremendous work bringing the Flint water crisis to light. His name was Curt Guyette. He, in turn, recognized the scientists, doctors, politician, lawyers and activists who had helped in that quest.'b'I was embarrassed to admit that I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t heard about this crisis before that night, but the details they laid out hit me with the force of a train.'b'Local officials made the decision to switch the city\xe2\x80\x99s water supply in 2014 from its longtime source supplied by the city of Detroit, which contained corrosion-control chemicals, to the Flint River, which did not contain those chemicals. It was billed as a cost-saving measure for a city facing financial distress.'b'But the Flint River water corroded the city\xe2\x80\x99s pipes and leached poisonous metals into the city\xe2\x80\x99s water supply, including lead, which is particularly dangerous if consumed by children or pregnant women.'b'Some of the water 'b'tested so high for lead contamination'b' that it was \xe2\x80\x9cmore than twice the amount at which the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency classifies water as hazardous waste,\xe2\x80\x9d according to Guyette.'b''b'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention'b':'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo safe blood lead level in children has been identified. Lead exposure can affect nearly every system in the body. Because lead exposure often occurs with no obvious symptoms, it frequently goes unrecognized.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The residents of Flint consumed this poisonous water, knowing that something was wrong because of its changing colors and smells, but mostly unaware of just how dangerous it was.'b'An entire American city exposed to poisoned water. How could this be?'b'It is hard to imagine this happening in a city that didn\xe2\x80\x99t have Flint\xe2\x80\x99s demographic profile \xe2\x80\x94 mostly black and disproportionately poor.'b'And, it got worse: Officials apparently kept assuring residents that things were under control, even though many residents knew intuitively that they were not.'b'As The New York Times 'b'reported in October'b':'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll along, through months of complaints from residents of this city about the peculiar colors and odors they said were coming from their faucets, the overriding message from the authorities here was that the water would be just fine.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And not only did the city not respond quickly, according to Guyette\xe2\x80\x99s reporting, it artificially suppressed finding on lead levels, and when the federal Environmental Protection Agency offered to help remedythe problem, city officials apparently declined the help.'b'The damage done by this misguided decision, and the callous apathy on the part of officials to quickly admit their error and work expeditiously to correct it, displays a staggering level of ineptitude, if not criminal negligence.'b'Lawsuits are sure to spring up by the thousand. It\xe2\x80\x99s not clear whether anyone will be held criminally responsible, but it is highly likely that civil suits for damages could be successful, so much so that they could bring the state to its knees.'b'The possible damage seems almost incalculable and one can imagine that a jury would find that the monetary damages should match.'b'I have not stopped thinking about Flint since November, and now the story has gained new urgency as it has become a cause celebre and entered the national political debate.'b'Bernie Sanders has called for the resignation of Gov. Governor Snyder should resign.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Hillary Clinton has condemned the Snyder administration, called for the federal government to \xe2\x80\x9cstep up\xe2\x80\x9d in the crisis and 'b'dispatched two top campaign aides'b' to meet with Flint\xe2\x80\x99s mayor.'b'(On Tuesday that mayor, Karen Weaver, 'b'endorsed Clinton for president'b'.)'b'The Rev. Snyder\xe2\x80\x99s Katrina, but it will become your Bush-Flying-Over-New Orleans Moment if you come to Michigan and then just fly away.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'(Obama did not go to Flint during his visit to the state, but 'b'did address it while there'b', and met with the mayor of Flint in Washington the day before.)'b'Snyder conceded Monday that the Flint water crisis was 'b'indeed his Katrina'b' and on Tuesday, during a State of the State address, 'b'apologized for the crisis'b'.'b'But Moore tweeted a response Tuesday that might well capture the outrage many feel about this story:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn Sat, I called Flint \xe2\x80\x98Governor Snyder\xe2\x80\x99s Katrina.\xe2\x80\x99 Today he said he accepts that comparison. Except Bush didn\xe2\x80\x99t cause the hurricane. 'b'#'b'Jail'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gov. While the federal website appears to be working well, the transition to a different system could cause problems.'b'The Kentucky exchange has made it extremely easy for people to enroll in a plan appropriate for them. If someone tries to sign up for private insurance but is judged by the exchange to be poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, the application is forwarded to Medicaid, which enrolls the person. Mr. Bevin needs to put a very high priority on providing a smooth exchange of information and enough enrollment assistants to help people find the right coverage.'b'The more vexing issue is what Mr. Bevin will do about Medicaid, which has enrolled far more people in Kentucky since its expansion in January 2014 than have the private plans sold on Kynect. All of you who think he\xe2\x80\x99s still just a free spirit flying around the country saying whatever the hell comes into his mind, be aware. This is now an increasingly careful politician.'b'Cruz, he said, without actually mentioning any names, is a tool of the oil companies. \xe2\x80\x9cHe goes wherever the votes are,\xe2\x80\x9d Trump said contemptuously.'b'None of that here, God knows.'b'As a political journalist, you never forget the first time you stop just covering a politician and start identifying with her. The first time you wed your high-minded vision of what politics should be to a real candidate\xe2\x80\x99s perishable breath.'b'My first time arrived in 2008. It lasted only a short while. Her name was Sarah Palin.'b'Let me explain. That spring, in between the Republican primary and the fall campaign, my friend Reihan Salam and I had published a book called \xe2\x80\x9cGrand New Party: How Republicans Can Win the Working Class and Save the American Dream.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the title suggests, we were calling for the G.O.P. to change, but not to moderate in the way that a lot of centrist pundits favored, returning to a Rockefeller-Republican model of fiscally prudent social liberalism. Rather, we thought the party\xe2\x80\x99s opportunity (and the country\xe2\x80\x99s) lay in a kind of socially conservative populism, which would link the family-values language of the religious right to an economic agenda more favorable to the working class than what the Republicans usually had offered.'b'Unfortunately this message conspicuously lacked a tribune in 2008. Mike Huckabee flirted with populism in the primary but never fleshed out an agenda, and the eventual nominee, John McCain, was an \xe2\x80\x9chonor and country\xe2\x80\x9d candidate who didn\xe2\x80\x99t care much about economic policy.'b'But in Alaska, there was a young, rising-star governor. She was pro-life, evangelical, a working mom. And her record way up north was 'b'reformist in a distinctly nonideological way'b': She was best known for fighting a corrupt nexus of politicians and the oil-and-gas industry, tackling crony capitalism on behalf of ordinary Alaskans.'b'And then, shockingly, McCain picked her as his running mate.'b'At which point the chattering classes went temporarily insane. Or maybe I went insane, who can say? But either way it seemed like everything I hated, a mix of sneering social liberalism, fecundophobia, anti-evangelical paranoia and class contempt, was being hurled at a candidate who seemed to fit exactly with the \xe2\x80\x9cGrand New Party\xe2\x80\x9d mold.'b'So I defended her. I assailed her critics. And then \xe2\x80\x94 well, you know what happened then.'b'Palin gave interviews \xe2\x80\x94 terrible, terrible interviews. She was in over her head. Her own paranoia took center stage. She became her critics\xe2\x80\x99 caricature, embracing a mix of willful ignorance and proud ressentiment. What was distinctive about her Alaskan career was subsumed into a much more conventional sort of movement conservatism, which she picked up from the professional ideologues who rallied to her during her trial by fire. And eventually the movement tired of her, the culture tired of her, and her act ceased to be interesting even as reality TV.'b'But now that she has re-emerged to endorse Donald Trump, uniting her brand with 'b'his \xe2\x80\x9cMake America Great Again\xe2\x80\x9d nationalism'b', it\xe2\x80\x99s worth revisiting the original Palin, the outsider who took on a corrupt Alaskan establishment.'b'A lot of conservatives, especially in Ted Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s orbit, have acted shocked or disappointed that Palin would endorse a figure like Trump, who has no plausible claim to be a principled conservative.'b'But given Palin\xe2\x80\x99s Alaskan past, the endorsement makes perfect sense. Her real roots are not in Reaganism or libertarianism or the orthodoxies of the donor class. They\xe2\x80\x99re in the same kind of blue-collar, Jacksonian, \xe2\x80\x9cwho\xe2\x80\x99s looking out for you?\xe2\x80\x9d populism that has carried Trump to the top of the Republican polls. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a populism that the G.O.P. is discovering has 'b'a lot more appeal'b' to many of its voters than the litmus tests of the official right.'b'Which means that in a certain way, Trump and Palin together on a stage is the closest American politics has come to offering the populist grand new party that Salam and I called for two presidential campaigns ago.'b'Except that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t what we called for, because we wanted a populism with substance \xe2\x80\x94 one that actually offered policy solutions to stagnant wages and rising health care costs, one that could help Republicans reach out to upwardly mobile blacks and Hispanics as well as whites, and so on down an optimistic wish list.'b'Whereas Trump-era populism, while it plays very effectively on economic anxiety, mostly offers braggadocio rather than solutions, and white identity politics rather than any kind of 'b'one-nation conservatism'b'.'b'I would like to tell you that this is all the fault of the Republican leadership \xe2\x80\x94 that had they been more receptive to populist ideas in 2008 or 2012, they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be facing a Trumpian revolt today.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s roughly the argument that 'b'David Frum makes'b' in this month\xe2\x80\x99s Atlantic, in a sweeping essay on the roots of Trumpism. And he makes a strong case. A large part of the Republican donor class would rather lose with \xe2\x80\x9cyou didn\xe2\x80\x99t build that!\xe2\x80\x9d than compromise on upper-bracket tax cuts. It would rather try to win Hispanics with immigration reform a hundred times over than try to win them once on pocketbook issues. It prefers to campaign as though it\xe2\x80\x99s always 1980, and has little to say to people who have lost out from globalization and socioeconomic change.'b'A critique that stops with G.O.P. elites, though, might let the voting public off the hook. Because it\xe2\x80\x99s also possible that Trumpism, in all its boastful, lord-of-misrule meretriciousness, is what many struggling Americans actually want.'b'That is, at a certain point disillusionment with the system becomes so strong that no wonkish policy proposal is likely to resonate anymore. So you can talk all you want (as Marco Rubio\xe2\x80\x99s water-treading campaign has tried to do) about improving vocational education or increasing the child-tax credit, and people will tune you out: They want someone who will arm-wrestle the Chinese, make Mexico pay for the wall, smite our enemies and generally stand in solidarity with their resentments, regardless of the policy results.'b'Since this is a recipe for American-style Putinism, it\xe2\x80\x99s not exactly a good sign for the republic that it seems to be resonating. But those of us who want a better, saner and more decent populism than what Donald Trump is selling need to reckon with the implications of his indubitable appeal.'b'Maybe \xe2\x80\x94 hopefully \xe2\x80\x94 there\xe2\x80\x99s a bridge from Trumpism to a more responsible alternative, as there was between Huey Long and F.D.R. or from 'b'George Wallace to Richard Nixon'b'.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s also possible that my fellow eggheads and I are grasping at a dream that\xe2\x80\x99s already slipped behind us \xe2\x80\x94 lost back in the land of might-have-beens, where the dark fields of Wasilla roll on under the night.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Justices to Hear State Challenge on Immigration'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 20):'b'This is how our constitutional republic works and has pretty much worked for more than two centuries: The three branches of government keep one another in check and balance. NOAA has already released the scientific data and methodology for the paper and extensive emails from its political leadership.'b'Next, the scientific community has established policies and procedures to protect against the now historical problems cited by Mr. Thacker. Respectable scientific journals require authors to sign conflict-of-interest statements indicating all sources of support and any interests that could appear to influence objectivity. Rigorous peer-review processes remain the best defense against biased science.'b'If journalists were asked to share their emails in the spirit of transparency and understanding the reliability of sources, it would have a chilling effect on freedom of the press. In science, email discovery may have a place in legal proceedings, but broad requests for disclosure risk exposing reviewers who provide candid, confidential critiques, as well as debates that are an essential part of the deliberative process.'b'MARCIA McNUTT'b'Washington'b''b'The writer is editor in chief of the Science family of journals.'b''b'KARACHI \xe2\x80\x94 With nearly all of the rest of the world on the brink of being free of polio, the disease\xe2\x80\x99s persistence in Pakistan has long challenged health experts both inside and outside the country. Last year, the 51 'b'cases of wild poliovirus reported here'b' represented the bulk of all 70 cases reported throughout the world.'b'Even so, last year\xe2\x80\x99s count is cause for optimism, since it was a huge drop from the 294 cases reported in Pakistan in 2014, and because it seems to be a product of some clever adjustments the country has made to its longstanding polio eradication program, with help from the Pakistani Army and smartphone-based technology.'b'Since 1978, the country has had an official 'b'Expanded Program on Immunization'b', in which vaccinators go door to door to immunize against many childhood and other diseases \xe2\x80\x94 tuberculosis, hepatitis, meningitis, measles and more. But when the goal became finally stamping out the last traces of polio, the regimen had to be ramped up to include more than these periodic household visits.'b'As part of the World Health Organization\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Polio Eradication and Endgame Strategic Plan 2013\xe2\x80\x932018'b', for example, the government announced that April 25 will be a National Switch Day for updating the kind of vaccine used, to account for the fact that Types 2 and 3 of the polio virus appear to have already been eliminated in Pakistan, with only Type 1 remaining. Recognizing that, the W.H.O. recommended a switch from a trivalent oral polio vaccine to a version that can target Type 1 more effectively.'b'The next milestone will be phasing out the oral vaccine, which is built from a weakened live virus, and replacing it with an inactive polio vaccine administered by injection. Starting in Punjab, that strategy will supplement the live-virus vaccine schedule with one dose of the inactive version, which eliminates even the small risk of contracting the disease from the live virus vaccine. One reason the inactive vaccine is coming into use only now is that it is five times more expensive than the live oral type. To overcome that obstacle, GAVI, a public-private organization funded by various countries, charities and international institutions, will help cover the cost. On Tuesday, GAVI and Unicef tweeted that the inactive vaccine is now available in all of Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s provinces (#Pakistan h/t @UNICEF_Pakistan).'b'At the same time, Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s government has supplied vaccinators with motorcycles, for which Britain\xe2\x80\x99s Fund for International Development, along with Unicef, will provide fuel allowances. Lack of fuel has been a popular excuse for vaccinators who miss their vaccine targets because they don\xe2\x80\x99t want to travel to the far-flung areas where they are most needed. Security for vaccinators is an even bigger issue, illustrated by the bombing last Wednesday of a polio eradication center in Quetta that killed 14 policemen during an immunization drive.'b'Indeed, a 'b'long campaign of disinformation spread by the Taliban'b' helps explain why Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s polio eradication program has not yet wiped out the disease. In 2006, the extremist group declared vaccination to be a Western plot to sterilize Pashtun children and stunt their growth. It threatened to kill parents who had their children immunized, and violently attacked polio vaccinators in Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s tribal areas and in metropolitan Karachi. Celebrities joined campaigns to counter the propaganda, and religious leaders issued fatwas declaring that Islam permitted the immunization of children, but those efforts did nothing to stop the attacks.'b'In 2012, Taliban commanders and clerics affiliated with the movement also halted the immunization program in North Waziristan, in protest against American drone attacks that had followed the killing of Osama bin Laden by American Special Forces; subsequent revelations that the C.I.A. had used a bogus vaccination program to capture DNA material from Bin Laden\xe2\x80\x99s relatives gave the Taliban additional ammunition with which to besmirch all vaccinators as spies for America.'b'But much of that changed last January, after the Taliban disrupted a three-day immunization drive in Sindh Province by killing three polio workers. First, vaccinators refused to work until they were given more protection. Then, the Pakistani Army provided the vaccinators with visible security.'b'By that point, the army had already begun a nationwide anti-militant campaign in the wake of an attack on an army-run public school. When the offensive drove militants out of North Waziristan\xe2\x80\x99s tribal areas and Karachi\xe2\x80\x99s no-go zones, parents finally lowered their resistance to immunizing their children. What followed was the 70 percent drop in new polio cases over the full year.'b'Nevertheless, the Taliban\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to fight the campaign continue, as do management problems within the national immunization campaign. Some officials have been accused of siphoning money from its programs, or of using expired vaccines, and some vaccination plans have had difficulty targeting vulnerable populations.'b'One effort to resolve that problem was the introduction in Punjab last year of a smartphone app on which the region\xe2\x80\x99s 3,700 vaccinators could keep track of their work. Now, instead of going household to household, they go to a center where children have been assembled for vaccination. The vaccinators then send the data via phone to a central office. Using this approach, vaccinators\xe2\x80\x99 attendance rates, which at times had been as low as 21 percent, have risen to 95 percent to 100 percent.'b'Officials also have analyzed satellite images to target population clusters, and have produced a color-coded map showing where vaccinations have and haven\xe2\x80\x99t reached children in need.'b'By now, the rates of vaccination with the two types of antigens have risen beyond 70 percent, a critical threshold toward the goal of eradication.'b'Encouraged by those results, the Punjab government and the World Bank plan to invest in 10,000 more vaccinator smartphones, which will also capture a child\xe2\x80\x99s photo and the mother\xe2\x80\x99s cellphone number, enabling automatic reminders to a mother that a child is due for a vaccine scheduled near home.'b'The Punjab government is eager to share its technological know-how with the rest of the nation. One target area this year is remote Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.'b'And if Sindh and Baluchistan follow suit, there\xe2\x80\x99s every chance that Pakistan can catch up quickly to the rest of the world. As the rulers of the sole Muslim nuclear power in the world, they were on a mission to bring peace to the region. Maybe they should lower their expectations at home.'b'Maybe they should try to ensure that when children go to school and university they don\xe2\x80\x99t become martyrs. The Pakistani political and military elites are fond of reminding everyone at every opportunity that the country\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear assets are safe. Could they one day make the same claim about our schoolchildren?'b'SIDELINED by homeland security, foreign policy and immigration, the economy is about to become a major topic in the race for the White House. Since the start of the year we have seen precipitous drops in the stock market and oil prices, combined with the threat that a slowing global economy may drag the United States down with it.'b'While political campaigns are rarely the best forum to achieve policy clarity, the spotlight this year\xe2\x80\x99s race will cast on economic issues will bring some needed debate about two pressing questions: Why is the United States still so economically insecure? And can we shore up that insecurity before the next downturn arrives?'b'The economy has repeatedly failed to achieve the liftoff that it is capable of. Despite the creation of six million jobs in the last two years, wage growth has been anemic, inequality has worsened and too many Americans lack the agility to adapt to structural changes, including those driven by technological innovations.'b'The success of the post-recession employment recovery and the uneven growth since then can be attributed to a single factor: After Congress\xe2\x80\x99s initial bailouts to stanch the bloodletting in 2008, the burden of economic policy making fell almost entirely on the Federal Reserve.'b'Having succeeded in helping the United States and the rest of the world avert a multiyear depression in 2008-9, the Fed pivoted to using unconventional monetary measures to pursue broader objectives. It did so through a combination of zero interest rates and large-scale purchases of securities to repress market volatility and increase asset prices, hoping to encourage consumption and investment.'b'This worked, to some extent. But it created a sizable wedge between artificially supported asset prices and rather sluggish fundamentals. And ultimately, these tools can buy time only until the political system delivers a broader policy response, which it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Now time is running out.'b'Thanks to mounting internal contradictions and operational stress, central banks are increasingly unwilling (like the Federal Reserve) or unable (like the People\xe2\x80\x99s Bank of China, the Bank of Japan and, soon, the European Central Bank) to borrow financial returns from the future. As a result, financial volatility is rising.'b'What follows is up to us. One road \xe2\x80\x94 where continued political dysfunction further sidelines a holistic policy response \xe2\x80\x94 could lead to recession. The other \xe2\x80\x94 a broadening policy response turbocharged by innovation and the productive deployment of corporate cash \xe2\x80\x94 could unleash high and inclusive growth.'b'Assuming that the presidential season clarifies these choices, the campaign\xe2\x80\x99s winner will face another challenge next year: how to deal with a Congress that has failed to handle even its most basic economic functions. Given the outlook for both a shaky global economy and higher financial volatility, the new administration will need to find a way to get Congress to implement measures in four specific areas, some of which already command bipartisan support.'b'The first covers long-overdue structural reforms. Guided by the administration, Congress needs to overhaul a tax system littered with anti-growth provisions, invest more in infrastructure, expand labor-market retraining and modernize our education system. The lack of such reforms, and the insecurity generated, is one main reason the private sector has held back from spending the enormous cash reserves on its balance sheets; encouraging that money to flow into productive activities, rather than share buybacks, would boost the economy.'b'America also needs a more responsive fiscal policy. This means, above all, redirecting resources that essentially subsidize the better-off segments of society, including the excessively low taxation of carried interest and other budgetary measures to help reduce the economic drag that inequality creates through reduced consumer demand.'b'Politicians must also act soon to avert the growing problem of student debt, a major obstacle for the incoming generation of workers. The government needs to increase the transparency of loan disclosures, enlarge steppingstone programs like community colleges, and make it easier for students to pay off their debt without sacrificing career opportunities.'b'Finally, the United States needs to push for critical reforms in the global finance infrastructure. It took embarrassingly long for the world to agree on modest changes in the governance of the International Monetary Fund, largely because Congress was disengaged. The next steps should include further reallocation of voting power from Europe to developing economies, consistent with today\xe2\x80\x99s global economic realities.'b'While I.M.F. reform might seem arcane, it could be vital to averting another global crisis \xe2\x80\x94 without changes, the fund\xe2\x80\x99s credibility will continue to be questioned, especially in the eyes of emerging economies, undermining global policy cooperation and increasing the risk of currency wars and other damaging coordination failures.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s little that is surprising about most of these items. What is surprising is that too few politicians, let alone presidential candidates, seem to grasp the need for them within the first year or so of the next administration. Even then, the risk of another recession will not be eliminated; that\xe2\x80\x99s the nature of business cycles. The point is to reduce the risk as much as possible, in the United States and abroad \xe2\x80\x94 and to lay the groundwork for high long-term and inclusive growth.'b'In 1936 George Orwell wrote a magnificent essay called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Shooting an Elephant'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Orwell had been working as a British police officer in Burma, enforcing colonial rule. An elephant had gone \xe2\x80\x9cmust,\xe2\x80\x9d broken its chains, trampled some homes and killed a man.'b'As Orwell walked, gun in hand, toward the elephant, a crowd of over 2,000 Burmese gathered behind him. They hated him, but it would be a diverting spectacle to see an elephant shot and they could use the meat. Orwell didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to shoot the poor creature, whose \xe2\x80\x9cmust,\xe2\x80\x9d or frenzied state, had passed and who was peacefully eating grass. But he felt the pressure of the crowd behind him. They\xe2\x80\x99d laugh at him if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t kill the thing.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI was only an absurd puppet pushed to and fro by the will of those yellow faces behind,\xe2\x80\x9d Orwell wrote. And so he subjected the animal to a long and agonizing death.'b'In his essay nobody feels like they have any power. The locals, the imperial victims, sure didn\xe2\x80\x99t. Orwell, the guy with the gun, didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like he had any. The imperialists back in London were too far away.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s sort of the way much of the world is today. As Anand Giridharadas writes in The International New York Times, \xe2\x80\x9cIf anything unites America in this fractious moment it is a widespread sentiment that power is somewhere other than where you are.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Republican establishment thinks the grass roots have the power but the grass roots think the reverse. The unions think the corporations have the power but the corporations think the start-ups do. Regulators think Wall Street has the power but Wall Street thinks the regulators do. The 'b'Pew Research Center asked'b' Americans, \xe2\x80\x9cWould you say your side has been winning or losing more?\xe2\x80\x9d Sixty-four percent of Americans, with majorities of both parties, believe their side has been losing more.'b'These days people seem to underestimate their own power or suffer from what Giridharadas calls the \xe2\x80\x9canxiety of impotence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sometimes when groups feel oppressed, they organize by coming up with concrete reform proposals to empower themselves. The Black Lives Matter movement is doing this.'b'But in other cases the feeling of absolute powerlessness can corrupt absolutely. As psychological research has shown, many people who feel powerless come to feel unworthy, and become complicit in their own oppression. Some exaggerate the weight and size of the obstacles in front of them. Some feel dehumanized, forsaken, doomed and guilty.'b'Today we live in a world of isolation and atomization, where people distrust their own institutions. In such circumstances many people respond to powerlessness with pointless acts of self-destruction.'b'In the Palestinian territories, for example, young people don\xe2\x80\x99t organize or work with their government to improve their prospects. They wander into Israel, try to stab a soldier or a pregnant woman and get shot or arrested \xe2\x80\x94 every single time. They throw away their lives for a pointless and usually botched moment of terrorism.'b'In a different way, the American election has been perverted by feelings of powerlessness.'b'Americans are beset by complex, intractable problems that don\xe2\x80\x99t have a clear villain: technological change displaces workers; globalization and the rapid movement of people destabilize communities; family structure dissolves; the political order in the Middle East teeters, the Chinese economy craters, inequality rises, the global order frays, etc.'b'To address these problems we need big, responsible institutions (power centers) that can mobilize people, cobble together governing majorities and enact plans of actions. In the U.S. context that means functioning political parties and a functioning Congress.'b'Those institutions have been weakened of late. Parties have been rendered weak by both campaign finance laws and the Citizens United decision, which have cut off their funding streams and given power to polarized super-donors who work outside the party system. Congress has been weakened by polarization and disruptive members who don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in legislating.'b'Instead of shoring up these institutions, many voters are inclined to make everything worse. Plagued by the anxiety of impotence many voters are drawn to leaders who pretend that our problems could be solved by defeating some villain. Donald Trump says stupid elites are the problem. Ted Cruz says it\xe2\x80\x99s the Washington cartel. Bernie Sanders says it\xe2\x80\x99s Wall Street.'b'The fact is, for all the problems we may have with Wall Street or Washington, our biggest problems are systemic \xe2\x80\x94 the disruptions caused by technological progress and globalization, mass migration, family breakdown and so on. There\xe2\x80\x99s no all-controlling Wizard of Oz to slay.'b'If we\xe2\x80\x99re to have any hope of addressing big systemic problems we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to repair big institutions and have functioning parties and a functioning Congress. We have to discard the anti-political, anti-institutional mood that is prevalent and rebuild effective democratic power centers.'b'This requires less atomization and more collective action, fewer strongmen but greater citizenship. It requires the craft of political architecture, not the demagogy of destruction.'b'There are still quite a few pundits determined to pretend that America\xe2\x80\x99s two great parties are symmetric \xe2\x80\x94 equally unwilling to face reality, equally pushed into extreme positions by special interests and rabid partisans. It\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense, of course. Planned Parenthood isn\xe2\x80\x99t the same thing as the Koch brothers, nor is Bernie Sanders the moral equivalent of Ted Cruz. And there\xe2\x80\x99s no Democratic counterpart whatsoever to Donald Trump.'b'Moreover, when self-proclaimed centrist pundits get concrete about the policies they want, they have to tie themselves in knots to avoid admitting that what they\xe2\x80\x99re describing are basically the positions of a guy named Barack Obama.'b'Still, there are some currents in our political life that do run through both parties. And one of them is the persistent delusion that a hidden majority of American voters either supports or can be persuaded to support radical policies, if only the right person were to make the case with sufficient fervor.'b'You see this on the right among hard-line conservatives, who insist that only the cowardice of Republican leaders has prevented the rollback of every progressive program instituted in the past couple of generations. Actually, you also see a version of this tendency among genteel, country-club-type Republicans, who continue to imagine that they represent the party\xe2\x80\x99s mainstream even as 'b'polls show'b' that almost two-thirds of likely primary voters support Mr. Trump, Mr. Cruz or Ben Carson.'b'Meanwhile, on the left there is always a contingent of idealistic voters eager to believe that a sufficiently high-minded leader can conjure up the better angels of America\xe2\x80\x99s nature and persuade the broad public to support a radical overhaul of our institutions. In 2008 that contingent rallied behind Mr. Obama; now they\xe2\x80\x99re backing Mr. Sanders, who has adopted such a purist stance that the other day he 'b'dismissed Planned Parenthood'b' (which has endorsed Hillary Clinton) as part of the \xe2\x80\x9cestablishment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But as Mr. Obama himself found out as soon as he took office, transformational rhetoric isn\xe2\x80\x99t how change happens. That\xe2\x80\x99s not to say that he\xe2\x80\x99s a failure. On the contrary, he\xe2\x80\x99s been an extremely consequential president, doing more to advance the progressive agenda than anyone since L.B.J.'b'Yet his achievements have depended at every stage on accepting half loaves as being better than none: health reform that leaves the system largely private, financial reform that seriously restricts Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s abuses without fully breaking its power, higher taxes on the rich but no full-scale assault on inequality.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a sort of mini-dispute among Democrats over who can claim to be Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s true heir \xe2\x80\x94 Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Clinton? But the answer is obvious: Mr. Sanders is the heir to candidate Obama, but Mrs. Clinton is the heir to President Obama. (In fact, the health reform we got was basically her proposal, not his.)'b'Could Mr. Obama have been more transformational? Maybe he could have done more at the margins. But the truth is that he was elected under the most favorable circumstances possible, a financial crisis that utterly discredited his predecessor \xe2\x80\x94 and still faced scorched-earth opposition from Day 1.'b'And the question Sanders supporters should ask is, When has their theory of change ever worked? Even F.D.R., who rode the depths of the Great Depression to a huge majority, had to be politically pragmatic, working not just with special interest groups but also with Southern racists.'b'Remember, too, that the institutions F.D.R. created were add-ons, not replacements: Social Security didn\xe2\x80\x99t replace private pensions, unlike the Sanders proposal to replace private health insurance with single-payer. Oh, and Social Security originally covered only 'b'half the work force'b', and as a result largely excluded African-Americans.'b'Just to be clear: I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying that someone like Mr. Sanders is unelectable, although Republican operatives would 'b'evidently rather face him'b' than Mrs. Clinton \xe2\x80\x94 they know that his current polling is meaningless, because he has never yet faced their attack machine. But even if he was to become president, he would end up facing the same harsh realities that constrained Mr. Obama.'b'The point is that while idealism is fine and essential \xe2\x80\x94 you have to dream of a better world \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s not a virtue unless it goes along with hardheaded realism about the means that might achieve your ends. That\xe2\x80\x99s true even when, like F.D.R., you ride a political tidal wave into office. It\xe2\x80\x99s even more true for a modern Democrat, who will be lucky if his or her party controls even one house of Congress at any point this decade.'b'Sorry, but there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing noble about seeing your values defeated because you preferred happy dreams to hard thinking about means and ends. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let idealism veer into destructive self-indulgence.'b'This weekend, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to the Mojave Desert, deep into an arid wilderness of a half-million acres, for some stargazing, bouldering and January sunshine on my public lands. I won\xe2\x80\x99t be out of contact. I checked. If Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s behalf \xe2\x80\x94 scratch that. 'b'When'b' Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s behalf, I\xe2\x80\x99ll get her speaking-in-tongues buffoonery in real time, along with the rest of the nation.'b'The old me would have despised the new me for admitting such a thing. I\xe2\x80\x99ve tried to go on digital diets, fasting from my screens. I was a friend\xe2\x80\x99s guest at a spa in Arizona once and had so much trouble being \xe2\x80\x9cmindful\xe2\x80\x9d that they nearly kicked me out. Actually, I just wanted to make sure I didn\xe2\x80\x99t miss the Seahawks game, mindful of Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s woeful offensive line.'b'In the information blur of last year, you may have overlooked news of our incredibly shrinking attention span. A survey of Canadian media consumption by Microsoft concluded that the average attention span had fallen to eight seconds, down from 12 in the year 2000. We now have a shorter attention span than goldfish, the study found.'b'Attention span was defined as \xe2\x80\x9cthe amount of concentrated time on a task without becoming distracted.\xe2\x80\x9d I tried to read the entire 54-page report, but well, you know. Still, a quote from Satya Nadella, the chief executive officer of Microsoft, jumped out at me. \xe2\x80\x9cThe true scarce commodity\xe2\x80\x9d of the near future, he said, will be \xe2\x80\x9chuman attention.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Putting aside Microsoft\xe2\x80\x99s self-interest in promoting quick-flash digital ads with what may be junk science, there seems little doubt that our devices have rewired our brains. We think in McNugget time. The trash flows, unfiltered, along with the relevant stuff, in an eternal stream. And the last hit of dopamine only accelerates the need for another one.'b'I can no longer wait in a grocery store line, or linger for a traffic light, or even pause long enough to let a bagel pop from the toaster, without reflexively reaching for my smartphone. One of the joys of going to Europe was always the distance \xe2\x80\x94 nine hours in my case \xe2\x80\x94 from compulsive contemporaneous chatter. While I hiked the Cinque Terre, the West Coast was sleeping. No more. Somebody, somewhere is alerting me to something that can\xe2\x80\x99t wait.'b'You see it in the press, the obsession with mindless listicles that have all the staying power of a Popsicle. You see it in our politics, with fear-mongering slogans replacing anything that requires sustained thought. And the collapse of a fact-based democracy, where, for example, 60 percent of Trump supporters believe Obama was born in another country, has to be a byproduct of the pick-and-choose news from the buffet line of our screens.'b'Even \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey,\xe2\x80\x9d supposedly an exemplar of popular taste for refined drama in the Digital Age, is in fact a very hyper-paced entertainment. The camera seldom holds a scene for long, cutting from Mrs. Patmore\xe2\x80\x99s sexual advice to the butler Barrow\xe2\x80\x99s latest plotting at a speed that is more Nascar than \xe2\x80\x9cMasterpiece Theatre.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A New York friend used to send me clever, well-thought-out emails, gems of sprightly prose. Then he switched to texting, which abbreviated his wit and style. Now all verbs and nouns have vanished; he sends emojis, the worst thing to happen to communication in our time.'b'But all is not lost. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what the neuroscience has to say about this, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve found a pair of antidotes, very old school, for my shrinking attention span.'b'The first is gardening. You plant something in the cold, wet soil of the fall \xe2\x80\x94 tulip bulbs or garlic \xe2\x80\x94 and then you want to shout, \xe2\x80\x9cGrow!\xe2\x80\x9d Eight seconds later, nothing. Working the ground, there\xe2\x80\x99s no instant gratification. The planting itself forces you to think in half-year-increments, or longer for trees and perennials. The mind drifts, from the chill of a dark day to a springtime of color. Hope, goes the Emily Dickinson poem, is the thing with feathers. But it\xe2\x80\x99s also the thing that rises from a tiny seed, in its own sweet time.'b'The second is deep reading, especially in the hibernation months of winter. I\xe2\x80\x99m nearly done with the second volume of William Manchester\xe2\x80\x99s masterly biography of Winston Churchill, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Last Lion.\xe2\x80\x9d (O.K., I\xe2\x80\x99m late to the book, Churchillians.) Paper books and stores that sell them are experiencing a revival of sorts. So, yes, I\xe2\x80\x99m as screen-scrolly as the next guy when I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the world in the palm of my hand. If anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s greater.'b'Irony alert: I invite you to follow me on Twitter, 'b'@nytegan'b'.'b'The 274 pages of emails released under pressure on Wednesday by Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan show a cynical and callous indifference to the plight of the mostly black, poverty-stricken residents of Flint, who have gone for more than a year with poisoned tap water that is unsafe to drink or bathe in. There is little doubt that an affluent, predominantly white community \xe2\x80\x94 say Grosse Pointe or Bloomfield Hills \xe2\x80\x94 would never face such a public health catastrophe, and if it had, the state government would have rushed in to help.'b'At every juncture when state officials could have avoided or reduced the harm in Flint, they ignored public pleas and made every effort to dismiss the truth.'b'The 'b'newly released emails'b' show that members of Mr. Snyder\xe2\x80\x99s administration consistently mocked and belittled the complaints of Flint residents and the evidence gathered by independent researchers. The people of his constituency had consistently voted for the local Shan party in the past.'b'Yet he lost to a candidate from the National League for Democracy (N.L.D.), the majority-Bamar party led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, which swept the general election last year, winning some 80 percent of contested seats in the national Parliament. Apparently, it was the ethnic Wa people of Shan State, many of whom resettled there from northern parts of country in the late 1990s, who cast the decisive votes.'b'Rumor has it they had received instructions to vote for the N.L.D. from the United Wa State Army \xe2\x80\x94 at 30,000-strong, the most powerful rebel group in the country \xe2\x80\x94 which is headquartered on Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s border with China. Chinese sources I spoke to in academe and the intelligence services denied that Beijing had anything to do with those directives. But one senior Shan politician and three Myanmar military insiders said they thought it was Chinese influence that had swung the Wa votes in Shan State.'b'Why would Beijing, which has long backed Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s military regime and refused to engage with pro-democracy parties, now support the N.L.D.? One reason is that in recent years it saw the political tide turning in Myanmar. Another is that it has come to think of Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi as a consummate pragmatist, and at a time when the Myanmar army, known as the Tatmadaw, was making political and military overtures to the United States and its allies.'b'But Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s rapprochement with the N.L.D. now threatens the legitimacy of Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s generals on issues they have long considered to be within their exclusive purview: foreign policy, border affairs, national security, federalism. So while improved relations between China and the incoming N.L.D. government could help quiet unrest in border areas, they could also upset the uneasy balance of power among Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s elites in Naypyidaw.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s relations with Myanmar have ebbed under President Thein Sein, down to lows not seen since the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960s, when anti-Chinese riots broke out and Beijing began backing Communist rebels in Myanmar. Ties had then slowly improved because both Deng Xiaoping and the military-led socialist government in Myanmar maintained a neutral foreign policy.'b'After a military junta took power in 1988, relations graduated to the level of strategic partnership. That the West promptly marginalized the junta and slapped it with sanctions helped matters along, and for the next two decades political, economic and military cooperation between China and Myanmar deepened. Myanmar offered China natural resources and strategic access to the Bay of Bengal, among other things. Beijing provided Myanmar with aid, arms and military training, as well as diplomatic cover.'b'Relations soured again when the Myanmar government started to liberalize in 2010. In 2011, the now-nominally democratic government in Naypyidaw suspended construction on the massive Chinese-funded Myitsone hydropower dam project. This was largely in response to local opposition to environmental damage and abusive Chinese business practices. But Beijing saw the move as another sign that the Myanmar government was trying to move away from its zone of influence. It reviewed its Myanmar policy.'b'In recent years, the Chinese government has courted opposition groups and critics of the Myanmar government \xe2\x80\x94 hosting, sometimes even feting, journalists, civil society leaders and representatives from ethnic groups and political parties, including Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi and other senior N.L.D. officials.'b'Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, for her part, has adopted positions that are generally accommodating to China\xe2\x80\x99s interests, including some that seem to cut against the N.L.D.\xe2\x80\x99s stated policies, such as the importance of public buy-in in major foreign projects.'b'To the dismay of some N.L.D. voters, she has said little to challenge the Myitsone project, and has come out in support of a controversial Chinese copper mine, even after the police cracked down on protesters opposing it. She has praised China\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOne Belt, One Road\xe2\x80\x9d initiative, a centerpiece of the foreign policy and development strategy of President Xi Jinping. Although she once pleaded with the international community, \xe2\x80\x9cPlease use your liberty to promote ours,\xe2\x80\x9d she has been noticeably quiet about human rights issues in China, including the imprisonment of Liu Xiaobo, a fellow Nobel Peace Prize Laureate.'b'The Chinese government, meanwhile, seems to have been stirring low-level trouble along the border in order to gain leverage and push its interests, both strategic and economic, in Myanmar. Lately, it has increased its patronage of local ethnic armed groups, especially the United Wa State Army and the Kokang army. Senior Myanmar officials allege that the Kokang insurgency, also in the north, flared up again in 2015 thanks to armament, logistical support and troops provided by China.'b'The Tatmadaw is now in an awkward position: Any improvement of relations between Beijing and Naypyidaw under an N.L.D. government would be a double-edged sword. Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s generals would surely welcome some respite from ethnic strife in the north, but they hardly want to be seen as outsourcing security issues to an elected civilian government.'b'Which may explain why the Tatmadaw has recently taken to describing its fight against ethnic rebel groups as an effort to defend the country\xe2\x80\x99s integrity and sovereignty, rather than as a simple counterinsurgency campaign. By casting local civil conflicts in broader geopolitical terms, it hopes to establish that it is indispensable.'b'Several political and military officials in Myanmar and intelligence officers in Yunnan have told me they expect Beijing and the N.L.D. to strike some kind of arrangement after the N.L.D. forms a new government in a few months. China would press ethnic rebel groups to cooperate with the N.L.D. on a national cease-fire accord, handing Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi a victory that has eluded the current government. In exchange, the N.L.D. would yield to important Chinese interests in Myanmar, such as major infrastructure and investment projects.'b'This leaves the Tatmadaw with few cards to play. It cannot try to undermine Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi\xe2\x80\x99s legitimacy or win support from the West by stoking anti-Chinese sentiment \xe2\x80\x94 at least not without also running the risk of triggering an aggressive response from China in the northeast. (Or else it would have to go all out, and invoke the clauses in the 2008 Constitution that entitle the military to take power in the case of a national emergency.)'b'However much the prospect of greater cooperation between the new N.L.D. government and China irks them, Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s generals may nonetheless be willing to accept it \xe2\x80\x94 so long as civilian authorities consult them first. Peace between Myanmar\xe2\x80\x99s Lady and its generals runs through Beijing.'b'The world has responded with billions of dollars in humanitarian aid to the multiplying emergencies around the world, but the need has far outstripped that generosity. The fact is, as the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, puts it, we are living in \xe2\x80\x9cthe age of the megacrises.\xe2\x80\x9d Wars and natural disasters have pushed 125 million people worldwide from their homes and severed them from their traditional livelihoods.'b'To provide these people with the barest means of survival requires $40 billion a year. Though humanitarian funding reached $24.5 billion in 2014, more than 12 times the $2 billion raised in 2000, that still left a shortfall of nearly $15 billion. The current system, based on responding to catastrophes as they happen and on the outdated notion that each crisis will be limited in scope and in time, clearly isn\xe2\x80\x99t working.'b'On Sunday, the United Nations released a report detailing ambitious plans to overhaul global humanitarian financing. The report recommends a multipronged approach: more concerted effort to end conflicts and prepare for natural disasters, increasing funds by imposing small taxes of a few cents on the sale of high-volume goods and services, tapping into Islamic finance mechanisms in the Muslim world and enlisting the expertise of global businesses. The report\xe2\x80\x99s recommendations will be discussed at the first-ever World Humanitarian Summit, to be held in Istanbul in May.'b'The members of the panel that worked on the report failed to reach consensus on some of the particulars, including microtaxes on transactions. Another possibility is placing small, voluntary fees on taxi rides, through Uber and other taxi apps.'b'At the summit in Istanbul, governments and organizations should strive for consensus around the main proposals of the United Nations report. Conspiracy theorists now traffic in the idea that 9/11 was an inside job and that gun massacres like Sandy Hook are \xe2\x80\x9cfalse flags\xe2\x80\x9d cooked up so the government can confiscate guns.'b'The rebooted \xe2\x80\x9cX-Files,\xe2\x80\x9d which premieres on Sunday, probably couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have ignored this development, and so \xe2\x80\x94 spoiler alert \xe2\x80\x94 it opts to embrace it, throwing the protagonists, Mulder and Scully, together with a conservative 9/11 truther named Tad O\xe2\x80\x99Malley, who\xe2\x80\x99s investigating a plot so vast that it includes nuclear bombs, alien-human hybridization and a takeover of the entire world using weather manipulation, junk food, the Patriot Act, military and police actions and, somewhat oddly, the Federal Emergency Management Agency.'b'Early reviews have not been especially kind to the reboot\xe2\x80\x99s first episode, and it\xe2\x80\x99s perhaps best viewed less as a new entry into the \xe2\x80\x9cX-Files\xe2\x80\x9d canon than as a reminder of what was great about the original.'b'Mulder and Scully did uncover some complex government plots in the original series, though many episodes ended not with dramatic revelations but with no resolution at all. \xe2\x80\x9cD.P.O.,\xe2\x80\x9d for instance, centers on an auto mechanic with the ability to channel lightning. After he gives a man a heart attack, saves him and zaps multiple others, he is hospitalized and examined. Scully relays the results: \xe2\x80\x9cNothing unusual was detected.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The show was at its best when its heroes investigated something very creepy \xe2\x80\x94 a ship on the Norwegian Sea whose crew mysteriously ages, for instance \xe2\x80\x94 and came up with more questions than answers. The real pleasure of \xe2\x80\x9cThe X-Files\xe2\x80\x9d wasn\xe2\x80\x99t having your worst fears about the government confirmed; it was realizing that our world might still contain phenomena that are unexplained, and perhaps unexplainable.'b'We get flashes of this old spirit in the second and third episodes of the reboot. I hope the rest of the six-episode series continues in this vein, because watching TV heroes embrace conspiracy theories isn\xe2\x80\x99t much fun when presidential candidates foster gun-confiscation paranoia and a 9/11 truther 'b'is campaigning for Donald Trump in Iowa'b'.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAll we can do, Scully, is pull the thread, see what it unravels,\xe2\x80\x9d Mulder says in the reboot\xe2\x80\x99s second episode. The most satisfying episodes of \xe2\x80\x9cThe X-Files\xe2\x80\x9d don\xe2\x80\x99t tie everything in the world up in a neat bow \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re content to let a few threads dangle.'b'On Wednesday, the New Orleans police 'b'arrested'b' Deonca Kennedy after her 3-year-old grandson was killed by a bullet fired from a gun under her pillow as the two slept.'b'Ms. Kennedy, who was charged with negligent homicide and is indigent, qualified to have a public defender represent her. But the Orleans Public Defenders Office turned her down because, as it had announced on Jan. 11, it 'b'could no longer afford to take on'b' serious new felony cases, including some involving murder, rape and armed robbery.'b'Currently, the office\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers handle an average of 350 felony cases each year, more than twice the American Bar Association\xe2\x80\x99s guideline of 150. It is impossible for them to provide an ethical or constitutionally adequate defense for their existing clients under these conditions, let alone to take on even more. The situation is only getting worse, and the office imposed a hiring freeze because of a $1 million budget shortfall.'b'Since the office represents about 85 percent of criminal defendants in New Orleans and nearly all defendants who are found to be indigent, the impact of the decision to decline new cases has been immediate. Already 15 defendants facing violent felony charges have been turned down. Until the state or the city comes up with money to pay for lawyers whom the Constitution requires the government to provide, these people, including Ms. Kennedy, are locked up in jail without lawyers to challenge their arrests, request reduced bail or file motions to preserve evidence.'b'Despite the 'b'Sixth Amendment\xe2\x80\x99s guarantee'b' of a lawyer to every person facing criminal charges, underfunded public defense systems are common across America. But perhaps nowhere is the system as perverse as in Louisiana, where most of the funding comes from court costs imposed on those who are convicted or plead guilty, most often in the form of a $45 fee assessed on traffic tickets.'b'This is an inadequate and unpredictable revenue stream; a 'b'2012 report'b' found that the New Orleans traffic court failed to pay the defenders office millions it owed. And using court costs to finance public defense creates a fundamental conflict of interest, since it gives defenders an incentive to lose their cases to ensure that the office gets paid.'b'Last week, the American Civil Liberties Union 'b'brought a class-action lawsuit'b' on behalf of several defendants stuck in jail, alleging violations of their right to due process, equal protection and assistance of counsel. It has brought similar suits in other states, including New York and California, but the problems in Louisiana are especially bad. According to Louisiana\xe2\x80\x99s public defender, James Dixon Jr., 31 of the state\xe2\x80\x99s 42 public defender districts will be insolvent, or close to it, within the year.'b'The solution is for Louisiana lawmakers to provide adequate funding to public defender offices statewide, and to give all their citizens the legal assistance the Constitution demands.'b'Given the brittle relations between the Obama administration and Israel, even truth-telling can ignite a firestorm. What really enraged his critics was an observation that during a time of increased violence in Israel and the West Bank, \xe2\x80\x9cToo many attacks on Palestinians lack a vigorous investigation or response by Israeli authorities, too much vigilantism goes unchecked, and at times there seem to be two standards of adherence to the rule of law: one for Israelis and another for Palestinians.\xe2\x80\x9d A statement from Mr. Netanyahu\xe2\x80\x99s office denounced the second comment as \xe2\x80\x9cunacceptable and incorrect.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Considering the relentless violence and attacks on Israel\xe2\x80\x99s very existence, Israelis are understandably on high alert to defend themselves. None of this is acceptable.'b'The criticism of Mr. Shapiro, a vigorous advocate for Israel, was unusually personal and unfair. He correctly identified a serious problem. Since 1967, there has been a dual legal system in the West Bank in which Palestinians are subject to military courts, where, experts say, they are almost always convicted. Israeli settlers fall under the Israeli civilian judicial system, with its greater rights and protections. The disparity is likely to become more acute if Israelis abandon the two-state solution in favor of a single state, as some in Mr. Netanyahu\xe2\x80\x99s cabinet desire.'b'Mr. Shapiro called indictments in the Duma case an important sign of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to prosecute acts of terror against Palestinians, and he urged Israel to \xe2\x80\x9cdevelop stronger, more credible responses to questions about the rule of law in the West Bank.\xe2\x80\x9d He also said America had been \xe2\x80\x9casking tough questions of the Palestinians and of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s Arab neighbors, questions about murderous incitement, about withholding recognition, questions about threats to end security cooperation, about support for terror groups and about misuse of the U.N. system.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Israel is moving quickly to establish 'b'facts 'b'on the ground that preclude a Palestinian state, leaving Palestinians increasingly marginalized and despairing. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is starting to look like a de facto annexation,\xe2\x80\x9d one American official said. Thousands of Palestinian homes are said to be pending demolition.'b'Significantly, some Israelis, including some former officials, have expressed growing concerns about their country\xe2\x80\x99s direction. The government is cracking down on Israeli groups that advocate for Palestinian rights and oppose the occupation and settlements. An odious bill introduced by Justice Minister Ayelet Shaked would require activists to wear badges when they met government officials, and if groups received funds from foreign entities, they would have to declare it on all correspondence. The measure, which is clearly intended to intimidate government critics, is expected to pass the Knesset.'b'With only a year left in office, President Obama is unlikely to make another run at a peace process or even apply serious pressure on Israel to halt settlement-building.
