Tragically, it may already be too late for the one formula that has the best chance of establishing a durable peace: two independent states, side by side.'b'Moscow \xe2\x80\x94 A BRITISH inquiry 'b'announced'b' this week that Alexander V. Litvinenko, a Russian security officer turned defector who died in a London hospital of polonium poisoning in 2006, was \xe2\x80\x9cprobably\xe2\x80\x9d murdered on the instructions of President Vladimir V. Putin. That\xe2\x80\x99s little surprise. For more than eight years the world has suspected that the Kremlin was behind the assassination. (Just as surely, Mr. Putin has denied his responsibility. His spokesman Dmitri Peskov denounced the inquiry as a \xe2\x80\x9cquasi investigation\xe2\x80\x9d and an expression of the \xe2\x80\x9celegant British sense of humor.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'In the years since Mr. Litvinenko\xe2\x80\x99s dramatic death by radioactive poison, Russia\xe2\x80\x99s government has engaged in an array of brazen acts: cyberattacks on Estonia in 2007, the invasion of Georgia in 2008 and covert operations to annex Crimea and destabilize Ukraine in 2014.'b'So was Mr. Litvinenko\xe2\x80\x99s assassination the start of a new era of dirty tricks?'b'It may have seemed like a good idea at the time and probably in the immediate aftermath; the Russian government viewed it as a success that deterred others in the rich Russian \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9 community of \xe2\x80\x9cLondongrad\xe2\x80\x9d from opposition activities. It\xe2\x80\x99s not. Modern Russia is thoroughly integrated into global markets and institutions. It seeks foreign investors and partners abroad. Moscow\xe2\x80\x99s elites vacation in Italy, bank in London and send their children to American universities. They can\xe2\x80\x99t afford the repercussions of transnational assassination plots.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why, since Mr. Litvinenko\xe2\x80\x99s murder, the Russian security forces have moved on to a rather different tradecraft. \xe2\x80\x9cWet work\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the Russian spy slang for murder \xe2\x80\x94 isn\xe2\x80\x99t entirely a thing of the past, of course. A 'b'number of Chechens'b' in Turkey believed to be supporting rebels inside Russia have discovered that. But even in those cases, there was none of the theatricality of a polonium poisoning.'b'Mr. Litvinenko\xe2\x80\x99s killing, after all, was primarily about silencing critics and scaring opponents rather than eliminating one man. Moscow has realized that in the age of the Internet and 24-hour news cycles, there are safer ways of doing the same thing.'b'These days, if there is assassination to be done in the West, it is of character. The F.S.B. (the successor to the K.G.B.) and the other security services have moved into the world of information operations, and Russian media and public affairs specialists now rank alongside spies and assassins as weapons of the state. Glossy foreign-language media outlets, serried 'b'ranks of paid Internet trolls and hackers'b' and mysteriously well-funded political fringe groups do the Kremlin\xe2\x80\x99s bidding.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not necessarily a reason to celebrate. While it\xe2\x80\x99s true that no one dies from a hacked website, this campaign to dismay, divide and distract the West may be more destructive than any one assassination.'b'One of Moscow\xe2\x80\x99s aims is deepening divisions among its rivals. As in the Cold War, the crucial battleground is in Europe. The Kremlin knows that it will win if the European Union breaks apart or becomes unmanageable \xe2\x80\x94 or if Europeans become disillusioned with the NATO alliance. To this end, Moscow eagerly supports extremist parties, divisive groups and separatist movements across the Continent. France\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEuroskeptic\xe2\x80\x9d National Front party, for example, 'b'has received Russian money'b'.'b'Meanwhile, the F.S.B. reportedly recruits and directs hackers to set off cyberattacks when it wants to punish or silence Russia\xe2\x80\x99s rivals. When the European Parliament and Commission began to criticize Moscow\xe2\x80\x99s takeover of Crimea in April 2014, for example, its systems were hit by networks of computers running a Russian-designed program called BlackEnergy. At the end of 2015, the 'b'same malware hit Ukraine\xe2\x80\x99s energy companies'b', leaving some 700,000 homes without power. It is not just foreigners who are targets. On the day of Russia\xe2\x80\x99s 2011 parliamentary election, coordinated cyberattacks crashed the websites of much of the country\xe2\x80\x99s liberal media outlets. Internet trolls have reportedly been paid to smear the opposition leader 'b'Alexei A. Navalny'b'. The moral seems clear: Mess with Moscow and bad things will happen.'b'The problem is that liberal countries with open economies, democratic politics and a legal presumption of innocence are far less able to resist these offensives. Money and misinformation move equally fast in the modern world. Proving that an extremist political group or a glib lobbyist is backed by Moscow is often impossible. Indeed, part of the genius of this new model of subversion is that it often can be done in plain sight, coyly wrapping itself in the mantle of free speech.'b'After Mr. Litvinenko\xe2\x80\x99s murder, Britain expelled Russian diplomats, limited visas for Russian officials and stopped intelligence sharing and police cooperation. There are no bodies and no smoking guns, no polonium trails and no easy answers.'b'AS a veteran, I want politicians and public figures to try and understand what military deployment is like, and to relate to my experiences. This is, of course, a disingenuous argument from a career opportunist. However, in a roundabout way, Mrs. Palin reignited a valuable discussion of combat and its psychological effects. Her portrayal of her son\xe2\x80\x99s condition seems aligned with enduring renditions of veterans as ticking time bombs, as damaged beings primed to harm.'b'I can\xe2\x80\x99t offer any grandiose pronouncements on the topic, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not an expert on the levels of domestic violence among veterans. But I can describe my own experience as someone with post-traumatic stress disorder.'b'Before my deployment to Afghanistan in early 2009, I was stationed in Alaska. My fondest memories of that state involve volunteering at a bicycle co-op the summer before heading overseas. When my tour ended, it took about 10 days to get back to Alaska from Afghanistan. During the long periods of waiting, I daydreamed about what I\xe2\x80\x99d do upon arriving home. The co-op was high on my list.'b'Within a week of my return in March 2010, I visited the co-op at its new, unfamiliar building. I found myself in a hot, loud and crowded room full of aloof young strangers. In that moment, I felt a sudden burst of panic, something completely unexpected. I felt as if I was going to die. I had to leave the room, to return to the safety of my truck parked outside in the snow. Something was very wrong; something about me was clearly defective.'b'This was the first indication that life after combat wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the idyll I had envisioned during my 13 months overseas. And there would be plenty more: When I was confronted with a crisis, it began to feel as if someone had placed a magnifying glass over my normal emotional responses. At times I\xe2\x80\x99d be hyper-alert, at others so brain-fogged that no amount of stimulants could enliven me, and no amount of alcohol could relax me. However, for three years I refused to seek help. I did not want it to affect my military career.'b'What those three years of denial entailed are scenes that I would much rather forget. Later, I realized that many of my friends had experienced similar moments: extreme reactions to emotional stimuli, hours of fear, weeks of hyper-vigilance. The common thread was not a tendency toward violence but rather toward self-hate. There were no flashbacks of combat. There was instead a sinking feeling that I\xe2\x80\x99d always be a downer, always on guard, never able to relax. It was the fear of being permanently broken.'b'In what I decided would be my final year in the military, I sought out mental health care. I received a PTSD diagnosis in June 2013 and left the military a year later; in 2015, the Department of Veterans Affairs rated me at 60 percent disability. I will have access to at least some kind of mental health care for the rest of my life, for which I am immensely grateful. Many veterans who did not seek care before leaving the military (or who were expelled from it) do not have this privilege. That is to say nothing of civilians who suffer the exact same symptoms, and experience the exact same stigma, without any kind of guaranteed care.'b'Because there is a stigma attached to mental health issues, there is a personal and professional risk attached with admitting an unseen ailment. I have the benefit of being a veteran, but I still worry about future graduate school applications or academic job searches. I worry about my own tenuous employment as an adjunct English lecturer. I also know that I\xe2\x80\x99ve managed to improve my symptoms greatly by seeking counseling, avoiding destructive behaviors and writing about my experiences. I can function in society because I was able to seek care, and I want to make that care more accessible to people who need it.'b'That process begins by speaking frankly. Facing up to destructive or abusive behavior comes next, along with the assertion that we are responsible for our actions, no matter what burdens we carry. Post-traumatic stress is no excuse for violence or abuse, nor should it be considered a default association. I\xe2\x80\x99d like to hope that, beneath the bluster and the political talking points, Sarah Palin understands this. I hope even more that her son seeks care and finds peace.'b'In the winter of 1985 my hometown, Buffalo, was engulfed in a blizzard \xe2\x80\x94 not an uncommon occurrence for the region, which is justly famed for epic snows. But this was a big one, and the city\xe2\x80\x99s blustery Irish-American mayor, Jimmy Griffin, was at pains to persuade people to stop trying to go about their business as conditions deteriorated. He urged Buffalonians to \xe2\x80\x9crelax, stay inside and grab a six-pack,\xe2\x80\x9d which must be the best advice any elected official ever gave the public in an emergency situation.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s something cartoonish about the menace of a blizzard, in which nature\xe2\x80\x99s wrath assumes a fluffy, roly-poly form and tries to kill you. It\xe2\x80\x99s the meteorological equivalent of getting smothered in 'b'Tribbles'b', or attacked by the 'b'Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man'b'. And yet, kill it does, via car accidents and heart attacks and other misadventures, usually involving people trying, unwisely, to do something.'b'Mr. Griffin, henceforth known as Jimmy Six-Pack, understood this. The Snow Gods reserve special contempt for those who don\xe2\x80\x99t respect their ability to bring human activity to a standstill. The snow cares not for your deadlines, your happy hour plans, your scheduled C-section. It wants only to fall on the ground and lie there. And it wants you to, too.'b'Needless to say, you should. Unless you\xe2\x80\x99re a plow driver or a parka-clad elected official trying to look essential, one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to do battle against a blizzard. You submit. Surrender. 'b'Hunker down'b'. A snowstorm rewards indolence and punishes the go-getters, which is only one of the many reasons it\xe2\x80\x99s the best natural disaster there is.'b'Jimmy Six-Pack also understood that snow functions as an arbiter of government effectiveness. (He stayed in office for 16 years.) In New York City, Mayor John Lindsay\xe2\x80\x99s lax response to a 1969 storm forever dinged his political fortunes. Cities need blizzards every few years to flush out incompetents, expose incipient dysfunction and generally stress-test the fabric of civilization. Like war, illness and poker, snow ruthlessly reveals true character.'b'And, gloriously if briefly, it hides everything else \xe2\x80\x94 the plastic grocery bags and mini-marts and dog poop and salt-grimed Toyotas and sundry disorder of modernity. Wachter (Sunday Review, Jan. 17), is right about the difficulties of appropriate measurement in health care.'b'Indeed, our research, which involves listening to covert recordings of visits between doctors and both real patients and trained actors playing the role of patients with targeted problems, suggests a major problem is overreliance on the electronic medical record as a source of performance data.'b'We and others who have used direct observation of care repeatedly find that medical records both fail to document care delivered and erroneously document care not delivered. Aid is based on need and consists entirely of grants. No student is required to take out loans.'b'Over all, nearly 60 percent of students receive grant aid, and on average their families pay $12,000 a year for tuition, room, board and fees combined. For nearly 20 percent of students \xe2\x80\x94 those from families with the most modest incomes \xe2\x80\x94 the expected family contribution is zero.'b'All this is possible because of the income generated by the university\xe2\x80\x99s endowment and the generous yearly contributions for student aid from Harvard\xe2\x80\x99s alumni and friends. But the endowment is not like one big bank account, to be drawn down at will. It consists of some 12,000 distinct funds, most designated by donors to support particular programs and activities, and all intended to provide support in perpetuity.'b'The university has an obligation to preserve the long-term value of those funds and to spend the income in accordance with donors\xe2\x80\x99 wishes. That includes support not just for undergraduate financial aid but also for all of Harvard College, for Harvard\xe2\x80\x99s 12 other schools, for its museums and its academic library, and for faculty research on challenges from cancer to climate change.'b'ROBERT REISCHAUER'b'Cambridge, Mass.'b''b'The writer, an economist, is a former senior fellow of the Harvard Corporation.'b''b'A mayoral election in Okinawa on Sunday is shaping up to be another stand-in for the fight over a plan to relocate an American military base to a less-populated site on the Japanese island. 'b''b'PARIS \xe2\x80\x94 We are reaching the end of the \xe2\x80\x9cHappy New Year\xe2\x80\x9d period which, in France, traditionally covers the whole month of January, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a relief. In Paris, last year started and ended with devastating terrorist attacks. As we all expect another assault anytime anywhere, amid persistent economic gloom and an unsolved migrant crisis, wishing the best for 2016 has become an inconvenient rite. The French radio host Philippe Meyer has taken to wishing his listeners \xe2\x80\x9ca better year than the one we\xe2\x80\x99re going to have.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This minor discomfort happens to betray a deeper reality, which is only starting to sink in: The events of 2015 changed our lives in a much more fundamental way than we like to admit. By \xe2\x80\x9cevents,\xe2\x80\x9d I mean more than the massacres at Charlie Hebdo, Hyper Cacher and the Bataclan. I mean the attacks in Tunis, Bamako, Jakarta, Istanbul, Ouagadougou, all those foreign places where Europeans and locals can be killed together. I mean the wars in Syria and Iraq, the millions of displaced people, the unstoppable flow of refugees to Europe, the enormous challenge of integrating them, as shown by the New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve nightmare in Cologne. I mean our jihadist fellow countrymen and women. I mean the rise of the far right and populist parties.'b'By \xe2\x80\x9cour lives,\xe2\x80\x9d I mean more than French lives. I mean German lives, Swedish lives, Danish lives, Greek lives \xe2\x80\x94 on top of all those involved outside Europe. All European Union countries \xe2\x80\x94 except maybe for a handful of post-Communist member states \xe2\x80\x94 are now affected by the terrorist threat or the migrant crisis, or both. Our hopes that the two could be distinct were dashed when the French police identified two of the Paris assassins as men who had arrived in Europe via the \xe2\x80\x9cmigrant route.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We are all Europeans, united by our geographic proximity to the chaotic Middle East, facing multiple challenges to our common cultural identity.'b'Part of our \xe2\x80\x9cnew normal\xe2\x80\x9d is now visible. Soldiers have been protecting our synagogues and mosques for a year. We learned to open our bags for a security guard; now we also open our coats to show we are not hiding an explosive belt. The chiefs of police and emergency services have reassessed their priorities; editors have reassigned reporters. French Jews are debating whether to give up wearing a yarmulke following the terrorist slashing of a Jewish teacher in Marseille, or keep it on, defiantly: In a poll, 70 percent of the French say they should keep it. Germany has hired 8,500 teachers to help with some 200,000 children of foreign refugees entering the school system this year.'b'Politicians are busy reviewing legislation to give more powers to anti-terrorist forces. To deter migrants, Sweden has imposed checks on its border with Denmark, which has in turn imposed checks on its border with Germany. Proposals that would have seemed completely off the wall a year ago are now being discussed in all seriousness, like seizing cash and valuables from asylum seekers (Denmark), interning those who arrive without passports (Germany), or stripping French citizenship from dual nationals convicted of terrorist acts.'b'Terrorism and Europe\xe2\x80\x99s biggest migration crisis since World War II frame the political debate in and among many E.U. countries. These twin problems also present formidable challenges for Brussels. All agree that the Union\xe2\x80\x99s external borders should be secured, but who will secure them? All agree that national intelligence services don\xe2\x80\x99t cooperate closely enough, but who will cede sovereignty on this sensitive activity? There is no common immigration or asylum policy, but how can we agree on one?'b'Beneath the surface of the new normal lie even more uncomfortable challenges. The public reaction to this situation, particularly in France and Germany, reveals a crucial dilemma: How, as a society, do we make necessary adjustments without betraying the values that define us? This question is at the heart of a passionate debate in France over where to stop the pendulum\xe2\x80\x99s swing between security and liberty; many of those who cherish their liberties struggle with the feeling that, at the moment, they value their security even more. Political elites may hate it, but polls show that proposals like depriving certain terrorists of French citizenship enjoy popular support.'b'Mourad Benchellali, a French former Guant\xc3\xa1namo inmate, who was released in 2004 and jailed in France until 2006, has experienced this changing sentiment first hand. Over the past few years, after writing a book, he has dedicated himself to preventing the radicalization of young Muslims. Now 34 and a father, he notices how feelings in France have hardened since the November attacks, which killed 130 people. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople are more reluctant to ask me to speak in schools or in prisons,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me recently. \xe2\x80\x9cSome are even canceling. After Charlie, people were worried about the government going too far with security. Since November, this is all they want.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Soul-searching is not the order of the day; liberal intellectuals have been incensed by recent remarks by Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who equals \xe2\x80\x9cexplaining\xe2\x80\x9d jihadism with \xe2\x80\x9cwanting to find ways to excuse it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Germans are equally torn. Since the ghastly New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve in Cologne, the celebrated Wilkommenskultur toward refugees has given way to serious doubts about how to integrate mass male migration, and to serious accusations against the police and the media. The cultural gap between a liberal, wealthy, secular Europe and a patriarchal, conservative, Muslim society has widened to an ocean. How long will it take to bridge it? How do you ensure that hard-won women\xe2\x80\x99s rights and freedom are not endangered? How do you teach cultural norms?'b'These are difficult questions \xe2\x80\x94 and they are being asked all over Europe. There are no easy answers, only a few predictions: Jihadism will not be defeated in 2016, and war and misery in the Middle East and Africa will send ever more people across the Mediterranean \xe2\x80\x94 around 2,000 still arrive in Europe by sea every day.'b'So we\xe2\x80\x99d better work together, set up common policies to secure our borders, fight terrorism, relocate refugees, and promote daring ideas for integration that will avoid ghettoization. The only response has to be a joint one: working separately would be foolish. If a 28-member European Union can\xe2\x80\x99t do it, then let\xe2\x80\x99s set up smaller groups. There is no more time to waste.'b'Heads are spinning.'b'When you grew up in an unmapped, unwired world and find yourself in this one \xe2\x80\x94 observing the panic when GPS fails or the extent of online status anxiety \xe2\x80\x94 you can\xe2\x80\x99t help wondering if somewhere along the way freedom got lost.'b'Freedom is still out there. We all have our idea of it, the deferred dream. Your psyche builds layers of protection around your most vulnerable traits, which may be closely linked to that precious essence in which freedom resides. Freedom is inseparable from risk.'b'Technology increases choice, but its prime purpose is to increase productivity; that is the amount that can be extracted from you in any given time. Like debt, it never sleeps. It confines you. It distracts you. It binds you. It depoliticizes you through isolation and through the blurring, in the cacophony it delivers, of fantasy with fact.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if the world is freer than a half-century ago. On paper, it is. The totalitarian Soviet Imperium is gone. The generals who bossed Latin America are gone, generally. Asia has unshackled itself and claims this century as its own. Media has opened out, gone social.'b'Yet minds feel more crimped, fear more pervasive, possibility more limited, adventure more choreographed, politics more stale, economics more skewed, pressure more crushing, escape more elusive.'b'Three things recently caused me to ponder these matters. The first was the appearance, like a letter in a bottle, of a diary from 1973, recording a time when I was in Afghanistan as a 17-year-old hippie. The second was reading \xe2\x80\x9cBarbarian Days,\xe2\x80\x9d William Finnegan\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful surfing memoir. The third was a question from my son. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take them in order.'b'The diary, written by Leslie Starr, covers three weeks that, as a young woman, she spent with me in Kabul, Bamian (its Buddhas still intact), Band-e-Amir and Mazar-i-Sharif. Starr, from Annapolis, traveled in a VW Kombi, named Pigpen after the keyboardist of the Grateful Dead, that I had driven with two friends to Afghanistan. It took her only 43 years to transcribe her jottings and so reverse time\xe2\x80\x99s arrow.'b'There I am, on Aug. 2, 1973, my 18th birthday, in a cave beside the beautiful lakes of Band-e-Amir, \xe2\x80\x9cpropped against bundles, surrounded by chickens, beautiful children, a kitten, a goat, women in the corners\xe2\x80\x9d eating. There, the next day, on the \xe2\x80\x9cterrible road\xe2\x80\x9d from Bamian to Mazar, \xe2\x80\x9czooming, crashing along into the night.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There again, on 'b'Aug.us'b't 10, at the Salang Pass (12,723 feet), camped out and cold with the engine bust. The next day, \xe2\x80\x9cwe coasted 40 kilometers, stopped in desperation.\xe2\x80\x9d Back in Kabul, I try a cake of, let us say, Colorado inspiration. It packs a punch. Starr writes, \xe2\x80\x9cDuring the night I heard Roger talking to Marcus about dying.\xe2\x80\x9d Oh, man. She observes these three young men \xe2\x80\x9cabout to enter Oxford\xe2\x80\x9d who \xe2\x80\x9csit around and write in notebooks or read Turgenev.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m struck by the haphazardness of that journey; the fact we drove across Iran; the way names likes Mazar and the Salang Pass have become synonymous with war; the idea of us teenagers thousands of miles from our parents, out of contact.'b'How much freer, in many ways, we were. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s that the world\xe2\x80\x99s more dangerous. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s that people are more frightened. Fear is a much-trafficked commodity.'b'Which brings me to Finnegan\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful book, a kind of hymn to freedom and passion. Freedom is inside you. It\xe2\x80\x99s the thing that cannot be denied. For Finnegan, that\xe2\x80\x99s surfing and writing. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could you know your limits unless you tested them?\xe2\x80\x9d he asks \xe2\x80\x94 a question as true before the ferocious energy of the wave as before the infinite possibilities of the written form.'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s a near- contemporary, embracing Kerouac and the Dead, contemptuous of what a friend calls \xe2\x80\x9cSuckcess,\xe2\x80\x9d hitting the road without a map to find the perfect wave somewhere between Guam and Cape Town, a child of a zeitgeist he describes as \xe2\x80\x9chippie culture, acid rock, hallucinogens, neo-Eastern mysticism, the psychedelic aesthetic.\xe2\x80\x9d Like me he laments the loss of the lost places, the beaches he was first to tread.'b'A patch of coast may demand a lifetime of study. Wave love, he observes, \xe2\x80\x9cis a one way street.\xe2\x80\x9d The wave, implacable, will turn on you. \xe2\x80\x9cScenes feel mythic even as they unfold. I always feel a ferocious ambivalence: I want to be nowhere else; I want to be anywhere else.\xe2\x80\x9d One near- escape produces this catharsis: \xe2\x80\x9cOn my knees in the sand, in the twilight, absolutely spent, I was surprised to find myself sobbing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What my son Blaise, who is 21, asked was whether it\xe2\x80\x99s still possible to have such adventures. He thought not \xe2\x80\x94 too much control, too much Google Earth. I suggested he might be wrong and that, on graduation, he might drive from New York to Patagonia. It\xe2\x80\x99s important to experience that \xe2\x80\x9cferocious ambivalence,\xe2\x80\x9d the threshold of freedom.'b'WITH the protests in Ferguson, Mo., the Black Lives Matter movement and the massacre of black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., on their minds, the presidents of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s two major Baptist groups \xe2\x80\x94 one predominantly white, one predominantly black \xe2\x80\x94 decided it was time for a bold gesture. The Southern Baptist Convention, founded by slaveholders and their supporters before the Civil War, is now the nation\xe2\x80\x99s second-largest Christian denomination after the Roman Catholic Church. Black Baptists formed their own churches and in 1880 founded what eventually became the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A.'b'Late last year, the leaders each invited 10 of their pastors to join in a public conversation on racial reconciliation in Jackson, Miss. The Rev. Dr. Ronnie Floyd, president of the Southern Baptist Convention, and the Rev. Dr. Jerry Young, president of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., visited The New York Times recently to discuss the Jackson meeting, and the goals behind it. An edited version of their conversation follows.'b''b'Q.'b' What was it like being in that room?'b''b'YOUNG'b' For me personally, it was almost euphoric. Literally to be in that room dealing with that particular issue in light of my own personal history and the history of Mississippi, and Southern Baptist history. That moment was filled with hope and a tremendous sense of possibility.'b''b'Q.'b' You\xe2\x80\x99ve told me that you were born on a plantation in the Mississippi Delta and grew up experiencing racism. Did you tell the Southern Baptists about those experiences?'b''b'YOUNG'b' In the little town I grew up in, Lamont, just north of Greenville, there were three stores, and I remember distinctly once, we went into one store and there was an elderly man there. They had a cooler where you got the sodas and took them to the counter. The man went and picked up a Coke and went to the counter, and the person behind the counter refused to sell him the Coke because it was a white man\xe2\x80\x99s drink. He had to put it back in the cooler.'b''b'Q.'b' Reverend Floyd, why did you, as a white Southern Baptist, want to sit down with African-American Baptists?'b''b'FLOYD'b' I had been deeply grieved by what I had seen happening in this country, ever since the events of Ferguson. And then the Charleston shooting, which broke our hearts. The Southern Baptist Convention has 51,094 churches, and out of that, 10,300 of them are nonwhite churches, so we really want deeply to move forward in reaching multiethnic people, nonwhite people.'b''b'Q.'b' Is that part of the motivation for doing this racial reconciliation effort, that you\xe2\x80\x99re just trying to grow your own denomination?'b''b'FLOYD'b' It\xe2\x80\x99s not our motive. We believe that God is sovereign over all affairs, and God miraculously led us together. I wrote an article helped by several nonwhite leaders in our denomination, along with a couple of guys that look like me, and it was a response to the Ferguson issue. And it just caught lots of fire, in a good way. It ended up being featured in an African-American magazine, and they sent me a copy of it. And there\xe2\x80\x99s Jerry Young on the front cover, bigger than Dallas. Then they got my picture down here in a little thing, talking about me speaking on racism. And I just got to tell you, that\xe2\x80\x99s one of the greatest pictures I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever had. And I mean that. Because 'b'[turning to Mr. Young]'b' I love you and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know you. But that day when I got that magazine I wrote you a congratulatory letter, and from that moment the Lord put us together.'b''b'YOUNG'b' I am convinced that if we don\xe2\x80\x99t get this racism issue right in the church, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think there\xe2\x80\x99s any way we can do it in the culture. The church has a checkered past, even now, with racism, no question. And that\xe2\x80\x99s not just white racism. It\xe2\x80\x99s racism period.'b''b'Q.'b' Are you saying the black church also has a problem with racism?'b''b'YOUNG'b' Sure, we all have a problem with racism, in a different way of course. There are some African-Americans who have had some real serious problems with the white church, with the Southern Baptist church for instance. Even in my own denomination, there are people right now who can\xe2\x80\x99t overcome the history. And for them, the history has become a serious stumbling block. In fact I\xe2\x80\x99ve never said this to Dr. Floyd, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve had fellows in my own denomination who called me and said: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing? I mean, are you not aware of the history?\xe2\x80\x9d And I say, obviously I\xe2\x80\x99m aware. They bring up the issue about slavery and that becomes a reason, they say, that we ought not to be involved with the Southern Baptists. Where from my vantage point, that\xe2\x80\x99s reverse racism. I do understand the history, and I understand the pain of the past. But what I\xe2\x80\x99m also quite clear about is, if the Gospel does anything at all, the Gospel demands that we not only preach but practice reconciliation.'b''b'Q.'b' The Southern Baptist Convention does have quite a history of racism.'b''b'FLOYD'b' Yes, and I\xe2\x80\x99m deeply regretful for that. The Southern Baptist Convention was formed in 1845. I can\xe2\x80\x99t do anything about what happened in 1845, but I can do a lot about where we are today in 2015. My church has a lot of people that are not white. We live in the homeland of Walmart, J. B. Hunt, Tyson Foods and the University of Arkansas. And with the growth of those companies, our whole region has changed. And in order for us to reach our region, we have to be able to reach all people.'b''b'YOUNG'b' I\xe2\x80\x99ve had this question asked of me about the motive. And my answer has been, one, I actually do believe in Dr. Floyd. I think he\xe2\x80\x99s honest, a fine Christian gentleman. But if the motive is not pure, I tell people all the time, if in the end, good comes out of it, the community is blessed, the church, the culture, America is made better, even if people have impure motives. Because I do believe it is so critical. America in my opinion is a powder keg. This racial thing is some awesome stuff.'b''b'Q.'b' The presidential campaign has gotten very nasty, with racial overtones. Some of the candidates \xe2\x80\x94 Gov. Mike Huckabee, Senator Ted Cruz \xe2\x80\x94 who have spoken most harshly about President Obama are Southern Baptists.'b''b'YOUNG'b' I think the tone of the public rhetoric incites racism. I think it gives persons who want to be racist a sense that it\xe2\x80\x99s O.K. to do this. It empowers them and they\xe2\x80\x99re emboldened by it.'b''b'FLOYD'b' I\xe2\x80\x99m a Baptist pastor, I\xe2\x80\x99m not in politics. But I would say that Governor Huckabee and Senator Cruz have got to answer for themselves. I told my people numerous times, don\xe2\x80\x99t call the president by his last name alone. Regardless if you believe in his politics or you don\xe2\x80\x99t, he is President Obama. I talked to them about the importance of preserving the office.'b''b'YOUNG'b' That\xe2\x80\x99s right, that\xe2\x80\x99s right.'b''b'FLOYD'b' Because if you don\xe2\x80\x99t model that with the leader of the nation, you\xe2\x80\x99re not going to model it to your teachers in your schools, to your bosses on your jobs.'b''b'Q.'b' Are there concrete things you see your churches taking on together? What about issues like criminal justice or sentencing reform?'b''b'FLOYD'b' We\xe2\x80\x99re going to encourage our pastors to swap pulpits, get them in uncomfortable or at least different environments than they\xe2\x80\x99re used to.'b''b'YOUNG'b' I will only go to Arkansas if he comes to Mississippi.'b''b'FLOYD'b' It will be a joy to come to Mississippi.'b''b'YOUNG'b' Fellowshipping is what he\xe2\x80\x99s talking about. We\xe2\x80\x99ve agreed to that. He\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely correct: Suspicion, fear, distrust, all that stuff is there. How do you get beyond that if you don\xe2\x80\x99t get to know people?'b'IN 2006, I sentenced a man to 18 years in prison. I have been wrestling with that decision ever since.'b'As a federal district judge, I\xe2\x80\x99ve sentenced hundreds of people, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve rarely agonized as much as I did over this man\xe2\x80\x99s fate.'b'He was the enforcer for a brutal gang of drug dealers in Bridgeport, Conn., known as the Terminators, and had sold heroin, assaulted rival dealers and murdered a potential witness. But after a falling-out with the head of the gang, he turned over a stash house to the police and fled the state. When captured in 2001, he immediately confessed to the murder and later testified as a star witness for the prosecution.'b'Thus arose my problem: He had committed horrible crimes, but he also seemed to be making an unusually sincere effort to atone for them. So which man was I sentencing? The murderer or the remorseful cooperator?'b'The prosecutor rewarded his cooperation by filing a so-called 5K motion, which allowed me to ignore the mandatory life sentence he otherwise would have faced. Still, after weighing the seriousness of his crimes, I sentenced him to 18 years, which was more time than even the prosecutor wanted.'b'I gave a speech encouraging the defendant to make the most of his time in prison. He promised to work hard and ready himself to lead a productive life after his release. But nearly everyone I sentence says something similar.'b'In the years that followed, I often wondered whether his remorse was strong enough to overcome his past.'b'In 2012, I had the chance to find out. While attending a conference on sentencing issues, I learned that he was serving time in a prison nearby. I wanted to know whether he had become a better citizen or a better criminal. So I asked a prison staffer if I could meet with him in private.'b'That the warden felt no need to post a guard was my first clue that he had changed for the better. He was working in his first real job at the prison industries factory and had been promoted to supervisor. He showed me recommendations from prison employees for good jobs on the outside. He brought a folder full of certificates he had earned for attending classes. He talked lovingly about his girlfriend and daughter, with whom he planned to live as a family after his release.'b'The meeting made me proud of his accomplishments, but sad that I had not been more confident in him. He still had several years left on his sentence, but it was clear that he had served enough time.'b'After I returned to my office, I contacted the prosecutor and his lawyer and encouraged them to find a way to get him released early. But they told me there was no straightforward way to shorten a federal inmate\xe2\x80\x99s sentence, even if prison officials acknowledge that more jail time is a waste of time and money. So he had to stay in prison, at an annual cost of $30,000 to taxpayers.'b'The tragedy of mass incarceration has recently focused much attention on the need to reform three-strikes laws, mandatory minimums and the federal-sentencing guidelines, which often direct judges to impose excessive sentences. We also need a mechanism for judges to re-evaluate the sentences they\xe2\x80\x99ve imposed.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s true that federal prisoners can earn up to 15 percent off the length of their sentences if they stay out of trouble. But this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t incentivize prisoners to take advantage of work or study opportunities.'b'Instead, Congress should enact legislation that would allow every sentenced defendant one opportunity to petition his sentencing court for a reduction based on extraordinarily good conduct and rehabilitation in prison.'b'This \xe2\x80\x9csecond-look review\xe2\x80\x9d should be available only to prisoners who are supported by their wardens. To minimize the increased workload on busy federal judges, each prisoner should be allowed only a single opportunity to seek early release and do so only after serving at least half of the sentence imposed (or two-thirds of a mandatory minimum sentence).'b'Factors in support of an early release should include more than just clean disciplinary records in prison. Job readiness, success with drug treatment, completion of vocational and educational training and extraordinary family or health circumstances should count as well.'b'While the Bureau of Prisons has the authority under the existing \xe2\x80\x9ccompassionate release\xe2\x80\x9d program to do much of what I advocate, that program has been used far too sparingly, in part because of bureaucratic hurdles. From 2008 to 2014, only 11 of the thousands of prisoners sentenced by federal courts in New York have been released under this program. Most of them were terminally ill. Compassionate release provides no realistic way out of prison. And prisoners with no reason to hope have little reason to reform.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t advocate for a return to the flawed federal parole system that was essentially abolished in the 1980s. In that system, a judge who believed that a defendant should spend three years locked up would impose a nine-year sentence because parole was likely to be granted after he served one-third of it. But if that defendant\xe2\x80\x99s parole was delayed or denied, the judge\xe2\x80\x99s original intent was impeded. In contrast, my proposal would give the sentencing judge control. This makes sense because judges know whether a particular defendant got a break at sentencing or not and can best gauge the extent of positive change in a person.'b'The man I sentenced in 2006 will soon leave prison. Counting the time he served in custody before sentencing and time off for good behavior, he is scheduled to be released in April. In total, he will have served over 14 years. The last three years of that sentence, if not more, were a waste of time.'b'Upon his release, I will reach out to express my regret for rejecting the prosecutor\xe2\x80\x99s request for leniency. And I will thank him for inciting my interest in this reform.'b'A \xe2\x80\x9csecond look\xe2\x80\x9d to adjust sentences would give inmates an incentive to prepare themselves for productive lives on the outside, and allow judges like me to correct sentences that turn out, in hindsight, to be unnecessarily long. This would improve the fairness of our criminal justice system and increase the public\xe2\x80\x99s confidence in our courts.'b'REMEMBER the poll last week that had Bernie Sanders ahead of Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire by three points?'b'No, you\xe2\x80\x99re thinking. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got it wrong. Sanders was up by 27.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s true, if you\xe2\x80\x99re talking about the figures that CNN and WMUR released on Tuesday. I\xe2\x80\x99m talking about the ones that Gravis Marketing and One America News Network released on 'b'Wednesday'b'.'b'There were three polls of New Hampshire voters over just two days last week, according to 'b'the archive'b' maintained by Real Clear Politics. There were three polls of Iowa voters on Thursday alone. One had Clinton up by eight, while another had Sanders up by that same margin. One had Donald Trump up by 11. Another had Ted Cruz up by two.'b'Over a monthlong period ending Thursday night \xe2\x80\x94 a monthlong period, mind you, that included the Christmas and New Year\xe2\x80\x99s break \xe2\x80\x94 there were 11 polls in Iowa, 10 in New Hampshire and nine nationally. There were polls focused on 10 different states.'b'And their findings were often treated as breathless news. On Wednesday evening, I visited the home page of the 'b'Politico'b' website \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m using Politico as a random example \xe2\x80\x94 and spotted four stories that were essentially about poll results.'b'My television was on: The 'b'CNN'b' anchor Erin Burnett began her show with a report on the latest poll.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99d say that we\xe2\x80\x99re in a period of polling bloat, but bloat is too wan a word. Where polling and the media\xe2\x80\x99s attention to it are concerned, we\xe2\x80\x99re gorging ourselves into a state of morbid obesity.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen anything like it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ralph Reed, a longtime Republican strategist who thought that things were bad in 2008 and 2012 and realizes now that those were days of temperance and innocence, to be pined for and perhaps never savored again.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s not the crazy bounty of polls that fascinates him (and me) most. It\xe2\x80\x99s something else.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere seems to be an inverse relationship between the preponderance of polling and the 'b'reliability'b' of polling,\xe2\x80\x9d Reed said, nailing one of the most illogical, paradoxical dynamics of the 2016 election so far.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99re leaning harder than ever on polling precisely when that makes the least sense. We\xe2\x80\x99re wallowing in polls even as they come to wildly different conclusions that should give us serious pause.'b'Good polls are arguably 'b'more difficult than ever'b' to do, for reasons I\xe2\x80\x99ll go into later. And from 2012 forward, there have been 'b'prominent examples'b' of how poorly they sometimes predict outcomes. They botched the most recent parliamentary elections in Britain and Israel. They botched the 2014 midterms in the United States, grossly miscalculating the margins in various congressional and gubernatorial races.'b'Last year, Reed noted, the Real Clear Politics average of polls in the Kentucky governor\xe2\x80\x99s race had the Democrat, Jack Conway, ahead of the Republican, Matt Bevin, by five points.'b'Bevin won by nearly nine.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was 14 points off,\xe2\x80\x9d Reed marveled. \xe2\x80\x9cBut everybody shrugs and moves on down the highway.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There are explanations for those shrugs, and they speak to the quirks and flaws of political journalism in a wired, revved-up world.'b'There are consequences, too. An obsession with polls and a quickness to weave narratives around them bolster certain candidates and retard others, and could well affect the outcome of this presidential election.'b'If Donald Trump wins the Republican nomination \xe2\x80\x94 or, heaven forbid, the White House \xe2\x80\x94 it will be partly because we in the media justified saturation coverage of him by pointing to polls, which in turn legitimized 'b'his'b' 'b'fixation'b' on them as proof that he\xe2\x80\x99s up to the job: He must be, because plenty of people apparently picture him in it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe 'b'caresses 'b'his polls numbers,\xe2\x80\x9d said David Axelrod, one of the chief architects of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 2008 and 2012 presidential campaigns, adding that Trump\xe2\x80\x99s first order of business when he steps up to a microphone is \xe2\x80\x9ca recitation of poll numbers. He\xe2\x80\x99s like a Lothario recounting his exploits every time he starts a speech.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If Jeb Bush\xe2\x80\x99s candidacy comes to naught, his underwhelming poll numbers \xe2\x80\x94 and how they were used to cast him instantly as an underachiever \xe2\x80\x94 will have been a factor. And if Clinton fails to win the nomination, the media\xe2\x80\x99s embrace of certain polls among an ever-changing riot of them will have played at least some small role.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf she\xe2\x80\x99s three points behind in New Hampshire, it\xe2\x80\x99s a close race,\xe2\x80\x9d Axelrod said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if she\xe2\x80\x99s 27 points behind, her campaign\xe2\x80\x99s in free fall. That\xe2\x80\x99s a sexier story and the one that\xe2\x80\x99s chosen. It becomes the meme. It becomes the prism through which everyone filters their coverage. It skews how people view everything that a candidate does: Is it conviction or desperation?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Desperation makes a better story. So the media dwells on the most pessimistic projections, ensuring that polling, no matter how divorced from reality, shapes it.'b'Polls determined which Republican candidates participated in which debates, although just a couple of percentage points \xe2\x80\x94 the margin of error, really \xe2\x80\x94 separated a few of the prime-time debaters from the early birds.'b'Some of these polls were national ones, which have minimal relevance to the decisive, trajectory-setting contests in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA national poll is absolutely meaningless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stuart Stevens, the chief strategist for Romney\xe2\x80\x99s 2012 campaign. \xe2\x80\x9cOne of every nine Americans lives in California. So one of every nine voters in that poll is going to be in California. When\xe2\x80\x99s the last time anybody read a story about the Republican primary in California?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And if you dig below the surface of these national polls \xe2\x80\x94 or of polls in the states with the first contests \xe2\x80\x94 you find a crucial detail that we in the media blithely gloss over: Many, if not most, voters haven\xe2\x80\x99t made up their minds. In last week\xe2\x80\x99s CNN/WMUR poll of New Hampshire voters, for example, about one in three Republicans said that they had definitely decided on a candidate.'b'Part of what I find so jarring about the media\xe2\x80\x99s insatiable appetite for polls right now is that it defies our past resolutions to go on a desperately needed diet. For all of my 30 years as a journalist, I\xe2\x80\x99ve listened to reporters, editors and producers bemoan the \xe2\x80\x9chorse-race coverage\xe2\x80\x9d of campaigns and exhort one another to be better come the next election and concentrate instead on issues, records, biographies, substance.'b'Suddenly the apologies and exhortations are gone. We\xe2\x80\x99re worse. Every candidate\xe2\x80\x99s a thoroughbred, every day the Kentucky Derby and just about every other story on many newscasts and news sites an assessment of his or her odds. We\xe2\x80\x99re resigned to treating campaigns as sport. It represents the surest path to a large enough audience to keep a beleaguered industry economically viable.'b'Some dispatches are overt in their reliance on polls, others less so, using polls as the prompts or context for discussions of stalled campaign momentum or new campaign strategies. The Times is guilty. 'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m guilty'b'. Polls are the seemingly irresistible argot of political coverage; to purge them from your vocabulary is to speak in an unrecognizable tongue.'b'BESIDES which, we need the content. In a fast-metabolism world of constantly monitored smartphones and routinely refreshed browsers, news organizations are under greater pressure to produce fresh nuggets of information even as their budgets and resources for reporting decline. So we readily trumpet and analyze polls, a practice that has even given birth and currency to a whole strain of news that\xe2\x80\x99s survey-based, with practitioners who burrow ever deeper into numbers.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a lot of people who don\xe2\x80\x99t ever go out on the campaign trail and actually talk to voters,\xe2\x80\x9d Stevens said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe now call those people data journalists. They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to report. It\xe2\x80\x99s a wonderful category.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Our demand for polls guarantees a robust supply of them: Churning these surveys out is great guaranteed publicity for news organizations, research companies and academic institutions. How many Americans are aware of Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn., or Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., only because they commission and put their stamps on polls?'b'But not all of the surveys that the media cites are created equal. Gary Langer, the founder of 'b'Langer Research Associates'b' and a former director of polling for ABC News, compared the variable quality of polls to the variable quality of what you eat. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are well-crafted, delicious meals,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThen there\xe2\x80\x99s fast food. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s listeria.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Listeria is common. People\xe2\x80\x99s reliance on cellphones has complicated polling: Federal law forbids automated calls to such phones, so pollsters must bear the considerable expense of dialing them by hand or, alternately, make do without them, which can lead to imperfect results.'b'Beyond that, there\xe2\x80\x99s the question of whether the kind of people who consent to polls are true weather vanes.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe entire industry rests on the idea that the people you get are representative of the people you don\xe2\x80\x99t get,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jon Cohen, who supervised polling for The Washington Post from 2006 to 2013 and is now the vice president of survey research at 'b'SurveyMonkey'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cI think that\xe2\x80\x99s an increasingly questionable premise and one that I keep in mind every time I design a survey.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPeople don\xe2\x80\x99t enjoy or even tolerate those conversations the way they used to,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cTaking a survey is a participatory act, and different kinds of people participate in different things.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Can we extrapolate from the kinds of people who have been professing adoration of Trump \xe2\x80\x94 or, for that matter, of Sanders \xe2\x80\x94 into the general population? Apart from that, can we trust the constancy of their affections? Will they actually cast votes?'b'Over the next few weeks, we\xe2\x80\x99ll find out, and I promise you this: There will be some surprises. If they\xe2\x80\x99re significant enough, polling could be as big a loser in the 2016 primaries as any candidate is. And we in the media will be forced to apologize anew for our poll-mad behavior. Sadly, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean we\xe2\x80\x99ll change it.'b'MODERN American culture is down on shame \xe2\x80\x94 it is, we are told, a damaging, useless emotion that we should neither feel ourselves nor make others feel. This is particularly the case when it comes to drug and alcohol addiction. The nation\xe2\x80\x99s drug czar, 'b'Michael Botticelli'b', has led a well-intentioned campaign to eradicate feelings of shame in addicted people by, in part, 'b'likening addiction to cancer,'b' a disease outside of people\xe2\x80\x99s control.'b'But in fact, the experience of shame \xe2\x80\x94 the feeling that one has failed to live up to one\xe2\x80\x99s own standards \xe2\x80\x94 can play a positive role in recovery from addiction, as well as from other kinds of destructive habits.'b'Certainly, as a psychiatrist and psychologist, respectively, we have observed the corrosive effects of shame on patients with conditions over which they have scant control, especially those with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. And like most people, we consider it unethical, cruel and clinically pointless to disparage or judge people whose disorders \xe2\x80\x94 severe mental illness, cancer \xe2\x80\x94 are largely or entirely impossible to modify by the sheer force of will.'b'But addiction is different. In sharp contrast to schizophrenics, the afflicted person can take at least partial control of it.'b'Although heavy and repeated drug use alters the brain, especially regions that mediate self-control, the essential question is not whether those neural changes occur. Instead, it is whether they necessarily disable a person\xe2\x80\x99s capacity to reason and to respond to carrots and sticks.'b'A vast literature shows that addiction is an activity whose course can be altered by its foreseeable consequences, including tangible rewards for cutting down on use. In contrast, no amount of reinforcement or punishment can alter the course of an entirely autonomous biological condition, like cancer. You would never bribe a patient with breast cancer to keep her tumor from spreading, or threaten to impose a penalty on her if it did.'b'Indeed, addicts make scores of choices every day. Most heroin addicts, for example, perform some kind of gainful work between shooting up. In the days between binges, cocaine addicts make many decisions as well. One of those decisions could be to enter treatment or to stop on their own.'b'This is not to say that quitting is easy; most people who enter treatment are deeply conflicted about giving up their habits. Still, many addicts have been motivated to quit by a spasm of self-reproach. In his addiction memoir \xe2\x80\x9cThe Night of the Gun,\xe2\x80\x9d the New York Times columnist David Carr 'b'recounted'b' how he decided to kick his drug habit after he realized how profoundly irresponsible he\xe2\x80\x99d been when he locked his twin baby girls in a car while he met with his dealer to score crack.'b'So under what conditions does shame end up prodding people into correcting their course? Alternatively, when does intense self-criticism make matters worse by further fueling an addiction (for example, drinking even more to mute the pain of those shameful feelings)?'b'An important influence appears to be whether people buy into the notion that a habit is under or out of their control. In a meta-analysis \xe2\x80\x94 a mathematical synthesis of previous studies \xe2\x80\x94 just published in The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, the University of Connecticut psychologist Colin Leach and one of his doctoral students, Atilla Cidam, 'b'examined'b' the links between shame and \xe2\x80\x9cconstructive approach behaviors,\xe2\x80\x9d such as helping or cooperating with others, apologizing and making amends for one\xe2\x80\x99s failures.'b'They found that study participants who were vulnerable to experiencing shame were less inclined to engage in corrective actions when they believed their mistakes were not fixable, such as when they had no opportunity to apologize to someone they\xe2\x80\x99d offended. In contrast, participants were more inclined to engage in positive behaviors when they thought their errors could be repaired.'b'The lesson is that shame can act as a spur to amend self-inflicted damage when people perceive that damage is fixable and manageable. In light of this finding, comparing addiction to a purely biological disorder, like cancer, might backfire, leading people to see their habits as unalterable.'b'None of this is to say that the culture, as a whole, needs to embrace the scarlet letter. But it does mean that therapists can harness patients\xe2\x80\x99 sense of shame to help them. Consider the patient who feels ashamed because she was \xe2\x80\x9ca bad mother\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 say, she took risks like routinely leaving her baby in the care of abusive adults. She should be helped to realize not only that her shame is realistic, but also that emotions can be signals. In this case, shame is a signal that the best way to mend and manage feelings of self-reproach is to fully commit herself to protecting her children and gaining their trust.'b'In other instances, shame is unwarranted and damaging. A classic example is a patient whose feelings of shame take the form of a conviction that she is inherently unlovable. It is critical for the therapist to help the patient distinguish such inappropriate shame, which goes to the core of self-worth, from realistic self-appraisals that guide restorative actions.'b'Despite its bad reputation, shame is an emotion like most others: It can be beneficial under certain circumstances. If people believe they can change, then shame might help bring that change about.'b'Tom Lutz is editor in chief of The 'b'Los Angeles Review of Books'b'.'b''b'READING'b' The third volume of Jane Smiley\xe2\x80\x99s astounding \xe2\x80\x9cLast Hundred Years\xe2\x80\x9d trilogy. The books can all be read separately although you\xe2\x80\x99d be robbing yourself if you skipped any of them. And 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDreamland,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' Sam Quinones\xe2\x80\x99s book on the heroin epidemic and its, to me, surprising causes \xe2\x80\x94 the overprescription of pharmaceuticals like OxyContin in combination with the legalization of marijuana.'b'Also my students\xe2\x80\x99 work \xe2\x80\x94 I teach creative writing at the 'b'University of California, Riverside'b' \xe2\x80\x94 as well as pitches and articles for LARB. And I read the books of whoever is coming on the 'b'LARB Radio Hour'b' \xe2\x80\x94 recently that\xe2\x80\x99s meant 'b'a book by Geoff Dyer'b', 'b'Terry McMillan\xe2\x80\x99s latest'b', Darryl Holter and Bill Deverell on 'b'Woody Guthrie'b', novels by 'b'Parnaz Foroutan'b', 'b'Viet Thanh Nguyen'b', 'b'Walter Mosley'b', 'b'Salman Rushdie'b','b' Karolina Waclawiak'b', 'b'John Rechy'b', 'b'Darryl Pinckney'b' \xe2\x80\x94 I guess I read a lot.'b''b'LISTENING'b' To myself play the piano \xe2\x80\x94 a baby grand I bought 20 years ago in a junk shop out in the desert, in Joshua Tree. Somebody had spray-painted it gold so it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t selling particularly well. I can sit down at that piano, play Ray Charles\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDrown in My Own Tears,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' sing it at the top of my lungs, occasionally on pitch, and do it over and over and over again, day after day, year after year. Makes me feel like a million bucks. My neighbors, I assume, hate me for it, but they are too nice to say so.'b'Other than that I listen to whatever my son, also a hobby musician, tells me to listen to. Lately it\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'The 'b''b'Budos'b' Band \xe2\x80\x94 solid, updated funk. 'b'Latimore'b' and 'b'Syl Johnson'b' sound the way Blaxploitation films look. And 'b'Portugal. It\xe2\x80\x99s endless entertainment. And I am starting to do my quadrennial 'b'Nate Silver'b' impression, gobbling up political polls, putting them through my completely unscientific matrix of second-guessing, and then making pronouncements about who is going to win the presidency and the Senate. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always followed politics. My mother was a 'b'Eugene McCarthy'b' delegate at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.'b''b'TRAVELING'b' I have a deep, almost pathological, wanderlust. It started when I was a kid hitchhiking and riding freight trains around the country. One of the great things about the train is I never really knew where I was going. Still my favorite way to travel is without an itinerary or predetermined goal, and the farther off the beaten path the better. Nothing makes me happier than going to countries at the bottom of other people\xe2\x80\x99s lists. Most recently it was 'b'Belarus'b'. It\xe2\x80\x99s a very rural country with only one big city. And yet they\xe2\x80\x99ve built this amazing 'b'high-tech industry'b'. A surprising 40 percent of the population does brain work.'b'The government of Colombia and the country\xe2\x80\x99s largest guerrilla group have made an 'b'unusual joint request'b' to the United Nations Security Council. Nearing the final stages of an armistice negotiation, the two sides asked the Council to set up a mission of international experts to oversee a critical part of the proposed agreement: disarming the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist-inspired insurgency.'b'It is a task the United Nations should embrace. The laying-down of arms is a critical prerequisite to a permanent cease-fire.'b'Since 'b'peace talks began'b' in Havana in 2012, the two sides have reached tentative agreements on fighting narcotics traffic, on land reform and on reparations for victims. But realizing these agreements will require peaceful collaboration on both sides, and that depends on the willingness of squads of guerrilla fighters to emerge from the jungle and relinquish their weapons.'b'Considering the lingering mistrust between fighters who have been at war for five decades, this could be a fraught process. Hence the joint request to the United Nations to oversee it. Although President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia hailed the request as a sign that the peace process was 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cincreasingly irreversible,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'the handover of arms will not be easy. FARC leaders have been reluctant to surrender their weapons to the government, arguing that doing so would be seen as an act of defeat. There is currently no agreement on who would take custody of the weapons and what would ultimately happen to them.'b'The Colombian government envisions that the FARC will assemble its fighters in a handful of regions once a final peace agreement is signed and that rank-and-file fighters will start to gradually transition into civilian life. Having teams of international observers present at those sites would increase the likelihood that the process could be carried out in an orderly fashion and that any disputes and unforeseen challenges could be settled quickly.'b'The government has promised to guarantee the safety of the United Nations personnel, who would be unarmed. The parties have asked that the teams include members from Caribbean and Latin American countries. The mission would have a one-year mandate that could be renewed by mutual consent. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon,'b' signaled his support'b' in a statement hailing the request as \xe2\x80\x9cyet another significant step toward the peaceful resolution of the armed conflict.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It is rare for combatants to turn to the United Nations by mutual consent for help in carrying out a peace agreement. At a time when the United Nations is struggling to contain conflicts in Libya, Yemen and Syria, the mission to Colombia is a promising opportunity. 'b'Managing a crucial phase of this process would be a powerful symbol that even long and bitter conflicts can end through dialogue.'b''b'THIS is, of course, a pointless column. The Republican presidential race is over, as you may have heard. Donald Trump has the nomination wrapped up \xe2\x80\x94 in the most luxurious, velveteen packaging you\xe2\x80\x99ve ever seen. Tell me the truth,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.'b'Her question rocked me for a moment. She was a hair\xe2\x80\x99s distance from landing a six-figure job. We sat overlooking a giant trading floor, a sea of men punching keyboards or barreling across a room bathed in testosterone. Here and there, you could see a woman in a tailored suit. Clearly, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t work in some sharing-and-caring girlfriend club where women confided in one another. We didn\xe2\x80\x99t gossip, we didn\xe2\x80\x99t mentor, and sometimes we even saw one another as the competition.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat exactly do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d I replied.'b'She noted correctly that few of the female traders and analysts at the firm were mothers and that even fewer had made it to the executive level.'b'I needed a moment to answer her carefully. I was then 11 years into my career, and seven months pregnant with my second child, and I hoped her journey would be different and better than mine.'b'Of course she would have to avoid stereotypical female behavior, and so she could never cry. She would work long hours and hide her pregnancies and her preschooler\xe2\x80\x99s art. One of my co-workers even hid being married. I had to re-earn the contents of that box, starting that morning. Women like me were \xe2\x80\x9cteam players,\xe2\x80\x9d and I was often complimented on my thick skin.
