The women labeled stellar successes were giving up more than I was willing to part with. With the benefit of some perspective, I began to think more deeply about what I and my female colleagues had experienced.'b'Hundreds of millions of dollars have been paid out to Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s victims of gender inequality and harassment. Countless books and articles have coached women to lean every which way, to share their domestic duties 50/50, and to demand the bonuses they have earned. Harvard Business School started an initiative to promote the advancement of women. Investment banks formed diversity committees and have taken a more generous stance on maternity leave, and Morgan Stanley, after being forced to settle 'b'a $46 million class-action discrimination suit'b', set up policies to help women succeed.'b'And what is the result of all these steps? While female M.B.A.s seem to be paid almost the same as men in their first job, the chasm appears quickly. According to a 2015 Bloomberg Businessweek 'b'survey'b' that tracked M.B.A. graduates from 2007 to 2009, the women earned, six to eight years later, on average 20 percent less than the guy who sat next to them in class; even more tellingly, female graduates of Columbia\xe2\x80\x99s business school, a significant proportion of whom land on Wall Street, earned nearly 40 percent less. How can everything have changed and nothing change at all?'b'Here is one explanation. Like most employees on Wall Street, my young candidate had to sign a 'b'U4, an arbitration agreement'b' that binds a worker to settle any job dispute with her employer in-house. Most people are so happy to have the job, they aren\xe2\x80\x99t worried about the prospect of settling complaints in a conference room, usually with 'b'arbitrators chosen because they are friendly to the bank'b'.'b'In fact, roughly two of every three cases are decided in Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s favor. In addition, half of the arbitration costs are borne by the complainant and what would be a few hundred dollar filing fee in court can quickly escalate to as much as $150,000 out of pocket. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lot to lose should things not go your way. No wonder this practice is an effective gag for many would-be whistle-blowers.'b'And when the bank is on the losing end? In a deep-pocketed industry like finance, it\xe2\x80\x99s considered cheaper and more efficient to settle than to risk having tales told in a court of law. A Bank of America-Merrill Lynch gender bias case that received class action status 'b'was settled in 2013'b' with as many as 4,800 individual payments totaling $39 million.'b'Many bankers will tell you that a lot of these complaints about harassment and discrimination are false. Indeed, while researching a novel about a woman working on Wall Street, I was told by people in banks\xe2\x80\x99 human resources departments that men are now often afraid of hiring women because of the potential litigation. They fear that even innocently intended comments can result in expensive complaints; that if a woman isn\xe2\x80\x99t working out, and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get promoted, the male employer has a legal problem on his hands. More than once I was told that it\xe2\x80\x99s just easier to fire a guy or \xe2\x80\x94 my favorite line \xe2\x80\x94 that \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s just less drama with men.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Jonathan Sack, a lawyer adept at representing both sides of these disputes, told me, \xe2\x80\x9cMen are being told they need to raise the ranks of women and minorities in their departments, but should someone not work out, especially at the more senior levels, employers worry they\xe2\x80\x99ll have a legal issue to contend with.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Sack\xe2\x80\x99s firm handled 80 such cases last year alone. I asked what he estimates the number of disputes against investment banks to be last year. \xe2\x80\x9cEasily 5,000,\xe2\x80\x9d he responded. Something is very broken.'b'Fake complaints likely do pollute and confuse the real ones. But this is one reason even the banks should embrace a change. If these complaints were aired in public, instead of behind closed doors, maybe banks would be less quick to settle, discouraging the opportunistic from lodging an unsubstantiated complaint. More important, lawsuits would shine a light onto the hidden stories, the family secrets that prevent banks from moving forward.'b'We need to ban mandatory arbitration, and let employees decide if they want to hash their differences out in a conference room or demand their constitutional right to a day in court.'b'Banks won\xe2\x80\x99t like it at first, but an end to this practice \xe2\x80\x94 through legislation or the courts, if necessary \xe2\x80\x94 would be a more effective cure for discrimination than their current habit of writing checks too meager to hurt them and too useless to root out the problem.'b'Women now receive the majority of college and graduate degrees, and we make the vast bulk of consumer decisions and purchases. 'b'Forty percent of American households'b' with children under 18 have a woman as primary or sole breadwinner. For future generations of women to do better, we must change the culture of institutions like Wall Street.'b'My candidate took the job, and while she was passionate about her work, she was uncomfortable with the raucous trading floor environment, and lasted only five years. While none of us were able to see the details of her sealed complaint, I can easily imagine what it might contain. Many women have shared their stories with me, and they go far beyond exclusion from meetings and golf courses. There was the young banker who was groped publicly to settle a bet about whether her breasts were real, and the senior deal makers who found out their pay was a fraction of their male counterparts\xe2\x80\x99.'b'Whatever her experience, her case went to arbitration. She signed a nondisclosure agreement and took a settlement check. Another case closed. Another brilliant woman\xe2\x80\x99s career on Wall Street ended.'b'Sitka, Alaska \xe2\x80\x94 FROM fall through spring, the fleet of commercial fishing boats here in the panhandle of Alaska stalk winter king salmon. In the mornings prisms of ice sparkle beneath the sodium lights of the docks, where I live on a World War II tugboat with my wife and 8-month-old daughter. This winter I\xe2\x80\x99ve been out a few times fishing on the I Gotta, catching pristine wild salmon, torpedoes of muscle. But the work is slow, five fish a day, and my skipper recently traveled down to Reno, Nev., for knee surgery.'b'Carpeted in rain forest and braided with waterways, southeast Alaska is among the largest wild salmon producers in the world, its tourism and salmon fishing industries grossing about $2 billion a year. But today, the rivers and the salmon that create these jobs \xe2\x80\x94 and this particular way of life, which attracted me from Philadelphia to Sitka almost 20 years ago \xe2\x80\x94 are threatened by Canada\xe2\x80\x99s growing mining industry along the mountainous Alaska-British Columbia border, about a hundred miles east of where I now write.'b'At least 10 underground and open-pit copper and gold 'b'mining projects'b' in British Columbia are up and running, in advanced exploration or in review to be approved. These operations generate billions of tons of toxic mine tailings stored behind massive dams, creating an ecological hazard at the headwaters of Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s major salmon rivers \xe2\x80\x94 the Stikine, Unuk and Taku, which straddle the border with Canada.'b'Despite being subjected to the environmental and health risks of these upstream mining projects, Alaskans have no say in their approval. Which is why fishermen, Alaska native tribes, local municipalities, tourism businesses, our congressional delegation and thousands of individual Alaska residents have been clamoring for the State Department to refer this issue to the International Joint Commission, an American and Canadian advisory body established in 1909 to ensure that neither country pollutes the waters of the other.'b'Last August, on a visit to Alaska, Secretary of State John Kerry addressed the issue: \xe2\x80\x9cDownstream impacts should not be taken lightly by any country anywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d But when Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s lieutenant governor, Byron Mallott, visited Washington to ask that the International Joint Commission examine the problem, he returned saying that State Department officials told him that this was a local issue.'b'Concerns about these mining projects are not new. In November 2011, a group of 36 scientists wrote an 'b'open letter'b' to Christy Clark, the premier of British Columbia, warning of the environmental impact of the province\xe2\x80\x99s mining industry. They predicted that \xe2\x80\x9chabitat for salmon and other wildlife will be destroyed\xe2\x80\x9d and that additional effects would include \xe2\x80\x9caltered flow and temperature patterns, disturbance to wildlife interacting with roads, and reduced water quality associated with sedimentation and acid mine drainage.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Three years later, in August 2014, a tailings dam at the Mount Polley mine in British Columbia failed. A volume of water equivalent to thousands of Olympic-size swimming pools, laden with sediment and heavy metals, washed away Hazeltine Creek and dumped into Quesnel Lake, a key salmon spawning ground of the Fraser River watershed. According to Jacinda Mack, a member of the Secwepemc Nation, located downriver from Mount Polley, the following summer was the first time in thousands of years that native tribes didn\xe2\x80\x99t gather sockeye salmon, because of concerns over metal in fish tissue. The episode is now considered one of the worst mining spills in North American history.'b'An independent 'b'investigation'b' funded by the government of British Columbia uncovered flaws in how the dam at the Mount Polley mine was built, maintained and operated, and recommended against using similar tailings facilities. The government publicly stated that the recommendations would be implemented. However, shortly after the release of the report, Imperial Metals, the owner of the Mount Polley mine, received a provincial permit to operate an open-pit mine called Red Chris, with a facility similar to that of Mount Polley \xe2\x80\x94 except this one was larger, built to contain highly toxic acidic tailings, and made use of an existing freshwater trout lake. So long, trout.'b'Today, the Red Chris mine processes 30,000 tons of ore a day \xe2\x80\x94 the equivalent of three Eiffel towers \xe2\x80\x94 about 150 miles from the Alaska border, and leaches untreated acidic water into the salmon-rich transboundary Stikine watershed.'b'Alongside big events like the Mount Polley disaster is the slow leach of toxins into Alaska waters. The Tulsequah Chief mine, built in the 1950s near the confluence of the Tulsequah River and the transboundary Taku River \xe2\x80\x94 and just over the border \xe2\x80\x94 has been polluting the Tulsequah for decades. Over the past 15 years there have been numerous 'b'remediation and pollution abatement orders'b' from the government of British Columbia, to no good effect.'b'The government again 'b'inspected'b' the Tulsequah Chief mine late last year, and 'b'found'b' numerous violations, including continued acid mine drainage flowing into the Tulsequah. Chieftain Metals, the mine\xe2\x80\x99s owner, has said it cannot stop the pollution unless it starts up production to gain needed revenue. British Columbia granted the company the permits. And so the game continues.'b'Except that now people are starting to pay attention. In late November, perhaps to dispel growing unease among Alaskans, Premier Clark signed a 'b'memorandum'b' of understanding with Alaska that would supposedly increase the state\xe2\x80\x99s role in reviewing mines. It\xe2\x80\x99s a charming document, but ultimately toothless: Language in the memorandum contains no legally binding obligations.'b'If we have learned one thing from depleted salmon runs in places like Norway, Iceland, Scotland, New England and Canada, it\xe2\x80\x99s that the waters and the forests nurturing these salmon cannot be destroyed without consequence. Secretary Kerry and the State Department need to take a stand on the part of Alaskans, Americans and some of the last wild rivers on earth, and request that the International Joint Commission act on this issue.'b'Soon my skipper will be back from Reno with a new knee, and I will fish with him, and perhaps his son. We will go out with our flashers and orange gloves and sharpened hooks and hunt salmon, tricking them onto dry land, as people here have done for thousands of years before us. And should be able to do for thousands more.'b'A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.'b'WHEN we talk about diversity, or the lack thereof, we refer to it as \xe2\x80\x9ca problem.\xe2\x80\x9d This or that industry, organization or group has a gender problem or a race problem or some other kind of diversity-related problem. We identify the problem and discuss it, exhaustively, often contentiously, because the problem is significant, pervasive, and for those of us who are most affected, the problem is personal.'b'Another year, another set of Oscar nominations. For the second year in a row, no 'b'black actors have been nominated'b'. This profound absence is compounded by the 'b'Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences'b'\xe2\x80\x99 robust history of overlooking the work of actors, writers, directors and other film professionals who are people of color.'b'Hollywood has a race problem. Hollywood has always had a race problem. The movie industry continues to ignore audiences of color, to its own detriment, given the box office success of movies that do feature diverse casts. It continues to ignore the simple fact that people of color want to see their lives reflected in the movies they watch. Representation is not a lot to ask.'b'I love movies unabashedly. I always have. The cinematic spectacle grabs hold of me every time. Han Solo frozen in carbonite and Princess Leia choking Jabba the Hutt with the chain binding her to him. The defiance of Private Trip in pursuit of dignity in \xe2\x80\x9cGlory'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' Julia Roberts as Vivian Ward in \xe2\x80\x9cPretty Woman\xe2\x80\x9d triumphantly returning to the Rodeo Drive boutique that snubbed her, laden with shopping bags from other stores \xe2\x80\x94 big mistake, 'b'huge.'b' Monica Wright-McCall, at center court, while her husband and daughter cheer her on in \xe2\x80\x9cLove and Basketball.\xe2\x80\x9d The ensemble of \xe2\x80\x9cFurious 7,\xe2\x80\x9d parachuting, in cars, from a cargo plane.'b'When I am at the movies, I lose myself. There is electricity running through my body. When I saw \xe2\x80\x9cThe Hunger Games\xe2\x80\x9d I wanted to jump up and shout because I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t contain the emotion I was feeling. During \xe2\x80\x9cWhiplash\xe2\x80\x9d I was speechless. Nostalgia and then sorrow overwhelmed me when I watched \xe2\x80\x9cThe Best Man Holiday'b',\xe2\x80\x9d'b' not once but three times. I am awed by what it takes to make a movie, so many people and practices that have to come together. Movies, the best and worst of them, offer me indelible memories and so much pleasure. They offer escape. They are an art form to which I, as a writer, aspire.'b'That aspiration is thwarted, though, because movies don\xe2\x80\x99t often feature people who look like me. I am not interested in writing movies about a sylph looking for love, living in New York in an improbably large apartment with a lot of natural light who never seems to spend much time at an actual job. I am not interested in writing movies about a white man who is on some kind of journey to find himself or avenge a wrong, whether in Brooklyn or the wilds of Montana and South Dakota. That there seems to be no place for people who look like me in movie making doesn\xe2\x80\x99t keep me from writing or working, but I am constantly aware of the iron ceiling above me.'b'As of 2012, 'b'94 percent of academy voters'b' were white and 77 percent of those voters were men. The demographics of who makes movies, writes movies, edits movies, produces movies and stars in movies are equally stark. According to a 2014 report by the University of California, Los Angeles, on diversity in Hollywood, only 10.5 percent of lead actors in movies from 2011 were people of color and only 7.6 percent of movies from that same year were written by people of color.'b'When this year\xe2\x80\x99s Oscar nominations were released, I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t surprised. I was tired. I was, despite my fatigue, disappointed to see Ryan Coogler overlooked as best director and Michael B. Jordan overlooked for best actor for their work in \xe2\x80\x9cCreed.\xe2\x80\x9d I was frustrated that even if these men had been nominated, the Oscar nominations would still have been unbearably white.'b'Yet again, people of color were told, both implicitly and explicitly, that our stories and ways of seeing the world are not as valuable. We were told we should be satisfied with the scraps of recognition received in years past.'b'There is, perhaps, some hope. A little more than a week after the all-white slate of nominees was unveiled, the academy\xe2\x80\x99s governing board 'b'announced Friday'b' that it was going to make changes that might address the problem. It said it was committed to doubling the number of women and academy members of color by 2020. Members will have their voting status reviewed every 10 years, and that status could be revoked if a member hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been active in the industry within that decade. These are not immediate solutions and they may do little to improve matters, but at least the academy is acknowledging the problem. Meanwhile, we still must face Hollywood\xe2\x80\x99s race problem as it currently stands.'b'In the debate that has followed the 2016 Oscar nominations, there is the usual outrage, disgust and, in some parts, indifference or thinly veiled contempt. Robert Redford, from the Sundance festival, said: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not focused on that part. To me, it\xe2\x80\x99s about the work, and whatever reward comes from that, that\xe2\x80\x99s great. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t think about it.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Redford, of course, already has his Oscar and he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think about \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x9d because he has the luxury of not needing to.'b'Charlotte Rampling, who is nominated for a best actress Oscar this year, 'b'suggested'b' that all this talk of Hollywood and diversity is racist against white people. \xe2\x80\x9cBut do we have to take from this that there should be lots of minorities everywhere?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. Let that sit for a minute. Hear what she is saying.'b'Michael Caine also had some insight, asking black actors to be patient because, well, it took him a long time to win his first Oscar. He 'b'also noted: 'b' \xe2\x80\x9cIn the end you can\xe2\x80\x99t vote for an actor because he\xe2\x80\x99s black. You can\xe2\x80\x99t say, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going to vote for him, he\xe2\x80\x99s not very good, but he\xe2\x80\x99s black, I\xe2\x80\x99ll vote for him.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Caine trotted out that old canard that the desire for diversity is the desire for the elevation of mediocrity.'b'Here, we have three veterans of the industry who appear to be positioning their white skin as the norm, as what deserves merit before anyone else receives consideration, as a marker of people whose experiences should be represented.'b'In the aftermath of the nomination announcements, the filmmaker 'b'Spike Lee'b' and the actor Jada Pinkett Smith and her husband, 'b'Will Smith,'b' have all stated that they plan not to attend the awards ceremony next month in protest.'b'The thing about a boycott is that there needs to be something at stake. I am not entirely clear what\xe2\x80\x99s at stake if we skip the Oscars. The root of the problem is not the academy, which selects the Oscar nominees, though certainly we should turn our critical eye to those voters who seem to favor white filmmakers and who tend to reward only a kind of \xe2\x80\x9cdiverse\xe2\x80\x9d movie that centers struggle as the mainstay in the black experience. They are just one part of a much larger, wholly diseased, industry.'b'The root of the problem is that there just isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough filmmaking by people of color. There isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough work in the pipeline. And not only are black actors and filmmakers overlooked by the academy, so are artists of other races and ethnicities. As often as we have conversations about this 'b'problem,'b' the conversation remains desperately narrow. There are a great many of us demanding a rightful place in the filmmaking world while the burden of keeping \xe2\x80\x9cproblem\xe2\x80\x9d conversations alive, and the burden of providing solutions, also falls to us.'b'Actors and filmmakers of color can and should take the stands they choose, but white people in the movie industry need to step up and spend less time complacently reveling in their privilege. White actors and filmmakers need to do more than offer a few thoughtful words in interviews. They need to unequivocally acknowledge the very real diversity problems that continue to go unsolved. They, too, need to stay home from the Oscars. They need to turn down projects that are monochromatic both in front of and behind the camera. They need to take on this problem as their own.'b'If we\xe2\x80\x99re going to boycott the Oscars, we also need to boycott the movie studios determined to ignore the box office success of movies featuring people of color. We need to boycott the people who are so reluctant to produce movies made by people of color. We need to boycott this system that refuses to acknowledge life beyond the white experience as rule and not exception. As a movie lover, I take no pleasure in the prospect of staking out such a hard line so that people of color might be heard and ultimately represented on the silver screen, but Hollywood has left us with little choice.'b'WHO among us hasn\xe2\x80\x99t wanted to let go of anxiety or forget about fear? Phobias, panic attacks and disorders like post-traumatic stress are extremely common: 29 percent of American adults will suffer from anxiety at some point in their lives.'b'Sitting at the heart of much anxiety and fear is emotional memory \xe2\x80\x94 all the associations that you have between various stimuli and experiences and your emotional response to them. Whether it\xe2\x80\x99s the fear of being embarrassed while talking to strangers (typical of social phobia) or the dread of being attacked while walking down a dark street after you\xe2\x80\x99ve been assaulted (a symptom of PTSD), you have learned that a previously harmless situation predicts something dangerous.'b'It has been an article of faith in neuroscience and psychiatry that, once formed, emotional memories are permanent. Afraid of heights or spiders? The best we could do was to get you to tolerate them, but we could never really rid you of your initial fear. Or so the thinking has gone.'b'The current standard of treatment for such phobias revolves around exposure therapy. This involves repeatedly presenting the feared object or frightening memory in a safe setting, so that the patient acquires a new safe memory that resides in his brain alongside the bad memory. As long as the new memory has the upper hand, his fear is suppressed. But if he is re-traumatized or re-exposed with sufficient intensity to the original experience, his old fear will awaken with a vengeance.'b'This is one of the limitations of exposure therapy, along with the fact that it generally works in only about half of the PTSD patients who try it. Many also find it upsetting or intolerable to relive memories of assaults and other traumatizing experiences.'b'We urgently need more effective treatments for anxiety disorders. What if we could do better than creating a new safe memory \xe2\x80\x94 and actually get rid of emotions attached to the old bad one?'b'New research suggests that it may be possible not just to change certain types of emotional memories, but even to erase them. We\xe2\x80\x99ve learned that memories are uniquely vulnerable to alteration at two points: when we first lay them down, and later, when we retrieve them.'b'Merel Kindt, a professor of psychology at the University of Amsterdam, and her colleagues have seemingly erased the emotional fear response in healthy people with arachnophobia. For 'b'a study published last month in the journal Biological Psychiatry'b', she compared three groups made up of 45 subjects in total. One group was exposed to a tarantula in a glass jar for two minutes, and then given a beta-blocker called propranolol that is commonly prescribed to patients for performance anxiety; one was exposed to the tarantula and given a placebo; and one was just given propranolol without being shown the spider, to rule out the possibility that propranolol by itself could decrease spider fear.'b'Dr. Kindt assessed the subjects\xe2\x80\x99 anxiety when they were shown the spider the first time, then again three months later, and finally after a year. What she found was remarkable. Those who got the propranolol alone and those who got the placebo had no improvement in their anxiety. But the arachnophobes who were exposed to the spider and given the drug were able to touch the tarantula within days and, by three months, many felt comfortable holding the spider with their bare hands. Their fear did not return even at the end of one year.'b'How does this work? Well, propranolol blocks the effects of norepinephrine in the brain. This chemical, which is similar to adrenaline, enhances learning, so blocking it disrupts the way a memory is put back in storage after it is retrieved \xe2\x80\x94 a process called reconsolidation.'b'Arachnophobes have an emotional memory that involves an association between spiders and a dreaded outcome, like a spider bite. This \xe2\x80\x9cfear memory\xe2\x80\x9d is the source of their phobia \xe2\x80\x94 even if (as is often the case) it never actually happened. The basic idea is that when Dr. Kindt briefly exposed the subjects to the spider, she reactivated their fear, which made the fear memory susceptible to the influence of propranolol.'b'Reconsolidation is a bit like pulling up a file on your computer, rewriting the same material in a bigger, bolder font and saving it again. Disrupting reconsolidation with propranolol or another drug is akin to retrieving this document, erasing some or all of the text and then writing something new in its place.'b'Dr. Kindt is not the first to demonstrate that disrupting reconsolidation can weaken or erase emotional memories. Several studies of rats done in 2000 showed that a drug called anisomycin, which blocks the synthesis of proteins in the brain, could reduce fear associations. In one, researchers taught rats to fear a sound by pairing it with a shock. After the animals were fear-conditioned, they were presented with the sound and then immediately given the drug. When the animals were exposed to the sound again, they no longer appeared afraid; they had forgotten their original fear.'b'Curiously, there is a very narrow time window after retrieving a fear memory when you can disrupt that memory \xe2\x80\x94 hours, in the animal studies \xe2\x80\x94 before it closes and the drug has no effect.'b'These studies suggest that someday, a single dose of a drug, combined with exposure to your fear at the right moment, could free you of that fear forever. But there\xe2\x80\x99s a flip side to this story about how to undo emotional learning: how to strengthen it. We can do that with drugs as well, and may have been doing it for some time.'b'ANXIETY enhances emotional memory. We all know that \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s why you can easily forget where you put your wallet, but will never forget being attacked. This is the case because anxiety leads to the release of norepinephrine in the brain, which, again, strengthens emotional learning. It is also why we should think twice about casually prescribing stimulants like Ritalin and Adderall for young people who really don\xe2\x80\x99t need them. Stimulants also cause the release of norepinephrine and may enhance fear learning. So it is possible that taking stimulants could increase one\xe2\x80\x99s risk of developing PTSD when exposed to trauma.'b'Indeed, a study that will be published next month found that the escalating use of stimulants by the military in active duty soldiers, including those serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, was strongly correlated with an increase in the rates of PTSD, even when controlling for other factors, like the rate of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. The study examined the use of prescription stimulants, like Ritalin and Adderall, and the rates of PTSD in nearly 26,000 military service members between 2001 and 2008, and found that the incidence of PTSD increased along with the prescriptions.'b'By blocking the effect of norepinephrine and disrupting memory reconsolidation, we could perhaps reverse this process. The clear implication of these studies is that emotional memory is not permanent after all.'b'Before you rush off into a panic about the dystopian possibility of mind control or memory deletion, it\xe2\x80\x99s important to recognize that the procedure in Dr. Kindt\xe2\x80\x99s study only weakened the subjects\xe2\x80\x99 fear memory and avoidant behavior. Although the procedure is able to alter or perhaps delete the fear memory (something exposure therapy cannot do), it does nothing to the factual, or biographical, memory, which remains intact.'b'This is not \xe2\x80\x9cEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,\xe2\x80\x9d the movie in which a dysfunctional couple decides to erase their memories of each other and start their lives all over again. To the contrary, you still remember your biography, but your fear would be stripped of its force. The subjects knew perfectly well after the study that they previously feared spiders and that they now \xe2\x80\x94 strangely \xe2\x80\x94 felt little to no anxiety around them.'b'If this new approach is effective in other anxiety disorders, like PTSD, you would expect someone who was assaulted in his home to remember the attack perfectly well, but no longer feel afraid of being at home. What\xe2\x80\x99s so bad about that?'b'It would certainly be superior to exposure therapy, which is far from a permanent fix. Once, while on vacation in Costa Rica, I was standing next to a young man on a zip line platform in a rain forest when he began to hyperventilate. I learned that he had a fear of heights and had had exposure treatment a year before, which he felt had fixed the problem. But now, his old fear was triggered and he was having a full-blown panic attack. I suppose he was lucky to be stuck with a psychiatrist in the jungle; I talked him down the ladder to the ground.'b'How effective this new memory-disrupting approach will be in treating more serious anxiety disorders like PTSD or panic is unclear. A few preliminary studies using propranolol in PTSD showed mixed results. Some found no effect, but a 2015 review of PTSD treatment studies published in Biological Psychology found that propranolol administered with six brief trauma reactivation sessions significantly improved PTSD symptoms compared with a placebo.'b'Study results may well change with the development of better methods for administering propranolol or new drugs that are more effective in disrupting memory reconsolidation. Marieke S. Tollenaar, a psychologist at Leiden University in the Netherlands who has studied the effects of propranolol on memory, told me that the \xe2\x80\x9cfinal test\xe2\x80\x9d would be to \xe2\x80\x9cexamine in real life whether propranolol in addition to standard exposure treatment procedures would be beneficial. Little has been done there yet; most work is still done experimentally in the lab.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some may view any attempt to tamper with human memory as disturbing because it seems at odds with what we ought to do as a culture with the darker aspects of our history: Never alter the facts, even if we have divergent interpretations of them. And it is critical not to destroy places where crimes of humanity and collective trauma took place, like the concentration camps, so we never forget what we have done and remain capable of doing. Fair enough. But I see no reason not to help frightened individuals soften their painful emotional memories.'b'Some may also argue that it\xe2\x80\x99s a mistake to tinker with our fear responses because they\xe2\x80\x99re natural \xe2\x80\x94 they evolved this way for a reason. Like most other animals, we come hard-wired with a flight or fight response along with its associated anxiety and fear. Without this warning system to protect us from predators and other dangers, we\xe2\x80\x99d have been dinner long ago on the savanna.'b'But what was once adaptive millions of years ago isn\xe2\x80\x99t always so helpful today. People who suffer panic attacks hyperventilate and have an intense desire to flee in situations where there is rarely actual danger. It turns out that panic disorder is associated with an increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide in the brain. If you lived in a cave with a clan of hominid fire-dwellers, you\xe2\x80\x99d have been one of the first to get out when the oxygen supply was dwindling.'b'Curiously, that might help explain why some people have panic attacks that wake them at night. These patients don\xe2\x80\x99t panic during so-called REM sleep, when dreams occur, but during non-REM sleep, when they are deeply relaxed, when breathing slows, and the levels of carbon dioxide rise, generating a false suffocation alarm.'b'Evolutionary design has left us a few million years out of date; we are hard-wired for a Paleolithic world, but have to live in a modern one. The irrational fear of anxiety disorders was once probably useful and lifesaving. No longer.'b'But maybe that modern world can help. I see nothing wrong with doing all we can to rid ourselves of pathological anxiety, including using drugs to alter our painful emotional memories.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 Until recently, Donald J. Trump was best known in Britain for \xe2\x80\x9cThe Apprentice\xe2\x80\x9d television series, the Miss Universe contest and a controversial 'b'golf course'b' development in Scotland. And most Britons would probably have viewed his decision to enter the presidential race with no more than mild envy: Why can\xe2\x80\x99t British elections be as much fun as American ones?'b'Thanks, however, to his incendiary comments about immigrants and Muslims, Mr. Trump has moved from being a buffoonish figure on the margins of British consciousness to the center of political debate. After Mr. Trump said that he, if president, would stop Muslims entering the United States, more than half a million people signed a 'b'parliamentary petition'b', thus requiring a debate in Parliament on whether to bar 'b'him'b' entry to Britain. (The debate, which was held this past week in a committee, generated plenty of indignation but had no issue because the power to refuse Mr. Trump admittance is held not by Parliament but by the home secretary.)'b'Mr. Trump also drew condemnation from leading British politicians, newspapers, the Metropolitan Police and the mayor of London. Even the leader of the UK Independence Party, which campaigns on a strong anti-immigration platform, said Mr. Trump had \xe2\x80\x9cgone too far.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When Mr. Trump speaks of barring Muslims from entering the United States, I hear an echo of a British politician from another age, one who is largely forgotten here but whose views on race and immigration were as polarizing in their time as Mr. Trump\xe2\x80\x99s are now. Enoch Powell was a politician whose career spanned most of the postwar period, first as a Conservative and later as an Ulster Unionist. He had grave reservations about mass immigration and frequently spoke in apocalyptic language about its consequences.'b'Mr. Powell was hardly an obvious demagogue. The Labour politician Denis Healey once compared him to the Athenian statesman Demosthenes. He was a classical scholar and gifted linguist, and his speeches were renowned for their erudition. Examples from Roman history are not part of Mr. Trump\xe2\x80\x99s rhetorical repertoire.'b'In 1960, Mr. Powell was appointed minister of health in the Conservative government. In this post, he encouraged many immigrants from the Commonwealth to come to work in the understaffed National Health Service \xe2\x80\x94 which adds a layer of irony to the fact that his most enduring fame, or infamy, is for an epoch-defining speech he gave 'b'against'b' immigration.'b'By 1968, he had become the opposition\xe2\x80\x99s chief spokesman on defense \xe2\x80\x94 if largely by virtue of the fact that, as a talented maverick, he was regarded by the Conservatives\xe2\x80\x99 new leader, Edward Heath, as too dangerous to leave out. Speaking in Birmingham, England\xe2\x80\x99s second largest city and one already changed by extensive immigration, 'b'Mr. Powell argued'b' that \xe2\x80\x9cwe must be mad, literally mad, as a nation to be permitting the annual inflow of some 50,000 dependents.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This policy, he warned, \xe2\x80\x9cis like watching a nation busily engaged in heaping up its own funeral pyre.\xe2\x80\x9d In the most often quoted line \xe2\x80\x94 an allusion to the poet Virgil \xe2\x80\x94 Mr. Powell said, \xe2\x80\x9cas I look ahead, I am filled with foreboding; like the Roman, I seem to see \xe2\x80\x98the River Tiber foaming with much blood.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Times of London called it \xe2\x80\x9can evil speech,\xe2\x80\x9d and the first direct appeal to \xe2\x80\x9cracial hatred\xe2\x80\x9d made by a senior British politician. Mr. Powell was summarily dismissed from his post by Mr. Heath.'b'Yet his lurid warning about the dangers of mass immigration resonated with many Britons. He received tens of thousands of letters of support for what became known as the \xe2\x80\x9crivers of blood\xe2\x80\x9d speech. Three days later, as a Labour government bill against racial discrimination was debated in Parliament, 1,000 dock workers marched from London\xe2\x80\x99s East End to protest the \xe2\x80\x9cvictimization\xe2\x80\x9d of Mr. Powell.'b'There are parallels between the way Mr. Powell gave voice to white working-class anxiety and Mr. Trump\xe2\x80\x99s primary campaigning. And like Mr. Trump, Mr. Powell discovered a ready audience: A Gallup poll a few weeks later found that 74 percent of those surveyed agreed with what Mr. Powell had said. For immigrants like my father, who arrived in Britain from Pakistan in the early 1960s, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Powell\xe2\x80\x99s words that were frightening so much as that so many seemed to agree with them.'b'My father settled in Luton, an industrial town about 30 miles north of London that had a significant immigrant population. He worked on the assembly line at the Vauxhall car factory, the largest employer in the area. By the time my mother and siblings joined my father, in 1974, Mr. Powell was already a marginal figure in national politics. But his race-based views had been taken up by far-right groups like the National Front.'b'The National Front\xe2\x80\x99s thuggish supporters were a visible, violent presence on the streets during my childhood. Mr. Powell\xe2\x80\x99s speech also lent its anti-immigrant message a veneer of mainstream acceptability. The party\xe2\x80\x99s program was crude \xe2\x80\x94 a ban on nonwhite immigration and repatriation for nonwhites \xe2\x80\x94 but, for a time, worryingly effective: In the 1979 general election, the National Front had more than 300 parliamentary candidates and won nearly 200,000 votes.'b'Growing up in the shadow of the \xe2\x80\x9cN.F.\xe2\x80\x9d and knowing that there were hundreds of thousands of Britons who wished to deport people like me induced both a profound anxiety and a deep conviction that I would never be fully accepted as British.'b'In recent years, the target of nativist anxiety about otherness in Britain has shifted from black to Muslim. From my background in Luton, I always looked to the United States as a place where almost everyone was \xe2\x80\x9cother,\xe2\x80\x9d from somewhere else; I imagined it as a nation that offered a welcome to all, regardless of color or creed.'b'That faith has been sorely tested by Mr. Trump. Like Mr. Powell, he demonstrates the appeal of a charismatic leader who presents himself as a principled truth-teller, the only man brave enough to break with the establishment consensus on immigration. As Mr. Powell did, Mr. Trump connects with voters \xe2\x80\x94 especially among the economically insecure white working class \xe2\x80\x94 who feel they\xe2\x80\x99re being lied to by the political elite.'b'The difference between them is that the \xe2\x80\x9crivers of blood\xe2\x80\x9d speech effectively ended Mr. Powell\xe2\x80\x99s political career (he never again held high office, though he remained a member of Parliament until 1987), whereas Mr. Trump has been rewarded so far for his harsh words. Mr. Trump has drawn some criticism from other Republicans, but he is certainly not the pariah that Mr. Powell became.'b'Mr. Trump, like Mr. Powell before him, speaks for those convulsed by fear. In his 1968 speech, Mr. Powell quoted a constituent who dreaded a future when \xe2\x80\x9cthe black man will have the whip hand over the white man.\xe2\x80\x9d That paranoia \xe2\x80\x94 an ugly delusion that inverts the actual history of slavery \xe2\x80\x94 was unfounded. Yet what is striking today is that though Mr. Powell was cast into the wilderness for his views, arguably his warning about the challenges to social cohesion from immigration 'b'was'b' prescient.'b'Thankfully, the rivers of blood he foresaw never flowed. But nearly five decades later, Britain\xe2\x80\x99s long experience of race riots and domestic terrorist attacks suggests that the countervailing doctrine of multiculturalism has not made for a land of milk and honey either.'b'The growth of a radical Islamic identity among some young Muslims has led to legitimate fears about the possible failure of British society to fully integrate its immigrants. Here, the populist UK Independence Party has inherited the mantle of Powellism. And in the United States, particularly in the wake of December\xe2\x80\x99s San Bernardino shootings, the target of fear and loathing has also been Muslims.'b'The experience of 'b'Rose Hamid'b', who was ejected from a Trump rally while silently protesting by wearing a T-shirt that read \xe2\x80\x9cSalam I come in peace,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d demonstrated the violence of such emotions. Mr. Trump is exquisitely attuned to popular anxieties and highly talented at exploiting them.'b'Mr. Trump has not even won his party\xe2\x80\x99s nomination, yet his agenda already seems to have influence. There have been several reports of British Muslims being denied the right to fly to the United States, seemingly only because of their religion. As someone who has long cherished the idea of America, I am distressed to see how quickly fear can travel and mutate from hot words to dangerous deeds.'b'The success of Mr. Trump\xe2\x80\x99s campaign is very disturbing, but the retaliatory effort to bar him from Britain is a move that seems as petty \xe2\x80\x94 and constitutionally suspect \xe2\x80\x94 as anything advocated by the mogul himself. Even if nearly 600,000 people signed the parliamentary petition to keep Mr. Trump out, a recent survey here also found that 29 percent of respondents 'b'would favor a similar ban'b' on Muslims entering Britain. So rather than a futile petition, it would be wiser to play the ball rather than the man: to dispute the actual issues rather than dismiss him as primitive and dumb.'b'In Britain, Powellism was eventually defeated as a political movement in part because politicians across the divide united against his views, in part because his dire predictions proved exaggerated and, not least, because people of good will mobilized to stop groups like the National Front from intimidating immigrant neighborhoods and winning elections. But Mr. Powell\xe2\x80\x99s legacy was long and bitter \xe2\x80\x94 a lesson for both Britain and America that the price of not confronting the fears that fuel this antipathy could be severe: Whether or not Donald Trump wins his immediate political battle, he may, like Enoch Powell, win the war of ideas.'b'Dhaka, Bangladesh \xe2\x80\x94 EVERY winter, I return here to my hometown, and every year, I feel a little shabbier. This time, when I was meeting a few old school friends at a neighborhood cafe, I finally understood why: the blow-dry. Everyone else had one. Everyone else had gone to the beauty parlor, and I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'When I was growing up, there were just three beauty salons in the capital: Lily\xe2\x80\x99s, Lisa\xe2\x80\x99s and Neelo\xe2\x80\x99s. Lily\xe2\x80\x99s, run by a Chinese family, was built above a garage. I got my first perm there, a chemical baptism that left me smelling like a tire factory for months.'b'Then there was Lisa, a woman of enormous girth who gave one of my aunts a particular side parting that remained in place throughout most of the 1980s and \xe2\x80\x9990s. I never went to Neelo\xe2\x80\x99s because, being on the upscale side of town, it was too intimidating. But one of my friends told me that her mother never washed her hair in the winter; she just went to Neelo\xe2\x80\x99s every other day between November and March.'b'Beauty parlors have now proliferated throughout the city. They have names like Dazzle and Hairobics. You can get anything from a haircut to a full bridal package, which includes waxing, makeup and a hairdo.'b'I see the appeal of the parlor \xe2\x80\x94 a reasonably affordable way to transform oneself into someone who appears to know what they\xe2\x80\x99re doing with a hairbrush and a bottle of nail polish \xe2\x80\x94 though, to me, it has always seemed like a chamber of medieval torture. Yet the anthropologist in me is intrigued in spite of my discomfort.'b'There is the issue of class, first and foremost. The women who work in the salons are from minority communities from the west and south of the capital. They themselves wear no makeup, their hair is never blow-dried, and they shuffle around the parlor looking defeated. The proprietors are paternalistic: In return for putting up these women in small, shared rooms above the premises, the owners expect unquestioning loyalty and long hours.'b'As for the clientele, the sleek, airbrushed-look hair that is now ubiquitous sets a certain class of women apart. You can spot the difference between a wealthy woman and a merely middle-class one not just by the neighborhood she lives in and the clothes she wears, but also by the permanent sheen and movement of her hair.'b'The beauty parlor is also where women are forced to face the color prejudice that is widespread in Bangladesh. Eavesdrop on a conversation and you\xe2\x80\x99re very likely to hear someone complaining about the color of her skin. She might then be offered a range of skin-lightening treatments. Once, a parlor girl nodded toward the customer next to me who was being embalmed by some kind of noxious white cream, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cHer shoulders are too dark.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Finally, there is what I call \xe2\x80\x9cextreme grooming\xe2\x80\x9d: a whole stack of procedures that take practically all day, including a mask of makeup to finish with, just for a night out. Once reserved for brides, these packages are now being purchased by anyone who wants to look perfect for the evening.'b'The result is that the fully polished look has become the norm, raising the standard for everyone else and normalizing what should really be a once-in-a-lifetime rite of passage.'b'The relentless rise of personal grooming is not unique to Dhaka. As the rise of blow-dry bars in major cities worldwide and the increasing popularity of on-demand beauty apps suggest, the pressure to look immaculately chic and coifed has dramatically increased in the age of Instagram. The idea that beauty should be accessible to all is evolving to mean that more and more women aspire to ever higher standards.'b'There may be some who will breezily declare the rise of the blow-dry an innocent, possibly even empowering, trend. But it rubs me the wrong way. The women of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s generation were revolutionaries; they called each other comrade and marched on the streets demanding independence for Bangladesh. And that feminist movement is one of the major reasons that today Bangladesh is still, against all the odds, posting impressive statistics on everything from girls\xe2\x80\x99 enrollment in primary school to maternal health.'b'So I hold on to my feeling that there is no such thing as an innocent blow-dry. Yet there are subtle complexities to this social trend. I have a friend who is, by her own admission, a compulsive parlorgoer. If she\xe2\x80\x99s been abroad, the first thing she does when she gets home is visit the parlor. She brings gifts for the salon girls, and they shower her with attention.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m addicted to the keratin blow-dry,\xe2\x80\x9d she tells me. But it\xe2\x80\x99s more than that: She likes being greeted by women who have watched her grow from an awkward teenager with kinky hair into an adult; she likes that they know exactly how her hair should be done; and she likes the expert, almost loving way they tend to her body. It\xe2\x80\x99s not quite a friendship, but there\xe2\x80\x99s an intimacy beyond the regular client-server relationship.'b'After a week in Dhaka, I succumb and pay a visit to my local parlor, Bliss. As I enter, I\xe2\x80\x99m hit by the smell of nail polish remover. I hover around the entrance for a while, but no one notices me. I spot an older woman who looks like she\xe2\x80\x99s in charge, and ask for a leg wax.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m shown into a narrow booth and given a petticoat and instructed to fasten it under my arms. She grabs my calf and smears the goo from knee to ankle. It\xe2\x80\x99s very hot. She presses the rag to the mix and pulls it off in one sharp movement. I wince.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt only hurts because your hairs are so long,\xe2\x80\x9d she complains. The shame.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYour skin is scaly,\xe2\x80\x9d she goes on, mercilessly. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you moisturize?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When she\xe2\x80\x99s done with my calves she\xe2\x80\x99ll tell me I have fat knees. I pick up other snatches of conversation and note the easy way the parlor girls and their clients tease one another, and I\xe2\x80\x99m secretly happy. Although this young woman fills me with self-loathing, I find I\xe2\x80\x99m glad she feels free to insult me.'b'The parlor laughter is genuine, at least in the moment, but it\xe2\x80\x99s all carefully orchestrated. There\xe2\x80\x99s only so far she will go, and there are the scary older aunties who will tolerate no comedy at all. The beauty parlor is a place where the rules are reinscribed, yet also upended. Peppered through the class-based rituals are moments when two people from disparate spheres of life might chafe against each other, and the person with less power may triumph, if just momentarily.'b'A woman in a neighboring booth is getting a bikini wax. I hear her giving the parlor girl strict instructions. There\xe2\x80\x99s a pause, and then sound of the wax being ripped off. The woman cries out in pain.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want me to do, rub it better?\xe2\x80\x9d the parlor girl asks. They both explode in laughter.'b'ISTANBUL \xe2\x80\x94 Entire towns and districts are under siege. Tanks ram through narrow alleys closed off by barricades and trenches. Residents are trapped indoors for weeks because of curfews. Those who venture outside risk sniper fire. Their bodies lie on the streets for days before they can be collected. Bullets fly in through windows and buildings collapse under shelling, killing those seeking shelter at home.'b'This is not Syria. This is 'b'Turkey'b', the European Union candidate country once hailed as a champion of the Arab Spring. The conflict that restarted here after the breakdown of talks between the Turkish state and the Kurdistan Workers\xe2\x80\x99 Party, or P.K.K., last summer has turned into a devastating war in Kurdish towns and cities.'b'One of the most affected places is the city of Diyarbakir\xe2\x80\x99s historic Sur district, where I was mayor from 2004 to 2014. Sur has been under 24-hour curfew since the beginning of December. Many of its neighborhoods lie in ruins. Its historic buildings are damaged, once busy shops are shut, hospitals lack staff, and schools are closed. Tens of thousands of people have fled.'b'Sur\xe2\x80\x99s walls surround an ancient city that has been inhabited for millenniums. Its narrow streets, spacious courtyards and elegant stone structures are reminders of a rich multicultural legacy \xe2\x80\x94 a legacy that has survived, albeit in an impoverished state, a century of conflict. Small but increasingly visible communities of Armenians, Assyrians, Chaldeans, Yazidis and other minorities live alongside adherents of diverse interpretations of Islam in what is now a predominantly Sunni Kurdish town.'b'Over the past decade, our municipality worked hard to revive and preserve this heritage. We oversaw the restoration of many historic buildings, including mosques and churches. The reopening of the Surp Giragos Armenian Church, which is now the largest Armenian church in the Middle East, after nearly a century in ruins has 'b'encouraged'b' \xe2\x80\x9chidden\xe2\x80\x9d survivors in Turkey of the 1915 genocide to rediscover and embrace their heritage. Efforts to restore the old synagogue in memory of Sur\xe2\x80\x99s once vibrant Jewish community were underway before the eruption of violence last summer.'b'In 2012, Sur\xe2\x80\x99s community leaders established an interfaith dialogue group bringing together representatives of the region\xe2\x80\x99s different religions, cultures and civil society groups. Known as the Council of Forty, it has played a crucial role in keeping sectarian violence from reaching our city. Thanks to its efforts, Sur came to symbolize the vision of peaceful coexistence in a region plagued by intolerance.'b'It causes me immense grief to see that pluralism fall apart along with Sur\xe2\x80\x99s buildings. Sectarianism is destroying Syria before our very eyes. To avoid the same fate in Turkey, the Council of Forty has called on the government to lift the curfews, and asked all sides to end hostilities and return to peace talks within the framework of parliamentary democracy.'b'President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said recently that military operations in the besieged Kurdish towns would continue until they were \xe2\x80\x9ccleansed\xe2\x80\x9d of \xe2\x80\x9dterrorists.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou will be annihilated in those houses, those buildings, those ditches which you have dug,\xe2\x80\x9d he threatened. But what peace can be built through destruction? Decades of military policies against the Kurds have shown only that violence begets more violence.'b'Many residents of these towns are poor families who were forced to flee the countryside when the conflict between the Kurds and the Turkish state was at its peak in the 1990s. Those who are digging trenches and declaring \xe2\x80\x9cself-rule\xe2\x80\x9d in Sur and other cities and towns of southeastern Turkey today are mostly Kurdish youths in their teens and 20s who were born into that earlier era of violence, poverty and displacement, and grew up in radicalized ghettos.'b'Now a new generation will grow up with the trauma of killing, destruction and forced migration. Where will they go? What will become of them? And how will an angrier generation of Kurds and Turks find common ground? The truth is that my generation may be the last to reach a peaceful settlement through dialogue.'b'Dialogue is possible when those in power want it. Last spring, the two sides were on the verge of a breakthrough after two and a half years of negotiations. The Kurds, when given a real and fair choice, have repeatedly picked politics over violence and opted for coexistence in a democratic Turkey, where their rights and identities are recognized, over separation. But as the destruction goes on, their faith in a political solution withers.'b'In 2007, Sur became the first municipality in Turkey to offer services in local languages, including Kurdish, Armenian and Assyrian, besides the official Turkish \xe2\x80\x94 a move that infuriated the authorities in Ankara, the capital, and led to my removal as mayor. In 2009, months after being re-elected with two-thirds of the vote, I was arrested on charges of separatism. (I was released five months later on health grounds and kept my role as mayor throughout my arrest.)'b'As I was rounded up along with hundreds of Kurdish activists and elected politicians, my teenage son left our house to join the P.K.K. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are wasting time with your politics and dialogue,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. I dedicated my life to trying to prove him wrong and bring him home in peace. I have been discouraged before, but never lost hope. Today, I struggle to keep that hope alive.'b'We all remember the \xe2\x80\x9cbad kids\xe2\x80\x9d from high school: the pregnant teen, the kid who was always getting into fights, the truant student, or the one who just couldn\xe2\x80\x99t keep up with the rest of us.'b'We take kids who can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to stay on track and write them off, dismissing them with summary labels. It\xe2\x80\x99s simpler that way \xe2\x80\x94 if we know what they are, we don\xe2\x80\x99t really have to think about why. So more often than not, the roots of a \xe2\x80\x9cbad kid\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d difficulties are left unexplored, as they would most likely force us to look at histories of abuse, neglect, abandonment, addiction or possibly even that huge unspoken problem that plagues our public education system: intractable, generational poverty.'b'This Op-Doc video profiles one of those kids, a talented art student named Summer Jordan, who attends Black Rock High School in the Mojave Desert town of Yucca Valley, Calif. An alternative public school for at-risk students, Black Rock is cautiously regarded, even in its own community, as the school where the \xe2\x80\x9cbad kids\xe2\x80\x9d go, despite consistently high graduation rates. But at Black Rock High, the staff does not judge at-risk students as failures; rather, they see them as fragile youths who are more than likely dealing with problems outside of school that would daunt most adults. And as you\xe2\x80\x99ll see in this Op-Doc, the students and their problems are much more complicated than they may initially seem.'b'Luckily for kids like Summer, the school\xe2\x80\x99s staff is not afraid of asking what impediments might be keeping its students from doing their best in school. The approach seems obvious, but it\xe2\x80\x99s quite revolutionary: It is the simple understanding that for a student who\xe2\x80\x99s hungry, or not sure where he is going to sleep that night, or afraid of someone she lives with, learning is impossible, no matter how innovative the curriculum or teaching methods.'b'A school may not be able to fix a student\xe2\x80\x99s home life, but it can offer students acknowledgment, advice, life skills, and most important, empathy. Meanwhile, in manufacturing, pay has fallen by 0.8 percent, and in the auto sector, by 12.7 percent.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLast point,\xe2\x80\x9d I said to the 100 or so guests: Average manufacturing compensation costs (includes wages and benefits) in the United States in 2012 were $35.67 per hour; in Mexico, they were $6.36 per hour. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd American auto executives will tell you that the productivity they get in Mexico is at least as good as what they get in the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'My central argument was not that we should close our borders or retreat from the world; it was that we need to be sensitive to the losers and try to help. The point \xe2\x80\x94 well illustrated in Steve\xe2\x80\x99s book \xe2\x80\x94 is that globalization is not only an economic matter but also a moral one.'b'Presently, the institute\xe2\x80\x99s blunt director, Adam Posen, used his final moments to shut me down, declaring that the \xe2\x80\x9cfetishization\xe2\x80\x9d of any industry was \xe2\x80\x9cimmoral.\xe2\x80\x9d The problem of manufacturing is technology, he declared flatly.'b'Blaming technology is a common refrain from economists who hate the thought that globalization is not the world\xe2\x80\x99s unambiguous salvation.'b'Sorry, Adam, I thought silently, having been afforded no time to respond. If technology were the source of manufacturing workers\xe2\x80\x99 woes, productivity would be rising sharply, which it surely isn\xe2\x80\x99t (notwithstanding claims by some economists that official statistics have been understating efficiency gains).'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t blame the robots for lost manufacturing jobs,\xe2\x80\x9d read the headline in a blog post last spring by two scholars at the venerable Brookings Institution.'b'I have never forgotten a powerful article I read in Foreign Affairs in 2007 that called for huge tax redistribution, both as a moral matter and as a mechanism for ensuring political support for free trade. (The authors were hardly left-wing shills \xe2\x80\x94 one had served in the administration of President George W. Bush.)'b'That still sounds like the right idea to me.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not only morally wrong to fail to help those on the losing end of globalization, but it will also end badly politically, as the ascendant candidacy of Donald J. Trump illustrates.'b'LAST March, the 'b'N.C.A.A.'b'\xe2\x80\x99s chief medical officer, Brian Hainline, announced that he was going to recommend that all male college basketball players undergo an electrocardiogram, which measures the electrical activity in the heart, presumably as a requirement for being cleared to play competitively. He said his action was in response to research suggesting that the risk of sudden cardiac death in Division I basketball players was about one in 5,200 per year, much higher than previously thought.'b'However, Dr. Hainline backed off his proposal after an outcry by about 100 college team physicians who questioned the use of electrocardiograms, or EKGs, as a screening tool for these athletes. EKGs can appear abnormal even in the absence of heart disease. These false positives, some physicians argued, would create a lot of unnecessary secondary testing, anxiety and sidelining of athletes, not to mention potential legal liability.'b'Those are legitimate concerns, but Dr. Hainline\xe2\x80\x99s original proposal was the right one: We should begin targeted screening of some groups of college athletes \xe2\x80\x94 starting with those in sports that recent research indicates pose a high cardiovascular risk, such as basketball and soccer.'b'The N.C.A.A. is currently developing guidelines for managing sudden cardiac arrest in its athletes. Expected to be released later this year, the guidelines are likely to endorse a standardized questionnaire on medical and family history, more training in CPR and increased access to automatic 'b'defibrillators'b'. However, they will almost surely not include EKG screening.'b'Several important organizations, including the European Society of Cardiology, the International Olympic Committee and FIFA, soccer\xe2\x80\x99s governing body, recommend EKG testing for competitive athletes. But in the United States, EKG screening is reserved only for professional athletes. (Italy and Israel mandate EKGs for collegians also.) It is a disparity that needs to be examined closely. Nothing suggests that college athletes are at any lower risk of sudden cardiac death than professionals.'b'Dr. Hainline\xe2\x80\x99s proposal came 25 years after perhaps the most famous incident of sudden death in college sports. On March 4, 1990, the Loyola Marymount University basketball star Hank Gathers collapsed while playing in a game against the University of Portland. His body convulsed on the hardwood floor, and despite shocks from a defibrillator, he could not be revived. He was pronounced dead at a hospital shortly after.'b'Mr. Gathers\xe2\x80\x99s sudden death was never fully explained, though some media reports suggested he had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an abnormally thickened heart that is the most common cause of sudden death in young athletes. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a heritable condition. Three years after Mr. Gathers died, his first cousin, a high school senior, also died while playing basketball.'b'Heart disorders like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are often detectable by a standard electrocardiogram. However, the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology are strongly opposed to routine EKG screening. Barry Maron, a Minneapolis cardiologist who was the chief author of a recent position statement by these organizations, argues that because of the low incidence of heart disease in young people, he believes the false positive rate will be too high \xe2\x80\x94 between one in three and one in seven, by some estimates.'b'Another reason, Dr. Maron says, that he opposes EKG screening is that there is a high likelihood of disqualifying athletes whose risk is small or difficult to quantify. For athletes who have spent much of their lives preparing to play competitive sports, such a prohibition is a tragedy.'b'But of course this tragedy pales before the tragedy of sudden death. Unfortunately there is no consensus on the incidence of sudden death in college athletes. Dr. Maron puts the rate between one in 50,000 and one in 100,000. However, research published last year in the journal Circulation by Dr. Kimberly Harmon and her colleagues found that the cumulative risk over a typical four-year career of a Division I male basketball player was a staggering 1 in 1,300, higher than his risk of dying in an automobile accident.'b'Some experts, including Dr. Maron, dispute this latest data, saying that it spuriously counts deaths from other causes, such as drug overdoses. But if it is correct, the incidence of sudden death is high enough to justify EKG or even ultrasound screening. Despite the N.C.A.A.\xe2\x80\x99s own position, some individual college programs already require their athletes to undergo either test. A few require both.'b'There are about eight million high school and 460,000 college athletes in this country. Screening all these young people with EKGs will not be feasible. Many communities do not have experts available to properly interpret EKGs in well-conditioned athletes. Cost is also a consideration. Screening all these athletes would most likely cost billions of dollars.'b'But targeted screening of higher risk groups, such as basketball and soccer players, makes sense. In the final analysis it is a moral judgment. Are the anxieties and associated costs of false positives outweighed by that rare life that might be saved? Though we still need more study of this issue, we should, in the meantime, begin to screen the highest-risk college athletes.'b'A runoff election on Sunday for president in Haiti was 'b'postponed'b' indefinitely late last week. 'b'According to the FiveThirtyEight'b' website, Cruz has the most conservative voting record in the entire Congress.
