Not Trump, Cruz or Sanders has any remote chance of turning his ideas, such as they are, into actual laws.'b'In every recent presidential election American voters have selected the candidate with the most secure pair of hands. They\xe2\x80\x99ve elected the person who would be a stable presence and companion for the next four years. I believe they\xe2\x80\x99re going to do that again. And if they\xe2\x80\x99re not, please allow me a few more months of denial.'b'Imagine you\xe2\x80\x99re discussing the presidential election with a group of friends who live in Iowa or New Hampshire. You ask them who they intend to vote for next month.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, whoever\xe2\x80\x99s the tallest,\xe2\x80\x9d one friend says. \xe2\x80\x9cSo Jeb Bush, I guess!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo way \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m voting for Bernie Sanders,\xe2\x80\x9d another friend says. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has a deeper voice, 'b'and'b' my best friend growing up was named Bernie.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It sounds ridiculous \xe2\x80\x94 like dialogue from \xe2\x80\x9cThe Twilight Zone\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 but it\xe2\x80\x99s not too far off from the sometimes superficial shortcuts our brains use to make decisions.'b'Casey Klofstad, an associate professor of political science at the University of Miami, studies how social and biological factors affect human decision making. Last year, he collaborated on a 'b'study'b' with his wife, Rindy Anderson, a biologist who studies birdsong. They had subjects listen to manipulated male and female voices saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI urge you to vote for me this November.\xe2\x80\x9d The subjects then participated in a mock election. They 'b'found that'b' both men and women picked candidates with lower-pitched voices.'b'In the final week before the Iowa caucuses, candidates are making a mad dash to prove themselves the best option. They have six days to call voters, knock on doors and generally make their case before the first actual decision of Decision 2016 is made. But this down-to-the-wire effort to share policy proposals and paint their opponents as establishment shills or unelectable wacko birds probably matters less than candidates hope.'b'Often, seemingly superficial characteristics and split-second judgments can affect voters\xe2\x80\x99 decisions. Another study found that most American presidents are taller than average, and that voters tend to choose taller candidates. In the general election, the taller of the two candidates won roughly two-thirds of the time.'b'A 'b'2005 study'b' by the psychologist Alexander Todorov presented participants with photos of two congressional candidates, and asked them to choose which one looked more competent. More than two-thirds of the time, participants were able to pick the winner of each Congressional race just by how \xe2\x80\x9ccompetent\xe2\x80\x9d he or she looked. The keys to looking competent? A square jaw, an intense stare \xe2\x80\x94 in other words, not too far from Donald J. Trump on the cover of 'b'Time'b'.'b'There is also a well-documented primacy effect in voting: Candidates who are listed first on the ballot have been found to get 2.3 percent more votes on average than when they are listed farther down on the ballot. Having a familiar-sounding name has also been found to help candidates\xe2\x80\x99 electoral success. In Cook County, Illinois \xe2\x80\x94 home to Chicago, a city with the second-largest Irish-American population in the country \xe2\x80\x94 Irish-sounding last names have been thought to help candidates so much that in 2005, a candidate for Cook County judge legally switched from Frederick S. Rhine to Patrick Michael O\xe2\x80\x99Brien. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seemed like a very voter-friendly name,\xe2\x80\x9d he 'b'said at the time'b'. (So far it seems unlikely that the Irish Name Effect will pay off for one Martin O\xe2\x80\x99Malley, any more than it did for the new Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien, 'b'who dropped out of his race'b'.)'b'What accounts for all this superficial reasoning? It comes down to something called decision heuristics, or mental shortcuts. As humans, we need to use our brain power efficiently. We do that by reducing the amount of effort we spend assessing each interaction, decision or task. Heuristics help us process the boatloads of information that we take in every day. As a result, we make decisions not by arduously ticking off a list of pros and cons, but by assessing the information, or cues, that are most readily available.'b'Some of these shortcuts can be built up over the thousands of daily encounters we\xe2\x80\x99ve had. For example, I tend to distrust people who unironically use the word \xe2\x80\x9c'b'synergy'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d It just makes life easier. Of course, there are instances when our own mental shortcuts and preconceptions distort the truth, and that is where our cognitive biases arise. The vocal pitch preference that Mr. Klofstad studies, for one, is pretty outdated. While voice pitch may be a sound proxy for figuring out which candidate may have the most testosterone, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily equate to being a better leader.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn human history, politics was about physical contact, fighting with rocks and sticks,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Klofstad said. \xe2\x80\x9cNowadays, war still matters, but our political battles are about ideologies and not physical conflicts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another example of this sort of cognitive bias is something called the \xe2\x80\x9cthird person effect,\xe2\x80\x9d according to David Greenberg, an associate professor of history at Rutgers University and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cRepublic of Spin'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' Because we like to protect our own egos, we tend to not worry about our own susceptibility to biased judgment, while worrying about others\xe2\x80\x99 lack of savviness. That is to say, we only think other people\xe2\x80\x99s biases are a problem.'b'Daniel Oppenheimer, a psychology professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, and a co-author of \xe2\x80\x9cDemocracy Despite Itself,\xe2\x80\x9d said there are \xe2\x80\x9cthree I\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d that unite voters: ignorance, irrationality and incompetence. He says that as voters, we don\xe2\x80\x99t reflect on our own core beliefs and then seek out the candidate who best matches them. Instead, it\xe2\x80\x99s usually quite the opposite: We decide which candidate we like based on subjective cues, then mold our beliefs to fit theirs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMost people have no idea where most candidates stand on most issues, so they just assume that the candidate agrees with them,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople will actually change their position to align with the candidates they prefer, and will also assume that candidates agree with them on important issues, even when that isn\xe2\x80\x99t true.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This isn\xe2\x80\x99t to say that shortcuts in decision making are necessarily bad; they are often good. It\xe2\x80\x99s evolutionarily beneficial for humans to be able to process a lot of information without shutting down.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHeuristics are usually very helpful. We wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t use them if they weren\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Oppenheimer said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just that sometimes they\xe2\x80\x99re not.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Good politicians know that voters make a large share of their decisions superficially, which is why campaigns spend so much time and energy devising an effective image for their candidate. Aside from celebrities, there is no one who is more conscious of his or her own subconscious signals, vocal and visual cues than a presidential candidate. Even politicians who appear messy or unscripted to the layman\xe2\x80\x99s eye are most likely calculating how to appear that way to voters.'b'Remember when Senator Marco Rubio was spotted wearing 'b'shiny, high-heeled boots'b' while campaigning in New Hampshire? Since then, Mr. Rubio has been 'b'upping his machismo'b' on the trail.'b'In some ways, political parties are the original decision-making shortcut for voters. Don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about your local county clerk race, but identify as a Republican? There\xe2\x80\x99s an easy way to help you quickly decide whom you\xe2\x80\x99d probably rather see get elected. Candidate endorsements can also act as a mental shortcut \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cI like Celebrity X, and she just endorsed Candidate Y, so I should support Candidate Y.\xe2\x80\x9d Being a single-issue voter is another way to ease decision fatigue. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lot easier to figure out where all the candidates stand on one issue that\xe2\x80\x99s important to you \xe2\x80\x94 abortion or climate change, say \xe2\x80\x94 than on every issue.'b'Mr. Oppenheimer said voting was a lot like grocery shopping, with more sensible but unappealing choices often losing out to tastier but less nutritious options. If someone like Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is a bag of low-calorie, gluten-free rice cakes, then Donald J. Trump, the Republican front-runner, is a big box of chocolate-chip cookies. Mr. Kasich may not have his own line of festive hats, but he does have experience both in executive office and in Congress. Sensible policy solutions just don\xe2\x80\x99t taste as good as emotional appeals to fear and braggadocio promises to restore America\xe2\x80\x99s lost greatness.'b'This is not to besmirch the good name of chocolate-chip cookies, or to suggest that American voters should support candidates they don\xe2\x80\x99t find engaging. It\xe2\x80\x99s unreasonable to expect every single voter in America to sit down and thoughtfully digest each candidates\xe2\x80\x99 policy proposals.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s simply silly to think that every single citizen is going to get up to speed on the differences between Medicare expansion and single-payer health care,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Greenberg said. \xe2\x80\x9cIndividuals shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be held to a standard of being public policy students. That\xe2\x80\x99s just not realistic. That\xe2\x80\x99s not how people live their lives.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What we can do is try to consciously push back against some of our baser instincts. When you decide to vote for a candidate, ask yourself: Why do I like this person? What does he or she represent that I agree with? Instead of trying to deny our innate superficiality, maybe we should try to embrace it. After all, we\xe2\x80\x99re only human.'b'The Supreme Court has ruled repeatedly over the last decade that it is morally and constitutionally wrong to equate offenses committed by emotionally undeveloped adolescents with crimes carried out by adults. It made this point again 'b'on Monday'b' when it ruled that people who were sentenced to mandatory life in prison without the possibility of parole as juveniles have the right to seek parole.'b'The decision has its roots in the 2005 case of Roper v. Simmons, in which the court held that children under 18 were ineligible for the death penalty. It found that children were less culpable than adults and more likely to be rehabilitated, and that extinguishing their lives violated the Eighth Amendment prohibition against \xe2\x80\x9ccruel and unusual punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Five years later, the court outlawed sentences of life without parole for adolescents convicted of crimes other than homicide. In 2012, it went a step further, ruling in Miller v. Alabama that mandatory life sentences without parole were unconstitutional for adolescents.'b'The court left open the question of whether that ruling should be retroactively applied to about 2,000 people who were sentenced automatically to life without parole before the 2012 decision. On Monday, in 'b'Montgomery v. Louisiana'b', the court offered the answer: The constitutional rule announced in the Miller decision applies retroactively to that group.'b'The plaintiff in the case, Henry Montgomery, was 17 years old when he was convicted in 1963 of killing a sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s deputy \xe2\x80\x94 a crime that carried an automatic sentence of life without parole. Mr. Montgomery, who has spent more than half a century behind bars, is said to be a well-behaved inmate.'b'Louisiana argued that the 2012 ruling need not be applied retroactively. But the court, in a 6-to-3 opinion written by Justice Anthony Kennedy, disagreed, writing, \xe2\x80\x9cThe court now holds that when a new substantive rule of constitutional law controls the outcome of a case, the Constitution requires state collateral review courts to give retroactive effect to that rule.\xe2\x80\x9d He also noted that \xe2\x80\x9cextending parole eligibility to juvenile offenders does not impose an onerous burden on the states\xe2\x80\x9d since prisoners who do not meet parole standards will continue to serve their life sentences.'b'The Montgomery decision will bring justice to some. But the court\xe2\x80\x99s finding that juveniles are less culpable than adults and more capable of rehabilitation suggests that the justices should take the final step. That means outlawing life sentences without parole for children altogether, whether mandatory or not.'b'DONALD J. TRUMP has made a shrewd bet. Mr. Trump has now usurped and vastly expanded upon Ms. Palin\xe2\x80\x99s constituency, but the connection between the two movements is undeniable.'b'As a senior adviser to the McCain-Palin campaign in 2008, I understand why, to this day, Senator McCain remains gracious toward Ms. Palin. Her legacy lies in her innate ability to wrap herself in the anger that those voters felt. While Senator McCain seemed slightly unnerved by the intensity of their discontent, Ms. Palin basked in it.'b'I stood backstage at a rally in Minnesota in October 2008 where Senator McCain took the microphone from a woman in the crowd who spoke about her fears, including that Barack Obama was \xe2\x80\x9can Arab.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Senator McCain said,'b' \xe2\x80\x9cNo, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d and explained that Mr. Obama was a good and decent family man and an American with whom he simply disagreed on policy matters. Bush to get his backing, then holds forth at such tone-deaf length about his disruptive plans for the Republican Party that the former president is appalled and repelled.'b'In The Times on Monday, Matt Flegenheimer 'b'noted'b' discrepancies between Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s accounts of his vital contributions to Bush\xe2\x80\x99s legal team during the 2000 Florida recount and the memories of others. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are a lot of people who claim to be in Florida at the time of the recount,\xe2\x80\x9d Joe Allbaugh, Bush\xe2\x80\x99s campaign manager, told Flegenheimer.'b'Every successful politician is a self-promoter. Every campaign is a sequence of boasts. In an ideal political environment, the narcissism is tempered and the worst narcissists foiled.'b'But the current ecosystem is toxic, and Trump and Cruz flourish. Neither demonstrates an especially robust appetite for listening, though listening is important. Both are full of a great many things. Humility isn\xe2\x80\x99t among them.'b'The 'b'sudden resignation'b' of the federal pardon attorney, Deborah Leff, an Obama appointee, is the latest evidence that until the clemency process is pried from the grip of the Justice Department, it will remain broken.'b'The pardon attorney\xe2\x80\x99s office, which operates out of the Justice Department, is responsible for reviewing thousands of petitions for pardons and sentence commutations and for making recommendations for clemency to the president. The president\xe2\x80\x99s power to grant mercy in these cases is nearly unlimited, but for most of his time in office, Mr. Obama, like his recent predecessors, has exercised this power only rarely.'b'Since 'b'2014'b', Mr. Obama has focused more attention on this issue. To overhaul the notoriously backlogged pardon office, he 'b'announced new standards'b' encouraging tens of thousands of federal prisoners to request reductions of their inordinately long drug sentences.'b'And he hired Ms. Leff to replace Ronald Rodgers, whose incompetent tenure included a 'b'finding'b' by the Justice Department\xe2\x80\x99s inspector general that in 2008 he hid information from President George W. Bush in recommending the denial of a clemency petition.'b'Ms. Leff\xe2\x80\x99s appointment was a promising sign that the dysfunctional pardon process would be repaired. But her tenure didn\xe2\x80\x99t last long. On Jan. 15, barely one year after she was formally appointed, she abruptly announced she would step down at the end of this month, saying only that the work of the office should \xe2\x80\x9cmove ahead expeditiously and expand.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As she leaves, more than 10,000 clemency petitions are waiting for review. While the pardon office, which has 10 lawyers, has remained virtually the same size it was 20 years ago, the number of petitions has increased almost sevenfold. The department 'b'recently announced'b' plans to hire 16 new lawyers, but this would still be far below the number needed to process the backlog.'b'The lack of resources is only part of a deeper problem, which is that the pardon office is caught in an incurable institutional conflict. The deputy attorney general has authority to review the pardon attorney\xe2\x80\x99s clemency recommendations, and federal prosecutors generally have little interest in revisiting or undoing the department\xe2\x80\x99s convictions. As one former pardon attorney 'b'put it'b', the prosecutors are \xe2\x80\x9cdeterminedly and irreconcilably hostile\xe2\x80\x9d to clemency.'b'This conflict has stymied presidents for decades, but Mr. Obama is under no obligation to leave the process in prosecutors\xe2\x80\x99 hands. He can 'b'end this blockage'b' either by running the pardon office directly out of the White House or by appointing an independent commission, as several states have done to improve and streamline their clemency processes.'b'Executive clemency is a critical check on a justice system that can impose wantonly excessive punishments without good reason. Right now, the most significant criminal-justice reform package, which would, among other changes, reduce unjustly long drug sentences, is teetering on the edge of collapse in Congress. Whether it will survive is anyone\xe2\x80\x99s guess.'b'But there is no question that Mr. Obama has the power to revitalize clemency and deliver more justice to more people, if only he would wield it.'b'IT has become part of the accepted history of our time: The bursting of the housing bubble was the primary cause of a financial crisis, a sharp recession and prolonged slow growth. The story makes intuitive sense, since the economic crisis included a collapse in the prices of housing and related securities. The movie \xe2\x80\x9cThe Big Short,\xe2\x80\x9d which is based on a book by Michael Lewis, takes this cause-and-effect relationship as a given.'b'But there is an alternative story. In recent months, Senator Ted Cruz has become the most prominent politician to give voice to the theory that the 'b'Federal Reserve'b' caused the crisis by tightening monetary policy in 2008. While Mr. Cruz (who is an old friend of one of the authors of this article) has been criticized for making this claim, he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t back down. He\xe2\x80\x99s right, and our understanding of the great recession needs to be revised.'b'What the housing-centric view underemphasizes is that the housing bust started in early 2006, more than two years before the economic crisis. In 2006 and 2007, construction employment fell, but overall employment continued to grow, as did the economy generally. Money and labor merely shifted from housing to other sectors of the economy.'b'This housing decline caused financial stress by sowing uncertainty about the value of bonds backed by subprime mortgages. These bonds served as collateral for institutional investors who parked their money overnight with financial firms on Wall Street in the \xe2\x80\x9cshadow banking\xe2\x80\x9d system. As their concerns about the bonds grew, investors began to pull money out of this system.'b'In retrospect, economists have concluded that a recession began in December 2007. But this recession started very mildly. Through early 2008, even as investors kept pulling money out of the shadow banks, key economic indicators such as inflation and nominal spending \xe2\x80\x94 the total amount of dollars being spent throughout the economy \xe2\x80\x94 barely budged. It looked as if the economy would be relatively unscathed, as many forecasters were saying at the time. The problem was manageable: According to Gary Gorton, an economist at Yale, roughly 6 percent of banking assets were tied to subprime mortgages in 2007.'b'It took a bigger shock to the economy to bring the financial system down. That shock was tighter money. Through acts and omissions, the Fed kept interest rates and expected interest rates higher than appropriate, depressing the economy. This point is easy to miss because the Fed lowered interest rates between September 2007 and April 2008. But raising rates is not the only route to tighter money.'b'Between late April and early October, the Fed kept the interest rate over which it has most direct control, the federal funds rate, at 2 percent. But when the economy weakens, the \xe2\x80\x9cnatural\xe2\x80\x9d interest rate \xe2\x80\x94 the rate that keeps the economy on an even keel \xe2\x80\x94 falls. By staying in place, the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s target interest rate was rising relative to that natural rate. The gap between expected interest rates and the natural rate was rising even more. Fed officials spent the late spring and summer of 2008 warning that rates would have to rise to combat inflation. Futures markets showed a sharp increase in expected interest rates.'b'Market indicators of expected inflation fell sharply that summer, a sign that the economy was getting weaker and monetary policy tighter. Nominal spending showed the change. After growing for years at a relatively steady rate, it began to drop.'b'In their early August meeting, some Fed policy makers nonetheless anticipated that they would raise rates soon. Inflation expectations and nominal spending kept falling. In mid-September, shortly after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the Fed refused to cut interest rates further, citing the risk of inflation. (To his credit, Chairman Ben Bernanke subsequently admitted that not cutting rates then was a mistake.) It did not cut rates until weeks after the crisis had become undeniable.'b'It was against this backdrop of tighter money that the financial stress of 2007 turned into something far worse in 2008. With nominal spending falling at the fastest rate since the Depression, households, businesses and banks all had incomes lower than they had expected. That made servicing debts and paying wages harder than expected. It also lowered asset values, since those were premised on expected streams of future income.'b'And, of course, the crashing economy made the housing crisis worse, too. That\xe2\x80\x99s why the standard account of the crisis took hold. It\xe2\x80\x99s true, after all, that housing fell and then, along with the economy, plummeted. Untangling cause and effect is tricky. But the timeline is a better match for the theory that the Fed is to blame. The economy started to tank not right after housing began to fall, but right after money tightened.'b'We could have had a decline in housing without a Great Recession. That\xe2\x80\x99s what we went through for two years. What we could not have had without a Great Recession was a decline in nominal spending. If it had cut rates faster, or merely refrained from talking up future rate increases, the Fed might have kept that decline from happening or at least moderated it. Australia had a housing boom and debt bubble, too, but kept a steadier monetary policy. The consequence was a mild correction, but nothing like our Great Recession.'b'It took decades for the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s responsibility for 'b'the Great Depression'b' to be widely accepted and it may take that long for most people to see its responsibility this time around. The Fed of 2008 feared inflation too much and recession too little. It placed too little weight on market expectations about future conditions and on how its behavior affected those expectations. If these mistakes go unrecognized, they could well be repeated.'b'Whether the winner of the 2016 presidential election emphasizes optimism or pessimism, he or she will face some sobering economic developments.'b'The first is the acceleration of corporate mergers. Why does this phenomenon matter? As Robert Litan, the chief economic adviser to Patent Properties Inc., 'b'explained last summer in the Wall Street Journal'b', it\xe2\x80\x99s'b'According to Litan, the increased number of mergers'b'A 'b'National Bureau of Economics working paper'b' released last month reinforces Litan\xe2\x80\x99s point. It shows that the \xe2\x80\x9cpace of business dynamism and entrepreneurship in the United States has declined over recent decades.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Ryan Decker'b' of the Federal Reserve and three co-authors write:'b'These four authors conclude that the decline in \xe2\x80\x9crapid firm-level growth\xe2\x80\x9d indicates that there has been a corresponding decline in the \xe2\x80\x9cefficient movement of labor toward high-productivity producers,\xe2\x80\x9d which, they cautiously note, is \xe2\x80\x9ca cause for concern.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Leigh Buchanan, an editor at large of Inc. Magazine, 'b'makes a similar point about corporate malaise'b':'b'Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern, about whom I have 'b'written'b' 'b'before'b', has just published a 768-page book, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Rise and Fall of American Growth'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d The message, as the title suggests, is deeply pessimistic.'b'Gordon 'b'contends that prospects'b' for an innovation-driven economic revival comparable to the post World War II boom are essentially nil.'b'The way Gordon sees it, recent information technology innovation \xe2\x80\x94 the so-called the third industrial revolution \xe2\x80\x94 boosted productivity for just the eight-year period from 1996 to 2004. In other words, the \xe2\x80\x9cthird industrial revolution\xe2\x80\x9d was far less consequential than the 'b'second industrial revolution'b', which extended from the 1870s into the 1960s:'b'Since 1970, in contrast, new innovations have occurred primarily'b'Gordon 'b'predicts'b' that the growth rate going forward will be a fraction of the 3.62 percent registered between 1929 and 1974, and will stay low \xe2\x80\x9cover the next decade or two.\xe2\x80\x9d Some of the factors contributing to this slowdown, he argues, include a \xe2\x80\x9cdecline in the growth rate of the working-age population,\xe2\x80\x9d a fall in worker hours per capita \xe2\x80\x9cdue primarily to the retirement of the baby boom generation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9can ongoing slowdown in the growth rate of output per hour.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Republican candidates have been talking more about doom and gloom than candidates usually do. If Gordon is right, whoever holds the White House after Jan. 20, 2017, will find the job as frustrating as it is rewarding.'b'In an email, Gordon forecasts a 0.3 percent annual growth rate of \xe2\x80\x9cmedian disposable income per person after taxes and transfers\xe2\x80\x9d for the period from 2015 to 2040 \xe2\x80\x94 one sixth the 1.69 percent rate from 1920 to 2014. Gordon\xe2\x80\x99s apprehension is based in part on his findings, which show the rise and fall of productivity (you can see this in the accompanying chart).'b'In addition to the slowdown in innovation, Gordon sees four \xe2\x80\x9cheadwinds\xe2\x80\x9d: the aging of the population, the decline of American education in comparison to foreign nations, rising inequality which, among other things, diminishes consumer purchasing power, and the growing federal debt burden.'b'Larry Summers, the former Treasury secretary, now a professor of economics at Harvard, makes a parallel argument \xe2\x80\x94 that the United States faces the danger of sustained \xe2\x80\x9csecular stagnation.\xe2\x80\x9d The tenor of Summers\xe2\x80\x99s analysis is reflected in the title of a blog post he published in November: \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Advanced economies are so sick we need a new way to think about them'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A key element of the 'b'Summers argument'b' is that since the end of the recession of 2008-9,'b'The lingering effects of the Great Recession, 'b'according to Summers'b', cast doubt on \xe2\x80\x9cthe economy\xe2\x80\x99s future potential.\xe2\x80\x9d One of the consequences, in Summers\xe2\x80\x99s view, is what economists call \xe2\x80\x9c'b'hysteresis'b'\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 a term he 'b'defines'b' as: \xe2\x80\x9cthe shadow cast forward on economic activity by adverse cyclical developments.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Hysteresis'b', as Investopedia puts it, sounds like something we have seen developing in America, particularly with sinking job force participation numbers (despite lower unemployment):'b'The views of both Summers and Gordon are controversial, and disputed by other scholars.'b'For example, a colleague of Gordon\xe2\x80\x99s in the Northwestern economics department, Joel Mokyr, a leading 'b'techno-optimist'b', is on the other side of this debate. His response to those who say \xe2\x80\x9cthat product and process innovation are running out of steam\xe2\x80\x9d is \xe2\x80\x9cshort and simple: we ain\xe2\x80\x99t seen nothin\xe2\x80\x99 yet, the best is still to come.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mokyr envisages a world of unprecedented opportunity \xe2\x80\x94 where \xe2\x80\x9cthe tools we have today for scientific research\xe2\x80\x9d make \xe2\x80\x9cthose of Galileo and Pasteur look like stone-age tools\xe2\x80\x9d; where 'b'digitalization'b' has led to \xe2\x80\x9cthe reinvention of invention\xe2\x80\x9d; where quantum computers will deepen research capacities \xe2\x80\x9cby orders of magnitude\xe2\x80\x9d; where \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is happening to materials now is nothing short of a sea change, with new resins, ceramics and entirely new solids designed 'b'in silico'b', being developed at the nanotechnological level\xe2\x80\x9d; and where the \xe2\x80\x9cpotential economic significance of genetic engineering is simply staggering, as it completely changes the relationship between humans and all other species on the planet.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Barry Eichengreen, an economist at Berkeley, takes Gordon to task in a chapter he contributed to \xe2\x80\x9cSecular Stagnation\xe2\x80\x9d:'b'Two leading technological optimists, 'b'Erik Brynjolfsson'b', a professor at M.I.T.\xe2\x80\x99s Sloan School of Management, and 'b'Andrew McAfee'b', a research scientist at M.I.T., argue in their most recent book, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Second Machine Age'b',\xe2\x80\x9d that \xe2\x80\x9ctechnical progress is improving exponentially:\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In this new world, there will be \xe2\x80\x9cbounty instead of scarcity, freedom instead of constraint.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a phone interview, Brynjolfsson made the point that \xe2\x80\x9cwe are far from tapping out the innovations\xe2\x80\x9d growing out of digitization, computers and information technology. Three-dimensional printing, he said, is \xe2\x80\x9cthe biggest revolution manufacturing has ever seen.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More important, Brynjolfsson believes \xe2\x80\x9cwe are entering the second wave of the second machine age,\xe2\x80\x9d when machines will be able to \xe2\x80\x9clearn by example, instead of requiring detailed coding.\xe2\x80\x9d This will address the computer programmer\xe2\x80\x99s quandary which, Brynjolfsson says, was best expressed 'b'in 1967 by Michael Polanyi'b', a professor of both physical chemistry and social science at the University of Manchester: \xe2\x80\x9cWe can know more than we can tell.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'According to Brynjolfsson, as computers learn to identify faces or cancerous lesions, or how to spot fraud in an accountant\xe2\x80\x99s report, the range of new uses for computers will grow geometrically.'b'Despite the conflicting views of optimists and pessimists on the future of technology, there is a surprising level of agreement among those engaged in the debate over the public policy imperatives.'b'Eichengreen of Berkeley puts it this way in his chapter of \xe2\x80\x9cSecular Stagnation\xe2\x80\x9d:'b'Although Brynjolfsson is optimistic about future economic growth, he believes that major improvements in education and training are necessary to ensure that workers have the skills to fill newly created jobs.'b'The current configuration in Washington precludes the adoption of such proposals. Big ticket items \xe2\x80\x94 a major boost in infrastructure spending, enactment of a federally directed program of school reform and alteration of tax and spending programs to redistribute income appear to be out of reach. The ironclad commitment of Republicans to oppose any domestic initiatives that require higher taxes or deficit financing stands in the way of progress. Democrats themselves have misgivings \xe2\x80\x94 ranging from teacher union rejection of school reform to the opposition of upscale Democrats to redistributive tax policies.'b'Perhaps, then, Gordon\xe2\x80\x99s pessimism is justified. \xe2\x80\x9cHypothetical legislation,\xe2\x80\x9d he writes:'b'When asked why he sought to cross the Antarctic unassisted and unsupported \xe2\x80\x94 with no supply drops or help from dogs, sails or any other source \xe2\x80\x94 Henry Worsley would say it was to raise money to help wounded soldiers. It indeed was that, and his adventure raised more than 100,000 pounds (about $142,000) for that worthy cause. But like the great explorers Mr. Worsley so admired, the 'b'quest that took his life'b' was far greater and far harder to define.'b'That was less of a problem for earlier explorers like Marco Polo or Christopher Columbus, for whom there were always great treasures to discover or blank spots to fill on their maps. For the later adventurers there was always the challenge of the \xe2\x80\x9cfirst\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 first to reach the earth\xe2\x80\x99s poles, first to climb Mount Everest, first to walk on the moon. It may be more difficult now, when so much is known and when adventures have been relegated to reality shows, to identify a genuine quest, but the longing to test oneself against the extreme and the unknown seems as powerful as ever.'b'Why? \xe2\x80\x9cBecause it\xe2\x80\x99s there,\xe2\x80\x9d was the famous response the mountaineer George Mallory gave to a reporter from The New York Times when asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. 'b'Felicity Aston'b', the British meteorologist who achieved many firsts for women, including a solo crossing of the Antarctic in January 2012 (with supply drops, in contrast to Mr. Worsley) offered this explanation: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I look at a map of the world, my eye tends to wander to the fringes \xe2\x80\x94 that\xe2\x80\x99s where I want to be.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Worsley, 55, would no doubt agree. A retired British Army officer and friend of Britain\xe2\x80\x99s royal princes William and Harry, Mr. Worsley was passionately interested in the explorers of the \xe2\x80\x9cheroic age of Arctic exploration\xe2\x80\x9d a century ago \xe2\x80\x94 Sir Ernest Shackleton, Robert Scott, Roald Amundsen. Mr. Worsley had already led expeditions following each of their celebrated Antarctic routes; his latest plan was to make the trek across Antarctica that Sir Ernest had failed to make in 1915 when his ship became stranded in ice \xe2\x80\x94 and to do so on his own, dragging a sled with all his supplies and equipment over 1,100 miles.'b'On Day 71 of the brutal voyage, with just 30 miles left to go, Mr. Worsley, exhausted, and suffering, as doctors subsequently discovered, from bacterial peritonitis, was compelled to give up. He was flown to a hospital in southernmost Chile, where on Sunday he died. In his last audio broadcast on Friday, he recalled that when Sir Ernest abandoned an attempt to reach the South Pole in 1909, he said he\xe2\x80\x99d shot his bolt. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, today I have to inform you with some sadness that I, too, have shot my bolt.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'STOCKHOLM \xe2\x80\x94 Now in his last year in office, 'b'President Obama'b' is in legacy mode. He has much to be proud of. But if he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want his achievements muddied by foreign policy, he\xe2\x80\x99ll spend his last year redoubling his efforts to contain the Middle East refugee crisis before it goes from a giant humanitarian problem to a giant geostrategic problem that shatters America\xe2\x80\x99s most important ally: the 'b'European Union'b'.'b'I know \xe2\x80\x94 putting \xe2\x80\x9cEuropean Union\xe2\x80\x9d into the lead of a column published in America is like a \xe2\x80\x9cDo Not Read\xe2\x80\x9d sign. Maybe I should call it \xe2\x80\x9cTrump\xe2\x80\x99s European Union.\xe2\x80\x9d That would go viral. But for the two of you still reading, this is really important.'b'The meltdowns of Syria, Somalia, Eritrea, Mali, Chad and Yemen and our takedowns of Libya, Iraq and Afghanistan \xe2\x80\x94 without proper follow-up on our part, 'b'NATO'b'\xe2\x80\x99s part or by local elites \xe2\x80\x94 has uncorked the worst refugee crisis since World War II. Because the E.U. is the United States of Europe \xe2\x80\x94 the world\xe2\x80\x99s other great center of democracy and economic opportunity. He made 'b'several key points'b'.'b'First, one in every 122 people on the planet today is \xe2\x80\x9cfleeing a conflict\xe2\x80\x9d at a time when wars between nations \xe2\x80\x9care at a record low,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miliband, a former British foreign secretary. Merkel\xe2\x80\x99s open-door policy drew even more refugees to the E.U., and now that the Germans want to stop the flow, their neighbors won\xe2\x80\x99t take them.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis refugee crisis is a real arrow pointed at the heart of the European Union,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miliband. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no solution that confines itself within the borders of Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d As long as there is \xe2\x80\x9cwar without law and without end in Syria,\xe2\x80\x9d the refugee flow will continue, with all its destabilizing implications.'b'Obama did not cause this Syria problem, and he can\xe2\x80\x99t fix it alone \xe2\x80\x94 but it\xe2\x80\x99s not going to get fixed without U.S. leadership. Though it was convened to investigate Planned Parenthood, it 'b'indicted two members of the group'b' that made the videos instead.'b'The Harris County prosecutor, Devon Anderson, a Republican who was asked by the lieutenant governor, a strident opponent of Planned Parenthood, to open the criminal investigation, said on Monday that the grand jurors had cleared Planned Parenthood of any misconduct.'b'Yet despite all the evidence, Texas\xe2\x80\x99 Republican governor, Greg Abbott, 'b'said on Monday'b' that the state attorney general\xe2\x80\x99s office and the State Health and Human Services Commission would continue investigating Planned Parenthood. This is a purely political campaign of intimidation and persecution meant to destroy an organization whose mission to serve women\xe2\x80\x99s health care needs the governor abhors.'b'Fortunately, in the Harris County case, the jurors considered the facts. David Daleiden, the director of the Center for Medical Progress, which released the videos, and Sandra Merritt, an employee, were indicted on felony charges of tampering with governmental records, probably connected to their alleged use of fake driver\xe2\x80\x99s licenses to get into a Planned Parenthood office.'b'Mr. Daleiden was also indicted on a misdemeanor charge of violating a Texas ban on the buying and selling of human organs. A lawyer for Planned Parenthood said Mr. Daleiden sent an email to Planned Parenthood employees last June offering to buy fetal tissue for $1,600 per sample, to which Planned Parenthood never responded. A lawyer for Mr. Daleiden said on Tuesday that his client planned to plead not guilty and would vigorously defend against the charges.'b'Neither the videos nor the many investigations that followed have found any evidence that Planned Parenthood employees offered to sell fetal tissue for a profit. Texas is the 12th state in which investigations stemming from the videos have found no wrongdoing by Planned Parenthood. In October, Representative Jason Chaffetz, chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, 'b'admitted'b' that the committee\xe2\x80\x99s investigation of Planned Parenthood had found no evidence of misconduct.'b'Nonetheless, the videos have already had a destructive effect. Texas and several 'b'other states'b' have moved to defund Planned Parenthood; a bill to deny money to the group in Ohio is before the State Senate 'b'this week'b'. A bill that would pull federal money from Planned Parenthood 'b'has reached the president'b', who is sure to veto it.'b'These efforts threaten to deprive the country\xe2\x80\x99s poorest women of health services they need, including cancer screenings, contraceptive care and sexually transmitted infection testing. In many parts of the country, Planned Parenthood is the 'b'only source'b' of contraceptive services for low-income women.'b'Several Republican presidential candidates continue to treat the falsehoods presented by the Center for Medical Progress as fact. In response to Monday\xe2\x80\x99s indictments, Carly Fiorina, for one, 'b'said,'b' \xe2\x80\x9cPlanned Parenthood has been trafficking in body parts,\xe2\x80\x9d a claim she has made repeatedly on the campaign trail.'b'The indictments should cause politicians to back away from an anti-abortion group that will stop at nothing to attack Planned Parenthood. Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is running for president on a platform of good governance and common sense. The campaign against Planned Parenthood is anathema to these principles, and if a bill to defund the organization reaches his desk, he should veto it.'b'If convicted, Mr. Daleiden and Ms. Merritt face up to 20 years in prison on the felony charge; the misdemeanor is punishable by up to a year. These penalties will not undo the damage the videos have already done to Planned Parenthood and women\xe2\x80\x99s health and reproductive rights. State and federal officials who care about the truth should work to remedy that damage in any way they can.'b'THE day after it stopped snowing in New York City last weekend, I took my daughter sledding in Prospect Park. Despite the near record blizzard, things were, remarkably, back to normal in my part of Brooklyn \xe2\x80\x94 thanks to stalwart efforts by city employees. The streets were plowed and salted to glistening blackness. The subway arrived seconds after we did. On Prospect Park\xe2\x80\x99s circular drive, cyclists serenely spun past.'b'There was only one flaw in this picture-postcard image of 'b'spirited urban resilience'b': the sidewalks. The walk to the subway was the most difficult part of our journey. There were the stretches that had not been shoveled (in front of houses under renovation, the perimeter of my neighborhood park) or barely shoveled, forcing walkers into an elaborately pantomimed dance of turn-taking on narrow passageways.'b'Where things got really bad, however, were intersections. Crossing the street meant plunging into slippery, thigh-deep masses of snow piled up by passing plows. Where a few hardy souls had first traversed, there were now single-file crevasses, filled with a melting, exhaust-tinged mire. As my 6-year-old struggled to navigate this urban Tough Mudder course, other pedestrians stacked up behind us, anxiously trying to get out of the street before the light changed and traffic began to rush through again.'b''b'Crossing the street \xe2\x80\x94 even with the walk signal \xe2\x80\x94 is one of the most statistically 'b'hazardous things a New Yorker can do'b'. Asking people to run an icy gantlet compounds this. I can only imagine how much more taxing this is for parents pushing strollers, people in wheelchairs or using walkers, or older pedestrians already struggling with making the light. A curb cut is of little use when covered by a barricade of snow.'b''b'The city\xe2\x80\x99s attitude toward pedestrians seems to be: Let them eat slush. This will only get worse in the coming days as snow melts and refreezes.'b'All this serves as a stark reminder that, even in the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'most walkable large city in America'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (per the website Walk Score), where 'b'households with cars are a minority'b', where any Manhattan intersection will inevitably be more populated by pedestrians than people in cars, people on foot are still routinely neglected \xe2\x80\x94 channeled into spaces that have, in many cases, radically shrunk over the years in favor of wider streets.'b'It is not that the city is unaware of the issue. As 'b'a report issued under the previous administration'b' suggested, \xe2\x80\x9cSystems for clearing heavy snowfall quickly and efficiently should be in place so that pedestrians can continue to use the sidewalk without having to trudge through muddy snow or risk their lives on black ice.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A good deal of the problem is that Americans typically do not think of sidewalks as a means of transportation \xe2\x80\x94 as 'b'infrastructure'b'. When news of the blizzard began to blanket the airwaves, there were images of plows hitting the streets, snowbound stretches of highways, or planes idling on tarmac. When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a \xe2\x80\x9ctravel ban,\xe2\x80\x9d many New Yorkers might have been temporarily puzzled: Does that mean I can\xe2\x80\x99t go down to the corner for a bagel?'b'Sidewalks occupy a curious place in the American city. As the scholar Anastasia Loukaitou-Sideris has noted, in 19th-century cities the maintenance of sidewalks was assigned to abutting homeowners because they were presumed to benefit the most from these newly built amenities. And yet, in most jurisdictions, municipalities have had a shared responsibility (particularly in slip-and-fall lawsuits, although this liability in New York was shifted to property owners in 2003).'b'So even though the sidewalk is, in practice, a public space that almost every New Yorker will use in the course of a day, it is treated instead as a piecemeal extension to private property. (As a thought experiment, imagine if property owners had to shovel not just their sidewalks, but the street in front of their buildings, too.) And there is that curious no man\xe2\x80\x99s land at street crossings, a legal limbo beyond the reach of the shovels of the corner bodega or bank, and buried by the snow pushed aside by rumbling city plows.'b'As I struggled to cross the street with my daughter, I dreamed of heated crosswalks (like the 'b'radiant sidewalks'b' luxury apartments now boast) powered by surplus Con Edison steam. A simpler, more practical solution, which would also improve pedestrian safety more generally, is to \xe2\x80\x9cdaylight\xe2\x80\x9d intersections \xe2\x80\x94 not allowing cars to park within a certain distance of the crosswalk. This not only would improve visibility, it would also provide a handy place for plows to shove snow that has accumulated at intersections.'b'In the wake of the storm, the city began hiring temporary \xe2\x80\x9c'b'snow laborers'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to shovel out hydrants, crosswalks and other spaces. This itself smacks of haphazard catch-up, a game other cities don\xe2\x80\x99t play. 'b'Rochester'b', for instance, plows the sidewalks after storms that drop more than four inches of snow; 'b'Montreal'b' starts doing it after one inch. Even car-oriented places like the Cleveland suburb of Shaker Heights has sidewalk-specific 'b'Bombardier snow removal machines'b'. New York City, the country\xe2\x80\x99s capital of pedestrianism, can do better.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Democratic Race Will Test Where the Left Stands'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 25):'b'The race will not test \xe2\x80\x9cwhere the left stands,\xe2\x80\x9d but rather whether Democrats with an assortment of political views have finally had enough of their own \xe2\x80\x9cestablishment,\xe2\x80\x9d as clearly represented by Hillary Clinton. As prices fall, so do some Mideast fortunes.'b'LAGOS, Nigeria \xe2\x80\x94 Forty-six years ago this month, 'b'Nigeria'b'\xe2\x80\x99s civil war came to an end with the surrender of the secessionist Republic of Biafra. The two and a half years of fighting took some two million lives, but when the bitter conflict ended the triumphant Nigerian government proclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cNo Victor, No Vanquished.\xe2\x80\x9d Nevertheless, the discontent of the ethnic Igbo people of southeast Nigeria lingers on.'b'In 1999, a group known as the Movement for the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra emerged, seeking through protests and political agitation to re-establish an independent nation. In recent years it has been overshadowed by another group, the Indigenous People of Biafra, which also calls for independence, by violence if necessary.'b'Led by Nnamdi Kanu, a Nigerian who was living in Britain until last October, it has demonstrated greater sophistication than Massob. Its main publicity tool is Radio Biafra, an online station that spreads the call for \xe2\x80\x9cliberation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cself-emancipation\xe2\x80\x9d from the \xe2\x80\x9czoo\xe2\x80\x9d called Nigeria. These activities have annoyed President Muhammadu Buhari, who has publicly backed Mr. Kanu\xe2\x80\x99s ongoing trial for treason.'b'When the Biafran War broke out in 1967 in the wake of widespread communal violence, Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, a leading Igbo officer, declared that \xe2\x80\x9ceastern Nigerians are no longer wanted as equal partners in the Federation of Nigeria.\xe2\x80\x9d That feeling is still widely shared among the Igbo. But the frustrations of today\xe2\x80\x99s would-be Biafrans are no different from those of their neighbors in the Niger Delta, whose oil keeps Nigeria going but gets them little in return, apart from gas fires and 'b'oil spills'b'. Nor do they differ from the grievances of their fellow countrymen in the north, who continue to wallow in levels of illiteracy and poverty that make the south seem prosperous in comparison.'b'The reality is that no part of Nigeria has a monopoly on victimhood. The impulse to protest suffering and to seek to determine one\xe2\x80\x99s destiny is not wrongheaded; the problem lies in seeking change in a manner that incites ethnic hatred and violence. It would be better for Biafran separatists to drop their calls for independence and push instead for constitutional change that would strengthen the federal system Nigeria purports to practice. Our current Constitution, like the others that followed independence from Britain in 1960, is the product of military leaders whose agenda has rarely coincided with the public good. Though it opens with the requisite words (\xe2\x80\x9cWe the people of the Federal Republic of Nigeria ... \xe2\x80\x9d), it was crafted by a handpicked committee and not made public until the military transferred power to the civilian government on May 29, 1999.'b'Igbo separatists would also do better to follow the example of Scotland and push for a referendum to decide the future of the region. Admittedly, the central government would be unlikely to endorse such a call for fear that it might trigger an avalanche of referendum requests in this country of more than 250 ethnic groups. But were one to take place, my guess is that it would turn out overwhelmingly in favor of preserving union with Nigeria.'b'There will never be enough support in the southeast for independence from Nigeria, mainly because most of the people there realize that there would be little to gain and much to lose. It\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful that the delta\xe2\x80\x99s several minority ethnic groups share the conviction of the Biafran agitators that the oil-rich delta states are a natural part of Biafra. Without the Niger delta, Biafra would be a tiny, landlocked nation, its enterprising people hobbled by a requirement to obtain visas to do business in places where they\xe2\x80\x99ve lived and traded in for decades.'b'Moreover, an independent Biafra would remain riven along the very tribal and religious lines that are being invoked to justify its leaving Nigeria. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy for the Igbo to regard themselves as a cultural and religious monolith as long as they remain in Nigeria. But all Nigerians should know that there is no end to subdividing ourselves, once we give in to the impulse. In an independent, overwhelmingly Christian Biafra, people would begin to identify themselves as Anglicans and Catholics and Methodists \xe2\x80\x94 as they already sometimes do in local politics. In the run-up to last year\xe2\x80\x99s elections, for example, Anglican bishops warned the ruling party in the Igbo state of Enugu that they would not accept a gubernatorial ticket composed entirely of Catholic candidates. The party disregarded the warning.'b'The clamor for a referendum would provide a great opportunity for those like me who believe (to take a phrase from British opponents of Scottish independence) that Nigeria would be \xe2\x80\x9cBetter Together.\xe2\x80\x9d Admittedly it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see this in a country where online comments routinely degenerate into ethnic sniping, but in fact Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s diversity could, with proper framing, be turned into a unifying motif.'b'That \xe2\x80\x9cBetter Together\xe2\x80\x9d campaign would require much soul searching about our country\xe2\x80\x99s painful past. It would also involve recognizing the complaints of the many Igbo voices who are weary of marginalization but do not support the idea of secession.'b'Almost every day since Mr. Kanu\xe2\x80\x99s arrest, there have been protests and calls for the government to free him. In handling his case, the government needs to tread carefully, ensuring that it does not transform him into a cause c\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8bre.'b'A few weeks ago, Nigerian newspapers reported the existence of a handwritten statement Mr. Kanu submitted to law enforcement agents shortly after his arrest, in which he apologized \xe2\x80\x9cunreservedly\xe2\x80\x9d for the \xe2\x80\x9cregrettable\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cuncomplimentary things\xe2\x80\x9d he had said about President Buhari and some other people. The government should consider capitalizing on this hint of remorse and making an offer of amnesty to Mr. Kanu in exchange for a pledge to be less-disruptive in his approach.'b'The best way for the government to permanently sideline those who call for political violence is to push for the economic reforms that President Buhari has vowed to accomplish. Tackling corruption and ensuring more equitable distribution of Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s wealth will benefit all its people. Splintering the country into a hodgepodge of independent states will not.'b'Back in 2000, George W. Bush did something fascinating: On the campaign trail he preached \xe2\x80\x9ccompassionate conservatism,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'telling wealthy Republicans'b' about the travails of Mexican-American immigrants and declaring to women in pearls that \xe2\x80\x9cthe hardest job in America\xe2\x80\x9d is that of a single mother.'b'Those well-heeled audiences looked baffled, but applauded.'b'That instinct to show a little heart helped elect Bush but then largely disappeared from Republican playbooks and policy. Yet now, amid the Republican Party\xe2\x80\x99s civil war, there are intriguing initiatives by the House speaker, Paul Ryan, and some other conservatives to revive an interest in the needy.'b'Liberals like myself may be tempted to dismiss these new efforts as mere marketing gestures, meant to whitewash what one of the initiatives acknowledges is \xe2\x80\x9cthe longstanding view of a meanspirited conservatism.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Maybe the liberal skeptics will be proved right. But we should still all root for these efforts, because ultimately whether the poor get help may depend less on Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders than on Republicans at every level. Whether Medicaid is expanded, whether we get high-quality pre-K, whether we tackle addiction, family planning and job training, whether lead continues to poison American children \xe2\x80\x94 all these will depend mostly on Republicans who control Congress and most states.'b'Moreover, Democrats are too quick to assume that they have a monopoly on compassion. President Bush, for example, didn\xe2\x80\x99t govern nearly as compassionately as he campaigned. Yet his program against AIDS 'b'saved millions of lives'b'. He did a 'b'stellar job battling malaria'b' and pressing the fight against sex trafficking.'b'This will be even harder for Democrats to accept, but Republicans have also sometimes been proved right on poverty issues. They were right that the best way to spell aid is often j-o-b. They were right on the importance of strong two-parent families: We now know that children in single-mother families are five times as likely to 'b'live in poverty'b' as those in married households.'b'So I\xe2\x80\x99d be thrilled if Republicans participated in debates about poverty, rather than forfeited the terrain. A real debate would also elevate issues that now are largely neglected, and it would create an opening to hold politicians\xe2\x80\x99 feet to the fire: If Ryan cares, then why did he try to 'b'slash budgets'b' for evidence-based programs that help children?'b'One of the new initiatives is \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Challenging the Caricature'b',\xe2\x80\x9d based on a document that will be presented at an event at Stanford\xe2\x80\x99s Hoover Institution next week. Written by Michael Horowitz, Michael Novak, John O\xe2\x80\x99Sullivan, Mona Charen, Linda Chavez and other prominent conservatives, it calls on the right to tackle human rights issues so as to shatter \xe2\x80\x9cthe caricatures that define conservatives as uncaring.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur values are regarded by millions of Americans as inconsistent with theirs and with America\xe2\x80\x99s inherent decency,\xe2\x80\x9d the document warns.'b'Ryan 'b'moderated a forum'b' this month on poverty that drew six Republican presidential hopefuls and tried to frame a G.O.P. perspective on the issue. \xe2\x80\x9cWe now have a safety net that is designed to catch people falling into poverty,\xe2\x80\x9d Ryan said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen what we really need is a safety net that is designed to help get people out of poverty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One reason for skepticism that any of this will get traction: Among the candidates who skipped the forum were the front-runners, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz. Neither seems interested in this arena.'b'A final initiative is 'b'an excellent plan'b' to reduce poverty put together by a team from the conservative American Enterprise Institute and the liberal Brookings Institution. The report pushes work requirements for government benefits, but also a modest rise in the minimum wage. Instead of increasing public funds for higher education, it suggests taking financial assistance that now goes to higher-income families and redirecting it to the neediest.'b'This report emphasizes that one way to bridge the political divide is to focus on evidence. We now have robust results showing that vocational programs like career academies help disadvantaged young people get jobs and raise their marriage rates. 'b'Parent-coaching programs'b' improve disadvantaged children\xe2\x80\x99s outcomes so much that they save public money.'b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re a liberal, you may be rolling your eyes. You\xe2\x80\x99re sure that Republicans are just layering compassion camouflage over policies meant to benefit billionaires. Sure, be skeptical. But at least now there can be a debate about how to help, about what the evidence says, about whether Ryan and others act the way they speak.'b'The parties see each other as the root of all evil. But when they have cooperated on humanitarian efforts, real progress has been made: on 'b'AIDS'b', on 'b'prison rape'b', on the earned-income tax credit.'b'The sad truth is that 'b'neither party has done enough'b' to address the shame of deep-rooted poverty in America. It has been linked to 'b'serious birth defects'b' and is threatening to invade the United States. It is imperative that the World Health Organization not repeat its sluggish response to the Ebola crisis and act urgently this time to mobilize international action.'b'Until it reached the Western Hemisphere, the Zika virus \xe2\x80\x94 related to dengue, yellow fever and West Nile virus and named after the Ugandan forest where it was first identified almost 70 years ago \xe2\x80\x94 had caused little more than relatively mild, flulike infections. But in the nine months since it came to the Americas, it has moved swiftly through Brazil and two dozen other countries and territories, spread by mosquitoes of the Aedes species, which can breed in the tiniest pools of water and usually bite during the day, making them especially hard to control.'b'Though not particularly dangerous to the person infected, the spread of Zika has been accompanied by a huge spike in microcephaly, a congenital and irreversible deformation of the skull in newborn babies. The number of reported cases in Brazil jumped from 147 in 2014 to nearly 4,000 in 2015, leaving health officials with little doubt \xe2\x80\x94 although no firm scientific proof \xe2\x80\x94 that Zika was responsible. Scientists have also identified a possible link between the virus and the neurological disorder known as the Guillain-Barr\xc3\xa9 syndrome.'b'At present there is no vaccine, no cure and no widely available test for Zika infection. In their absence, the obvious course is to avoid mosquito bites by wearing clothes that cover arms and legs, and using air-conditioning and screens and insect repellents containing DEET. Brazil, which is hosting the Olympic Games this summer, has begun an extensive 'b'campaign'b' to eradicate mosquitoes, including the deployment of 220,000 soldiers to search for breeding sites, and has urged women to avoid getting pregnant until the outbreak is brought under control.'b'El Salvador 'b'has advised'b' women to delay pregnancy until 2018. In the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention 'b'has issued'b' a list of countries pregnant women would be wise to avoid and has urged pregnant women who have traveled to affected areas to see a doctor and determine whether a test is required. None of that is likely to quickly end the scourge, and no country can do that on its own. On the contrary, the virus could migrate to southern areas of the United States when winter ends.'b'Regrettably, despite these actions, the World Health Organization seems, once again, to be dozing and has yet to generate a broad and coordinated international response. 'b''b'Part of the reason that pundits (myself included) have tended to rate the Florida senator highly as a candidate is that he combines a conservative record with some of the gifts of Bill Clinton circa 1992 and Barack Obama circa 2008 \xe2\x80\x94 eloquence, optimism, a strong personal narrative, a clear interest in domestic policy.'b'But in this election, many Republican voters seem to be 'b'looking for a Richard Nixon'b' \xe2\x80\x94 a hard man for hard times, you might say, which isn\xe2\x80\x99t really a slogan that fits the boyish-looking first term senator.'b'This is why perhaps \xe2\x80\x94 just perhaps \xe2\x80\x94 Rubio\xe2\x80\x99s strategy of avoiding conflicts with Trump has been a strategic error. A young politician can try to project toughness all he likes, but the only way to actually prove your toughness is to fight the battle that\xe2\x80\x99s right in front of you.'b'And for Rubio, sooner rather than too late, that might mean finding a way to fight with Donald Trump and win.'b'The Supreme Court earlier this week 'b'upheld a federal regulation'b' that encourages factories, shopping malls and other users of electricity to reduce their consumption during periods of high demand, like hot summer afternoons. The well-reasoned decision will save consumers money and improve the reliability of the electricity grid.'b'By a 6-to-2 majority, the court ruled in favor of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in a case brought by a group representing power plants. In 2011, the commission issued a rule applying to the wholesale markets that operate in many parts of the country in which electricity production and distribution are divided into separate businesses. In those markets, which are operated by nonprofit entities, power producers like Exelon sell electricity and utilities like Con Edison buy it to distribute energy to homes and businesses.'b'Under the rule, the operators of the wholesale markets are required to pay users of electricity like big stores and factories if they voluntarily agree to cut consumption during peak periods. The commission also created a formula to determine how much those users should be paid. This approach is known as \xe2\x80\x9cdemand response\xe2\x80\x9d and it can reduce the need for power plants to generate more supply on short notice, which is expensive and can strain power lines and cause blackouts.'b'The Electric Power Supply Association, which represents power producers, challenged the rules because its members stand to earn less money if there is an incentive for businesses to use less energy when it is most expensive. The group argued that the commission had authority only to regulate interstate wholesale electricity markets, but that its rule also affected retail prices, which Congress has said should be regulated by states. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled in favor of the power plants in 2014.'b'The Supreme Court overturned that decision on Monday, rightly concluding that the regulation applies only to wholesale markets. State officials still regulate retail rates and also have the authority to stop electricity users from participating in demand-response programs.'b'Of course, any rule that influences wholesale prices will have an impact on retail prices. In some parts of the country, industry officials and experts say demand response has saved consumers 'b'billions of dollars'b' a year. It would be absurd to use the link between wholesale and retail markets as a reason to strike down a federal rule that helps conserve energy and strengthens the electricity grid.'b'In this decision, like in previous 'b'rulings upholding pollution regulations'b' issued by the Environmental Protection Agency, the Supreme Court is clearly saying that regulators have broad discretion to enforce federal laws. Their job is not to protect the profits of a segment of an industry. Regulators ought to do what is in the public interest, which is exactly what the energy commission\xe2\x80\x99s rule does.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Trump, in Feud With Network, Shuns Debate'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 27):'b'I hope that by boycotting the Fox debate on Thursday, Donald Trump has finally found a way to kill his run for president. This is Mike Bloomberg we are talking about \xe2\x80\x94 a man who has wanted to be president since his college years, when he told friends at Johns Hopkins that he was interested in three jobs: secretary general of the United Nations, head of the World Bank and president of the United States. They never forgot, convinced he was dead serious.'b'The former mayor of New York, 74 next month, always wanted to be his own boss, never wanted to work for anyone else, and has said so outright, whenever his name was floated for a cabinet job or the equivalent. Even in his first job out of graduate school, at Salomon Brothers, he told his bosses he could do a better job of running their company than they could.'b'He did well at Salomon, but by the early 1970s he was impatient. The rare Wall Street trader who understood the nexus between investing and computer technology, Mr. Bloomberg preached change. He said that investors wanted data, news and analytics in real time, and pushed for smaller desktop computers to replace the company\xe2\x80\x99s monster mainframes, accessible only to underpaid researchers. History would prove him right, but his needling won him no friends and he was demoted to the information-technology department.'b'Stuck in what was then Siberia, he was tempted to quit, but stayed and burnished his technical knowledge until he was dismissed a few years later following a merger. He used some of his $10 million golden parachute to start his own company \xe2\x80\x94 and so the Bloomberg empire was born. That nascent company would create the wildly successful Bloomberg terminal, the data-rich phenomenon that the pesky Salomon trader had envisioned.'b'Mr. Bloomberg never looked back. He has, from then on, always been his own boss, has always run his own thing. And why, he has to be asking himself, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t that thing now be the United States of America?'b'During the 2008 presidential campaign, he told friends and advisers he was sure he could do a better job than Barack Obama, the freshman Democratic senator from Illinois, or Senator John McCain of Arizona, the Republican nominee. One of his political advisers talked about \xe2\x80\x9ca billion-dollar campaign\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the same figure bandied about now.'b'He wanted to run in that race. The mayor even flew to the University of Oklahoma that winter to participate in a conference on bipartisanship with political figures like the former Democratic senator Gary Hart. Mr. Bloomberg was a headliner at the event, but a few days earlier, Mr. Obama pulled an upset victory in the Iowa caucuses, and the attention moved away from Oklahoma.'b'Seeing no way to win, Mr. Bloomberg did not run in 2008. He again mulled, then decided against, an independent run in the 2012 election. Though hugely ambitious, he is also deliberative and risk averse. He is careful, calculating, protective of his reputation and his privacy.'b'He also hates to lose, and does everything he can to make sure he does not. He first considered running for mayor four years before the election, and prepared intensively for two years. He\xe2\x80\x99d never run for office but, bored with making money and intrigued with the notion of managing a city, he hired advisers, debriefed former mayors, visited neighborhoods, took polls. Helped mightily by his wealth (he spent $74 million), the city\xe2\x80\x99s desire for strong business leadership after the Sept. 11 attacks and Democratic Party infighting \xe2\x80\x94 he ran as a Republican \xe2\x80\x94 the billionaire from Medford, Mass., took New York\xe2\x80\x99s City Hall.'b'Could the improbable happen again? The presidential lineup today is unusually tempting for Mr. Bloomberg, the sensible centrist. As he looks at the candidates, he sees a threat to the country in the ignorance of Donald J. Trump, the rigidity of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, the extremism of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. He is watching Hillary Clinton, too, in case her campaign craters.'b'Is there an unorthodox path for him to the White House in this odd political season? He surely sees hunger in the country for middle-of-the-road politics and policies. There is no question that many voters favor an approach that combines fiscal prudence and social tolerance. His wealth cuts both ways with most voters: It guarantees his independence, a plus; but it shouts Wall Street, a minus.'b'Mr. Bloomberg knows the persona he projects: He is uncharismatic. He is not good on the stump. He can be cranky, impatient with emotion, stiff. He is also a New Yorker and Jewish, fiercely anti-gun, pro-choice, pro-immigrant, pro-Wall Street, even anti-soda. He was a leader in the fight for 'b'same-sex marriage'b' in New York, he believes in climate change, he will not talk about his faith or lack of same.'b'How many Republicans and Democrats would defect to support this willful child of Wall Street? How many independents? Could Mr. Bloomberg, ardent defender of his administration\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'stop-and-frisk'b' policing policy, count on significant support from black voters? Would his maneuvering to win a third mayoral term undercut his claim to be above back-room politics?'b'He has to reckon, too, with the failed candidacies of every third-party candidate, from Theodore Roosevelt in 1912 to H. Ross Perot in 1992. And, likely to take most votes from the Democrat, he would risk being the spoiler, handing the election to the Republican, as Ralph Nader might have been for Al Gore in 2000.'b'Another possibility: With three candidates in the race, none of them would get a majority in the Electoral College. If that happened, the choice of the president would be thrown into a chaotic House of Representatives.'b'Mr. Bloomberg has to weigh all these possibilities by early March to give him time to qualify for the ballots in all 50 states: a high-risk guessing game on incomplete information.'b'What he will decide is an open question. How he will decide is easier to predict: He will sift through the data, listen to advisers, discount the advice of those more interested in their own futures than his (a common campaign-season affliction). And, in the bargain, they will do immeasurable harm to the capacious idea of what it means to be Indian.'b'TAIPEI, Taiwan \xe2\x80\x94 On a drizzly Tuesday night earlier this month, Chen Li-hung, a celebrity news television host, strode onto a stage in Changhua, in central 'b'Taiwan'b', and launched into a passionate speech, feeding red meat to his Democratic Progressive Party\xe2\x80\x99s assembled faithful.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy parents are from mainland 'b'China'b',\xe2\x80\x9d he told the crowd. \xe2\x80\x9cYet I was born in Taiwan. She knew that if voters detected too much populism, they would have turned on her. And she realized that Beijing and Washington watch her words closely.'b'The range in performances between Mr. Chen and Ms. Tsai helps explain the Democratic Progressive Party\xe2\x80\x99s crushing margin of victory two weeks ago over Mr. Ma\xe2\x80\x99s Kuomintang party, which lost both the presidency and, for the first time, Parliament. The rally highlighted why, with this election, China has lost Taiwan for good.'b'When the Kuomintang was defeated in a civil war by Mao\xe2\x80\x99s Communists in 1949, its leadership retreated to Taiwan with millions of mainlander refugees like Mr. Chen\xe2\x80\x99s parents, establishing an independent authoritarian government that gave way to democracy in the 1990s. Since 1949, Beijing has claimed Taiwan as a wayward province that must be reunited with the mainland, peacefully if possible but by force if necessary. The United States is Taiwan\xe2\x80\x99s security guarantor, but also wishes to avoid offending Beijing and has been unsympathetic to Taiwanese leaders who rock the boat. Taiwan\xe2\x80\x99s voters punish candidates who needlessly provoke China, or alienate Washington.'b'Beijing has pursued a decades-long strategy of patience and economic courtship, hoping that Taiwan would peacefully rejoin the mainland. And the Taiwanese do want stable, functional ties with China. Polls show most Taiwanese favor the status quo of de facto independence, without any official declaration that would enrage Beijing and possibly provoke an invasion.'b'But with the mainland\xe2\x80\x99s economic miracle running aground, many Taiwanese are questioning the wisdom of lashing themselves to the mast. The Taiwanese worry that Mr. Ma\xe2\x80\x99s rapprochement with Beijing has gotten too close, without enough trickle-down benefits to average Taiwanese. A free-trade bill that would have opened sensitive industries, such as media, to mainland Chinese ownership, stalled in Parliament in 2014 amid student protests, which became known as the Sunflower Movement.'b'Meanwhile, the Taiwanese see an increasingly repressive mainland government across the strait \xe2\x80\x94 and want no part of it. President Xi Jinping\xe2\x80\x99s crackdown on dissent and nationalist appeals to the glory of Chinese culture are uncomfortable reminders of Taiwan\xe2\x80\x99s own experiences under martial law.'b'But it was the sentiment expressed by Mr. Chen during the rally that suggests why, unless Beijing resorts to force, the China-Taiwan divorce could be permanent. Polls show that the generation of islanders who identify as \xe2\x80\x9cChinese\xe2\x80\x9d is fading, and more people are identifying themselves as \xe2\x80\x9cTaiwanese.\xe2\x80\x9d Decades of de facto independence have whetted Taiwanese appetites for the real thing. Polls show most Taiwanese are unwilling to rejoin even a democratic China.'b'These feelings will deepen as a younger generation of Taiwanese finds its political voice. Indigenous identity and attachment to liberal civic values are strongest among the increasingly assertive youth, whose Sunflower Movement spawned the New Power Party, which in coalition with Ms. Tsai\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic Progressive Party toppled several Kuomintang incumbents in the election.'b'Still, while Taiwanese may increasingly identify with a unique local culture \xe2\x80\x94 and the passion of someone like Mr. Chen \xe2\x80\x94 for now they prefer Ms. Tsai\xe2\x80\x99s more measured public persona. A cerebral technocrat, she is different from the earthier elders in her party, some of whom started their political careers in Kuomintang prisons.'b'Even as Ms. Tsai\xe2\x80\x99s surrogates played the identity card, her campaign stressed economic competence and promised no formal independence, a position meant to avoid offending Beijing and Washington. Yet Ms. Tsai\xe2\x80\x99s party platform still advocates independence, and her victory will give her power to entrench Taiwan\xe2\x80\x99s separateness with subtle policy tweaks.'b'The Pacific Rim\xe2\x80\x99s shifting politics may tilt Washington\xe2\x80\x99s calculus as well. Since the Nixon administration, Washington has prioritized a realpolitik relationship with Beijing over any attachment to Taiwan. America\xe2\x80\x99s current stance toward China\xe2\x80\x99s claims on Taiwan is implicit acquiescence. But Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s growing assertiveness along its periphery has raised alarms for American allies in Tokyo, Seoul and Manila, all of whom are watching to see how China tests America\xe2\x80\x99s defense commitments to Taiwan.'b'Ms. Tsai will not miss chances to remind Washington of the importance of that alliance. Inside were items (body lotion, halvah, olive oil) produced in Jewish settlements in the 'b'West Bank'b'. Or rather, as Mr. Dermer put it in an accompanying letter, in Judea and Samaria \xe2\x80\x94 the term used by religious nationalists who see the settlements as no less a part of Israel than the Galilee or Tel Aviv.'b'From a biblical perspective, this view may be tenable. A significant amount of land, it turns out. There are roughly 1,000 factories in the chain of Israeli-administered \xe2\x80\x9cindustrial zones\xe2\x80\x9d strung across the West Bank. If workers complain, employers sometimes retaliate by fabricating a \xe2\x80\x9csecurity incident\xe2\x80\x9d that will deprive Palestinians of their work permits, according to the H.R.W. report.'b'To view goods made under these conditions as no different than products made within Israel requires going blind to such indignities.
