Under a provision of a 'b'larger piece of legislation,'b' popularly known as the Customs Bill, that has been approved by the House and is expected to soon pass the Senate, American officials will be obligated to treat the settlements as part of Israel in future trade negotiations.'b'The ostensible reason this provision was added to a bill on international trade is to combat the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement, a grass-roots campaign that seeks to pressure Israel to change its policies toward the Palestinians. But under 'b'existing law'b', Washington already forbids American companies to cooperate with state-led boycotts of Israel. Under the guise of an antiboycott provision, the Customs Bill extends similar protections to \xe2\x80\x9cIsraeli-controlled territories\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 meaning settlements. For American trade negotiators, the industrial zones dotting the occupied territories would have the same status as the high-tech industry in Tel Aviv, just as settler zealots insist.'b'This potential, and largely unnoticed, shift in American policy comes just as frustration with the stalled peace process and Israel\xe2\x80\x99s deepening grip on the occupied territories is leading to more targeted pressure on Israel\xe2\x80\x99s settlements. This month, the pension board of the United Methodist Church 'b'decided'b' that five Israeli banks that fund construction in the settlements are ineligible for its investment. In November, the European Union, Israel\xe2\x80\x99s largest trading partner, declared that products made in the occupied territories 'b'should be labeled separately 'b'from Israeli goods.'b'As the H.R.W. report makes clear, these steps are consistent with international law. Since all companies that do business in or with settlements inevitably contribute to human rights violations, they should stop. And since no country recognizes Israeli sovereignty over the occupied territories, all of Israel\xe2\x80\x99s trading partners should insist that the label \xe2\x80\x9cMade in Israel\xe2\x80\x9d be removed from products from the settlements.'b'The Palestinian Authority has described separate labeling of settlement goods as a useful step. (The authority supports boycotting these goods.) Not surprisingly, the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu disagrees. But if this provision becomes law, it will be a major victory for the Israeli right, albeit one that it may come to regret. The more the line between Israel and the occupied territories is blurred, the more likely the rest of the world will be to question the legitimacy of not just the settlements but Israel itself. In the long run, this will not prevent Israel from being depicted as a pariah state, but instead will provide powerful ammunition to those who see it as such.'b'Pay as you go: This country is no place for freeloaders.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 WHILE presidential candidates from both parties feverishly pitch their legislative agendas, voters should also consider what presidents can do without Congress. Agency rules, executive actions and decisions about how vigorously to enforce certain laws will have an impact on every American, without a single new bill introduced in Congress.'b'The Obama administration has a substantial track record on agency rules and executive actions. Its conclusion: \xe2\x80\x9cCorporate criminals routinely escape meaningful prosecution for their misconduct.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a single year, in case after case, across many sectors of the economy, federal agencies caught big companies breaking the law \xe2\x80\x94 defrauding taxpayers, covering up deadly safety problems, even precipitating the financial collapse in 2008 \xe2\x80\x94 and let them off the hook with barely a slap on the wrist. Often, companies paid meager fines, which some will try to write off as a tax deduction.'b'The failure to adequately punish big corporations or their executives when they break the law undermines the foundations of this great country. Justice cannot mean a prison sentence for a teenager who steals a car, but nothing more than a sideways glance at a C.E.O. who quietly engineers the theft of billions of dollars.'b'These enforcement failures demean our principles. They also represent missed opportunities to address some of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most pressing challenges. Consider just two areas \xe2\x80\x94 college affordability and health care \xe2\x80\x94 where robust enforcement of current law could help millions of people.'b'When the Education Management Corporation, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s second-largest for-profit college, signed up tens of thousands of students by lying about its programs, it saddled them with fraudulent degrees and huge debts. Those debts wrecked lives. Under the law, the government can bar such institutions from receiving more federal student loans. But EDMC just paid a fine and kept right on raking in federal loan money.'b'When Novartis, a major drug company that was already effectively on federal probation for misconduct, paid kickbacks to pharmacies to push certain drugs, it cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars and undermined patient health. It\xe2\x80\x99s about whether government works and who it works for. Last year, five of the world\xe2\x80\x99s biggest banks, including JPMorgan Chase, pleaded guilty to criminal charges that they rigged the price of billions of dollars worth of foreign currencies. No corporation can break the law unless people in that corporation also broke the law, but no one from any of those banks has been charged. While thousands of Americans were rotting in prison for nonviolent drug convictions, JPMorgan Chase was so chastened by pleading guilty to a crime that it awarded Jamie Dimon, its C.E.O., a 35 percent raise.'b'To be fair, weak enforcement is sometimes a result of limited authority. Despite the company\xe2\x80\x99s history of egregious safety failures, for example, the former C.E.O. of Massey Energy was convicted only of a single misdemeanor in the deadly Upper Big Branch mine disaster that killed 29 miners in West Virginia in 2010, because federal mining laws are too weak. It\xe2\x80\x99s on Congress to stiffen such penalties.'b'But in many instances, weak enforcement by federal agencies is about the people at the top. Presidents don\xe2\x80\x99t control most day-to-day enforcement decisions, but they do nominate the heads of all the agencies, and these choices make all the difference. Strong leaders at the Environmental Protection Agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Labor Department have pushed those agencies to forge ahead with powerful initiatives to protect the environment, consumers and workers. The Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, a tiny office charged with oversight of the post-crash bank bailout, has aggressive leaders \xe2\x80\x94 and a far better record of holding banks and executives accountable than its bigger counterparts.'b'Meanwhile, the Securities and Exchange Commission, suffering under weak leadership, is far behind on issuing congressionally mandated rules to avoid the next financial crisis. It has repeatedly granted waivers so that lawbreaking companies can continue to enjoy special privileges, while the Justice Department has dodged one opportunity after another to impose meaningful accountability on big corporations and their executives.'b'Each of these government divisions is headed by someone nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate. The lesson is clear: Personnel is policy.'b'Legislative agendas matter, but voters should also ask which presidential candidates they trust with the extraordinary power to choose who will fight on the front lines to enforce the laws. And if he wins on Monday, the people of Iowa will have answered him.'b'The Supreme Court had people like Taurus Buchanan in mind this week when it 'b'reinforced a 2012 decision'b' banning mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juveniles and found that people sentenced before that ruling had a constitutional right to seek parole.'b'The Buchanan case, documented in an investigation by 'b'T'b''b'he Marshall Project'b' and Mother Jones magazine, illustrates what the court meant when it found that it was morally and constitutionally wrong to equate emotionally undeveloped children with adults. This included Louisiana, where a second-degree-murder charge required that he be tried as an adult because he was over the age of 14.'b'According to the Marshall investigation, Louisiana has more juvenile offenders serving life sentences per capita than any other state. But it can release him from prison when he has a clemency hearing next month.'b'The people of Ireland have shown a commendable willingness to strike anachronistic bias from the country\xe2\x80\x99s laws, most emphatically in legalizing gay marriage last year in a referendum approved by three out of five voters. The most encouraging force in the debate is the Irish public\xe2\x80\x99s realization that their nation can no longer afford shameful religious bias to remain in the law.'b'IOWA is the nation\xe2\x80\x99s top producer of corn, and nearly half of it ends up as ethanol, thanks to a government mandate that requires ethanol to be mixed into gasoline. The mandate is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to farmers there.'b'No wonder most Iowans talk it up, as do most of the presidential candidates campaigning there in the lead up to the caucuses.'b'Ethanol thrives because of the volume-based approach of the mandate, which specifies that a growing percentage of various renewable fuels must be mixed into gasoline every year until 2022.'b'But that approach has stifled innovation and, if its track record to date is any indication, biofuels will not be a major player in meeting our 2050 targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks.'b'What we should be talking about is a performance-based approach to developing gasoline substitutes that will reduce emissions. We\xe2\x80\x99ve had much greater success using this approach and allowing the market to decide which technology works best to meet a target set by the government.'b'For instance, when the 'b'Environmental Protection Agency'b' set 2025 limits for greenhouse gas emissions for cars at half of 2008 levels, automakers were given flexibility on how to make that happen. Some companies are investing heavily in 'b'electric vehicles'b'; others are focusing on hybrids and fuel cells. So far, all have met their interim goals.'b'Not so with the ethanol mandate, which requires that 36 billion gallons of biofuels must be mixed into gasoline by 2022. Of that, about 85 percent of that blend is supposed to come from a nearly even mix of corn ethanol and cellulosics (derived from wood chips, 'b'corn stover'b', grasses and other nonedible plant parts).'b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s not what is happening. Because corn ethanol is cheap and easy to produce and was already in use as a gasoline additive before the mandate was imposed, and because existing corn ethanol plants are exempted from greenhouse gas emissions requirements, production has vastly exceeded that of cellulosic ethanol. In 2014, less than 2 percent of the mandated volume of cellulosics was produced.'b'This is a problem. At best, corn ethanol provides a 20 percent reduction in greenhouse gas pollution over gasoline, while cellulosic fuel produces an 80 percent reduction in that pollution and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t compete with food.'b'The cellulosic industry has taken much longer to get off the ground than Congress anticipated. Production of this fuel is more complex and costly and requires significant upfront investments.'b'If we could start again from zero, a performance-based standard would produce better results. Setting the standard based on how clean the fuel should be would give companies the flexibility to figure out how to reach the target.'b'This is already being done in California and Oregon, which have performance-based fuel standards. The California program, for instance, requires fuel producers to reduce greenhouse gas pollution by 10 percent in transportation fuels in 2020. Because it is technology neutral, and interested only in the result, this approach supports investments in the cleanest fuels while providing maximum flexibility to the industry to develop them.'b'Still, the existing federal fuel standard, as imperfect as it may be, is now an essential component of our efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow 'b'climate change'b'.'b'To move forward, the E.P.A. should phase in the fuel standard mandate in a predictable way to provide a growing market for advanced and cellulosic renewable fuels. We also need to shift tax policy for cellulosic fuels to support long-term investment similar to the tax policies for wind and 'b'solar power'b'. And we need several more states to adopt performance-based standards, and to support investment to encourage the development of the next generation of renewable fuels.'b'The United States needs to reduce carbon pollution from cars and trucks by 80 percent by 2050. Advances in propulsion technology alone will not be enough to meet that goal. Passenger cars will have to not only go farther on less fuel, but also travel those miles on lower-carbon fuel.'b'As the candidates continue their quest for the White House, the question should not be, as it was in Iowa, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you support the renewable fuel standard?\xe2\x80\x9d but \xe2\x80\x9cHow do we move to the next generation of renewable fuels?\xe2\x80\x9d We must demand an approach that spurs innovation and makes steady progress on lower-carbon fuels.'b'DES MOINES \xe2\x80\x94 Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s absence, of course, was the most compelling presence.'b'At the Republican debate here on Thursday night, Fox News didn\xe2\x80\x99t put up an empty lectern. Not some coherent ideology that puts the people\xe2\x80\x99s interests first, but a policy based on opportunism, on cultivating a grandiose sense of national identity and then presenting that identity as being threatened by domestic and foreign enemies. Several other wealthier European Union countries also feel their way of life and identity are threatened, and fear further unification. In Britain, an argumentative minority found a reason to exist by accusing Brussels of interfering with national sovereignty, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to risk his country\xe2\x80\x99s membership in the European Union 'b'with a referendum'b'.'b'A chasm separates the social liberalism and internationalism of Syriza from the Christian Nationalism of its right-wing partner, the Independent Greeks. When the government presented a law allowing civil partnerships of same-sex couples, it was passed with votes from Syriza and opposition parties; most Independent Greeks voted against it.'b'Yet the two parties stick together. Before their election a year ago this week, they presented themselves as patriots fighting foreigners and local elites. They built on anti-German anger in public gatherings and the media \xe2\x80\x94 where German politicians were routinely portrayed as Nazis \xe2\x80\x94 demanding reparations from Berlin and paying highly charged 'b'visits to memorials of wartime atrocities'b'. They backed a campaign of civil defiance (called 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t pay\xe2\x80\x9d'b'), arguing that it was not Greece that owed money to its creditors, but the other way around. Syriza\xe2\x80\x99s leader, Alexis Tsipras, undermined every reform effort by previous governments, promising voters that the \xe2\x80\x9cday after\xe2\x80\x9d his party\xe2\x80\x99s election he would scrap the bailout agreement, with its hated austerity and reforms.'b'Demagogues oversimplify things by making false promises and excessive accusations. They \xe2\x80\x94 and, through them, their supporters \xe2\x80\x94 are always in the right, no matter how mixed up reality may be. At the same time, they complicate things needlessly, often employing primitive conspiracy theories so that no one can understand what must be done.'b'In Greece, the populist narrative was that the local and foreign elites ran up huge debts that the citizens were then forced to pay through reduced incomes, higher taxes and unemployment. Instead of noting that the Greek state was spending beyond its means and had to be reformed, Syriza argued that simply by voting for it, citizens could end the pain, and all the measures of the past few years would be reversed.'b'Technicalities \xe2\x80\x94 European Union regulations regarding the rule of law, the possible suspension of loans, the fact that the European Central Bank could withhold 'b'emergency funding'b' \xe2\x80\x94 were depicted as machinations aimed at undermining the pure patriots in power.'b'The argument was so convincing that even after the coalition government was forced to default on the International Monetary Fund, 'b'close Greece\xe2\x80\x99s banks'b', impose controls on the movement of capital and then accept the terms of an onerous new bailout with creditors, the two parties were 'b'returned to power'b' in snap elections last September. Anyone in Brussels or Berlin who thinks that Warsaw, Budapest or any other member state\xe2\x80\x99s capital will give in to pressure on issues they see as pertaining to national sovereignty need only look at how far the Greeks were prepared to go before capitulating, and how the voters stayed with them.'b'This kind of populism makes partnerships extremely difficult. It creates a climate of suspicion and ill will. In Greece, the more our partners and creditors press for compliance with the bailout agreements, the more they are seen as impinging on our sovereignty, stoking further resistance. At the same time, Greek reluctance or inability to achieve something is seen as a direct affront to its partners.'b'We noted this in the economy; now we see it in the refugee crisis. Greece is accused \xe2\x80\x94 simplistically \xe2\x80\x94 of not stopping the influx. Some of them, however, are also opposed to a German-inspired plan to spread refugees among all European Union members, prompting Germans to feel they have been left in the lurch. The end of civility among members is contagious. Scapegoating Greece helps gloss over this problem \xe2\x80\x94 another populist trick.'b'Populist demagogy is a highly effective way of gaining power and consolidating it. Playing the people against elites, dividing citizens into patriots and quislings, seeing the world as \xe2\x80\x9cus versus them\xe2\x80\x9d and oversimplifying issues in a complex, pluralistic world provide the illusion of national determination and an outlet for public anger.'b'But however effective populism is in domestic politics, it\xe2\x80\x99s a dead end: Countries that give in to its charms cannot find the strength to reform, and are alone when facing the problems that inspired their inward turn in the first place. In Greece, a rising wave of anger at inevitable reforms signals the failure of easy promises. In the globalized world, economic competitiveness, climate change, mass migration, terrorism and other challenges can only be dealt with collectively \xe2\x80\x94 no matter how much any nation, party or citizen may feel that isolation is an option.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 When America catches a cold, Britain sneezes \xe2\x80\x94 eventually. The argument about the proper limits of free speech and \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical correctness\xe2\x80\x9d that has raged for years on American campuses has arrived at British universities with a vengeance.'b'Here, the fate of one statue in Oxford has become the focus of fierce debate.'b'The stone figure of Cecil Rhodes, the mining magnate who gave his name to the southern African state of Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, has graced the facade of Oriel College since before World War I. In addition, the university has a Rhodes professorship of race relations and every year admits a phalanx of talented young people from abroad, 'b'including'b' 32 Americans, on Rhodes scholarships. (Bill Clinton, George Stephanopoulos, Bobby Jindal and Susan Rice are all alumni.)'b'Now, though, a campaign calling itself \xe2\x80\x9cRhodes Must Fall\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 one of whose founders, ironically, is a Rhodes scholar from South Africa, Ntokozo Qwabe \xe2\x80\x94 has demanded the statue\xe2\x80\x99s removal. In 1933, the Oxford Union debating society caused a scandal by 'b'supporting'b' the motion \xe2\x80\x9cthat this House will in no circumstances fight for its King and Country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More recently, in 2000, Gordon Brown, who was then the chancellor of the Exchequer, 'b'drew'b' national attention to Oxford\xe2\x80\x99s failure to offer a place to a state school pupil, Laura Spence, in spite of her superb grades. Those leaders, to be sure, had other motives: the colonial impulse to claim land for their countries or the goal of doing science. But what drove them to the edge of survival was the unquenchable urge to discover what was there. At the time, Antarctica was a virtual blank on the map.'b'Today, the continent has been completely mapped. Adventurers strive for \xe2\x80\x9cfirsts\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 fastest times from A to B, or long-distance treks with a minimum of support. The goal is not discovery, but setting records.'b'Jaded observers lament the extinction of all blanks on the map of the earth. Their gloom, however, is unwarranted. True exploration is alive and well today.'b'Henry Worsley\xe2\x80\x99s solo journey was a grueling and perilous one, as he faced the daily threat of hidden crevasses and violent storms that could trap him in his tent. It was a feat of uncommon endurance, as he hauled a sledge that initially weighed more than 300 pounds for 71 days across 913 miles of snow and ice. But he followed a well-planned course across 'b'terra cognita'b'. Nothing he found was new.'b'The trend toward record setting has overtaken what used to be called exploration. Climbers ascend the highest peaks on each continent faster than anybody else before them. Wingsuit fliers strive for record times aloft. Transocean rowers vie to cover the greatest distance possible.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s polar adventurers, moreover, inevitably hedge the risk with constant communication to support teams ready to come to their rescue. Mr. Worsley sent his message of resignation to the world via satellite phone, quoting Shackleton, who had lamented having \xe2\x80\x9cshot his bolt\xe2\x80\x9d before reaching the South Pole. But in 1909, when Shackleton and his men turned around, they had no one but themselves to count on to get back to their base camp. In 1912, Scott and his four companions died in a storm on their desperate return journey.'b'Mr. Worsley\xe2\x80\x99s call started an airlift rescue. He died not on the ice, but in a hospital in southern Chile when doctors could not reverse a fatal bout of peritonitis. His death was reported last week.'b'These epic efforts at \xe2\x80\x9cfirsts\xe2\x80\x9d seem to have obscured the true exploration that is taking place around the globe. Cavers are in the middle of their own golden age, as the deepest and largest underground grottoes remain undiscovered. In serious caving, there are no hourly communications by satellite phone, no rescues by plane or helicopter. No wonder, then, that the best cavers are uninterested in speed records or endurance feats per se. They\xe2\x80\x99re busy trying to find out what lies underground.'b'The 'b'cenotes of Yucat\xc3\xa1n'b', still mostly unexplored, have galvanized some of the best cave divers to prowl through these nightmarish subterranean labyrinths. Cave diving is arguably the most dangerous pursuit in terrestrial adventure today.'b'The world\xe2\x80\x99s most unnavigable rivers also await their first descents. Rafters have yet to brave, for instance, the headwaters of the Heilongjiang or Songhuajiang Rivers in China. I was privileged to participate in the first (and to this date, only) attempt to raft the Tua and Purari Rivers in Papua New Guinea in 1983. Our party turned back in the face of what looked like suicidal rapids far short of the river\xe2\x80\x99s terminus.'b'In terms of mountaineering, the news media tends to focus ad nauseam on Everest. Yet there are scores of unclimbed peaks in Alaska, Greenland and western China. Just last fall, two of the world\xe2\x80\x99s best climbers, Conrad Anker and David Lama, threw themselves at Lunag Ri, an unclimbed peak on the border of Nepal and Tibet. Extreme cold and fiendish granite walls thwarted their boldest efforts. The world\xe2\x80\x99s highest unclimbed peak, the 24,830-foot Gangkhar Puensum, is protected by Bhutan\xe2\x80\x99s ban on climbing on the country\xe2\x80\x99s sacred mountains.'b'Climbers, like cavers and river runners, don\xe2\x80\x99t worry about whether their quests are \xe2\x80\x9cuseful.\xe2\x80\x9d It is the pursuit of knowledge and adventure that animates them.'b'No part of the globe is more unexplored than the depths of the great oceans. The Mariana Trench in the western Pacific enfolds a slot-shaped valley more than 36,000 feet below the surface, the deepest point known on earth. Daring probes in 1960 and 2012 delivered divers to the bottom in deep-sea submersibles. Yet most of the trench still remains a mystery. Alas, exploration in the crushing ocean depths may belong more to remote-controlled submersibles than to human explorers.'b'All the same, the last unknown corners of the earth await discovery. But so is the solution \xe2\x80\x94 and it deserves mention.'b'SANJAY RAWAL'b'New York'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Pardon Problem'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 27):'b'Removing the clemency process from the Justice Department would solve part of the president\xe2\x80\x99s pardon problem, but he needs to take a second step.'b'Clemency is ill suited to deal with the systemic issue that concerns him, which is that thousands of federal prisoners are serving sentences far longer than would be imposed today. The courts are institutionally in the best position to handle sentence reductions on a large scale, and there is authority for them to do it under current law.'b'The United States Sentencing Commission will hold a hearing next month to consider whether courts should make broader use of the so-called compassionate-release law, which until now has been used only rarely.'b'The president should send his attorney general to this hearing with a clear message: The federal courts should step up to the job of modifying long sentences, and federal prosecutors will help them do it.'b'MARGARET COLGATE LOVE'b'Washington'b''b'The writer, the United States pardon attorney from 1990 to 1997 under Presidents George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton, represents applicants for executive clemency.'b''b'Europe\xe2\x80\x99s current refugee crisis is often presented as a quantity problem: There are simply too many migrants for the European Union to absorb. But this situation is not without historical precedent. Europe has accepted large numbers of immigrants before. The issue this time is political. It has little to do with the absolute numbers of asylum seekers. The problem lies with the European Union\xe2\x80\x99s dysfunctional asylum system, which encourages countries to pass refugees on like hot potatoes, and places the burden of registering and processing asylum seekers on a small number of countries on the Union\xe2\x80\x99s border.'b'An intractable gridlock prevents a common response. On the one end of the spectrum stands Germany\xe2\x80\x99s chancellor, Angela Merkel, who has stated that \xe2\x80\x9cthe right to political asylum [has] no limits on the number of asylum seekers.\xe2\x80\x9d On the other extreme are some European leaders who refuse to grant asylum to any claimants, however small the numbers. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only way to eliminate risks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia, is to steer away from \xe2\x80\x9cany decision that could lead to the emergence of a compact Muslim community in Slovakia.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'However, unless the European Union arrives at a unified response, the border controls now dividing Schengen countries will remain, leaving a permanent dent in the European construction. But there are ways out of this seemingly desperate situation.'b'For one, the quota system, proposed by the European Commission, could be made flexible. In 1997, the Yale University legal scholar Peter Schuck proposed a system of tradable refugee quotas. The European Union would still have to agree on the total number of migrants to whom it is willing to grant asylum, and on how they would be distributed among the member states. But the quota market would allow countries such as Slovakia or Hungary, whose leaders refuse to accept any refugees, to \xe2\x80\x9cbribe\xe2\x80\x9d others to carry their obligations on their behalf, putting a concrete price tag on the unwillingness of Central Europeans to help.'b'If such a market with refugees appears dehumanizing, consider that some version of it already exists between Europeans and Turkey. In November, the European Union promised Turkey 3 billion euros in aid, alongside various political favors, in exchange for Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to keep refugees from fleeing to Europe.'b'But an explicit market in refugee quotas is not the only possible fix to the current crisis, according to two researchers at the University of Oxford, Alex Teytelboym and Will Jones. To bring the chaotic influx of refugees under control, the European Union could also create a centralized \xe2\x80\x9cmatching system,\xe2\x80\x9d which would involve none of the cash payments that are often seen as repugnant. Originally developed by economists such as the Nobel Laureate Alvin E. Roth, matching systems are used to allocate kidney donors to patients (the New England Program for Kidney Exchange) or to match medical students with hospital residency programs (the National Resident Matching Program).'b'From the standpoint of the refugees \xe2\x80\x94 most of whom arrive in Greece or Italy \xe2\x80\x94 the appeal of pushing further into the European Union lies in the fact that they are forced into a lottery by being able to apply for asylum in only one European Union country. In contrast, a matching system would offer Syrian refugees in Turkey and elsewhere a route to asylum in the European Union in which getting to a particular country (say, Germany) would be much less important. Applicants would rank European Union countries by order of preference and submit that ordering to a central clearinghouse.'b'Some countries, such as Germany or Sweden, would likely remain oversubscribed. But because applicants would be submitting a complete ordering of European Union countries they are applying for, they could still be matched with, say, their second, or third choice, instead of being rejected outright.'b'The European Union member states would in turn specify how many and what refugees they are willing to accept. Earlier in 2015, some European governments, including that of Mr. Fico, expressed interest in accepting refugees \xe2\x80\x94 as long as they were Christian. In principle, the matching system could accommodate such preferences, in addition to less controversial ones, concerning education, skills or languages spoken.'b'Unlike the quota system proposed by the European Commission, the matching system would neither coerce countries to take in refugees against their will, nor would it require an European Union-wide agreement over the total number of asylum slots offered by the Union. Instead, countries would be free to determine the minimum and maximum numbers of asylums they are willing to grant.'b'Some countries, such as Hungary or Slovakia, could even choose to free ride and not accept any refugees without necessarily jeopardizing the matching mechanism. Of course, the numbers would have to add to a meaningfully large figure for the system to provide an alternative to illicit migration to the European Union.'b'Governments would not just control the numbers but also the characteristics of refugees that they want to accept, which would place them firmly in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s seat. As a result, the mechanism would limit the space for political grandstanding and for populist backlashes of the kind seen across Europe last year. Those reactions were largely results of the quota system being perceived as an inflexible, top-down imposition of an unaccountable European elite.'b'The matching system is not magic. It would not solve the conflict in Syria, nor would it relieve Europeans of their humanitarian duties toward asylum seekers fleeing the conflict. But it would be a marked improvement over the status quo. It would provide the European Union with a tool that would enable it to deal collectively with the refugee crisis of the current magnitude, in spite of substantial differences in opinion existing among its members, and without setting in motion the centrifugal forces that risk destroying the European project altogether.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 All the world\xe2\x80\x99s seas are bedeviled by global warming, pollution and overfishing, but the Mediterranean and the 20-plus nations that ring it face another threat: A rising flood of invasive marine species flowing through the Suez Canal.'b'On Aug. 6, 2015, over the objections of environmentalists and the reservations of many economists, the canal\xe2\x80\x99s latest expansion opened to shipping. The new 22-mile channel will double the canal\xe2\x80\x99s capacity, allowing 97 ships to pass through each day. It also opens a wider path for invasive species from the Indian and Pacific Oceans to flood through the Red Sea into the Mediterranean.'b'Once they\xe2\x80\x99re in, there\xe2\x80\x99s no way to get them out, and the changes they bring are irreversible. Israeli scientists have identified more than 450 alien species of fish, invertebrates and algae that are not part of the Mediterranean\xe2\x80\x99s natural ecosystem. Several pose public health hazards, while others threaten fisheries and tourism and denude underwater ecosystems, greatly reducing biodiversity.'b'Egyptian authorities say the $8.5 billion project will reduce bottlenecks and increase toll revenue from $5.3 billion to $13.2 billion a year by 2023. But these benefits come at the cost of continuing environmental degradation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe recent doubling of the canal will decimate coastal ecosystems with dire implications for the regional economy and human health. We can\xe2\x80\x99t continue to overlook this threat,\xe2\x80\x9d warns Dr. Bella Galil, a senior scientist at Israel\xe2\x80\x99s National Institute of Oceanography.'b'It can take generations, she says, for an alien species to expand its range. The presence of Red Sea fish in the Levant Basin, for example, was not recorded until 1902, more than three decades after the canal first opened in 1869. Subsequent waves have followed major canal expansions in 1980 and in 2010. The eastern Mediterranean, mere miles from the canal\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, has been hardest hit, and experts from Turkey, Cyprus, Greece, Israel and Lebanon say this invasion has drastically altered fisheries.'b'In the 1970s, according to Dr. Dor Edelist, a marine ecologist at the University of Haifa, invasive species constituted 21 percent of Israeli trawler catch; today, more than half are alien. In the first decade of this century, Israel\xe2\x80\x99s Mediterranean fishery brought in $14 million to $26 million a year. Today, it\xe2\x80\x99s about $16 million, of which $6 million to $10 million are invasive species. Some are edible, like the goldband goatfish, but it has replaced the native species, red mullet. Gone too are native food fish like European hake and porgies. Turkish and Lebanese fisheries report similar losses.'b'Putting a precise figure on the economic impact is difficult. Standard commercial fisheries statistics tell how much fish is caught and sold, but fishermen are notorious for underreporting their catch. And no one is tracking the economic loss from season to season as commercial species collapse or as environmental degradation reduces tourism.'b'Three alien species have been particularly destructive. Rabbit fish have devoured algal forests, leaving wide areas of bare rock and undermining the complex ecosystems of the Levant Basin.'b'A more recent arrival is the poisonous silverside puffer fish, native to the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Puffer fish eat 20 percent to 33 percent of fish caught on long-line hooks and often chew through a trawler\xe2\x80\x99s nets, according to Aylin Ulman, a doctoral student at the University of Pavia, who studies Turkish fisheries. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere gill nets used to last 15 years, puffer fish cause so much damage that nets have to be replaced in just a few months,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. Researchers say Greek fishermen face the same issues in the Aegean and off Crete. Among other prey, they devour such staple foods as squid, octopus and cuttlefish. Off the coast of Cyprus, the octopus catch has plummeted from 175 tons per year in 2001 to below 50 tons in 2009, according to the Sea Around Us, an environmental fisheries program run by the University of British Columbia.'b'Another voracious and painfully venomous predator, the nomad jellyfish, entered the Mediterranean in the 1970s. Now they form large swarms every summer, washing up on shores, endangering beachgoers and divers, blocking the water-intake pipes of power and desalinization plants. Swarms have reached the Straits of Sicily and are endangering Atlantic bluefin tuna eggs, threatening a fishery already on the verge of collapse.'b'Though we can\xe2\x80\x99t remove invasive species, we do have the engineering expertise to stem the migration. The Panama Canal, which opened to shipping in 1914, offers an example of what might be accomplished. It operates a series of locks that function like sets of double doors, allowing ships to pass while making it more difficult for alien species to follow. Moreover, the fresh water of Gatun Lake, which forms a major part of the canal complex, provides a 21-mile barrier that impedes the migration of most saltwater species.'b'The Suez Canal once had its own salinity barrier, known as the Bitter Lakes. Previous expansions and agricultural wastewater dumped into the canal flushed it away, but recreating it could be cost-effective. Installing locks for the Suez Canal, located in a much simpler physical environment than the mountainous Panamanian region, should be easier and less costly than the $3.2 billion the Panama authorities expect to pay for modernized lock equipment.'b'Scientists and environmentalists have appealed to the European Commission to install locks and salinity barriers in the Suez Canal and have requested an environmental impact assessment. Despite Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s assurances that the information would be provided by May, European Union officials say they have still not received a definitive report. But in discussions last October conducted by the United Nations Environment Program, the Egyptians reportedly said they would not sign an updated United Nations Mediterranean Action Plan unless language stating that invasive species are coming through the Suez Canal was removed. The MAP draft decision, with the language regarding the Suez Canal in brackets, goes to the Barcelona Convention for the Protection of the Mediterranean for review in February.'b'Observers say that Brussels doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to lean too hard on Egypt because President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is cooperating in dealing with the refugee crisis. Many European Union member states with their own national interests in the Mediterranean see the Suez expansion as a sovereign decision by the Egyptian government and are loath to interfere.'b'But Egypt and its neighbors are losing sight of the big picture. For Egypt, with its large underemployed population, managing the fishing industry more wisely would employ more people and have greater long-term economic benefits than building expensive canal infrastructure that is vulnerable to a volatile global economy.'b'So, how can these competing interests be resolved? The problem may require new ideas and neutral leadership. In the mid-2000s, overfishing and environmental degradation was ruining fisheries off California. The Nature Conservancy bought up boats and licenses and leased these back to fishermen willing to employ more sustainable methods and use reporting software to help the NGO develop baseline data on the fishing stocks themselves. The result: Local fishermen are still fishing, and fish stocks are coming back. The program has been copied by several New England fisheries.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s surely a creative solution for the Mediterranean\xe2\x80\x99s problems, and the place to start is by rebuilding salinity barriers in the Suez Canal. As we become more aware of the risks to our planet, we must remember that human beings, by nature, are not only competitive \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99re also cooperative.'b'DES MOINES \xe2\x80\x94 IN the final, furious days of campaigning here, it was sometimes hard to tell whether this state\xe2\x80\x99s Republicans were poised to vote for a president or a preacher, a commander or a crusader.'b'The references to religion were expansive. It is our century\xe2\x80\x99s great unfinished business.'b'THE Virgin Mary, the mother of Jesus, is the most revered woman in the Christian tradition. In the history of art, she appears almost as frequently as Jesus himself. But for the past 80 years, one of the oldest paintings of her may have been hiding in plain sight.'b'At the Yale University Art Gallery hang wall paintings from one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s oldest churches. Buried by the middle of the third century, this house-church from eastern Syria had images of Jesus, Peter and David. The gallery showcases a well-preserved procession of veiled women that once surrounded its baptistery, a room for Christian initiation.'b'Off to the side, seldom noticed among the likes of Jesus and Peter, stands a different wall fragment, faded but still discernible: a woman bent over a well. Holding the rope of her vessel, she looks out at the viewer or perhaps over her shoulder, seemingly startled in the act of drawing water.'b'Who is she? The museum\xe2\x80\x99s identification is certainly plausible: \xe2\x80\x9cThe painting most likely depicts a scene from the encounter between Christ (not shown) and a woman from Samaria,\xe2\x80\x9d as recorded in the Gospel of John. But historians also know that the Samaritan Woman, a repentant sinner who conversed at length with Jesus, was usually depicted in dialogue with him. This woman appears to be alone.'b'Is it possible that a painting from a building excavated in 1932 and publicized around the world has not been correctly identified? These murals come from the eastern frontier of the Roman Empire, a military outpost variously called \xe2\x80\x9cDura\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cEuropos\xe2\x80\x9d in antiquity.'b'Perched high above the Euphrates in the region that is now called Deir ez-Zor, the ruins of Dura-Europos have yielded more distinct artifacts than almost any other ancient archaeological site: an intact Roman shield, a lavishly painted synagogue, a temple to the gods of nearby Palmyra. It is the \xe2\x80\x9cPompeii of the Syrian desert,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Michael Rostovtzeff, director of Yale\xe2\x80\x99s excavations at the site.'b'But no Vesuvius buried this Pompeii. Portions of Dura-Europos were buried intentionally, to bolster a rampart against a 'b'Sasanian'b' army invading from the east in the 250s. The misfortune of the Roman garrison, which lost the battle, would become good fortune for historians. The earthen rampart sealed cross-sections of many buildings, including the house-church, so that both contents and date were secure.'b'The church\xe2\x80\x99s painted baptistery remains a unique discovery. Outside of funerary contexts, such as the catacombs in Rome, there are precious few Christian paintings from before Emperor Constantine\xe2\x80\x99s conversion to Christianity in the fourth century. These also offer a glimpse into the beliefs and rituals of Syrian Christians, a community currently in peril.'b'While the Samaritan Woman at the Well was a respected biblical figure for early Christians, there was actually a more prominent \xe2\x80\x9cwoman at the well\xe2\x80\x9d in Syria: the Virgin Mary during the Annunciation, when an angelic visitor informed her of her miraculous pregnancy. Where does this episode take place? The setting of the canonical account, in the Gospel of Luke, is not specified. But the second-century biography of Mary\xe2\x80\x99s early life, usually called the Protevangelium of James, describes how one day, during a break from her work, \xe2\x80\x9cshe took the pitcher and went forth to draw water, and behold, a voice said: \xe2\x80\x98Hail, you are highly favored, the Lord is with you, blessed are you among women.\xe2\x80\x99 And she looked around on the right and on the left to see from where this voice could have come.\xe2\x80\x9d During this first encounter, at a well or spring, the angel was heard but not seen. Mary appeared to be alone.'b'Most people, when they imagine the Annunciation, have in mind some western Renaissance masterpiece: a studious, cloistered Mary welcoming the angel from the comfort of home. But Byzantine images of the scene, though coming centuries later than the figure from Dura-Europos, bear an arresting formal resemblance to it. The brilliant illumination in James of Kokkinobaphos\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHomilies on the Virgin\xe2\x80\x9d and the grand mosaic from the Byzantine monastery at Chora in Istanbul both demonstrate the importance in eastern Christianity of placing Mary at the well. Some manuscripts even depict this type among illuminations of the Gospel of Luke itself, showing that artists preferred the evocative iconographic traditions of the noncanonical text over the unspecified setting of the canonical one. At Chora, Mary\xe2\x80\x99s figure can also be contrasted with the portrayal of the Samaritan Woman in the same church, who looks across a well at a pictured Jesus.'b'The woman at Dura-Europos has yet more secrets to reveal. Archival photographs and drawings made by the archaeologists on site show that the supposed absence behind the female figure is not totally silent \xe2\x80\x94 it speaks a couple of lines. That is to say, a field sketch of the wall done \xe2\x80\x9cto show additional details\xe2\x80\x9d depicts two painted lines touching the woman\xe2\x80\x99s back, along with a kind of starburst on the front of her torso, features described as \xe2\x80\x9cunexplained\xe2\x80\x9d in the archaeological report. But with the new interpretation of the figure, in connection with the Eastern iconography that came later, the lines invite a rather evident meaning. They appear to represent a motion toward the woman\xe2\x80\x99s body and a spark of activity within it, as if something invisible were approaching and entering her \xe2\x80\x94 an incarnation.'b'If correct, this woman at a well is the oldest securely datable image of the Virgin Mary. Devotees of the Roman catacombs may demur, since a few female figures there are often presented as Mary. But these are challenging to date with certainty, and many scholars argue that the proposed examples have insufficiently specific iconographic signifiers.'b'Identifying the oldest image of Mary isn\xe2\x80\x99t an end in itself. Reidentifying this woman helps us to ponder anew the distinctive emphases of early Christians in Syria, who in this baptistery celebrated salvation through images of marriage, pregnancy and birth \xe2\x80\x94 as much or more than through participation in a ritualized death. This is not to undermine the power of Jesus\xe2\x80\x99 passion and resurrection accounts, but rather to rebalance the perspective of modern Western viewers, looking back after centuries of art focused on the cross. In the extant art from Dura-Europos, we see the hope of new spiritual birth, but the death of Christ is not pictured once.'b'Today the paintings from this church are safe. But further opportunities to understand early Syrian Christianity are slipping away, as the archaeological sites of Deir ez-Zor are being systematically plundered under the auspices of the Islamic State. According to satellite images and reports from the ground, the looting pits at Dura-Europos are innumerable. Even while the human tragedy of the refugee crisis justifiably occupies our attention, the destruction of cultural heritage tells a parallel narrative.'b'Images from this ancient Syrian church are thus much more than museum pieces. They illuminate a people and heritage that need salvation \xe2\x80\x94 and not the kind of salvation found in a baptistery.'b'ONE of the puzzles of the 2016 campaign, unexpectedly defined by the ascent of a billionaire reality TV star and a septuagenarian Vermont socialist, is 'b'why now? 'b'Yes, voters are angry, yes, they\xe2\x80\x99re exhausted and disgusted and cynical about everything. A society disillusioned with existing religions and ideologies, but lacking new sources of meaning to take their place.'b'This is how many Americans, many Westerners, experience their civilization in the early years of the 21st century. And both Trump and Bernie Sanders, in their very different ways, are telling us that we don\xe2\x80\x99t have to settle for it anymore.'b'With Trump, the message is crude, explicit, deliberately over the top. 'b'Make America Great Again'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will have so much winning if I get elected that you may get bored with the winning.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But it resonates because the diagnosis resonates \xe2\x80\x94 especially with older Americans, who grew up amid the post-World War II boom, the vaulting optimism of the space age, the years when big government and big business were seen as effective and patriotic rather than sclerotic and corrupt. Trump is offering nostalgia, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not a true reactionary\xe2\x80\x99s lament. He wants to take us back to a time when the 'b'future'b' seemed great, amazing, fantastic.'b'Likewise Sanders, except that in his case the glorious future is more midcentury Scandinavia than space age America. After Obamacare became law it seemed to many people that the welfare state project was 'b'basically complete,'b' that the future of American liberalism mostly involved tweaking entitlements around the edges to keep them solvent. But Sanders is telling liberals, younger liberals especially, that the heroic age of liberalism isn\xe2\x80\x99t over yet, that they can have a welfare state that\xe2\x80\x99s far more amazing and fantastic than the one their forefathers constructed.'b'The fact that both of these messages \xe2\x80\x94 Trump\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cMake America great again\xe2\x80\x9d and Bernie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not socialism?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 involve essentially recycled visions of the future is a sign of how hard it is for a decadent society to escape the trap of repetition.'b'But more important, the fact that both men are promising the implausible or the impossible \xe2\x80\x94 and the fact that Trump is openly contemptuous of our ragged republican norms \xe2\x80\x94 is a reminder that there are worse things than decadence, grimmer possibilities for the future than drift and repetition.'b'The disappointment and impatience that people feel in a decadent era is legitimate, even admirable. But the envy of more heroic moments, the desire to just 'b'do something 'b'to prove your society\xe2\x80\x99s vitality \xe2\x80\x94 Invade Iraq to remake the Middle East! Open Germany\xe2\x80\x99s borders! Elect Trump or Sanders president! \xe2\x80\x94 can be a very dangerous sensibility.'b'There are pathways up from decadence. But there are more roads leading down.'b'Rutland, Vt. \xe2\x80\x94 BERNIE SANDERS gained his largest margin of victory as a member of the House of Representatives the same year that Vermont experienced its fiercest conservative backlash. In the wake of a bruising fight over civil unions in 2000, Republicans regained the Vermont House and gave the popular Democratic governor, Howard Dean, his severest test.'b'The independent socialist candidate for Congress won 69 percent of the vote, and in that result is the paradox of Bernie Sanders.'b'This state was having a grass-roots upheaval that year. The landscape filled with signs, in ominous black print, demanding that voters \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Take Back Vermont'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Letters to the editor flooded the state\xe2\x80\x99s newspapers repudiating the first step toward same-sex marriage. And Mr. Sanders, a supporter of civil unions, but not yet of marriage, overwhelmed his opposition.'b'John L. Franco Jr., a longtime Sanders ally, says Vermont is an \xe2\x80\x9coff-the-grid\xe2\x80\x9d state and Bernie Sanders has always been an off-the-grid politician. Now, somewhat improbably, Mr. Sanders is taking that off-the-grid strategy to the biggest grid there is: a quest for the White House. How well will what works in Vermont translate?'b'Bernie Sanders arrived in our state as part of an influx of newcomers who brought with them an abundance of new energy and new ideas. The newcomers included Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, of future ice cream fame, and a young doctor named Howard Dean.'b'Mr. Sanders brought with him ideas about economic justice and the interests of ordinary people. His speeches from the 1970s are little different from those he is delivering today.'b'He shocked Vermont and won national attention in 1981 when he was first elected mayor of Burlington. It is the state\xe2\x80\x99s largest city, though with only 42,000 people today it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to call it large. The old Democratic Party establishment dominated its politics. Mr. Sanders was long associated with a raffish antiwar party called Liberty Union. He won by 10 votes, and the avowed socialist took office as mayor the same year that Ronald Reagan began his presidency.'b'As mayor he trained his anti-establishment ideas on specific city problems, so he seemed less ideological and more of a pragmatist.'b'Today, Mr. Sanders is being cast as the idealist in the Democratic primary, and it\xe2\x80\x99s unclear how much importance will be \xe2\x80\x94 or should be \xe2\x80\x94 attached to his record as a hard-nosed mayor. It\xe2\x80\x99s one thing to push a tax package past the merchants of Burlington and quite another to take on the vast forces arrayed in Washington.'b'Garrison Nelson, who has been a political-science professor at the University of Vermont since 1968, says Mr. Sanders always oriented toward the interests of individual workers. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s an evangelical leftist,\xe2\x80\x9d Professor Nelson says.'b'From the beginning, that set him apart from the old-school Democrats who dominated Vermont\xe2\x80\x99s small cities \xe2\x80\x94 Barre, Winooski, Rutland \xe2\x80\x94 where Italian, French-Canadian, Irish and Polish immigrants had come to work in the mills and quarries. By 'b'running for mayor'b', he challenged the old boys\xe2\x80\x99 network that supported the incumbent Democrat, Gordon Paquette, alienating the party for years.'b'Later, when he decided to run for Congress, he knew he had to broaden his appeal. Vincent Illuzzi, a Republican state senator for 32 years, represented two counties in the Northeast Kingdom, the state\xe2\x80\x99s poorest, remotest region, where voters are more conservative. He says that over the years Mr. Sanders has spent more time there than any other member of Vermont\xe2\x80\x99s congressional delegation.'b'When Mr. Sanders showed up, he talked about how the banks or the cable companies were ripping people off, how the government was letting veterans down. He was there to help workers in their bid to unionize the local furniture mill.'b'He was not there to push same-sex marriage, and he was not going to emphasize those environmental issues that might cost a logger his job. And he definitely was not going to argue for gun control among voters who depended on their rifles to put meat on the table.'b'If Mr. Sanders had come across as a liberal, he would not have done as well as he did among voters in the Northeast Kingdom. For his first victory as mayor, he benefited from divisions among Democrats that stole votes from the incumbent.'b'He ran for Congress in 1988 against Vermont\xe2\x80\x99s Republican lieutenant governor, Peter Smith, and a Democratic legislator who failed to mount an effective challenge. Mr. Sanders ended up as a strong second-place finisher.'b'By 1990 Mr. Sanders was ready to take on Mr. Smith again, and Democratic opponents essentially opted out. Mr. Sanders won 56 percent of the vote.'b'Mr. Sanders practices the same personal politics that other politicians do. His is a well-known face not just in the Northeast Kingdom, but at Labor Day picnics and Memorial Day parades around the state, marching among the horse-drawn floats.'b'In Vermont, Mr. Sanders draws support from across the political spectrum. Peter Shumlin'b'.'b'Many Vermonters who take satisfaction in Mr. Sanders\xe2\x80\x99s progressive message may also wonder whether his single-minded focus on economic inequality and his relative narrowness of experience would make him a good president.'b'For Mr. Franco, his success thus far is a result, in part, of the fact that working-class voters tend to respond positively to a strong personality.'b'The 2016 race features no shortage of strong personalities. But White House officials have taken to what a report in this newspaper recently called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'linguistic contortions'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to obscure the forces\xe2\x80\x99 combat roles.'b'As the military as a whole downsizes, Special Ops recruitment continues to rise. There are approximately 70,000 Special Ops personnel today, a number that includes soldiers, civilians, National Guard and Reservists, as well. This number is up from 45,600 in 2001 and 61,400 in 2011. Still, Adm. William H. McRaven \xe2\x80\x94 then the head of Socom \xe2\x80\x94 told Congress in 2014 that \xe2\x80\x9cthe force has continued to fray\xe2\x80\x9d from the endless deployment cycles. In response, the Army alone last year put out a call for 5,000 new Special Ops candidates.'b'In the political sense, the policy works. The secrecy surrounding Special Ops keeps the heavy human costs of war off the front pages. But in doing so, it also keeps the nonmilitary public wholly disconnected from the armed violence carried out in our name. It enables our state of perpetual warfare, and ensures that as little as we care and understand today, we\xe2\x80\x99ll care and understand even less tomorrow.'b'Special Operations are not a panacea. Just as SWAT teams can\xe2\x80\x99t fulfill their purpose without everyday beat cops on corners, operators can\xe2\x80\x99t and don\xe2\x80\x99t function in a vacuum. Many a military analyst has compared our current \xe2\x80\x9ccounterterror\xe2\x80\x9d approach to a Band-Aid; while effective, that effectiveness has no clear end state. And recent history suggests an overreliance on our commandos can lead to tragedy. In 1993, in Somalia, Special Operations seemed a cure-all, too. Then came the battle of Mogadishu. Same with 1980 and Operation Eagle Claw, as we desperately tried to end the Iran hostage crisis. The former led to a short-lived retreat from international intervention, the latter to the very creation of Socom.'b'Further, like a postmodern Praetorian Guard, our operators don\xe2\x80\x99t serve at the will of the American people. Though Congress holds the purse strings for Special Operations, decisions about individual missions are not generally put before them for approval. Individual force commanders overwhelmingly make those calls. While Mr. Obama has proved cautious in authorizing their use, the next commander in chief might not be so prudent.'b'Clear away the smoke and romance, and Special Ops often function as highly trained kill squads sent out into the beyond in the name of country. They are the best there is at that. But this strategy ensures a recurring cycle of armed conflict, a decision of such significance that all citizens need to be weighing it and considering it, not just a select few.'b'My own experience with Special Ops is mixed. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have many positive encounters with them overseas. As part of the fabled surge in Iraq, my scout platoon and I patrolled a rural town north of Baghdad for 15 months on a counterinsurgency mission that often seemed to conflict with that of the operators.'b'IN early 2008 we were called to a farm to help pick up the pieces after a commando raid. A tribal leader claimed that two of his lieutenants had been taken by mistake by \xe2\x80\x9cthe other Americans, the ones with helicopters.\xe2\x80\x9d Those other Americans, the tribal leader told me, said that the two Iraqis were brothers, and members of Al Qaeda in Iraq. Now we were left to explain to the men\xe2\x80\x99s family why they were gone, why their house had been cycloned, and why a placard of Mecca had been torn from a wall, and receive the hard stares from those men\xe2\x80\x99s children as we stood over a dead pet dog that had been shot during the raid.'b'I didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell that story to our dinner companions, though. Instead I talked about a visit I made to Tacoma, Wash., in 2011, when I got to know the other side of these other Americans. I\xe2\x80\x99d left the military and was now a writer, or trying to be one. A college friend and his Ranger unit were returning from Afghanistan, and I had visions of writing a tale of young men constantly at war but in between battles.'b'The Rangers, the Special Ops unit that Pat Tillman left his N.F.L. career in 2002 to join, is a proving ground of sorts, and attracts many younger soldiers. Though designed in part as an elite light infantry for airfield seizures, the Rangers have seen their purpose morph: More than ever, kill-or-capture raids are their raison d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xaatre. They\xe2\x80\x99re the fullbacks of the Special Ops world, all brute force and power, as memorialized in the film \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Hawk Down\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cWe get on the five-yard line,\xe2\x80\x9d a Ranger officer tells a dismissive Delta soldier, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re going to need my Rangers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The days in Tacoma were spent trying (and failing) to get the Rangers\xe2\x80\x99 public affairs office to approve on-post access. The nights in Tacoma were mostly spent in bars with young Rangers looking to unwind from their last tour while also prepping for the next one. They described the routine: three to six months deployed, three to six months stateside, rinse and repeat. Elizabeth Samet, who teaches English at West Point, calls these service members \xe2\x80\x9cwar commuters.\xe2\x80\x9d More than one observer in Tacoma, including some partners and spouses, termed it an addiction.'b'If that was true \xe2\x80\x94 and it didn\xe2\x80\x99t apply to many, in my estimation \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99d have their reasons.'b'A number of Rangers I met joked that vampires saw more light than they did during their deployments. I came to see these young men in a way I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t when I\xe2\x80\x99d worn the uniform myself, because of the way they embraced the endlessness of it all. They weren\xe2\x80\x99t fighting for resolution, as we\xe2\x80\x99d been in Iraq, or how we thought we\xe2\x80\x99d been. Peace over there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t their goal. This was no Cowboys and Indians. They were playing \xe2\x80\x9cRangers and Rangers.\xe2\x80\x9d They all wanted to be like Daddy, and none were willing to play the role of an Al Qaeda jihadist, even in pretend.'b'The baby-faced Ranger privates I helped sneak into bars in 2011 are hardened sergeants by now. They remain anonymous silhouettes to the country they serve, not just because their bosses at the Pentagon want it that way, but because we do, too.'b'The other Americans, indeed.'b'A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.'b'IN recent years, New York City has invested over $2 billion in spectacular new waterfront parks. But that investment, and New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 enjoyment of their parks and neighborhoods, is being ruined by an invasion of noisy, polluting tourist helicopters.'b'The long piers in Hudson River Park, near Chelsea, seem an inviting retreat, well removed from the noise of the West Side Highway. But these days the pleasure of a sunny bench and a river view is being obliterated by a fleet of helicopters flying up and down the Hudson. Just as the noise from one chopper fades away, a new one approaches, and it feels as if we\xe2\x80\x99re trapped in a landing zone on a military base.'b'This experience is not unique to one pier, or even to one city park. Daily, about two million people on both sides of the Hudson have their senses attacked by the plague of tourist helicopters.'b'According to New York City Economic Development Corporation estimates, there were over 56,000 sightseeing tourist helicopter trips in 2014, operating every day, for as much as 10 hours a day \xe2\x80\x94 and all taking off from the Downtown Manhattan Heliport. In 2014, nontourist flights accounted for merely 1,936 of the 58,021 flights taking off from the downtown heliport. Moreover, tours represented 75 percent of 'b'all'b' flights taking off from Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s three city-owned heliports.'b'City leaders should consider the high price we pay for helicopter tourism, a cost to our environment and to the quality of life in our parks and neighborhoods. While the revenue to the city is negligible, a 1999 report on one of the heliports cited research stating that helicopters were the \xe2\x80\x9csource of measurable quantities of smog-forming gases and elevated levels of formaldehyde and other cancer-causing toxic emissions.\xe2\x80\x9d Workers at 55 Water Street have filed more than 1,200 complaints of headaches, nausea and respiratory irritation caused by helicopter exhaust in their building\xe2\x80\x99s ventilation system.'b'The Airbus AS350 series of helicopters, one of the most popular among tour operators, produces approximately 950 pounds of carbon dioxide'b''b' emissions per hour; the average car produces 22 pounds per hour. There are often eight helicopters motoring on the downtown heliport at any time. For those living and working nearby, that\xe2\x80\x99s like 340 cars idling outside your window. Conservatively estimated, the 56,000 annual tourist flights have a carbon footprint greater than 6,000 metric tons.'b'The reason so many people are affected is the city-defined route the sightseeing helicopters take. The tourist choppers take off from the city-owned heliport in the Financial District, and typically swoop over toward Brooklyn Bridge Park, circle around Governors Island and the 'b'Statue of Liberty'b', and fly north up the West Side, buzzing over miles of new waterfront parks. They then motor to the New Jersey side of the river and make the trip back down, effectively passing these locations twice per trip. Each tourist pays between $144 and $290 for a 15- to 30-minute ride. And with helicopters carrying up to six passengers, that means a half-hour trip could earn operators more than $1,500.'b'The recent public and private investment in new waterfront parks is aimed at providing rest and relaxation at the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge. But you can\xe2\x80\x99t find quiet at the ends of the piers there, or on Governors Island or in Hudson River and Riverside Parks because of the unending din of tourist helicopters. And Lower Manhattan, the fastest growing residential area in the state in recent years, is becoming an unpleasant place to raise a family, say some residents whose children cannot sleep.'b'At a recent City Council hearing on the subject, speaker after speaker talked about the torture of endless pollution and noise. More startling, Economic Development Corporation officials, defending the city\xe2\x80\x99s permitting of the flights, testified that the lease to the operators of the downtown heliport brought in only $3 million a year in direct revenue. But the private companies that run the tourist fleet probably gross tens of millions a year, using a heliport the city spent $6 million to renovate. To put that $3 million in context, the food concessions in Central Park alone net more revenue. Is that tiny rounding error in the city\xe2\x80\x99s revenue worth the daily misery inflicted on millions of New Yorkers?'b'Legislation being considered by the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s Environmental Protection Committee could help, and can\xe2\x80\x99t come soon enough. (On Sunday, the city announced a deal that would 'b'cut the number of tourist helicopter flights in half'b' by next January.) Banning helicopters that exceed federal noise levels from taking off and landing at city-owned heliports, as the council members\xe2\x80\x99 proposal would do, would instantly improve the city\xe2\x80\x99s air quality, and make our parks and neighborhoods once again oases of (relative) quiet.'b'And if the impact on the environment and on quality of life aren\xe2\x80\x99t enough to spur action, consider the security risks. Each day, hundreds of tourists are recruited off the street, whisked past a light security \xe2\x80\x9cwanding,\xe2\x80\x9d with no X-ray machine or background check, and loaded onto an idling helicopter with no barrier between passenger and pilot. These helicopters then fly within 1,000 feet of the most densely populated urban area in the country.'b'Most tourists (more than 58 million last year) come to New York to enjoy its magnificent public spaces, visit theaters and museums, shop, dine in restaurants, and perhaps get a view from a tall building. They will not stop coming if helicopter tours are ended.'b'New York City\xe2\x80\x99s priority must lie with those who day in and day out have to suffer from the incessant noise and air pollution these tourist helicopters produce, and not with the tourists, who will in any event also benefit from cleaner air and quieter skies.'b'Anna Robbins is a costume designer best known for her work on 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' which airs on \xe2\x80\x9cMasterpiece\xe2\x80\x9d on PBS.'b''b'READING'b' I\xe2\x80\x99m reading 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMurder on the Leviathan,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' the third book of a series by Boris Akunin about a Russian detective called Erast Fandorin. Now, whether he\xe2\x80\x99s threatening to \xe2\x80\x9c'b'carpet bomb'b'\xe2\x80\x9d Syrian villages or pitching a phony \xe2\x80\x9c'b'flat tax'b'\xe2\x80\x9d that would batter middle-class consumers, Mr. Cruz will say anything to win.
